Entrants to the non-commissioned ranks of the three Services are given basic
training, and further training is given during the course of their careers.
Young servicemen have the opportunity to read for the General Certificate of
Education ‘O’ level (see pp. 150-51). Trade and technical training, though
primarily designed for Service purposes, leads in many cases to nationally
recognised qualifications; completion of many Service trade or technical
courses followed by experience is recognised by trade unions as a qualification
for membership by men who have left the Services.
Commissions may be granted for short, medium or long terms. Promotion
from the non-commissioned ranks is possible in all three Services. In the
Royal Navy, the normal method of entry is through cadetship in the Britannia
Royal Naval College, Dartmouth; in the Army through cadetships in the
Royal Military Academy Sandhurst. This is followed by specialist training
which may include degree courses. The RAF trains cadets for long-term
commissions at the RAF College, Cranwell, Lincolnshire, but the majority of
entrants to the flying and executive branches take Direct Entry Commissions
(of medium length). There is special provision in all three Services for the
entry of men with appropriate qualifications including doctors, dentists and
other graduates. Plans have been made to set up a Royal Defence Academy to
provide higher education for men from all three Services.
Selected officers of all three Services who have had previous staff training or
have been to the Royal Naval Staff College, Greenwich (London), the Army
Staff College at Camberley (Surrey), or the Royal Air Force Staff Colleges
(due to be merged by 1970) at Bracknell (Berkshire) or Andover (Hampshire)
go to the Joint Services Staff College at Chesham (Buckinghamshire), where
particular attention is paid to the inter-Service aspects of staff work. A few
specially selected and more senior officers from the Services, the Civil Service,
and from other Commonwealth countries are sent to the Imperial Defence
College in London. Considerable training is done through joint-Service and
inter-allied exercises, on which increasing emphasis is being placed.
The Regular Reserve consists of various categories of former full-time officers
and ratings liable to recall in emergency. The Voluntary Reserves comprise
the Royal Naval Reserve (with its associated women’s reserve) and the Royal
Marines Reserve, and carry out part-time training.
The Royal Naval Auxiliary Service, a civilian organisation composed of
men and women volunteers, is responsible in time of war for minewatching
duties around the coast and the waterways, and other duties.
Men who have completed the Colour portion of their service with the Regular
Army are retained on the Regular Reserve to complete a total engagement of
12 years; as such they are liable to recall to the Colours. Thereafter they are
transferred to the Long Term Reserve (LTR) where they remain until the age
of 45 and are liable to recall in an emergency.
The Territorial and Army Volunteer Reserve (T & AVR) comprises
categories I, II, III and IV. Category I, together with individual volunteers
from the Regular Army Reserve of Officers, from the Regular Reserve and from
category II, is known as the Special Army Volunteer Reserve and is liable to
be called out at any time at the discretion of the Secretary of State for Defence.
Both categories I and II are liable for service with the Regular Army when
warlike operations are in preparation or progress. The third category, T &
AVR III (the ‘Territorials’) is being run down as a result of the decision to

Britain
reduce home defence to a care and maintenance basis (see below). T & AYR
IV consists of miscellaneous units (for example, University Officer Training
Corps) with various roles which do not fit them for inclusion in the other
categories.
The Regular Reserve consists of former full-time officers and airmen, of whom
a few are detailed for specific tasks in emergency and the remainder have a
statutory liability for recall. The Royal Auxiliary Air Force, consisting of
three maritime headquarter units controlled by Coastal Command (see p. 109),
and the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve are liable for part-time training
and for recall in an emergency. Auxiliary formations include the mainly
civilian Royal Observer Corps and the 20 University Air Squadrons (for
information about the Combined Cadet Force, see p. 165). The principal
function of the Royal Observer Corps is to be ready to report and measure
radioactivity in the event of nuclear attack. After reductions resulting from
cuts in expenditure on home defence (see below) it is intended that the Corps
comprise 12,500 volunteers with 873 observation posts.
The Government decided in 1968 to reduce existing civil defence arrange¬
ments to a care and maintenance basis. The physical assets of civil defence
organisations are being preserved so far as is practicable, and training and
planning continues at the minimum level required to maintain knowledge and
techniques and to enable more active preparations to be resumed if this should
appear to be necessary. Most volunteer services in this field are in the process
of disbandment, but the Royal Observer Corps (see above) and Women’s
Royal Voluntary Service are to be retained. Total annual expenditure on home
defence is estimated at about £13 million in 1968-69 and is intended to fall,
in later years, to about £7 million.
The arrangements being maintained include an emergency system for
decentralised governmental control and communications, and the United
Kingdom Warning and Monitoring Organisation, including the Royal
Observer Corps, which would provide public warning of an attack, of the
location and power of nuclear explosions, and of the distribution and level of
radioactive fall-out.
DEPLOYMENT
In January 1968 British and locally enlisted uniformed troops were deployed
roughly as follows:
Britain, 255,400; European continent, 63,700 (nearly all in Germany);
Mediterranean and Near East, 18,500; Middle and Far East, 56,400
(including Gurkhas); and elsewhere, 42,300 (mostly Royal Navy at sea).
The deployment of forces is summarised below:
The Western Fleet operates in European sea areas; frigates, submarines and
coastal minesweepers carry out training, trials and fishery protection, and
ships of all classes spend periods at home for refitting. All ships at home have
NATO commitments in the Channel or Eastern Atlantic.
Stationed in Britain are Army Strategic Command and certain other front
line units; skeleton headquarters, public duties, training and logistic units.
The Royal Air Force in Britain consists of units of Strike Command,
comprising aircraft of the former Bomber and Fighter Commands, strategic
112
Germany
Mediterranean
and Middle
East
Far East
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
reconnaissance and tanker aircraft; Air Support Command, with strategic and
tactical transport aircraft, and ground-attack reconnaissance forces whose
main role is to support the Army. Long-range maritime reconnaissance
aircraft for protection of sea routes, in conjunction with the Royal Navy, will
come within the Maritime Group of Strike Command. There are also units of
the Royal Air Force Regiment. The Ballistic Missile Early Warning Station at
Fylingdales Moor, Yorkshire, built under an Anglo-American agreement of
i960, is part of a chain of such stations starting in Alaska and Greenland.
Britain has stationed in the Federal Republic of Germany an army corps of
three divisions—the British Army of the Rhine (BAOR)—with associated
troops and a tactical air force including light bomber, reconnaissance and
air-defence squadrons; also fighter reconnaissance aircraft and a brigade in
Berlin (which the NATO powers have agreed to treat as part of the Atlantic
Treaty area): giving a total force of some 63,000. BAOR equipment includes,
as tactical nuclear weapons, the Honest John free-flight missile and the 8-inch
howitzer. A brigade of BAOR and a squadron of support helicopters are now
stationed in Britain.
Britain contributes toward the defence infra-structure of the CENTO area,
provides various military training facilities and keeps an RAF bomber force
in Cyprus for the defence of the region. Britain also supplies at its own expense
over 1,000 men for the United Nations Force in Cyprus (about a quarter
of the total) and provides logistic support for the force. Certain forces are
stationed in Malta under bilateral arrangements and there is a small garrison
in Gibraltar.
Destroyers, frigates and minesweepers are deployed in the Mediterranean
and are supplemented from time to time by other major naval units.
British Land Forces in the Persian Gulf consist of infantry supported by
artillery, armoured cars and engineers stationed at Bahrain and Sharjah. RAF
forces also based at Bahrain and Sharjah include ground-attack and fighter
reconnaissance, tactical transport and long-range maritime reconnaissance
aircraft. Royal Navy frigates and coastal minesweepers, based at Bahrain,
operate in the Gulf.
In the South East Asia Treaty Organisation (SEATO) area, Britain provides
training facilities and, in particular, has built an airfield in Thailand with the
help of Australia and New Zealand.
Naval forces in Far East Command contain most types of warships and fleet
auxiliaries, including one carrier, a commando ship, an assault ship, sub¬
marines, and frigates. These forces operate in the Arabian Sea and the Indian
and Pacific Oceans and undertake patrol duties in the Mozambique channel.
Ships of the Royal Australian and Royal New Zealand Navies are attached to
and operate with the Far Eastern Fleet.
Britain has retained in the Far East only army units required to assist in the
defence of Malaysia and Singapore, and of British dependencies, and for
commitments to SEATO. The Brigade of Gurkhas was reduced to about
12,500 men in June 1968, and it is intended to bring it down to 6,000 by the
end of 1971.
Singapore provides bases for all three Services.
A small garrison of Gurkhas is stationed in Brunei. A substantial garrison,
including a Gurkha brigade, remains in Hong Kong.

The Far East Air Force, made up of units of the RAF and Royal Australian
and Royal New Zealand Air Forces, includes fighter, light-bomber, ground-
attack, tactical sea and long-range maritime reconnaissance, support heli¬
copter, short and medium range transport and surface-to-air missile squadrons
as well as squadrons of the Royal Air Force Regiment.
A small naval force, normally carrying a detachment of Royal Marines,
operates in the Caribbean. HMS Protector is employed in the Falkland
Islands and Dependencies, and in the Antarctic during the southern summer
months, and in the 1968-69 season is being replaced by HMS Endurance,
undergoing her first commission as the Navy’s ice-patrol ship. During the
southern winter, a small Royal Marine force is maintained in the Falkland
Islands.
A small Army garrison remains in British Honduras.
COMBAT FORCES
Combat forces can be divided into six major groups, according to their
functions and corresponding equipment, as described below.
The main British contribution to the strategic nuclear deterrent of the Atlantic
Alliance has hitherto been the medium bombers (V-bombers) of the Royal
Air Force. Their role, however, is being progressively taken over by the Royal
Navy’s four Polaris submarines as they become operational. The first sub¬
marine, HMS Resolution, became operational in 1968, and is to be followed by
Renown and Repidse in 1969 and Revenge in 1970. The V-bomber force
comprises Victor Bz squadrons (being withdrawn from service during the
second half of 1968) and Vulcan Bz squadrons, equipped with either Blue
Steel stand-off bombs or free-fall weapons. V-bombers can also carry
conventional weapons.
Each Polaris submarine carries 16 missiles with nuclear warheads and a
range of some 2,500 nautical miles. The submarines’ nuclear-powered engines
enable them to cruise, submerged, for long periods. The Polaris and other
submarines will be supported by the Clyde submarine base completed in 1968.
Britain also provides facilities for a depot ship for United States Polaris
submarines at Holy Loch on the Firth of Clyde.
Britain has assigned its strategic nuclear forces to NATO. The British
Government considers it essential to associate the non-nuclear members of
NATO closely with the nuclear policy of the Alliance, and thus to strengthen
the nuclear interdependence of its members, and Britain has played an active
part in discussions for this purpose.
The cost of nuclear strategic forces for 1968-69 is estimated at £25 million
for the bomber force, and £70 million for the Polaris fleet.
The European theatre ground forces consist of the BAOR and an independent
brigade in Berlin. Their cost in 1968-69 is estimated at ^212 million. (Royal
Air Force, Germany, is included among Royal Air Force Combat Forces, see
P- 116-)
Armoured regiments are being equipped with the Chieftain main battle tank,
which incorporates many new features in protection and mobility, in succes¬
sion to the Centurion. Two armoured car regiments are equipped with the
Vigilant anti-tank guided weapon mounted on the Ferret scout car. Szvingfire,

a long-range, guided, anti-tank weapon, is being introduced into certain units
during 1969. The field artillery has been re-equipped. New weapons include the
British Abbot self-propelled 105 mm. gun with good cross-country mobility,
range, fire power and protection for its crew, and the American self-propelled
155 mm. Mi09 and 175 mm. Mi07 guns. Missile regiments equipped with
the Honest John free-flight rocket and the 8-inch howitzer provide surface-to-
surface tactical nuclear support for the ground forces. Infantry battalions have
new tracked armoured personnel carriers. Some armoured personnel carriers
in each battalion are being converted to fire the 81 mm. mortar or the Wombat
anti-tank gun, and some are being fitted with a mount for the general purpose
machine gun. The infantry have also been provided with Carl Gustav anti¬
tank weapons, and with improved chemical and nuclear defensive equipment.
Sioux helicopters used by brigade headquarters are to be replaced by Scouts,
with greater range and carrying capacity, by the end of 1968. A semi-automatic
multi-channel trunk system for communications in the combat area comes
into operation during 1968.

The naval general purpose combat elements of the Fleet1 comprise the
following: amphibious forces; aircraft carriers and squadrons; submarines
(excluding the Polaris force); cruisers, destroyers and frigates; mine counter¬
measures forces; and support and other ships. All these forces can be sent to
other theatres if needed in an emergency, either as reinforcements or to carry
out joint operations with the Army and Royal Air Force. Their cost in 1968-69
is estimated at £301 million.
The aircraft carriers HMS Eagle and HMS Hermes are to be in commission
during 1968 and thereafter. The carriers are equipped with the angled flight
deck, the steam catapult, the automatic aircraft positioning device for the
catapult and the projector sight (all British inventions). HMS Eagle also has
Action Data Automation (ADA), the most advanced system of command and
control. The main strike and fighter strength is at present provided by
Buccaneer and Sea Vixen aircraft, both with the United States Bullpup air-to-
surface guided missile capability. The Buccaneer Mark 2 is a long-range low-
level strike aircraft with an advanced weapon system. The Sea Vixen Mark 2
carries air-to-air missiles Firestreak and Red Top for use against high-flying
and supersonic targets. During 1968 an advanced air defence aircraft, the
Phantom, with true supersonic performance and equipped with both Sparrozv
and Sidewinder air-to-air missiles, will be introduced into Royal Navy service.
The carrier force will be phased out when the withdrawal of British forces
from Singapore and Malaysia is complete. Amphibious forces are provided by
the commando ships HMS Albion and HMS Bulwark, the assault ships
HMS Fearless and HMS Intrepid, and the Royal Marine Commandos.
Commando ships are equipped with landing craft, Wessex Mark 5 helicopters,
which can be armed with the SS 11 anti-tank guided missile, and Sioux
helicopters. Of the three Tiger class cruisers HMS Blake and HMS Tiger are
being converted to carry Sea King helicopters; it is planned to convert HMS
Lion later. The cruisers have fully automatic armament and the most modern
control equipment. Destroyers and frigates, the largest part of the Fleet, give
the main surface protection against enemy submarines and surface and air
I In 1968 the following ships of the Fleet were operational, preparing for service, or
engaged on trials and training: 2 aircraft carriers, 2 commando ships, 2 assault ships,
6 guided-missile destroyers, n other destroyers, 55 frigates, 33 submarines, 54 mine¬
sweepers, and an ice-patrol ship. In addition the following were in reserve or undergoing
long refit, conversion, etc.: 2 aircraft carriers, 3 cruisers, 5 destroyers, 15 frigates,
II submarines, 23 minesweepers and one ice-patrol ship.

forces. The new Type 82 guided-missile destroyer, HMS Bristol, to be
launched in April 1969, will introduce into the Fleet in 1971 the new advanced
area anti-aircraft and anti-missile weapon system Sea Dart, as well as the
anti-submarine weapon, Ikara, specially developed to counter fast
submarines.
The six County class guided-missile destroyers are to be joined by two more
in 1969. Leander class frigates have advanced anti-submarine equipment
including variable-depth and medium-range sonar and mortars; both they and
Tribal class frigates can carry Wasp anti-submarine helicopters.
All ships of frigate size and above are to carry helicopters. The Whirlwind
Mark 9 helicopter carries out search and rescue duties, and the Wessex Mark 1
and Wasp are for anti-submarine tasks. The yet more advanced Wessex
Mark 3, with a new anti-submarine system, is now in service, to be followed in
1969 by the introduction of Sea King, a British-built and British-engined
version of the Sikorsky SH-3D, of still greater capacity. Naval helicopters, in
addition to their anti-submarine function, will be able, if required, to carry out
reconnaissance and light surface attack with air-to-surface missiles.
The submarine has been revolutionised by nuclear power propulsion,
which enables it to operate submerged for prolonged periods at sustained high
speed. Three nuclear-powered Fleet submarines are now in service—
Dreadnought, Valiant and Warspite. Four more have been ordered including
the first of a new improved design.
Support-ships replenish the Fleet and offer it maintenance and repair
facilities. They include submarine depot ships (equipped with workshops
and plant to support a squadron or more of submarines), a heavy repair and
maintenance ship and mine counter-measures support ships, all manned by
naval personnel. Ships of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary Service provide afloat
logistic support such as fuel, food, ammunition, stores and spare gear. These
ships fly the Blue Ensign and are manned by Merchant Navy officers and
seamen. The dockyards at Portsmouth, Devonport, Chatham and Rosyth
provide the Navy with major supplies and repair facilities in Britain. Singapore
and Gibraltar are the main dockyards overseas.
Army general purpose combat forces consist mainly of the ground forces
deployed outside Europe; the Army Strategic Command; and other front line
units in Britain. Their cost in 1968-69 is estimated at £169 million.
The new Army Strategic Command is to consist of most field force units
stationed in Britain and the supporting arms and services. Its units are capable
of operations varying from internal security and counter-insurgency to limited
war, and are available to support BAOR in the event of general war.
A general-purpose machine-gun has been introduced and is to replace the
Vickers and Bren in infantry battalions, which have also all been issued with
the 81 mm. mortar. Some battalions will receive an improved version of the
Mobat heavy anti-tank weapon, the Conbat, during 1968. Other equipment
includes night-fighting devices, engineer equipment for crossing obstacles, and
the Stalwart high-mobility load-carrier. Field Artillery Computer Equipment
(FACE) is being issued to training units in Britain during 1968. A new British
air-portable bridge is to come into service early in 1969.
The Army’s force of Scout and Sioux helicopters is being increased. These
can be used for reconnaissance, to carry patrols, casualties and urgently
needed stores, and as airborne command posts. Armed helicopters have been
used successfully in operations. The Army also has Canadian Beaver light
aircraft for liaison purposes. The Landing Ship Tank (LST), for support

operations, is being superseded by the faster and more advanced Landing
Ship Logistic (LSL). An Army Hovercraft Unit has been formed, of four
Westland hovercraft modified for military use.
The Royal Air Force combat forces comprise all the front-line formations
and units except the V-bomber, transport and tanker forces. They fall into
five main categories: air defence, ground attack and fighter reconnaissance;
light bomber and tactical reconnaissance; maritime reconnaissance; head¬
quarters; and general support, including the Royal Air Force Regiment,
which is responsible for protecting bases. Their cost in 1967-68 is estimated
at ^287 million.
Fighter squadrons are equipped with Lightning Mark 3 and Mark 6 supersonic
aircraft, which carry Firestreak or Red Top air-to-air missiles and can be
refuelled in flight. The Lightning is fitted with a computer to aid bomber
interception. Air defence is also the function of the Bloodhound Mark 2
surface-to-air missile. Air defence squadrons are controlled by ground radars.
New military radars and centralised data-handling equipment are being
installed in Britain as part of the integrated plans for air defence and national
air traffic control. Overseas, new transportable radars are supplementing static
radar. The ballistic missile early warning station at Fylingdales (see p. 112)
would provide warning of a missile attack on Britain and also detects, tracks
and identifies objects in orbit.
Ground attack and short-range Army support is the function of the Hunter
aircraft. It will be replaced by the Phantom now being converted for RAF use
and by the British P 1127 vertical take-off and landing aircraft (the Harrier)
still being developed, which is planned to enter squadron service in 1969-70,
the first such aircraft in the world to do so. Eventually it is planned that a
strike version of the Anglo-French Jaguar light-strike and trainer aircraft
should release Phantoms from this role to replace the Lightning fighters.
Overseas fighter-reconnaissance squadrons are equipped with Hunter FR10
aircraft.
Light bomber forces are assigned to NATO but they can also use conven¬
tional weapons to meet Britain’s requirements outside the NATO area.
Squadrons are also declared to CENTO and SEATO. They are equipped
with Canberra aircraft, some of which are armed with AS 30 missiles. It is
intended to transfer medium bombers to the conventional tactical role as they
are released from their strategic nuclear tasks. The effects of the decision in
January 1968 to cancel the order for 50 United States FmK aircraft which
were to have replaced the Canberras, are being studied. As an interim measure,
additional Buccaneer aircraft are being purchased.
Reconnaissance forces comprise the Canberra PR7 and Victor Mark 2
aircraft. Maritime-reconnaissance squadrons are equipped with modernised
Shackleton Mark 2 and Mark 3 aircraft. In addition to their reconnaissance
functions they can also be used for attacking surface ships and submarines,
and as transport aircraft. The Shackleton Mark 2 is to be replaced by the
Nimrod (the first all-turbo-jet maritime reconnaissance aircraft), formerly
known as the HS 801, from 1969-70 onwards.
Air mobility forces are made up of the strategic and tactical transport forces,
tanker aircraft to refuel combat aircraft in flight, support helicopters and
communications aircraft. Their cost in 1968-69 is estimated at ^115 million
(which includes million on civil charter).

The strategic transport force includes Comet 4C, Britannia, Belfast and VC 10

WEAPONS AND EQUIPMENT
Responsibility for the supply of aircraft, guided weapons, nuclear weapons and
certain radar and other electronic equipment lies with the Ministry of
Technology. The Ministry of Defence is responsible for the procurement of
other weapons, stores and equipment. Total expenditure on research and
development for 1968-69 was estimated at £254 million.
A substantial part of the equipment used by the Services is developed and
produced in Britain, some by private industry on a contract basis and some
by the Royal Ordnance Factories, the Royal Dockyards and other establish¬
ments operated by the Ministry of Technology and the Ministry of Defence.
Production of nuclear warheads is undertaken by the Atomic Energy Authority
(see p. 198) under contract with the Ministry of Technology. In some cases 
particularly where development costs would be disproportionately high 
aircraft, weapons and other equipment are bought from overseas. Conversely,
British defence equipment has been adopted by allied and friendly nations:
for example, the United States, the Federal Republic of Germany, Denmark
and Sweden are using the British 105 mm. tank gun, and British early warning
radar equipment has been adopted by several countries and by NATO.
Britain also undertakes manufacture in collaboration with other countries.
The United States Bullpup short-range air-to-surface guided weapon is in
service with the Royal Navy and is being manufactured in Europe under a
NATO international agency.
Other collaborative projects in progress are: with France, the Jaguar light
strike and trainer aircraft, the Martel stand-off air-to-surface guided missile,
an air-portable helicopter (SA 330) for the RAF, and a light helicopter
(SA 340) and a utility helicopter (WG 13), each for all three Services; with
Canada and the Federal Republic of Germany, a reconnaissance drone; with
the Netherlands, a surveillance radar; and with Australia, the long-range
anti-submarine Ikara system; and with Australia, Canada and the United
States, the Mallard tactical trunk communication system for the 1970s.
Britain is participating in the United States Interim Defence Communi¬
cations Satellite Project (IDCSP) and a memorandum of understanding
has been signed under which Britain is acquiring an operational satellite
communications system, Skynet, functioning initially through two satellites
providing communications for the area between Britain and Australia.
Research and development are undertaken at a number of specialised establish¬
ments. Among the most important are: the Royal Aircraft Establishments,
Farnborough and Bedford; the Royal Radar Establishment, Malvern; the
Aeroplane and Armament Experimental Establishment, Boscombe Down,
Wiltshire; the Services Electronics Research Laboratory, Baldock; and the

Signals Research and Development Establishment, Christchurch, Hants. The
Navy Department’s two research establishments carry out research on ships,
maritime equipment and weapons and also on certain kinds of electronic
equipment on behalf of all three Services. They are at Portsdown (near
Portsmouth), where the design and development of ship-borne gunnery and
suided-missile systems are carried out, and at Portland (Dorset), where a
aspects of work on underwater detection are co-ordinated with work on
underwater weapons. Research establishments controlled by the Army

in these establishments, and the progress of military research often contributes
to advances in related civil fields.
Much experimental work has been carried out by the Navy and the Atomic
Energy Authority on nuclear-propelled submarines (see p. 115), and a nuc ear-
submarine power unit prototype is in operation at Dounreay (see p. 198). e
Royal Naval College, Greenwich, has a low-power training reactor whic
provides facilities for basic education in nuclear engineering and research.
Guided missiles are tested at the Ministry of Technology’s research establish¬
ments and at the Woomera range set up in Australia under the Joint. United
Kingdom/Australia Guided Weapon Project. Service firing trials of air-to-air
and surface-to-air missiles are carried out at Aberporth and at the Army
gunnery range in Anglesey; a range for testing surface-to-surface missiles has
been set up on South Uist in the Hebrides.
Research into nuclear weapons began in Britain during the second world war
It was continued, as an allied project, in the United States where the firs
atomic bomb was produced. After a subsequent period of independent
development in both countries, collaboration was resumed in 1955, and in
iq?8 an agreement was concluded which made possible the exchange oi
information on the design and manufacture of nuclear weapons This was
supplemented by a further agreement in May 1959, which contained provisions
to enable Britain to buy from the United States component parts of atomic
weapons and weapons systems other than actual warheads, and to make
possible the exchange of nuclear materials between the two countries.
Britain’s nuclear programme is based on an agreement of 1963 y w ic ^
Britain buys from the United States a number of Polaris missiles, to be fitted
with British nuclear warheads, for submarines to be built largely by Britain.
In addition to research and development, there is support of a general nature
supplied in Britain to the Services as a whole. The major items inclu e:
general training; the overhead costs of naval dockyards ordnance factories
and repair, maintenance and storage units; Ministry of Defence and loca
administrative services in Britain; and military pensions. The total estimated
cost for 1968-69 is £822 million.

5 SOCIAL WELFARE
STATE AND VOLUNTARY SERVICES
In Britain the State is now responsible, through either central or local govern¬
ment, for a range of services covering family allowances, social insurance, help
for war victims, financial assistance when required, health and welfare services
for mothers and young children, the sick, mentally disordered, elderly and
handicapped and for families in difficulties of various kinds, and the care of
children lacking a normal home life (all described in this chapter); and for
education (see Chapter 6) and housing (see Chapter y). Public authorities in
the United Kingdom are spending over £7,000 million a year on this range of
services; that is, over ^130 a year per head of the population.
Voluntary organisations, especially the Churches, were the pioneers of
nearly all the social services. They provided schools, hospitals, clinics,
dispensaries, and social and recreational clubs before these were provided by
the State. They made themselves responsible for the welfare of the very young
and the very old, the homeless and the handicapped. Gradually the State
accepted the primary responsibility for the major services, supplementing the
voluntary services and developing a comprehensive structure that ensured a
minimum standard of living and well-being for all citizens.
State and voluntary social services are now complementary and co-operative.
The State may work through voluntary agencies specially adapted to serve
particular needs and ensures that necessary standards are maintained. The
officers of central and local government, in carrying out their duties, co-operate
with the workers of many voluntary social service societies, while the resi¬
dential provision made by the State and by local authorities for the care of the
chronic sick and the aged is supplemented by voluntary homes of various
types. Most of the sick and elderly receive State pensions or benefits.
The Charity Commission, a government department, gives free advice to
trustees of charities, making schemes to modify their purposes or facilitate
their administration when necessary; it maintains central and local registers
of charities which are open to public inspection; and it works to promote
co-operation between charities and State services.
Voluntary^ The number of voluntary societies and institutions in Britain runs into
Organisations thousands; they range from national organisations to small individual local
groups. Most organisations, however, are members of larger associations or
are represented on local or national co-ordinating councils or committees.
Some are chiefly concerned with giving personal service, others in the forma¬
tion of public opinion and exchange of information. A number are concerned
with giving help to immigrants. In recent years there has been an increase in
organised service by young people.
Organisations concerned with personal and family problems and misfortunes
include the voluntary family casework agencies, of which the Family Welfare
Association, working mainly in London, is the best known; marriage guidance
centres affiliated to the National Marriage Guidance Council; the Family
Service Units; and the National Council for the Unmarried Mother and her
Child.
122
Social Workers
Immigration
and Welfare
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Voluntary service to the sick and disabled in general is given by the British
Red Cross Society, the St. John Ambulance Association and Brigade and the
Leagues of Hospital Friends, but a number of societies exist to help people
with particular disabilities, such as the Royal National Institute for the
Blind, the Royal National Institute for the Deaf, the National Association for
Mental Health, the constituent members of the Central Council for the
Disabled and their Scottish equivalents.
Bodies working on a national scale whose work is specifically religious in
inspiration include the Salvation Army, the Church Army, Toe H, the
Committee on Social Service of the Church of Scotland, the Church of
England Children’s Society, the Church of England Council for Social Work,
the Young Men’s Christian Association, the Young Women’s Christian
Association, the Society of Friends, the Crusade of Rescue, the Society of
St. Vincent de Paul, the Catholic Marriage Advisory Council and the Jewish
Welfare Board.
A wide range of voluntary personal service is given by the Women’s Royal
Voluntary Service, which gives help in every kind of practical difficulty, brings
‘meals on wheels’ to housebound invalids and old people, provides flatlets and
residential clubs for the elderly, helps with family problems and assists in
hospitals and clinics, as well as doing relief work in emergencies.
A central link between voluntary organisations and official bodies concerned
with social welfare is provided in England and Wales by the National Council
of Social Service, which brings together most of the principal voluntary
agencies for consultation and joint action, either as a whole or in groups of
those concerned with particular aspects, such as youth work or old people s
welfare. There are also the Scottish Council of Social Service and the Northern
Ireland Council of Social Service, which perform similar functions. The
Citizens’ Advice Bureaux, of which there are now nearly 500 in Britain,
are steadily increasing in number. The primary role of the bureaux is to give
explanation and advice to the citizen who is in doubt about his rights or who
does not know about the State or voluntary services which could help him.
While the voluntary worker giving full-time or part-time service has done
pioneer work in many of Britain’s social services and continues to play an
essential part, social services of all kinds increasingly depend for their operation
chiefly on the professional social worker, that is, the full-time salaried worker
trained in the principles and technique of social work. Training for many
forms of social work consists of a basic university degree, diploma or certificate
course in social science followed by a university course in applied social
studies or specialised training for a particular service. The latter is sometimes
organised by the profession concerned. The Council for Training in Social
Work also promotes the training, in the first instance, of workers in the local
authority health and welfare services and similar services run by voluntary
bodies. Full-time courses lasting two years, which may be taken at colleges of
further education, lead to the Council’s Certificate in Social Work.
Social workers when trained may work in a variety of services including
child care and youth work, medical social work, psychiatric social work or the
probation service, or in the community services.
Since the 1950s many people have entered Britain from Commonwealth
countries in Asia, Africa and the West Indies to take up employment, some
with the intention of returning home when they have acquired savings or
additional skills but many coming to settle permanently with their families;
SOCIAL WELFARE
123
others bring their families over later. Immigrants from the Commonwealth
and their families now comprise about two per cent of the total population.
The Home Office is responsible for co-ordinating government action
designed to help Commonwealth immigrants to settle in Britain and to deal
with a number of social problems which have arisen. The National Committee
for Commonwealth Immigrants was appointed in 1965 under the chairmanship
of the Archbishop of Canterbury to promote and co-ordinate on a national
basis voluntary efforts directed towards the integration of Commonwealth
immigrants into the community; it received a grant from the Government.
The National Committee has now been superseded by the Community
Relations Commission constituted under the Race Relations Act 1968 to deal
with this work in the broader context of fostering harmonious community
relations in a multi-racial society.
Under the Race Relations Acts 1965 and 1968 there are legal sanctions
against certain discriminatory behaviour; local conciliation committees may
enquire into complaints of racial discrimination and try to settle differences.
The Race Relations Board, established under legislation, examines cases
where conciliation is not achieved and may take proceedings in the civil courts.
SOCIAL SECURITY
National insurance, industrial injuries insurance, family allowances and
supplementary benefits together with (in a special category) war pensions
constitute a comprehensive system of social security in the United Kingdom.
The Ministry of Social Security administers these services in Great Britain;
within the Ministry the Supplementary Benefits Commission is responsible
for the system of supplementary benefits. In Northern Ireland the first four of
these schemes are administered by the Ministry of Health and Social Services
which contains the Supplementary Benefits Commission for Northern Ireland.
Pensions and welfare services for war pensioners and their dependants are
the responsibility of the Ministry of Social Security throughout the United
Kingdom. Appeals relating to claims for insurance benefits, family allowance?
or war pensions, or to applications for supplementary benefit, are decided not
by the Ministries but by independent authorities.
Although the development of public provision for social security in Britain
can be traced back for several centuries (the Poor Relief Act of 1601 may be
regarded as specially important in England and Wales), the modern system of
comprehensive provision is a creation of the twentieth century. Non-contri-
butory old age pensions were introduced in 1908, and the first contributory
pensions for old people, widows and orphans in 1926. A contributory National
Health Insurance Scheme was begun in 1912, and in the same year a scheme
of unemployment insurance was introduced which in 1920 was extended to
cover the great majority of employees. By the beginning of the second world
war social security provision in Britain was among the best in the world, but
lacked co-ordination because of its piece-meal development, and not everyone
came within its scope. In the immediate post-war years a series of Acts
introduced the present comprehensive system, which became fully operative
on 5th July 1948. Adjustments have been made by a number of subsequent
Acts. Statutory provision for the war disabled goes back to the end of the
sixteenth century, but the main lines of the present war pension provisions
were laid down during the first world war.
Family allowances and national insurance benefits or allowances, other than
maternity, unemployment or sickness benefit, are included in the taxable
124

Reciprocity

income on which income tax is assessed. On the other hand, various income
tax reliefs and exemptions are allowed on account of age or liability for the
support of dependants. War disablement pensions are not taxable.
The national insurance, industrial injuries and family allowances schemes of
Great Britain and those of Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man operate as a
single system. Reciprocal agreements on industrial injuries, family allowances
and most national insurance benefits are in operation with Belgium, Denmark,
Finland, the Federal Republic of Germany, Guernsey, Jersey, Norway,
Sweden and Yugoslavia. Agreements with France, Israel, Italy, Luxembourg,
Malta, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Turkey cover industrial injuries and
most national insurance benefits. With Australia and New Zealand there are
agreements on family allowances and most national insurance benefits. An
agreement with Cyprus covers all national insurance benefits and one with the
Irish Republic covers most national insurance benefits and certain provisions
on industrial injuries relating to seafarers. There is a limited agreement with
Canada. Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man are also party to most of these
agreements with other countries.
Family allowances are provided in Great Britain under the Family Allowances
Act 1965 (which consolidated the Acts of 1945-64), and in Northern Ireland
under its own legislation. Over 6-6 million allowances are being paid in Great
Britain to more than 4 million families with two or more children, and in
Northern Ireland to 129,000 families. An allowance is paid for each child other
than the first child below the age limits. The age limits are 15 years for
children who leave school at that age, 16 years for certain incapacitated
children, and 19 for children who remain at school or are apprentices.
The rate of the allowance is (from October 1968) 18s. a week for the second
child below the age limits and 20s. a week for the third and each subsequent
child.
Family allowances are paid from the Exchequer and their object is to benefit
the family as a whole; they belong to the mother, but may be paid either to the
mother or to the father. There is no insurance qualification for title to the
allowances, but there are certain residence conditions.
The National Insurance Acts apply, in general, to everyone over minimum
school-leaving age living in Great Britain. There are similar schemes in
Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man. (The National Insurance Act 1965
consolidated the provisions of the National Insurance Acts 1946-64.)
The national insurance scheme provides benefits in specified contingencies
where contribution conditions have been fulfilled. The benefits are paid for
partly by insured persons’ contributions, partly by contributions of employers
in respect of their employees, and partly by a contribution made by the
Exchequer out of general taxation.
The original system was based on flat-rate contributions and benefits.
Contributions varied only with the sex and insurance class of the insured
person and benefits were at standard rates. (In both cases lower rates apply to
those under 18.) Two modifications were subsequently introduced to provide
additional earnings-related contributions and benefits. For retirement,
graduated contributions and pensions were introduced in 1961. For the first
six months of sickness, unemployment or widowhood the National Insurance
Act 1966 introduced a scheme for earnings-related supplements to the flat-rate
benefit and contributions.
SOCIAL WELFARE 12$
Contributors Contributors under the national insurance scheme are divided into three
classes:
Class i. Employed people. Those who work for an employer under a contract
of service or are paid apprentices—over 23 million.
Class 2. Self-employed people. Those in business on their own account and
others who are working for gain but do not work under the control of an
employer—about 1^ million.
Class 3. Non-employed people. All those insured who are not in class 1 or
class 2—about a quarter of a million.
There is a general liability to pay flat-rate contributions according to this
classification but certain people are excepted. These include full-time students,
prisoners, and most people in receipt of national insurance benefits. Self-
employed and non-employ ed persons whose income is about £312 a year can
apply for exception. Married women can choose to pay contributions and
receive benefit in their own right or not to pay flat-rate contributions (if they
are working they must pay graduated contributions) and rely upon their
husband’s insurance for maternity grant, retirement pension (at a lower rate),
widow’s benefit, and death grant. If a married woman works for an employer
he must pay his full share of the flat-rate contributions even if she has chosen
not to pay flat-rate contributions.
Flat-rate contributions are credited to students up to the age of eighteen,
and to most people in receipt of national insurance benefits. People who are
excepted from liability to pay but are not entitled to credits may pay contribu¬
tions at the non-employed rate if they wish to safeguard entitlement to
retirement pension and widow’s benefit.
An employed person ceases to be liable for national insurance contributions
at the age of 70 for men, 65 for women, or when he retires from regular
employment after reaching minimum pension age (65 for men, 60 for women),
whichever is the earlier. If he does any work as an employed person thereafter,
he must pay an industrial injuries contribution; the employer still has to pay
his full share of the flat-rate contribution.
Contributions Flat-rate contributions are paid by means of national insurance stamps bought
from a post office and fixed, for each contributor, to a single contribution card.
All three classes pay flat-rate contributions (see Table 9). The stamps for
class 1 contributors also include the employer’s redundancy contribution (to
help to provide for payments in certain circumstances to employees whose
work is terminated, see p. 415) and the selective employment tax paid by
employers (see p. 362); and for all contributors the National Health Service
contribution (which for convenience is paid with the national insurance
contribution although the two services are separately administered). It is the
employer’s responsibility in the first place to see that the class 1 contributions
are paid, but he can deduct the employees’ share from their wages. The
self-employed and non-employed must stamp their own cards. Flat-rate
contributions are usually credited for weeks of unemployment, sickness or
injury, or if widow’s benefit is being paid.
In general graduated contributions are payable by employed people (includ¬
ing married women but not retirement pensioners) aged between 18 and 70
(65 for women) who earn more than £9 a week. The range of graduated
contributions is given in Table 9. Employees whose job provides them with
an occupational pension of at least ^3 9s. yd. a year for each year of service
(£2 18s. for women) may be ‘contracted out’ of the graduated pension part

The scheme provides payments to contributors in the event of unemployment
(if normally working for an employer), sickness (if normally working for an
employer or self-employed), and confinement and the weeks immediately
before and after (for women normally working for an employer or self-
employed and paying national insurance contributions at the full rate).

SOCIAL WELFARE I27
Retirement pensions are paid to people who have reached 65 (60 for women)
if they have retired from regular work and from the age of 70 (65 for women)
even if they continue to work; widows receive benefit in the first 26 weeks
after bereavement and subsequently while they have young children or if they
have reached the age of 50 when widowed or when their children have grown
up; and there are two kinds of allowance in respect of orphan children where
a widow’s pension is not payable. The scheme also provides lump-sum cash
grants for two expensive contingencies—the birth of a child and a death.
For most of the benefits there are two contribution conditions. First, before
benefit can be paid at all, a minimum number of contributions must actually
have been paid since entry into insurance; secondly, the full rate of benefit
cannot be paid unless a specified number of contributions have been paid or
credited over a specified period. There are special rules to help a widow who
does not become entitled to a widow’s pension at widowhood or when her
children have grown up, to qualify for sickness or unemployment benefit in
the period before she can have established or re-established herself in insur¬
ance through her own contributions; there are also provisions to help a
divorced woman who was not paying contributions during her marriage.
The basic amount of the majority of flat-rate benefits is £4 10s. a week which
may be reduced if insufficient contributions have been paid, but is not affected
by other unearned income or the previous level of earnings. Earnings received
while the benefit is in payment, however, may cause its reduction or with¬
drawal : unemployment benefit cannot be paid to a person earning more than
a specified amount from a subsidiary occupation; retirement pensioners under
the age of 70 (65 for women) have their pensions reduced in step with earnings
over certain specified amounts; sickness benefit, though not affected by
continued payment of wages during illness, is not normally payable to a person
doing any actual work. Exceptions to the basic flat rate are the higher rate of
^6 7s- a week payable to widows during the first 26 weeks after bereavement,
the increased retirement pension earned by someone who has continued at
work and paid contributions beyond minimum pension age, and the lower rate
°f L?> 2S> a week unemployment or sickness benefit payable to married women
who pay contributions. The standard rate of retirement pension for a woman
on her husband’s insurance is £2 16s. a week.
Standard increases of flat-rate benefit are payable for dependants at the rate
of £2 16s. for an adult (generally a wife), ^1 8s. for the first or only child under
the family allowances age limits; 10s. for the second child and 8s. for each
other child over and above any family allowances payable (see p. 124). The
amounts payable to widows for their children are appreciably larger.
The allowance provided for a child who has lost both parents (one of whom
was insured under the National Insurance Acts) is a guardian’s allowance of
£2 5s. 6d. a week. It is paid to the person in whose family the child is, for the
time being, included. For certain fatherless children there is a child’s special
allowance also of ^2 5s. 6d. a week inclusive of family allowances; this is
payable to a woman whose marriage has been dissolved or annulled and who
has not remarried, if her former husband dies and she has a child to whose
support he was contributing before he died.
The graduated addition to retirement pension is at the rate of 6d. a week
for each £7 10s. of all graduated contributions paid by a man and for each £9
of such graduated contribution paid by a woman (with, in each case, the
matching amount of graduated contribution coming from the employer). The
earnings-related supplements to flat-rate unemployment and sickness benefit
are one-third of a person’s average weekly earnings between £9 and £30, but

the supplements cannot raise the total benefit, including increases for

An earnings-related supplement is paid on top of the widow’s allowance to

The rates of grants are varied: £22 maternity grant is payable for a confine¬
ment and a further £22 grant for each additional child born at the same
confinement living 12 hours after birth; and £30 death grant on the death of an
adult (less for a child, or for an adult who was within 10 years of minimum
pension age when the scheme started).
In general, national insurance payments are paid as long as the situation
requiring them lasts. However, sickness benefit cannot be paid for more than
a year if fewer than 156 contributions have been paid (possible in three years
for a contributor continuously at work) and unemployment benefit is payable
for a maximum of one year. The supplement to unemployment and sickness
benefit is paid for a maximum of six months starting from the thirteenth day
of unemployment or incapacity for work. Maternity allowance begins 11 weeks
before the expected week of confinement and ends after the sixth week
following the expected week or the actual confinement if this is later.
Similarly, a widowed mother’s allowance at the full rate ceases when her
children are no longer dependent on her, though a mother can continue to
receive ^4 10s. a week for herself while she has living with her a son or
daughter under 19. The widow’s pension payable to the childless widow,
provided she is over 50 (and had been married at least three years when her
husband died), or the similar pension normally paid to the widowed mother
who has reached 50 when her widowed mother s allowance ends, continues
until she has reached minimum pension age and retired, or at most till the age
of 65. If she has satisfied the conditions she then becomes entitled to a
retirement pension.
The industrial injuries insurance scheme, which, in July 1948, replaced the
workmen’s compensation scheme (first introduced by the Workmen s
Compensation Act of 1897), provides benefits for personal injuries caused oy
accidents arising out of, and in the course of, employment, and for prescribed
diseases due to the nature of employment. It covers practically everyone in
class 1 of the national insurance scheme and certain others. Like the national
insurance scheme, the industrial injuries scheme is financed partly from
contributions (see Table 9) and partly from taxation. The legal basis of the
scheme is the National Insurance (Industrial Injuries) Act 1965 which
consolidated the 1946 Act and subsequent legislation. Similar cover against
industrial injuries and diseases in Northern Ireland is provided by Northern
Ireland’s legislation.
Injury benefit for an adult is f'] 5s. a week plus £2 16s. for an adult dependant,
8s. for the first or only child under the family allowances age limits, 10s.
for the second child and 8s. for each other child in addition to any family
allowance payable. It is paid when the insured person is incapable of work as
a result of an industrial accident or prescribed disease, and payment can
continue for a maximum of 26 weeks beginning on the date of the accident or
development of the disease. A person entitled to sickness benefit who draws

129
injury benefit instead, also receives any earnings-related supplement (see
p. 126) to which he is entitled.
Disablement Disablement benefit may be paid (but not at the same time as injury benefit)
Benefit when, as the result of industrial accident or prescribed disease, there is a loss
of physical or mental faculty. The amount depends on the extent of the
disablement as assessed by a medical board; it varies from £7 12s. for 100 per
cent disablement to £1 10s. 6d. a week for 20 per cent disablement, but for
disablement of less than 20 per cent a gratuity of up to £500 is normally paid.
In certain circumstances disablement benefit may be supplemented as
follows: unemployability supplement, at the weekly rate of ^4 10s.; constant
attendance allowance of up to £3 weekly normally, or at an intermediate rate
°f ^4 IOS- or a special rate of £6 a week in exceptionally severe cases; an
allowance of ^3 a week for a person entitled to constant attendance allowance
at more than the normal maximum rate whose need for an allowance at such
a rate is likely to be permanent; a special hardship allowance of up to £3 is.
for a person who is unfit to return to his regular job or work of an equivalent
standard; and hospital treatment allowances which raise the benefit to that
for a 100 per cent assessment during hospital treatment for the industrial
disability. Increases of benefit for dependants are payable with unemploy¬
ability supplement and hospital treatment allowance.
Death Benefit If the accident or disease results in the insured person’s death, death benefit
may be paid to the dependants.
For a widow a pension of £6 7s. a week is payable for the first 26 weeks of
widowhood. In addition she receives any earnings-related supplement (see
p. 128) that would have been paid had she claimed widow’s allowance under
the main national insurance scheme. Thereafter, the widow can receive a
pension of £5 is. a week if she was aged 50 at the date of her husband’s death,
or has dependent children or other special needs; otherwise she receives
£1 1 os. a week. If she had been living apart from her husband, the pension is
limited to the weekly rate of maintenance he was paying, if less than the rate
otherwise appropriate.
In addition, allowances are paid for children under the family allowances
age limits. For widows, these allowances together with any family allowance
payable amount to £2 5s. 6d. a week for each child. For other beneficiaries,
the rate is £1 8s. each.
Certain other dependants, such as parents and other relatives, may be
entitled to pensions (of up to .£1 a week), allowances or gratuities.
SUPPLEMENTARY The Ministry of Social Security Act 1966 provided for a scheme of supple-
ENEFITS mentary benefits to replace the system which had been administered by the
former National Assistance Board since 1948. The Act established within the
Ministry of Social Security a Supplementary Benefits Commission responsible
for guiding the scheme and for determining awards of benefit. The parallel
legislation in Northern Ireland made similar provision.
Every person in Great Britain aged 16 or over who is not in full-time work,
attending school or involved in a trade dispute and whose resources are
insufficient to meet his requirements is entitled to a supplementary benefit.
The benefit takes the form of a supplementary pension for those over the
statutory retirement age, and of a supplementary allowance for others. The
benefit is the amount by which a person’s requirements exceed his available
resources, both being defined by rules laid down by the Act. The calculation
of requirements is based on different amounts for single people and family
130
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
groups (for blind people there are special higher amounts) with, in each case,
an addition for rent. For the old and most other long-term cases a special
addition is made. Available resources include certain income and capital; the
main national insurance and industrial injury benefits, family allowances and
maintenance payments from a husband or the father of the claimant’s children
are taken into account in full but some part of all other resources is disregarded.
There is a right of appeal if the claimant is dissatisfied with the decision of the
Commission.
The payment of a supplementary allowance in the case of an able-bodied
man of working age may be subject to the condition that he registers for
employment at an employment exchange of the Department of Employment
and Productivity; the allowance is then paid at the exchange. Otherwise the
supplementary benefit is paid weekly through a post office.
The Supplementary Benefits Commission also has a duty to influence people
without a settled way of living to lead a more normal life. The Commission
provides temporary accommodation for them in reception centres, sometimes
through the agency of local authorities. For men who have been unemployed
for long periods and who are in receipt of supplementary allowances or are
using reception centres, it runs 12 non-residential and two residential
re-establishment centres where they are given help to fit them again for
work.
WAR PENSIONS
AND RELATED
SERVICES
Pensions and allowances for people disabled or bereaved through the wars or
service in the Forces since the second world war are paid under Royal Warrants
and other instruments administered by the Ministry of Social Security.
The current basic pension for 100 per cent disablement for a private soldier
is £7 12s. a week, but the amount varies according to rank and the degree of
disablement. The latter is assessed by comparing the condition of the person
disabled by service with that of a normal healthy person of the same age and
sex. Allowances for a wife and children are paid in addition to the basic
pension. There is a wide range of supplementary allowances, the main ones
being for unemployability (£4 17s. 6d. a week), constant attendance (up to £2
and, exceptionally, £6 a week), comforts (12s. 6d. or £1 5s. a week), and
lowered standard of occupation (up to £3 is. a week). An additional allowance
of £3 a week is payable to war pensioners who are receiving constant attend¬
ance allowance at a rate above the normal maximum. An age allowance
(between 7s. 6d. and £1 a week) is payable to disablement pensioners who
are aged 65 or over and whose assessment is 40 per cent or more.
Both the basic disablement pension and the supplementary allowances are
free of income tax, and children’s allowances are paid in addition to any
allowances payable under the Family Allowances Acts.
Pensions are also paid to war widow's and war orphans. The standard rate
of pension for widows of private soldiers is £2 17s. a week, with additional
allowances for their children (a maximum of £2 9s. 6d.), and, in certain cases,
an allowance for rent (up to £2 5s. a week). There is an additional allowance
of 15s. a week for widows aged 70 or over. Parents or other relatives who were
dependent on a person whose death resulted from service in the Forces may
receive pensions if they are in financial need.
The Ministry of Social Security maintains a welfare service for war
pensioners and war orphans which is available to help any who require
advice and assistance. War pensioners have priority for treatment of their war
disablements in National Health Service hospitals subject only to needs of
emergency and other urgent cases.
SOCIAL WELFARE
Many voluntary associations and ex-Service organisations give financial aid
and personal service to disabled ex-Service men and women and their families.
The Ministry’s welfare officers work in close co-operation with these voluntary
bodies and with the specialist government welfare agencies.
HEALTH
The concern of the State with the nation’s health is chiefly a development of
the years since the passing of the Public Health Act of 1848. The second half
of the nineteenth century was notable for the growth of the environmental
or public health services, such as provision of pure water, sewerage, disposal
of refuse and cleaning of streets, and the first half of the twentieth century
for the development of publicly provided personal health services, as distinct
from environmental services, culminating in the introduction in 1948 of a
comprehensive National Health Service available to every resident. Scientific
discoveries of importance to medicine and health, including the development
of new drugs, and the improved services of the last 60 years, particularly in
maternity and child welfare, school health services and school meals, are
reflected in declining mortality rates (see p. 9) and improved physique. The
infant mortality rate has more than halved since the National Health Service
was inaugurated; this and the maternal death rate are among the lowest in the
world. The health of children has steadily improved and the proportion of
school children considered to be in an ‘unsatisfactory’ condition of health
is now the lowest recorded. Deaths from such diseases as tuberculosis,
poliomyelitis and diphtheria have fallen so markedly that they are no longer
major health problems. Diseases now in the forefront of research programmes
include cancer and diseases of the central nervous system, such as muscular
dystrophy. Efforts are also being made to combat some of the most prevalent
diseases, which include, besides the common cold and influenza, bronchitis,
rheumatism and heart diseases.
PUBLIC HEALTH The Public Health Act of 1936 constitutes the present basic public health code
in England and Wales. Local authorities (under the general direction of the
Ministry of Health or the Welsh Board of Health and the Ministry of Housing
and Local Government) have extensive powers for making and administering
by-laws on matters of public health. The local authorities chiefly concerned
are the councils of county and non-county boroughs, London boroughs and
the City of London, urban and rural district councils and, to a limited extent
parish councils.
Public health services in Scotland and in Northern Ireland have developed
on much the same lines as in England and Wales, although they are based on
separate Acts and there is a different allocation of services between the various
types of local authority (working under the direction of the Scottish Home and
Health Department and the Northern Ireland Ministry of Health and Social
Services). The Public Health (Scotland) Acts 1897-1945 and the Burgh
Police (Scotland) Act 1892 as amended by later Statutes constitute the basic
legislation for Scotland. The local authorities concerned are the councils of
counties and burghs. In Northern Ireland the councils of county and non¬
county boroughs and urban and rural districts are mainly responsible for
administering the Public Health Acts (Northern Ireland) 1878-1966.
132
Control of
Infectious
Diseases
Pure Food
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Medical Officers of Health of local authorities are responsible for
investigating outbreaks of infectious diseases and for disinfection and other
preventive measures. They must also keep records of the incidence of
‘notifiable’—the more dangerous—infectious diseases.
Port health authorities supervise health control at seaports and airports, the
primary object of which is to prevent the introduction of infectious disease into
the country. This health control is undertaken by health authorities using the ser¬
vices of medical officers, public health inspectors, rodent inspectors and others.
The purity, hygiene and description of food are controlled by the Food and
Drugs Act 1955 in England and Wales, by the Food and Drugs (Scotland) Act
1956 in Scotland, and by the Food and Drugs (Northern Ireland) Act 1958 in
Northern Ireland.
In England and Wales the question of the composition, adulteration and
description of food are the concern of food and drugs authorities (county,
county borough, London borough and City of London councils and, generally,
the larger borough and urban district councils) and questions of soundness,
purity and hygiene are the concern of all local authorities, except parish
councils. The Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries
and Food are the central departments responsible for giving advice and making
regulations. Places where food for sale for human consumption is prepared,
sold or stored must conform to certain hygienic standards. Authorised officers
of the councils may take for analysis or for bacteriological or other examination
samples of any food for sale for human consumption. Special regulations are
in force for certain foods such as milk, meat and ice-cream.
In Scotland the local authorities chiefly concerned are the councils of
counties and large burghs.
In Northern Ireland administration is in the hands of the county and
county borough health authorities, the central department being the Ministry
of Health and Social Services.
Other Public Local authorities are also responsible for the public health aspects ol water
Health Duties supply, sewerage and drainage; street paving and housing; and the abatement
of noise nuisance. They have power to establish smoke-controlled areas to
secure cleaner air, and to arrange with statutory water undertakings for the
addition of fluoride to water supplies to reduce dental decay.
THE NATIONAL The Acts setting up the National Health Service the National Health
HEALTH SERVICE Service Act 1946, the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1947, and the
Health Services Act (Northern Ireland) 1948—came into force simultaneously
on 5th July 1948. ,
The object of the National Health Service Act 1946 is to promote the
establishment in England and Wales of a comprehensive health service
designed to secure improvement in the physical and mental health of the
people of England and Wales and the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of
illness, and for that purpose to provide or secure the effective provision of
services’. The service is available to all according to medical need without
regard to any insurance qualification; it was originally free to users but certain
small charges were introduced under subsequent legislation. The removal of
anxiety about the cost has encouraged people in need of treatment to seek it
where previously they might not have done so.
National insurance contributors are required to pay a separate weekly
national health contribution under the National Health Service Contribution

*The services in Scotland and Northern Ireland are somewhat differently organised. In Scotland the responsible Minister is the
Secretary of State for Scotland, and in Northern Ireland the Minister of Health and Social Services
Acts 1957 to 1961 (see Table 9) but contributors and non-contributors are
entitled to the same full range of services. Visitors from other countries who
come to Britain for treatment are expected to pay for it, but treatment can be
given under the emergency provisions of the National Health Service to any
who fall ill during a visit to Britain.
The services provided by the National Health Service fall into three main
groups1:
1. The hospital and specialist services for which the Minister of Health or
Secretary of State for Scotland is directly responsible. These are
administered through 20 regional hospital boards and over 460 hospital
management committees, or, in the case of teaching hospitals in England
and Wales, boards of governors. The three special psychiatric hospitals in
England for people with criminal propensities are directly administered
by the Minister of Health, and the similar hospitals in Scotland by the
Secretary of State.
2. The general practitioner services consist of the family doctor service, the
dental service, the eye service and the pharmaceutical service, for which
the Health Ministers are indirectly responsible. They are administered by
some 160 local executive councils on which doctors, dentists and pharm¬
acists are represented. Each council in England and Wales has an
ophthalmic services committee; in Scotland there are five joint ophthalmic
services committees.
3. The local authority health and welfare services.
