receive government grants. So too do various national bodies which promote
educational activities of a non-political kind, such as the National Federation
of Women’s Institutes. Many of these bodies also receive grants from local
education authorities for services rendered locally. .
A major share in the provision of adult education is increasingly being
assumed by local education authorities. Most of it is on a part-time basis,
mainly in the 7,600 evening institutes, which have a total of well o\ er a million
students, and also in colleges of further education, schools of art, adult
education centres, community centres, literary institutes and youth clubs. There
are about 30 short-term residential colleges in Great Britain maintained or
aided by local education authorities, providing courses varying in length
between a weekend and a fortnight. Many of the courses are practical, but
there are widespread opportunities for academic study. .
The Village Colleges pioneered in Cambridgeshire and variously adapted
in Cumberland, Monmouthshire, Leicestershire, Peterborough and
Somerset are a local education authority development mainly in rural areas.
The colleges are secondary schools planned also as community centres,
providing educational, social and cultural opportunities for adults in the areas
served. Community centres, though aided by the local education authorities
are usually managed by community associations many of which are affiliated
to the National Federation of Commumty Associations.
Six residential colleges (five in England and Wales, one m Scotland) provide
courses of one or two years, some of which lead to a diploma. The colleges
vary in character, although they all aim at providing a liberal education and
do not apply academic entry tests r u •
A number of voluntary bodies provide adult education as part of their
services. The Women’s Institutes and Townswomen’s Guilds, for example,
generally offer courses in social studies, arts, drama and handicrafts. These
too are aided bv local education authorities.
In general, courses at the highest levels in liberal studies are provided by
the extra-mural departments of the universities, many of which have full-time
staff appointed for this purpose and can call on the services of other members
of the university staff; and by the Workers’ Educational Association, which
also emplovs organising tutors and works closely with the university extra¬
mural departments. In 1967 over 250,000 students in Britain attended such
courses. Similar wrork is also promoted in some of the centres maintained y
local education authorities. . . , (
The National Institute of Adult Education provides in London a centre ot
information, research and publication for adult education, as well as a channel
of co-operation and consultation for the many organisations in England and
Wales which are interested in this subject. It is mainly financed by contri¬
butions from local education authorities and assisted by a grant fronJ the
Department of Education and Science. The Scottish Institute of Adult
Education is the corresponding body in Scotland. , Tt •
In Northern Ireland the extra-mural department of the Queen s University
of Belfast organises and staffs adult education classes which are supple¬
mented by classes organised by various non-official bodies. The Wor ers
Educational Association is responsible for classes at other than university
level and receives grants from the Ministry of Education.
Teachers are appointed by local education authorities or school governing
bodies or managers. In 1967 there were about 357,000 full-time and 42,000
part-time (equivalent to 21,500 full-time) teachers in publicly maintained
Teaching Aids
and Educational
Techniques
higher
education
EDUCATION 155
primary and secondary schools in Britain, an average of one teacher to 23
pupils; but because of the shortage of teachers, particularly those for younger
children, and their uneven distribution throughout the country, many classes
have more than the statutory maxima of pupils (40 pupils for primary and
30 for secondary school classes in England and Wales; in Scotland 45 for
primary, 40 for classes in the first three years and 30 for classes in subsequent
years of secondary departments). The rise in school population has created
a need for more and more teachers; although greater numbers are entering the
colleges of education (see p. 158), more university graduates are turning to
teaching, and many married women, formerly teachers, are returning to the
profession, yet more are needed if the Government’s aim of eliminating
oversize classes is to be achieved. In 1967 there were about 50,000 full-time
teachers in grant-aided establishments of further education in Britain, and, be¬
cause of the special conditions, many more part-time teachers. Most teachers in
technical colleges have had some industrial and professional experience.
There are national salary scales for teachers in schools and other educational
institutions maintained from public funds in England and Wales, in Scotland,
and in Northern Ireland.
Radio broadcasts to schools and colleges of further education are well
established. In 1967-68 the School Broadcasting Department of the BBC sent
out 70 different radio series, some of which were repeated within each week
to make it easier for the schools to arrange their listening times. These
programmes were used by about 32,000 schools in Britain. Television reached
some 18,000 schools and the British Broadcasting Corporation and the
Independent Television Authority between them provided some 30
programmes a week, most of which were repeated.
Radio provides a great variety of educational programmes for adults, both
vocational and non-vocational; most of them are grouped in the ‘Study
Session’ hourly programmes on five nights a wTeek. Television programmes
for similar audiences have grown fast; they are mostly shown on Saturday
and Sunday mornings and in the evening during the week. There have also
been a number of experimental projects sponsored between the BBC, some of
the independent television companies, universities, local education authorities
and a voluntary' body, the National Extension College. (For the proposed
‘open university’ see p. 156.)
There has been a rapid development in the use of programmed learning and
a National Centre for Programmed Learning has been established in the
Department of Education at the University of Birmingham. Language labora¬
tories (using tape recorders in individual booths) are being used at all levels of
the educational system. Most universities in Britain use closed circuit
television in one or more of their departments; it is also used increasingly in
medical schools, colleges of education, technical colleges and schools.
Schools and colleges co-ordinate different methods of audio-visual
presentation, including radio, television, films, colour slides, wall charts,
maps, models and tape recordings. For example, the BBC’s ‘Radiovision’
programmes for schools use coloured film strips synchronised with sound
programmes. The National Council for Educational Technology advises all
bodies connected with education and with training in industry and in the
Services on the availability' and use of audio-visual aids and other media.
The system of higher education includes universities, colleges of education
and advanced courses at various colleges in the further education system.
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
(Advanced courses are dealt with on p. 153 and higher education in Northern
Ireland on p. 159). The expansion of higher education has been accelerated by
the report of the Committee on Higher Education under Lord Robbins’
chairmanship (published in 1963, see Bibliography, p. 471), which suggested
that by i973_74 there should be 390,000 places in higher education in Great
Britain, of which 218,000 should be in university institutions. All sectors of
higher education are ahead of their schedules for the attainment of this target
and the Government now expects that there will be 220,000 to 225,000 places
in the universities by 1971-72.
Universities
University Finance
There are 44 universities in Britain, compared with 17 in 1945. Although the
Government is responsible for providing nearly three-quarters of universities’
income it does not control their work or teaching nor does it have direct
dealings with the universities. The grants are distributed, and the Secretary
of State is advised on university matters, by the University Grants Committee,
whose members are drawn from the academic and business worlds. Univer¬
sities as such are not represented on it. • • u
The English universities are: Aston1 (Birmingham), Bath1, Birmingham,
Bradford1, Bristol, Brunei1 (London), Cambridge, City1 (London), Durham,
East Anglia1, Essex1, Exeter, Hull, Keele, Kent at Canterbury1, Lancaster1,
Leeds, Leicester, Liverpool, London, Loughborough1, Manchester, Newcastle
upon Tyne, Nottingham, Oxford, Reading, Salford1, Sheffield, Southampton,
Surrey1, Sussex1, Warwick1 and York1. The federated University of Wales
includes the University of Wales Institute of Science and Technology and
St. David’s College, Lampeter. The Scottish universities are: Aberdeen,
Dundee1, Edinburgh, Glasgow, Heriot-Watt1 (Edinburgh), St. Andrews,
Stirling1, and Strathclyde1 (Glasgow). In Northern Ireland there is Queen s
University, Belfast, and the New University of Ulster1 in Coleraine, which
opened in 1968 (see p. 159).
The Universities of Oxford and Cambridge date from the twelfth and
thirteenth centuries and the Scottish Universities of St. Andrews, Glasgow,
Aberdeen and Edinburgh from the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. All the
other universities were founded in the nineteenth or twentieth centuries.
There are three other institutions where the work is of university standard:
University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, whose
students read for degrees of the University of Manchester, and the two post¬
graduate business schools which are supported jointly by industry and the
Government—the Manchester Business School and the London Graduate
School of Business Studies, associated with the London School of Economics
and the Imperial College of Science and Technology.
The Government is establishing an Open University which will provide
degree and other courses, using a combination of television and correspondence
courses together with a network of viewing and listening centres. No formal
academic qualification will be required to register for these courses, but the
standards of its degrees (to be awarded on a system of credits for each course
completed) will be as rigorous as those at other universities. The university
is expected to open in 1970-71.
In spite of the large sums of public money spent on universities they have
remained autonomous and independent institutions, due largely to the
existence of the University Grants Committee. The Committee acts as a link
between the Government from which it receives a block grant and the
1 Has received its charter since i960.
EDUCATION
157
universities to which it allocates this grant. In this way the Government
contributes over 70 per cent towards the current income of universities and
about 90 per cent towards their capital programmes for building work,
purchasing sites and properties, professional fees and furniture and equipment.
Further sums are raised by the universities themselves.
Recurrent grants for the academic year 1968—69 are provisionally estimated
at some £160 million, over four times the amount for 1958-59. Capital grants
paid out during 1968-69 are expected to be rather less than ^80 million, or
approaching five times the 1958-59 figure. In 1945 the total public expendi¬
ture, capital and current,on universities was £4 million. Mainly because of this
large increase, the Comptroller and Auditor General (see p. 3 58) was, in 1967,
given access to the books and records of the University Grants Committee and
the universities to check that the funds entrusted to the universities are
efficiently administered. He cannot question policy decisions or decisions
reached on academic grounds.
Courses in arts and science are offered by most universities. At nearly all
universities courses are available in one or more applied sciences. Imperial
College, London, University of Manchester Institute of Science and Tech¬
nology, the University of Strathclyde and some of the newer universities
concentrate on technology although they may also offer a number of courses
in social studies, modern languages and other non-technological subjects.
About 43 per cent of full-time university students in Great Britain are
taking arts or social studies courses and 44 per cent science and technology;
more than 10 per cent are studying medicine, dentistry and veterinary science,
and the remainder agriculture, forestry, architecture and town planning.
University degree courses generally extend over three or four years, though
in medicine, dentistry and veterinary science five or six years are required.
The first degree of Bachelor (Master for Arts, in the older Scottish univer¬
sities) is awarded on the completion of such a course, depending on satisfactory
examination results. Further study or research is required at the modern
universities for the degree of Master and by all universities for that of Doctor.
Actual degree titles vary according to the practice of each university. Diplomas
and certificates are awarded after shorter courses in some subjects. A uniform
standard of degree throughout the country is ensured by having external
examiners on all examining boards. In the last decade there has been a
tendency for degree courses to become more broadly based in subject matter,
particularly in the new universities.
University teaching combines lectures, practical classes (in scientific sub¬
jects) and small group teaching in either seminars or tutorials, the last being
a traditional feature of the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge.
Most members of the academic staffs devote time to research and at all
universities there are postgraduate students engaged in research.
Admission to the universities is by examination and selection; there is no
religious test and no colour bar. Women are admitted on equal terms with
men, but at Cambridge their numbers are limited by statute. The general
proportion of men to women students is nearly three to one; at Oxford it is
five to one, and at Cambridge nine to one. A third of all full-time university
students in Britain are living in colleges and halls of residence, slightly under
a half are in lodgings, and the remainder live at home.
Despite recent expansion programmes, applications for places at universities
for arts studies still exceed the number available. Prospective candidates for
i58

Staff
Colleges of

nearly all the universities apply for places through the Universities Central
Council on Admissions. The only students to apply directly are Scottish
candidates for the universities of Glasgow, Aberdeen and Dundee.
At the beginning of the academic year 1967-68 there were over 205,500
full-time university students in Britain. About 35,000 were postgraduate.
There were also in 1967-68 some 19,000 part-time students, more than
92 per cent of whom were working for university-level qualifications. A further
11,000 registered for London University’s external degree, the only external
degree available in Britain.
In 1967-68 there were about 29,500 full-time university teachers in Great
Britain; about 10 per cent of them were professors. The ratio of staff to
students was about one in eight, one of the most favourable in the world.
Teachers in maintained schools must hold qualifications approved by the
education departments. In England and Wales the majority qualify by
undertaking a three-year course of studies at a college of education. There
are also opportunities for college students to obtain a degree (Bachelor of
Education (BEd)) as well as a professional qualification by means of a four-year
course. There are special shortened courses for well-qualified older students.
University graduates and certain specialist teachers are qualified by their
degree or specialist qualification although many do an additional one-year
course at a university or college of education. In Scotland all teachers in
secondary schools must be graduates (or have equivalent qualifications) and
must have taken a course of teacher training but primary school teachers may
qualify by taking a three-year course at a college of education. The General
Teaching Council has almost complete powers over the profession excluding
salary matters but including the function of compiling a register of teachers,
admission to which will replace the former system of qualification by certificate.
In England and Wales there are 161 colleges of education 16 of which are
for day students only, 5 departments of education in technical colleges, 28
university departments of education, 4 colleges for training teachers for
technical institutions and 13 art teacher training centres. In 1967-68 there
were nearly 96,000 students in colleges of education in England and Wales
(including 6,600 in day colleges), 5,200 in university departments of education,
and 2,000 in technical and art training establishments. The total of 103,200
students is three times that for 1957-58. In Scotland there are ten colleges of
education; the number of students in training in 1967 was 10,240 with a
proposed increase to over 14,000 in 1970-71. Thus the Robbins report target
of 122,000 teacher training places in Great Britain by 1973-74 has been nearly
achieved already. More day colleges are being opened, some training is to be
organised on a part-time basis and there are more refresher courses, and more
nursery classes for children of potential teachers.
The education departments, universities, local education authorities and
other bodies provide a variety of short in-service training courses for
practising teachers.
In 1966-67 over 178,000 students in Great Britain were taking advanced
courses other than in universities and colleges of education in a wide variety of
subjects including architecture, art and design (see p. 216), catering,
engineering, natural sciences and business studies. (Over 63,000 were full¬
time or sandwich course students; the Robbins report target for that year
was 45,000.) An increasing proportion of the students were taking courses
leading to the awards of the Council for National Academic Awards. The
EDUCATION
Awards
Northern
Ireland
159
Council has power to award degrees and other academic qualifications,
comparable in standard with those granted by universities, to students who
successfully complete approved courses of study in establishments which do
not have the power to award their own degrees. In 1967-68 there were 167
courses being followed by about 10,630 students in 46 colleges. These courses
were mainly in science and technology but included the arts, social studies,
business studies and law, and some subjects in which there are few or no
courses offered in universities. The Council’s powers extend over the whole of
Great Britain.
The Government is concentrating higher education provision outside
universities and colleges of education within 30 major national institutions to
be known as ‘polytechnics’ and to be formed from some 60 existing colleges.
They will have, ultimately, at least 2,000 full-time students each and will be
comprehensive institutions providing all types of courses (full-time, sandwich
and part-time) at all levels of higher education.
Management studies are provided by universities and technical colleges,
by individual companies and by trade and industrial federations. (For the two
postgraduate business schools, see p. 156.) Certain independent colleges
specialise in management training. Several universities have introduced
management studies into the curriculum and courses for the postgraduate
Diploma in Management Studies are run by certain technical colleges. In
Scotland courses leading to the Certificate of Business Administration are
provided for students in junior supervisory positions.
Awards to enable students to undertake higher education are made under one
of the most generous grant systems in the world. It is national policy that no
boy or girl should be prevented by lack of means from taking an advanced
course at a university or elsewhere. As a result, over 90 per cent of students in
higher education in Great Britain are aided from private or public funds.
A UNESCO survey has indicated that university students in Britain are drawn
from a wider social background than those in any other Western European
country.
In England, Wales and Scotland most adequately qualified British students
can obtain awards from public funds in order to attend full-time at a university,
college of education or major further education establishment. In England and
Wales local education authorities provide awards. In Scotland students’
allowances for advanced courses are granted by the Scottish Education
Department. The amount of these awards depends upon the income of the
student and his parents. Studentships for advanced postgraduate study are
offered annually by the Department of Education and Science, the Research
Councils and the Scottish Education Department.
Higher education in Northern Ireland is also expanding. The Government
accepted most of the recommendations put forward in 1965 by the committee,
under Sir John Lockwood’s chairmanship, on higher education in Northern
Ireland (see Bibliography, p. 471). The Government agreed that there should
be between 8,000 and 9,000 full-time university places by 1973-74 an<^ has
established a second university called the New University of Ulster, at
Coleraine. The first students were admitted in October 1968.
Technological studies are to be concentrated at the existing university,
Queen’s University, Belfast, and the Lockwood Committee recommended that
the new university should concentrate on the biological sciences. The Govern¬
ment also accepted in principle the committee’s proposals for teacher training.

The New University of Ulster includes an education centre for non-graduate
teachers and the general teacher training colleges have been renamed colleges
of education and brought into closer association with Queen’s University.
Higher education outside the universities is to be centred on a new Ulster
College ultimately envisaged as an association of the colleges of technology,
art and’ domestic science and other colleges providing a Northern Ireland
service.
Queen’s University, Belfast, and a recognised college, Magee University
College, Londonderry (which is to be integrated into the New University of
Ulster) had a total of 5,660 students in 1967-68. Between 1957 and 1907
nearlv /i2-5 million was spent on university building projects and further
expansion over the next 10 years is planned. Recurrent expenditure in I967_o8
was estimated at nearly £3 million. Government grants are made by the
Ministry of Education which usually first seeks the advice of the University
Grants Committee. Teacher training takes place in the university departments
of education and six training colleges, with 135 and 2,260 full-time students
respectively in 1967-68. Technological education outside the university
sphere is given under the sponsorship of the Joint Authority for Higher
Technological Studies. Under the proposed reorganisation this worn wifi be
transferred to the Regional College of Technology and the Joint Authority
will be wound up. University and further education scholarships are awarded
by local authorities and postgraduate awards and teacher training scholarships
by the Ministry of Education, the conditions of award being identical with
those for Great Britain.
EDUCATIONAL
RESEARCH
Research into the theory and practice of education and the organisation o
educational services is supported financially by the educational departments,
local education authorities, philanthropic organisations, universities and
teachers’ associations. The Social Science Research Council is an additional
channel for government support. . ,
The greater proportion of educational research is done in the universities,
particularly within departments or institutes of education and departments
concerned with sociology, psychology, statistics and problems of physical and
mental handicap. Outside universities, the major research institute is the
National Foundation for Educational Research, an autonomous body which
derives its income mainly from corporate members, including xocal education
authorities, teachers’ organisations and universities and from an annual grant ,
from the Department of Education and Science. There are also the Scottish
Council for Research in Education and the Northern Ireland Council for
Educational Research. The Schools Council sponsors a number of projects in
England and Wales. . . ,
There is no single central organisation for the co-ordination of education, [
research, but the central departments, by their allocation of funds for projects,
exercise some influence on the direction of research effort. In 1967 68 the
Department of Education and Science had a total commitment of about £2
million spread over 136 projects, and current expenditure exceeded £500,000;
the Scottish Education Department’s grant to the Scottish Council and other
research bodies totalled about £55,000.
Among philanthropic organisations that provide generously for research are
the Nuffield Foundation and Ford Foundation, the Gulbenkian Trust, the
Leverhulme Trust, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Carnegie United King¬
dom Trust, the Wolfson Foundation and the Foundation for Management
Education.
INTERNATIONAL
RELATIONS
Overseas
Students
in Britain
EDUCATION l6l
There are many opportunities for overseas students to study in Britain and
for British students to study abroad and British teachers are encouraged to
serve overseas for a period.
Students come to Britain from countries throughout the world to study at
universities or other educational institutions or for professional training. In
the academic year 1967-68 there were over 73,000 overseas students in
Britain, of whom about 17,500 were at universities, another 17,700 at technical
colleges and the remainder learning English or training as teachers, doctors
and nurses, for the law, banking and accountancy, or in industry. About two-
thirds of all overseas students were from the Commonwealth.
A wide range of public and private fellowships and scholarships for advanced
study in Britain are awarded annually to students and research workers from
other countries. Under the Commonwealth Scholarship and Fellowship Plan,
the Governments of certain Commonwealth countries have made awards
available at their own institutions of higher education to men and women from
other Commonwealth countries. At the beginning of the academic year
1967-68, 611 scholarships and fellowships (including the recently established
medical awards) were held in Britain. In addition the Commonwealth Bursary
Scheme achieved its highest total (553) of teachers and others training in
Britain. Examples of smaller government schemes are the Athlone Fellowship
Scheme, under which about 40 fellowships a year are awarded to Canadian
engineering graduates for up to two years’ further study, training and research
in institutions or industries in Britain, and the Indian Centres of Advance
Study Scheme in which, as part of a plan for establishing links between British
and Indian universities, academic staff from 12 Indian universities spend a
period with British universities.
About 500 British Council1 scholarships, tenable usually for one year in
Britain, are offered annually to graduates of overseas universities. Twenty-four
Marshall Scholarships for two years’ study at any university in Britain are
offered annually by the British Government to graduates from the United
States of America and over 60 Rhodes Scholarships are awarded annually to
Commonwealth and United States graduates for two years of study at the
University of Oxford. Other universities and colleges themselves offer many
scholarships for which graduate students of any nationality are eligible.2
Fellowships and training awards for study in British institutions are available
under the Central Treaty Organisation, the Colombo Plan, the Special
Commonwealth African Assistance Plan and British technical assistance
programmes for many other countries. Large numbers of awards for study or
1 The purpose of the British Council (founded in 1934) is defined in its Royal Charter as
the promotion of a wider knowledge of the United Kingdom and the English language
abroad and the development of closer cultural relations between Britain and other
countries. The Council is governed by an executive committee of 30 members,
broadly representative of many elements of the life of Britain and including nine
members nominated by ministers. It is financed almost entirely from public funds.
The activities of the Council, which has staff in 70 overseas countries, are concerned
with: English language teaching and other educational work including science;
fostering personal contacts between British and overseas people, especially in the
educational, professional and scientific fields; running, or helping to maintain, libraries
of British books and periodicals overseas; and presenting overseas the best in the arts
in Britain. Its work in Britain is concerned mainly with professional visitors and with
the welfare of overseas students.
2 The Association of Commonwealth Universities publishes every two years a handbook,
United Kingdom Postgraduate Awards (see Bibliography, p. 470), listing postgraduate
awards tenable at universities in Britain (and a short list of awards at overseas
universities for which British students are eligible).

training in Britian are also made under the United Nations Programmes of
Technical Assistance and by the United Nations specialised agencies such as
UNESCO, FAO and WHO.
The Commonwealth Education Liaison Committee supplements normal
direct dealings on education between the countries of the Commonwealth.
The fourth Commonwealth Education Conference was held in Lagos in
1968.
Arrangements The national representatives in London (Office of the High Commissioner or
for Overseas Embassy) of a number of countries accept certain special responsibilities for
Students their students in Britain. The British Council acts as an agent for the overseas
departments of State in matters affecting the welfare of overseas students,
and provides certain services, such as meeting on arrival, introduction
courses, an accommodation bureau and student centres in London and other
university cities. The Council also organises a varied programme of lectures,
discussions and social and other activities and arranges introductions of
students to people who wish to invite them to their homes. In the vacations
there are courses in many parts of the country which offer opportunities for
getting to know more about British life in town and country. In term time
there are visits to various places of interest, and theatre and concert parties
are arranged.
Among many voluntary organisations which offer a welcome to overseas
students are the East and West Friendship Council, Rotary, Round Table, the
Victoria League, the Royal Over-Seas League, the Royal Commonwealth
Society, the National Union of Students, the English-Speaking Union and
Churches of all denominations. The London Conference on Overseas
Students, for which the British Council provides the secretariat, co-ordinates
their work for overseas students in the metropolis. In many London boroughs
and in other large cities there are committees which help students to make
contact with local residents and organisations. Similar conferences have come
into being in other large cities in Britain. These organisations also help by
entertaining overseas students and many of them have established hostels with
the financial help of the Overseas Students Welfare Expansion Programme
which is administered by the British Council. By the beginning of 1968 grants
had been approved for 104 projects, providing places for 4,800 students.
British Students Under the Commonwealth Scholarship and Fellowship Plan, a number of
Overseas scholarships are made available annually to United Kingdom students by the
Governments of other Commonwealth countries for study in their universities,
colleges and other institutions of higher learning. In 1967-68, 71 scholarships
were held by United Kingdom students in seven Commonwealth countries.
In addition the Study and Serve Scheme enables British students to undertake
a year’s postgraduate study at universities in the developing countries on
condition that they also work for a period in appropriate employment in the
country concerned. . .
For many years the United States/United Kingdom Educational Commis¬
sion (still sometimes called the Fulbright Commission) has offered travel
grants for postgraduate study in the United States. Notable among recently
established scholarships are the Kennedy scholarships, to enable British
students to study at three American universities, and the Churchill travel
scholarships, for men and women in all walks of life. British students are also
offered scholarships at institutions of higher education in 22 European and
seven non-European countries (see footnote, p. 161).
EDUCATION
Teachers
Serving
Overseas
Other
Educational
Aid
163
Over 1,425 teachers were recruited in Britain during 1967 for posts in
schools, colleges of education, technical colleges and universities in develop¬
ing countries, including 1,310 for posts in the developing countries of the
Commonwealth; all of them are supported by public funds. Steps taken by
the Government to help school teachers to serve for a period overseas have
included the establishment of a National Council for the Supply and Training
of Teachers Overseas and the introduction of special measures to safeguard
their interests both while abroad and on their return home. Recruitment
is carried out by the Ministry of Overseas Development, the British Council
and the voluntary teacher recruiting agencies, such as the Catholic Overseas
Appointments and the Overseas Appointments Bureaux.
There are about 1,000 British university teachers serving overseas, most of
them recruited through the Inter-University Council on Higher Education,
the Association of Commonwealth Universities or the British Council.
Government encouragement also includes support for the work of the
Committee on University Secondment and the Special Commonwealth
Awards, which are made to leading scholars from British universities who are
willing to work for a minimum of two years in important posts in the
universities of developing Commonwealth countries.
Outside the schemes, an increasing number of graduate and qualified
volunteers, also cadet volunteers (school leavers), 1,550 in 1967-68, are going
overseas for one or two years, a large number to teach. Many of them go with
the support of voluntary bodies (co-ordinated under the British Volunteer
Programme) which receive financial assistance from the Government.
Interchange schemes, under which teachers in Britain exchange posts for
a year with teachers overseas, include one with the United States and another
with Commonwealth countries, whereby each year over 100 British teachers
exchange posts with teachers from Canada, Australia and New Zealand.
Official exchange schemes also operate between Britain and several European
countries both for teachers and for temporary assistants’ posts for language
specialists.
Britain provides, on request, assistance to the developing countries in several
other ways, including the loan of educational experts for technical and
consultant services and specialist missions, through various educational
organisations and the Ministry of Overseas Development. For example, the
Centre for Educational Television Overseas (see p. 436) helps to advance the
education of adults and children in developing countries by means of television,
and the Oversea Visual Aids Centre in London gives advice to teachers and
others from overseas countries on all aspects of audio-visual aids. Financial
assistance is also given for building and equipping educational institutions.
YOUTH SERVICES
The object of youth services in Britain is to provide for the leisure-time
activities of young people in the 14 to 20 age group (these age limits are under
review), and to offer them opportunities—complementary to those of home,
formal education and work—for discovering and developing their personal
resources, so that they may be better equipped to be responsible members of
the community. Membership of youth organisations is voluntary and the
facilities are sufficiently varied to appeal to every type of boy and girl.

State and
Voluntary

The Voluntary
Organisations
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
A number of youth organisations have spontaneously developed over the last
century, mainly by voluntary effort. These organisations now work in
partnership with local education authorities and the central government in the
Youth Service. There is no attempt to impose uniformity or to create any
national youth organisation. The status of Youth Service as an essential part
of the educational system of Great Britain was confirmed by the Education
Act 1944 and the Education (Scotland) Act 1945; in Northern Ireland, youth
welfare work is promoted under the Education Act (Northern Ireland) 1947,
and the Youth Welfare, Physical Training and Recreation Act (Northern
Ireland) 1962.
The education departments provide grants in aid of the administrative and
training work of some national voluntary youth organisations, towards the
expense of training full-time youth leaders and towards the cost of premises
and equipment of youth clubs provided by voluntary bodies.
Local education authorities co-operate with voluntary organisations in their
areas: most give some financial help and lend premises and equipment; most
also employ youth organisers to help in the promotion and encouragement
of youth work. Where voluntary services are considered inadequate, local
authorities themselves organise youth centres and clubs. Most local authorities
have appointed youth committees on which official and voluntary bodies are
represented.
In addition to grants received from the State and local authorities, voluntary
organisations may receive help for special projects from charitable trusts.
Most of the funds of the voluntary organisations are raised by their own efforts.
Ministers are advised on the finance and development of the Youth Service
by the Youth Service Development Council for England and Wales, the
Standing Consultative Council on Youth and Community Service for Scotland
and the Youth and Sports Council for Northern Ireland. Annual grants to
the value of over £300,000 are made towards the headquarters expenses of
the national voluntary youth organisations and there are special grants for
voluntary projects. The Department of Education and Science authorised a
£27-5 million building programme for England and Wales for the period
1960-68. There is a national training college for youth leaders at Leicester,
where there is also an information centre; there are more than 1,500 trained
youth leaders. Local authorities’ contributions to the youth service in England
and Wales amounted to some £7-9 tn i967-68. In Scotland annual
expenditure on the youth services is estimated at about £400,000.
The voluntary organisations vary greatly in character since nearly all of them
were formed to serve specific groups of young people; some of them provide
educational and religious activities as well as social and recreational pursuits
for their members, and all of them seek to inculcate high ideals of personal
conduct and service to the community.
Twenty-five national voluntary youth organisations, all with memberships
of at least 10,000, are constituent members of the Standing Conference of
National Voluntary Youth Organisations, a consultative body which takes
action only in the name of its member bodies and with their consent. A further
28 bodies are associate or observer members, for example, the Church of
England Youth Council, which represents about 400,000 young people who
are members of clubs sponsored by the Church of England. The corresponding
body in Scotland is the Scottish Standing Conference of Voluntary Youth
Organisations, in Northern Ireland the Standing Conference of Youth Organi¬
sations, and in Wales the Standing Conference for Wales of Voluntary
EDUCATION
Youth Organisations. These major organisations have a total United Kingdom
membership of about 3 million young people under 21.
Among the youth organisations with a mainly religious origin and purpose
are the Young Men’s Christian Association (YMCA) and Young Women’s
Christian Association (YWCA), with about 52,000 and 18,000 members under
21 respectively; the Boys’ Brigade (150,000), the Church Lads Brigade
(12,000), the Girls’ Brigade (91,000), the Girls’ Friendly Society (19,000),
the Methodist Association of Youth Clubs (157,000), the Salvation Army
Youth Organisations (109,000), the Catholic Young Men’s Society of Great
Britain (15,000), the Catholic Youth Service Council (39,000), the Young
Christian Workers (18,000), the Grail (12,500), and the Association for Jewish
Youth (18,000).
The Scouts Association and Girl Guides Association have world-wide
affiliations; they are undenominational and non-political, and were founded
by Lord Baden-Powell in 1908 and 1910 to develop character and good
citizenship in boys and girls. Their total United Kingdom membership under
21 is about 489,000 scouts and 594,000 guides.
The National Association of Boys’ Clubs, with about 2,000 affiliated clubs
and 165,000 members, and the National Association of Youth Clubs, with
over 3,000 affiliated clubs and 262,000 members, are concerned mainly with
the 14 to 20 age group. Each affiliated club has its own rules, but ail aim at
giving young people opportunities to develop into mature members of
society. Representatives from clubs form local committees and these send
representatives to the national members’ councils.
A notable trend in recent years has been the growth in voluntary service by
young people to those in need in the community, such as the elderly and the
sick, the mentally ill and the handicapped. Through organisations such as
International Voluntary Service, Community Service Volunteers, Task Force,
Toe H and others, thousands of young people are doing valuable voluntary
work, both within and outside Britain. The Government has set up the
Young Volunteer Force Foundation which controls a team of 30 young people
available on request to assist local authorities, hospitals and other organisations
in encouraging and organising voluntary service.
The pre-Service organisations for boys (the Combined Cadet Force,
Army Cadet Force and Air Training Corps) combine social, educational and
physical development with training for possible entry into the armed forces;
their combined membership is about 125,000. The Combined Cadet Force
(CCF) contingents are based on schools in which education is continued to
the age of 17 or beyond. Training normally begins at 14 and the boys can
choose whether they will join the Royal Navy, Army or Royal Air Force
sections. The Army Cadet Force and the Air Training Corps are for boys in
schools that do not have CCF contingents or for those who have left school.
The Sea Cadet Corps, although not a pre-Service organisation, helps boys
who wish to make their career at sea; its membership is about 17,000. The
Girls’ Venture Corps, with about 6,400 members, formed in 1964 from the
Girls’ Training Corps and the Women’s Junior Air Corps, has an Air Wing
offering aviation courses.
The National Federation of Young Farmers’ Clubs in England and Wales
has about 34,000 members between 10 and 25 years old, the Scottish
Association of Young Farmers’ Clubs has about 7,500 and Northern Ireland
Young Farmer Clubs about 4,000 members: in addition to encouraging
interest in agriculture and appreciation of country life, the clubs provide
training in the arts of citizenship and develop ability to serve the community.

The Welsh League of Youth (Urdd Gobaith Cymru) has a membership
of about 43,000; its aim is the ‘development of Christian citizenship among
the youth of Wales’.
The Youth Hostels Associations in England and Wales, Scotland and
Northern Ireland have a network of hostels for walkers and cyclists, particu¬
larly intended for young people of limited means. They seek to promote
knowledge and love of the countryside, and are closely linked with each other
and with similar organisations in other countries.
Adult organisations with youth sections include the British Red Cross
Society, St. John Ambulance Association and Brigade and the political parties.
Other King George’s Jubilee Trust was established in 1935 by King George V to
Organisations promote the welfare of the younger generation. Since its inauguration it has
Concerned with disbursed nearly ^i-8 million to the headquarters of the principal voluntary
Youth Work youth organisations and to many local projects, particularly those of an
experimental nature.
In 1968 about 112,000 young people between the ages of 14 and 20 took
part in the Duke of Edinburgh’s Award, which is a scheme operated by local
authorities, schools, youth organisations, industrial firms and other bodies,
and is designed as a challenge to boys and girls to reach certain standards of
achievement in three progressive stages in leisure-time activities. There are
three separate levels of Award—Gold, Silver and Bronze each comprising
four sections. Three of the sections, entitled service, pursuits and interests,
and expedition, are common to boys and girls; the fourth section is fitness,
for boys, and design for living, for girls. A number of Commonwealth
countries, including Canada, Australia and New Zealand, now operate the
scheme.
The Outward Bound Trust maintains in Great Britain five schools for boys
which offer 26-day character-building courses, based on adventure and
overcoming testing experiences. There is a similar school for girls, with
modified courses. About 4,500 boys and 850 girls, between the ages of 14^
and 19J, take part each year.
The aims of the Central Council of Physical Recreation, the Scottish
Council of Physical Recreation and the National Playing Fields Association
bring them into touch with many youth organisations (see Chapter 19).
In addition to organisations on a nation-wide basis, there are a large
number of town, district or village social clubs run by voluntary groups for
general or particular purposes, for instance, photographic societies, folk dance,
table tennis or jazz clubs.
7 PLANNING AND
HOUSING
TOWN AND COUNTRY PLANNING
Britain is one of the most densely populated areas in the world: it is, therefore,
essential to plan land use for a satisfactory national distribution of employment
and population, to undertake a programme of urban renewal, to build new
towns and to preserve the amenities of the countryside.
From 1909 successive Acts of Parliament recognised the principle of the
planned use of land, but because the pattern of development over much of
the country had already hardened into large unplanned urban concentrations
the powers granted to local planning authorities were inadequate for the task
in hand.
The 20 years between the two world wars were decades of rapid social
and industrial change and of developments in industry, engineering, house¬
building, and motor transport; the population was increasing and becoming
more mobile; there was a widespread demand for improved standards of
accommodation and consequently a greater need for systematic planning than
had hitherto been required. At the beginning of the 1930s a major effort was
made to strengthen planning law and to extend the planning powers of central
and local authorities. This resulted in the Town and Country Planning Acts
of 1932 which remained the basis of planning law for 15 years.
Although inter-war planning legislation improved sanitary and environ¬
mental conditions and did something to preserve amenities, its general effect
was unsatisfactory mainly because it failed to deal adequately with the problems
involved in compensating property owners who stood to lose by the intro¬
duction of positive planning schemes. Local authorities often hesitated to
exercise their powers effectively for fear of being involved in financial liabilities
beyond their means, and as a result there was still much unregulated urban
development spreading over the countryside.
Renewed efforts to tackle these problems were made immediately before
and during the second world war. Between 1937 and 1942 three expert com¬
mittees were appointed to study and report upon the unregulated growth and
spread of industry; the restriction of planning by the financial and administra¬
tive difficulties of compensation and betterment; and the encroachment of
urban development upon the countryside. After the second world war other
committees studied the question of new towns and national parks. Almost all
the principal planning recommendations of these committees have now been
incorporated in Acts of Parliament. Two comprehensive Town and Country
Planning Acts (one for England and Wales and one for Scotland), introduced
in 1947, imposed compulsory planning duties on all local planning authorities
(the larger local authorities) and gave them extensive powers to acquire and
develop land for planning purposes. The Acts also established a centralised
planning structure under which the Minister of Housing and Local Govern¬
ment and the Secretary of State for Scotland (and since 1965 the Secretary of
State for Wales) had the duty of approving all development plans and making
decisions on appeals against development control decisions. Over the past few
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
years the increase in population, leading to a demand for more and better
housing, and the growth in the volume of motor traffic with its effects on the
structure of towns and on the countryside (see p. 173)’ have overstrained the
planning system.
The Town and Country Planning Bill 1968 provides for a new procedure
to reduce administrative delays; to place emphasis on a positive approach to
provide pleasant surroundings in which people might live and work, rather
than on negative controls; and to enable individuals to play a greater part in
the planning process than hitherto. ‘Structure plans are to be drawn up by
local planning authorities (the councils of counties and county boroughs, the
London authorities and, in some cases, joint planning boards) in England and
Wales and submitted to the Minister of Housing and Local Government or
the Secretary of State for Wales for approval. These plans set out ‘broad
policies’ for land use in counties and major towns and relate these policies to
transport patterns. They also indicate ‘action areas’ where development,
redevelopment or improvement is expected to start within a specified period.
In addition, local planning authorities are to prepare local plans which they
formally adopt, generally without the need for ministerial approval. These
plans contain detailed proposals (including plans for the action areas) within
the framework of the structure plans. All the plans may be amended periodic¬
ally. The new system is being introduced progressively where the local
planning authorities are suitably staffed and organised to draw up satisfactory
structure plans, for example, in Greater London. It may be adapted to what¬
ever form the structure of local government might take in the 1970s (see
p. 66). Similar legislation is to be introduced for Scotland.
The Bill provides safeguards for the public in the form of publicity for
development proposals and the consideration of objections by independent
inspectors with professional qualifications appointed by the Ministers. The
inspectors will also, after enquiries, be largely responsible for decisions on
planning appeals, many of which relate to small-scale residential development.
In exceptional cases, when a wider national issue is involved, the jurisdiction
will be that of the Minister, who may set up a planning enquiry commission to
consider in depth large development schemes such as the siting of an airport.
The Government has set up a committee to consider ways in which the public
may be able to participate in the making of local development plans at the
formative stage.
In Northern Ireland applications for permission to undertake development
are the responsibility of local planning authorities, with a right of appeal to
the Northern Ireland Ministry of Development. Proposals for changes in the
administration of planning have been published. A Central Development
Office would be responsible for the continuing review of the region’s plan and
for the preparation of area plans under the guidance of steering committees
composed of local authority representatives. Local planning authorities would
be responsible for preparing ‘action plans’, including urban renewal schemes
and other development projects in a defined area.
Advisory machinery for planning on a regional basis has been set up by the
Government (see p. 234). Local planning authorities are advised to consult the
regional economic planning councils before drawing up their development
plans. Studies showing the economic and social resources in several regions
have been made (see Bibliography, p. 476) and certain areas, where land,
communications and facilities are favourable, have been proposed as places
where development should be concentrated.
The Location
of Industry
New Towns
PLANNING AND HOUSING 169
Provisions relating to the location of industry and offices have been made in
the Town and Country Planning Acts, the Local Employment Acts 1960-66,
the Control of Office and Industrial Development Act 1965, and the Industrial
Development Act 1966. General problems of industrial development are
dealt with jointly by a number of government departments, but the consent
of the local planning authority is, as a rule, required for any new industrial
building, any extension of a building or any change in the use of an existing
building. Financial incentives to encourage the location of industry in
particular areas have been made available by successive governments (see
p. 249). There is special control on office building in south-east England and
the Midlands.
The Newr Towns Act 1946 (now consolidated in Acts passed in 1965 and 1968)
gave the Minister of Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of
State for Scotland power to make an order designating any area of land
(which may include any existing town or other centre of population) as the
site of a new town; in 1965 the same power was given to the Secretary of State
for Wales. The Minister of Development in Northern Ireland has similar
powers under the New Towns Act (Northern Ireland) 1965. The appropriate
minister must consult the local authorities in the area about the proposal and
an opportunity is given for objections to be made by the public. Once the site
has been designated, the Minister appoints a development corporation (a
development commission in Northern Ireland), consisting of a chairman, a
deputy chairman and up to seven other members, to be responsible for the
development of the new town, including the preparation of a ‘master plan’.
The development corporations have powers in general (subject to the
consent of the appropriate minister) to acquire, by agreement or compulsory
purchase, land or property within the designated areas, or, in some cases,
land near to or outside those areas, and they may provide buildings, roads and
services essential for the development of the towns. Ministerial approval of
proposals for development, given after consultation with the local planning
authority, constitutes planning permission.
As each new town in England and Whales is substantially completed the
development corporation is dissolved and its assets and liabilities are handed
over to a government appointed central agency—the Commission for New
Towns—which was set up in 1959. The Commission has taken over respon¬
sibility for the maintenance and management of land and property in
Crawley, Hatfield, Hemel Hempstead and Welwyn.
The capital cost of developing the new towns is advanced to the corporations
and the commission from public funds and is repayable over 60 years out of
the income from the property. The corporations and the commission submit
annual reports (which include copies of their audited accounts) to Parliament.
Twenty-seven new towns have been, or are being, established in Great
Britain; twenty-two in England and Wales and five in Scotland. Eleven of the
new towns in England and Wales (Basildon, Bracknell, Crawley, Harlow,
Hatfield, Hemel Hempstead, Milton Keynes, Northampton, Peterborough,
Stevenage and Welwyn) are designed to help relieve housing problems in the
Greater London area. Of the others, Aycliffe, Corby, Cwmbran, Peterlee and
Washington are serving the special needs of their areas; Runcorn and
Skelmersdale are to meet the overspill needs of Liverpool and north Mersey¬
side; Dawley and Redditch will take population from Birmingham; and
Warrington will be expanded to take people from Manchester. Newtown in
mid-Wales is to be developed to promote economic growth in the area.
170
Town
Development
Schemes
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
To help in solving the housing problems in London, Manchester, Liverpool
and Birmingham proposals are also under consideration for the expansion of
Ipswich, for large-scale development in the Leyland-Chorley area of Lanca¬
shire and for the expansion of Dawley to include Wellington-Oakengates.
Studies are also being made of the possibilities of development in the Dundee
and Tayside area and the regions of the Humber and the Severn rivers to
provide for a rapidly growing population.
The Scottish new towns (Cumbernauld, East Kilbride, Glenrothes, Irvine
and Livingston) are helping to house people from Glasgow. Irvine and
Livingston are also to be centres for industrial activity in the central belt of
Scotland.
The new towns represent a notable achievement in positive land use. They
are generally recognised as one of the most successful post-war experiments,
both socially and industrially, and as a profitable long-term investment. More
than half a million people have moved into the new towns during the past
20 years; young people form a higher proportion of their populations than in
the country as a whole. An extensive building and civil engineering programme
has provided houses, flats, factories, schools, shops, churches, health centres
and libraries as well as public buildings including the town hall and law
courts. Roads, water supplies, sewerage, gas and electricity, police, fire and
bus stations, postal, telegraph and telephone facilities have also been provided;
most of the towns are well equipped with parks and playing fields of various
kinds. All towns have become concerned with the increasingly high level of car
ownership of their inhabitants and are making more adequate provision for
parking and the segregation of pedestrians from motorists.
A number of the more developed towns are becoming regional centres and,
as the populations grow large enough to give the necessary support, offices,
hotels, and department stores, as well as full entertainment and recreational
facilities such as skating rinks, dance halls, bowling alleys, swimming
pools, sports stadia, golf courses and youth centres are gradually being
provided.
Under the New Towns Act 1946 Parliament approved a fund of ^,50 million
to provide for advances to the development corporations for work on the new
towns. This fund was increased by subsequent Acts and now stands at ^800
million; a total of over £563-5 million had been advanced to the corporations
by March 1968.
In Northern Ireland, Craigavon is being developed as a new city; it will
provide homes for people from Belfast and is expected to become an area of
major industrial growth. Other new towns, of which two, Antrim and Bally¬
mena, have been designated, are also to be developed as centres of economic
growth.
The Town Development Act 1952 makes provision for the relief of congestion
in large industrial towns in England and Wales (such as London and
Birmingham) by encouraging the transfer of population from these areas to
country areas suitable for expansion where employment is provided. Schemes
have been approved for providing some 152,000 dwellings in this way, of
which over one-third have been completed or are under construction. Some of
the expanding towns, for example, Aylesbury, Basingstoke, Swindon and
Thetford are already well established; further large-scale development is to
take place at Swindon. The Housing and Town Development (Scotland) Act
1957 makes similar provision for Scotland. Schemes have been approved for
some 30,000 dwellings; about a quarter of these have been completed.
Urban
Renewal
Historic
Buildings
Green Belts
Other Measures
to Protect the
Environment
PLANNING AND HOUSING 171
The renewal and re-shaping of existing towns and cities is being undertaken
to meet the growth in population and the impact of more traffic. Glasgow,
for example, has started a programme of rebuilding 30 areas, housing nearly
a third of its population and accommodating much of the industry and
commerce of the city. The Buchanan report (see p. 330) which assessed the
conflicting demands of traffic and environmental standards has influenced
many authorities’ redevelopment plans. The Government believes that the
greater integration of land use and transport planning is of basic importance.
An urban planning directorate, in which the Ministry of Housing and Local
Government and the Ministry of Transport are collaborating, is developing
policies and techniques involved in urban renewal. A centre for environmental
studies financed by the Government and the Ford Foundation (see p. 160) is
sponsoring research into the problems of urban planning.
Responsibility for the preservation of the historic, scenic and architectural
beauties of Great Britain rests mainly with the Minister of Housing and Local
Government, the Secretary of State for Scotland, the Secretary of State for
Wales, and the local planning authorities. Lists of buildings of special
architectural or historic interest are being compiled (covering 107,000 so far).
Close supervision is maintained over development proposals that might affect
these buildings so that their character is not destroyed. The respective
ministers (on the recommendation of the appropriate Historic Buildings
Council) are responsible for administering the grants available for the repair
and maintenance of buildings of outstanding historic or architectural interest.
Grants totalling nearly £7 million have been made under the Historic Build¬
ings and Ancient Monuments Act 1953 towards the cost of urgently needed
repairs to over 1,500 historic buildings in England, Scotland and Wales.
Under the Civic Amenities Act 1967 local authorities have powers to protect
areas of special architectural or historic interest in towns. Special studies are
being made in Bath, Chester, Chichester and York to consider the particular
difficulties of preserving features of historic interest in ancient towns, in the
face of commercial development and of the increase in motor traffic. The
Ministry of Public Building and Works is responsible for the maintenance of
royal parks and palaces and (under the Ancient Monuments Acts) for the
protection of ancient monuments of which over 700 of the more important are
in its care.
In order to restrict the further sprawl of large built-up areas, to prevent
adjacent towns merging into one another, and in some cases to preserve the
special character of a town and the amenities of the countryside, the policy has
been adopted of establishing ‘green belts’ around all or part of certain urban
areas. Green belts are areas which it is intended should be left permanently
open and where, in consequence, there is a proscription against most new
development.
Local planning authorities have power to protect trees and woodlands by
means of tree preservation orders (some 7,000 of which are in force throughout
Great Britain) and to ensure that trees are protected or replaced on sites
undergoing development. Increasing use is being made of the planting of
semi-mature trees for landscaping purposes. The authorities have powers to
prevent mineral workings becoming permanent eyesores by attaching suitable
conditions to planning permissions, to regulate the display of advertisements
in the interests of amenity and safety and to make it an offence to leave litter,
I72
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
including bulky rubbish such as old cars, on open land. They may, for health
reasons, declare ‘smoke control areas’, in which the emission of smoke from
chimneys constitutes an offence. River authorities (see p. 268) are responsible
for the prevention of pollution of rivers.
Voluntary organisations have been particularly active in ensuring that
development takes full account of considerations of amenity. The National
Trust for England, Wales and Northern Ireland, which was founded in 1895
and now has some 165,000 members, is among the biggest land-owners in the
United Kingdom. It owns and protects from harmful development 400,000
acres of land and nearly 200 historic buildings for the benefit of the public—
often acquired through gifts (sometimes by arrangement with the Treasury in
lieu of death duties, see p. 361). With government support it is at present
engaged on a £2 million campaign, Enterprise Neptune, to preserve 900 miles
of coastline. The National Trust for Scotland is an independent body founded
in 1935. It has about 31,000 members and has under its care some 70
properties, covering in all about 70,000 acres.
The Civic Trust, financed through covenants from leading industrial
firms, was founded in 1957 to encourage high quality in architecture and
planning and to stimulate public interest in the protection of beauty in town
and country. It has, for example, produced plans for the redevelopment of
town centres and for a recreational area in the Lee Valley. The Trust makes
use of local initiative; it has separate sections in the north-east and north-west of
England and in Wales and Scotland and advises some 600 local civic societies.
Other amenity societies dependent upon the support of their members
include: the Council for the Preservation of Rural England, the Association
for the Preservation of Rural Scotland and the Council for the Preservation of
Rural Wales; the Commons, Open Spaces and Footpaths Preservation
Society; the Ramblers’ Association; the Society for the Protection of Ancient
Buildings; the Georgian Society; the Pilgrim Trust; and the Historic
Churches Preservation Trust.
National Parks The National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949 provided that
selected areas of beautiful and relatively wild country in England and W ales
should become national parks, where the characteristic landscape would be
safeguarded and facilities for open-air recreation provided or improved.
A National Parks Commission, an advisory body, was set up by the Act and
given responsibility for selecting national parks and ‘areas of outstanding
natural beauty’ and making proposals for the creation of long-distance foot¬
paths and bridleways. Ten national parks have been established: Northumber¬
land, the Lake District, the Yorkshire Dales, the North York Moors and the
Peak District in the north of England; Snowdonia, the Pembrokeshire Coast
and the Brecon Beacons in Wales; Exmoor and Dartmoor in the south-west of
England. They cover a total area of some 5,260 square miles, or 9 per cent of
the total area of England and Wales. They have various forms of administra¬
tion, based on representation of the local planning authorities of the areas in
which they are situated, as well as members nominated by the Minister of
Housing and Local Government or by the Secretary of State for Wales. By
1968, 25 areas of outstanding natural beauty had been designated covering
some 4,300 square miles.
The land in these parks and designated areas generally remains in private
ownership, but agreements or orders to secure additional public access may be
made by the local authorities. Steps are taken to preserve and enhance the
natural beauty of the landscape by high standards of development control, and
PLANNING AND HOUSING
Countryside
Commissions
Forest Parks
Nature
Reserves
by positive measures for which government grants are available such as tree
planting and preservation, and the removal of eyesores. In national parks,
public enjoyment is promoted, for example, by the provision of car parks and
camping and caravan areas and the setting up of information centres. All
national parks and some other designated areas have warden services. Nearly
1,300 miles of long-distance footpaths and bridleways had been approved by
1968. Large stretches of these paths are already public rights of way; the first
long-distance footpath to be completed (the Pennine Way, which stretches for
some 250 miles) was opened in 1965. The establishment of further routes is
proposed.
Under the Amenity Lands Act (Northern Ireland) 1965 national parks may
be designated in Northern Ireland and an advisory Countryside Committee
set up. Five areas of outstanding natural beauty have been designated.
Although there are no national parks as such in Scotland, five large areas
are subject to a special planning control under ministerial supervision. The
areas are Loch Lomond—Trossachs; Glen Affric—Glen Cannich—Strath
Farrar; Ben Nevis—Glen Coe—Black Mount; the Cairngorms; and Loch
Torridon—Loch Maree—Little Loch Broom.
Under the Countryside Acts 1967 (for Scotland) and 1968 (for England and
Wales) Countryside Commissions are being set up to replace and extend the
work of the National Parks Commission because of the need for additional
facilities for leisure-time activities for a rising and increasingly mobile
population. The Commissions (and a Committee for Wales with delegated
functions) will encourage the provision and development of opportunities for
open-air recreation in the countryside to relieve pressure on the national parks.
Measures envisaged include the creation of country parks by local authorities
within easy reach of towns; the establishment of camping sites and picnic
areas; and the increased use of reservoirs and canals for bathing, sailing and
other activities. The Commissions will also ensure that the natural beauty of
the countryside is conserved—for example, by regulating traffic movement—
and will undertake research projects and experimental schemes: they will
work in consultation with such bodies as the Nature Conservancy and the
Sports Councils (see p. 445). Grants will be available from the Government
for certain approved schemes and the Commissions will have powers to make
grants or loans to people working for the same purposes.
The Forestry Commission (see p. 319) has formed, and opened to the public,
seven Forest Parks in some of the finest country in Britain: Argyll, Glen Trool,
Glen More, and the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park in Scotland; the Forest
of Dean and the Wye valley woods on the borders of England and Wales;
Snowdonia in Wales; and the Border Forest Park on the borders of England
and Scotland. The total area of the seven parks approaches half a million acres.
Camping and other recreational facilities are provided in all the parks.
The historic New Forest, in Hampshire, although not a Forest Park, is also
open to the public.
Northern Ireland has two forest parks, Tollymore Park and Gortin Glen
Forest.
Responsibility for nature conservation in Great Britain is exercised by the
Nature Conservancy on behalf of the Natural Environment Research Council
(see p. 200), of which the Conservancy is a component body. The Conservancy
derives its powers from its royal charter and the National Parks and Access to
the Countryside Act 1949, as amended by the Science and Technology Act
