tenable both at home and abroad. The programme includes fundamental
studies of the structure and natural processes of the body; clinical and
laboratory studies of disease; the development and evaluation of special
methods of treatment and also of prophylaxis and diagnosis; and the study of
social and occupational factors affecting health and the efficiency of body and
mind.
The National Institute for Medical Research, at Mill Hill and Hampstead,
London, is the Council’s main research establishment; in addition, there are
over 70 smaller establishments, known as research units, which are attached
in most cases to universities and hospitals in the United Kingdom. By 1970
it is hoped that the first phase of the Clinical Research Centre being built at
Northwick Park in north-west London as an integral part of the new district
hospital for the North West Metropolitan Regional Hospital Board will be
ready. The Centre will be the clinical counterpart of the National Institute
for Medical Research.
The Council also undertakes work overseas and, with additional support
from the Ministry of Overseas Development, maintains laboratories in The
Gambia and units in Uganda and Jamaica.
Agricultural research is carried out by the Agricultural Research Council, the
Government agricultural departments and by private industry.
The Agricultural Research Council (ARC), established in 1931, consists of not
less than 15 and not more than 18 members, including the Chief Veterinary
Officer and certain appointments made by the Ministers of the agricultural
departments. In addition to distinguished scientists, the membership includes
people with practical farming experience. The Council is under the general
oversight of the Secretary of State for Education and Science.
The Council is responsible for 14 independent state-aided agricultural
research institutes and also has 10 institutes under its direct control and
14 units which it has established under distinguished scientists associated with
universities. In addition there are eight independent institutes in Scotland
financed by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland with
advice from the Council on their scientific programmes, staffing and
equipment.
The Council makes special research grants to support promising new lines
of work in university departments. It awards research fellowships to enable
research workers of exceptional promise to undertake independent research
and also a limited number of postgraduate training awards for those wishing
to undertake a career in veterinary research.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food carries out applied and basic
research in its own veterinary laboratories at Weybridge, Surrey, and at
Lasswade, Midlothian, and also at its plant pathology laboratory at Harpenden,
Hertfordshire; while at its infestation control laboratory at Tolworth, Surrey
(with a field station at Worplesdon), it co-ordinates work on the control of
insect pests of stored food and conducts research on the control of harmful
mammals and birds. The Central Veterinary Laboratory at Weybridge has
been appointed by the World Health Organisation (WHO) as the third
international laboratory for biological standards. In Northern Ireland the
Ministry of Agriculture is responsible for the promotion of agricultural
research and research divisions dealing with a variety of aspects have been
established.

197
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food maintains four laboratories
for marine, shell-fish and salmon and freshwater fisheries research, and four
marine research vessels. The Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for
Scotland maintains a marine research laboratory and six research ships at
Aberdeen, and a freshwater fisheries research laboratory at Pitlochry.
With the guidance of the Chief Scientific Adviser (Food), the Food
Standards, Science and Safety Division of the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food is responsible for formulating the Ministry’s general policy
on the acquisition and dissemination of scientific and technical information
about food and the food handling and processing industry; for furnishing
scientific advice to the other divisions of the Ministry; and for sponsoring or
carrying out experimental work. The division has its own experimental
laboratories in London and Norwich. The Food Research Advisory Com¬
mittee advises on food problems requiring investigation or research.
The Forestry Commission undertakes experimental work relating to
silvicultural and allied problems (see p. 320). By means of grants, it also aids
forest research work undertaken by various universities and other institutions,
including the Commonwealth Forestry Institute, Oxford.
The Atomic Energy Authority (AEA), set up under the Atomic Energy
Authority Act 1954, is responsible for research and development in nuclear
energy1. It is answerable to the Minister of Technology, who is responsible
under the Atomic Energy Acts 1946 to 1949 for promoting and controlling
the development of nuclear energy and ensuring that the proper degrees of
importance are attached to its various applications. The Authority has a large
programme of research into, and development of, the peaceful applications of
nuclear energy. As an essential part of the British Government’s nuclear
power programme, the Authority develops new types of nuclear power
stations for the generation of electric power on a commercial scale and for this
purpose it builds and operates experimental and prototype nuclear reactors.
Construction of the nuclear power stations themselves is carried out by
industry to the order of the electricity authorities, which supervise their
operation. Under the Science and Technology Act 1965 the functions of the
Authority have been extended so that the Minister may, after consultation,
require it to undertake research and development outside nuclear energy.
Non-nuclear wrork so far undertaken includes research into desalination,
hydrostatic extrusion, satellite design, biological centrifuges, tribology, non¬
destructive testing, ceramics, atmospheric pollution and carbon fibres.
The Secretary of State for Defence became responsible for the development
and production of nuclear weapons for the Services in 1966; in practice,
however, the AEA produces the explosive nuclear material and assemblies for
nuclear weapons under contract and carries out weapons research.
The Department of Education and Science and the AEA collaborate with
a number of other government departments and with the Radiological
Protection Service on various aspects of health and safety in relation to atomic
energy. Expert advice on radiation hazards is provided by the Medical and
Agricultural Research Councils and by the Radioactive Substances Advisory
Committee, appointed by the Secretary of State for Education and Science.
The Ministry of Technology and the Authority are jointly responsible for
co-operation with other countries in nuclear energy, partly through the
medium of bilateral agreements with a large number of individual countries
1 A reorganisation of the nuclear industry is being carried out by the Government
with the assistance of the Industrial Reorganisation Corporation.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Atomic
Energy
Authority
and partly through British membership of bodies, such as, the International
Atomic Energy Agency and the European Nuclear Energy Agency.
The Atomic Energy Authority, the members of which are appointed by the
Minister of Technology, consists of a chairman, a deputy chairman and up to
14 other members, some of whom may be part-time.
The Authority, like other statutory public corporations, is free from day-
to-day government control (subject to the power given to the responsible
minister to issue directions to the Authority in matters of overriding national
importance), but differs from them in that most of its revenue is derived
from money voted by Parliament. Some of the commercial activities of the
AEA are financed through a trading fund with an initial capital of about ^37
million.
The AEA has submitted tenders for the construction of a nuclear power
station overseas as a prime contractor, and is a member of the British Nuclear
Export Executive, established in June 1966.
The organisation has a London office, responsible for central financial and
administrative matters and for procuring raw materials. Its Radiochemical
Centre at Amersham produces and markets radioisotopes, about one-half for
export. The rest of its establishments are divided into five groups.
The Research Group’s principal establishment is the Atomic Energy
Research Establishment (AERE) at Elarwell. Others are the Wantage Research
Laboratory, which does research into new and improved uses of radioisotopes,
and an establishment for research into plasma physics and controlled thermo¬
nuclear fusion at Culham. Harwell also runs an isotope school, as part of a
postgraduate education centre, for training home and overseas students.
The Weapons Group, centred on Aldermaston, conducts research on and
development of nuclear weapons and other research work with civil, as well as
defence, applications. It has outstations at Foulness and Orfordness.
There are three groups with headquarters at Risley, in north-western
England. The Reactor Group works on the design, development and applica¬
tion of nuclear power reactors. It has developed the Advanced Gas-Cooled
Reactor (AGR), a prototype which has been operating successfully at
Windscale since February 1963. This system has been chosen for the first
stations of Britain’s second nuclear power programme (see p. 261). The
Reactor Group has also developed the Steam Generating Heavy Water
Reactor (SGHWR) system at Winfrith, Dorset.
The Reactor Group also includes the Dounreay experimental reactor
establishment in the north of Scotland, which houses a materials-testing
reactor and an experimental fast-breeder reactor (DFR). Successful operation
of the DFR has led to the design of a fast-breeder reactor power station (PER)
of 250 MW (E) under construction at Dounreay. The Group has research
laboratories at the main establishments of the Production Group, which
provides complete fuel services for the United Kingdom nuclear power
programme. It also sells these services to reactor operators overseas and
almost all its activities are now conducted on a commercial basis. The Group
consists of the fuel element factory at Springfields (Lancashire), the diffusion
plant for the enrichment of uranium at Capenhurst (Cheshire), the plutonium
factory at Windscale (Cumberland), and the nuclear power stations at Calder
Hall (Cumberland) and Chapelcross (Dumfriesshire). The third group is the
Engineering Group, responsible for the construction of plant, works and
buildings, and for the design and inspection of fuel elements for production
purposes.

High Energy

SPACE
ACTIVITIES
l99
The Atomic Energy Establishment at Winfrith, where work on a wide range
of other reactors is done, is also the location of the Dragon project, a 20 MW
(thermal) reactor financed jointly by the member countries of the European
Nuclear Energy Agency of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and
Development (OECD).
The provision of expensive facilities for research in high energy physics is the
function of the Science Research Council (see p. 193). The SRC establish¬
ments concerned are the Rutherford High Energy Laboratory, Chilton, with
a 7,000 million electron volt (MeV) proton synchrotron (particle accelerator),
completed in 1963 and the Daresbury Nuclear Physics Laboratory, Cheshire,
with a 4,000 MeV electron accelerator, completed in 1966.
Government responsibility for space activities is divided between the Secretary
of State for Education and Science, the Secretary of State for Defence, the
Minister of Technology and the Postmaster General. Total expenditure on
civil space activities in 1967-68 is estimated at about ^30-5 million; of this,
j£i6-i million represents expenditure on Britain’s national programme and
^14-4 million contributions to international bodies such as the European
Space Research Organisation (ESRO), the European Space Vehicle Launcher
Development Organisation (ELDO) and Intelsat.
The first two of these were set up to give European countries the opportunity
to participate more fully in space research and technology. ELDO was
established to develop large satellite launchers; the British Blue Streak is
being used as the launching vehicle for ELDO’s Europa rockets. ESRO was
founded to provide facilities for scientific experiments in space; it has a
programme of launchings of sounding rockets and satellites of various sizes.
Under two inter-related international agreements reached in 1964, in
Washington, Britain, together with the US and other countries in Europe and
elsewhere, is taking part in International Telecommunications Satellite
Consortium (Intelsat). The Government announced in April 1968 that it
would cease to contribute to ELDO after 1971 but would increase its
contribution to ESRO.
The execution of the civil scientific space research programme is the
responsibility of the Secretary of State for Education and Science, through
the Science Research Council.
Scientific space experiments are arranged by scientists in the universities
and in government research establishments, under the general supervision of
the Space Research Management Unit of the Science Research Council. The
Royal Society represents Britain in non-governmental international scientific
groups such as the Committee on Space Research (COSPAR) of the Inter¬
national Council of Scientific Unions (ICSU).
In addition, Britain is co-operating with the United States in a programme
which includes the launching of the Ariel series of satellites and the incorpora¬
tion of British experiments in US satellites. The third such artificial earth
satellite, Ariel 3, launched in May 1967, and the upper atmosphere Skylark
rockets were designed and produced in Britain.
The Ministry of Technology is responsible for conducting research into,
and for developing and producing, launchers, space vehicles and their
ancillary equipment. As an example, it is responsible at the Royal Aircraft
Establishment, for the development of the Skylark rockets used by the
Science Research Council, and is also carrying out a programme for the
development of an all-British satellite launcher vehicle, Black Arrow, on

OPTICAL AND

THE NATURAL

RESEARCH

which some £3 million a year is being spent and which is being developed
from the successful Black Knight research rocket.
The General Post Office is responsible for the use of satellites for civil
communications purposes and undertakes research work in connection with
communications systems using satellites.
The satellite prediction centre at the Radio and Space Research Station,
Slough, also the home of one of the three World Data Centres for space
research, co-ordinates optical tracking activities in Britain. Optical observation
of satellites is carried out regularly by many individual observers in Britain
and by the Royal Edinburgh Observatory’s outstation (see below); radio
tracking is undertaken at the Radio and Space Research Station and by radio
telescopes at Jodrell Bank and the Royal Radar Establishment at Malvern.
Large optical telescopes were first constructed in Britain by Herschel and
Rosse in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. The latest addition to the
equipment at Herstmonceux is the 98-inch Isaac Newton telescope, the largest
in Western Europe, completed in 1967. Grants by the SRC to the Radcliffe
Trustees have enabled British optical astronomers to have continued access to
the 74-inch telescope at the Radcliffe Observatory in South Africa for
observations in the southern skies. In April 1967 the SRC assumed responsi¬
bility for supporting and managing this telescope. The Royal Edinburgh
Observatory has been re-equipped with modern instrumentation for use in
stellar spectroscopy and photometry. The British and Australian Governments
have agreed jointly to build a ^4-4 million 150-inch optical telescope in New
South Wales.
Radio astronomy, developed since 1931, is carried out mainly at Cambridge
University, at the Jodrell Bank Experimental Station of Manchester University
at Cheshire, and at the Royal Radar Establishment at Malvern. Britain
occupies a pre-eminent position in this branch of research.
The Natural Environment Research Council (NERC) was established by
Royal Charter in June 1965 under the Science and Technology Act 1965 to
encourage, plan and conduct research in those sciences, both physical and
biological, that relate to man’s natural environment. The work of the Council
falls into five main groups: the solid earth, its physical properties and mineral
resources (geology, geophysics and geochemistry); the inland waters and their
living resources (hydrology, freshwater biology, ecology and fisheries); the
terrestrial communities, their resources and amenities (terrestrial ecology,
forestry and conservation); the seas and oceans, their behaviour and their
living and mineral resources (oceanography, marine biology and ecology, and
fisheries); and the atmosphere (some aspects of meteorology). The Council
controls the British Antarctic Survey, the Institute of Geological Sciences, the
Institute of Hydrology, the National Institute of Oceanography; the Nature
Conservancy, and the Research Vessel Unit. It is also responsible for support¬
ing the Marine Biological Association, the Scottish Marine Biological
Association, the Freshwater Biological Association, the Fisheries Helminth¬
ology Unit, and the Marine Invertebrate Biology Unit.
Much of the Council’s activities is related to university research in the
environmental sciences, which it supports by postgraduate training awards,
research grants and fellowships.
Further responsibilities of the NERC include the support of long-term
forestry research in consultation with the Forestry Commission; financial and
policy control of research in seismology and geomagnetism carried out by the

The Social Science Research Council began functioning in December 1965.
It has the same status as the other research councils and consists of a chairman
and not more than 16 nor less than 10 other members. It provides grants for
research projects at universities and other institutions, and makes training
awards to postgraduate students. The Council’s field of interest includes
economics; political science; psychology; social anthropology; social and
economic statistics; sociology and social administration; education; manage¬
ment; and various aspects of a wide range of other disciplines.
Several government departments have funds allocated for social research
related to their responsibilities, including the Home Office, which has a large
research unit which carries out a wide variety of sociological studies. The
Social Survey conducts sample survey enquiries at the request of government
departments and from time to time also carries out studies in collaboration
with universities and other independent research organisations.
Zoological research is among the activities of the world-famous Zoological
Gardens, extending over 34 acres in Regent’s Park, London, which were
opened by the Zoological Society of London in 1828. A natural zoo of 500
acres was opened in 1931 at Whipsnade, in Bedfordshire, by the Society.
Among other well-known zoos are those at Edinburgh, Bristol, Chester and
Dudley, and a small, private one at Chessington, Surrey.
The British Museum (Natural History) is the principal centre in the
Commonwealth for the general study of natural history; it has extensive
collections of extant and fossil animals and plants and of minerals, rocks and
meteorites. The Science Museum illustrates the development of pure and
applied science in all countries, but chiefly in Britain, which has always held
a leading place in engineering, agriculture, navigation, mining, aeronautics,
and in the development of industrial machinery and processes. The geology of
Britain is probably known in more exact detail than that of any other country
in the world, and the Geological Survey has an outstanding collection of
exhibits in its Geological Museum. These three museums are in South
Kensington, London.
Other important collections are those of the Museum of Science and
Industry, in Birmingham, and the Museum of the History of Science, at Oxford.
The dissemination of the results of research to other research workers and
to ultimate users has become a problem of some magnitude as the volume of
information has grown. The traditional method of scientific publication, in
which results are written up into papers and published in journals, is still the
main means of communication among scientists. The leading learned societies
have for long been important agencies for communicating scientific information.
The Office for Scientific and Technical Information (OSTI) was set up in
1965 within the Department of Education and Science to promote more
efficient handling of scientific and technical information. It also seeks to
co-ordinate such action as is taken with the work of other government and
202
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
National
Research
Development
Corporation
independent organisations. It has responsibility for the National Lending
Library for Science and Technology (NLL) at Boston Spa, Yorkshire, and for
grant-aid to Aslib (a specialised library service).
The NLL aims to collect for loan purposes all literature which is likely to be
of interest to the practising scientist and technologist, covering all branches of
science and technology (including agriculture and medicine) and, since 1967,
the periodical literature of the social sciences. Besides collecting all available
translations of Russian scientific literature the library is responsible for
arranging the translation of some Russian periodicals, books and articles.
Details are published monthly in the NLL Translations Bulletin. The Library
acts as a centre for MEDLARS, the Computer Board Medical Information
Service, produced by the US National Library of Medicine. (A description of
general library services which also cater for scientific needs is given on p. 218.)
Aslib undertakes research into the operation of information services, gives
assistance in setting up and running them, provides membership services, and
holds a Commonwealth Index of Translation covering scientific subjects.
The National Reference Library for Science and Invention is administered
by the British Museum. The former Patent Office Library is included in the
new library.
An Advisory Committee for Scientific and Technical Information was set
up in October 1965 to advise the Secretary of State for Education and Science
particularly in relation to the work of OSTI and the co-ordination of this
work with other government departments and independent organisations.
The Ministry of Technology and the AEA devote considerable sums to
advisory information services. The former has nine regional offices and
sponsors over 60 industrial liaison centres, based on universities or technical
colleges, which make contacts with local industries to promote greater use
of existing scientific and technical knowledge. A Production Engineering
Advisory Service equipped with mobile demonstration units brings knowledge
of new techniques directly to the workshop floor. The grant-aided industrial
research associations circulate research reports and provide information
services to members. Besides information services provided by its various
groups, which include the Ceramics Centre and the Non-destructive Testing
Centre at Harwell, the AEA has an information centre at its London head¬
quarters, and a network of regional advisers on the use of radioisotopes.
In agriculture, the Commonwealth Agricultural Institutes and Bureaux
(see p. 203) provide abstracts and an information service in various branches
of agricultural science. The ARC publishes an Index of Agricultural Research
in Progress, and gives an account of current developments in its annual reports.
The advisory services of the agricultural departments bring research results
directly to the farmer.
Medical research results are communicated mainly through journals and
periodicals; but the MRC issues special reports and includes special articles
in its annual reports.
The National Research Development Corporation (NRDC), an independent
body for which the Minister of Technology has statutory responsibility, was
set up under the Development of Inventions Act 1948 to secure the develop¬
ment and exploitation of inventions in the public interest. The Corporation
can also assist research work where this is likely to lead to an invention.
Under the Development of Inventions Act 1967, up to ^25 million can be
advanced to the Corporation from public funds without time limit. This was
increased to ^50 million under the Industrial Expansion Act 1968.

Projects so far sponsored include hovercraft, computers, advanced types of
electric motor, towed flexible barges (Dracones), diesel engines, insecticides,
fuel cells and antibiotics. NRDC support for hovercraft development has been
given mainly through a wholly owned subsidiary, Hovercraft Development
Ltd., which holds and manages the hovercraft patent. Another subsidiary,
Tracked Hovercraft Ltd., was formed in 1967 to develop an air-cushioned
tracked vehicle. NRDC is a minority shareholder in the British Hovercraft
Corporation Ltd., a company formed in 1966 to design and build hovercraft.
Most government departments concerned with science and technology make
special arrangements for dealing with international scientific relations but the
DES, through its International Scientific Relations Division, has a number
of inter-departmental responsibilities including the recruitment and scientific
support of Britain’s scientific counsellors overseas, who are seconded to the
Diplomatic Service. In areas of non-governmental collaboration, the primary
representative of the United Kingdom is the Royal Society.
The Government is concerned with inter-governmental organisations.
These include: specialised agencies of the United Nations, for example, the
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO),
the World Health Organisation (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organisa¬
tion (FAO); nuclear energy, for example, the International Atomic Energy
Agency, the European Nuclear Energy Agency and the European Organisation
for Nuclear Research; space research, for example, ESRO; and the Inter¬
national Agency for Research on Cancer. There are agreements between the
United Kingdom AEA and other atomic energy authorities, including that of
the Soviet Union (and there are permanent representatives of the United
States Atomic Energy Commission in London and of the United Kingdom
AEA in Washington). Also, there are inter-governmental agreements with
Euratom, and bilateral agreements with other countries. Britain is also
represented on the three scientific committees of the OECD.
The Commonwealth Scientific Committee (CSC) consisting of the heads of
the national research organisations of Commonwealth countries, formed in
1958 from the previous Standing Committee set up in 1946, meets biennially.
Operating under the CSC is an executive sub-committee, membership of
which consists of officials responsible for scientific matters in the Common¬
wealth Missions in London, and representatives from British Government
departments, the research councils and the Royal Society. There are various
specialist committees. The secretariat for the Committee and its executive
sub-committee is provided by the Commonwealth Scientific Liaison Offices.
A British Commonwealth Scientific Conference held in 1946 recommended
the continuance and extension of the scientific collaboration of the war years
by the creation of the Commonwealth Scientific Liaison Offices, a group at
present consisting of the Scientific Liaison Offices in London of Australia,
Canada and New Zealand together with the International Scientific Relations
Division of the Department of Education and Science.
The Commonwealth Agricultural Bureaux, financed by contributions from
all Commonwealth countries, comprise three Institutes and 11 Bureaux, all
of which except one Institute are in Britain and each of which is concerned
with a particular branch of agricultural science. They act as clearing houses
for the interchange of information of value to research workers in agricultural
204
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Ministry of
Overseas
Development
The British
Council
science throughout the Commonwealth and increasingly throughout the
world. Seventeen Abstract Journals, one Primary Journal and an Index are
published periodically and have a combined annual circulation of about 29,000
copies. The Institutes and Bureaux also issue monographs on their own
particular subjects and deal with enquiries received from research workers in
all parts of the Commonwrealth.
The Ministry of Overseas Development’s (ODM) promotion of scientific
research in the interests of developing countries covers specialist advice from
Britain, advisory visits, conferences for exchange of information, training
scientists from overseas in universities and research institutions in Britain,
recruiting scientific staff from Britain, and providing support for existing
research services overseas, for example, in East Africa and the Caribbean.
Some equipment is also given to encourage scientific training and applied
research. It administers and supports the work of, for example, the Anti-
Locust Research Centre in London, internationally recognised as a world
centre for locust research since 1931. The Ministry is also responsible for the
Tropical Products Institute in London which aims at improving the economic
viability of the less-developed tropical countries, especially those within
the Commonwealth, by research into new uses for tropical plant and animal
products. The ODM provides about £3 million a year to research for the
benefit of developing countries.
The principal aims of the British Council (see p. 161) in the sciences (including
agriculture, medicine and technology) are to foster co-operation between
British scientists and scientists of other countries, to promote among overseas
specialists a better understanding and knowledge of Britain and its scientific
achievements, and, in the developing countries, to assist in curriculum reform
at school level and in the training of teachers of science and mathematics.
Much emphasis is placed on the interchange of scientists between Britain
and other countries. Overseas tours and advisory visits by British specialists
are arranged and scientists recruited for overseas posts. In the other direction
the Council invites senior specialists to Britain for visits and discussions with
British experts, and makes awards to postgraduate students; it also administers
the programmes of a large number of senior specialists and students who
travel to Britain under the auspices of the UN specialised agencies, or under
various bilateral technical assistance schemes, or as private individuals. The
Council is also responsible for administering travel grants awarded under the
Foreign and Commonwealth University Interchange Schemes.
Information on Britain’s scientific achievements is provided either through
the Council’s overseas libraries or direct from the London headquarters
which includes specialist departments (and libraries) for medicine and science.
Material published or compiled by these London departments includes
British Medical Bulletin, British Medical Book List, British Medical Index,
part of Scientific Research in British Universities and Colleges (see Bibliography,
p. 474), and publications listing facilities for education and training in Britain.
THE PROMOTION OF THE ARTS
This section describes the assistance and encouragement given to the arts
by the Government, local authorities, voluntary societies and other
organisations. Although valuable support comes from private sources,
including trusts and commercial concerns, the Government and local
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS
205
authorities are taking an increasingly active part. In 1964, for the first time,
a minister was appointed to take special responsibility for the arts. The
Government considers that its role is not ‘to dictate taste or restrict the
liberty of even the most unorthodox and experimental of artists’ but to
support the arts so that a high level of artistic achievement can be sustained
and the best in the arts made more widely available (A Policy for the Arts,
see Bibliography, p. 474). Government support to the arts can be grouped
under three heads: education, preservation and patronage.
The main educational functions are carried out in England and Wales
through the Department of Education and Science, in Scotland through the
Scottish Education Department and in Northern Ireland by the Ministry of
Education. In partnership with local education authorities and voluntary
bodies, they are concerned with schools, colleges of further education and
community centres. The Department of Education and Science is also
concerned with public libraries in England and Wales and is responsible for
the Victoria and Albert Museum, and the Scottish Education Department is
responsible for the Royal Scottish Museum.
The Government aids the preservation of Britain’s cultural heritage by
means of grants which largely finance most of the national museums and
galleries; through the Ministry of Public Building and Works, which looks
after ancient monuments and the Ministry of Housing and Local Government
which is responsible for historic buildings; and by giving financial help to
independent bodies concerned with preservation, such as the National Trust
(see p. 172).
General help for the arts is given through government grants for music,
drama, literature, painting and sculpture; these are channelled for the greater
part through the Arts Councils of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, which
contribute to the aspects of the arts not provided for by other agencies. Other
state-aided organisations include the British Film Institute and the Council
of Industrial Design.
Estimated government expenditure on the arts in Great Britain in 1968-69
was over ^15-2 million. Direct allocations included ,£7-75 million for the Arts
Council of Great Britain (£550,000 more than in 1967-68) and over £6-8
million for the running costs of national museums and galleries. In addition
£3-15 million was allocated for the preservation of historic buildings and
ancient monuments.
The Arts Council of Great Britain was established in 1946 under a Royal
Charter. (A new charter was granted in 1967.) Its members are appointed by
the Secretary of State for Education and Science, in consultation with the
Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales. Its main objects are to develop
and improve the knowledge, understanding and practice of the arts, to increase
the accessibility of the arts to the public, and to advise and co-operate with
government departments, local authorities and other organisations.
The Arts Council of Northern Ireland, which has similar aims, receives
a grant from the Northern Ireland Government. In 1968-69 this amounted
to L'ISP00-
The British Council (see footnote, p. 161) takes an active part in displaying
overseas the best in British drama, ballet, music and the visual arts.
Local support Local authorities do valuable work in encouraging the arts. Under the Local
Government Act 1948 they may levy up to a sixpenny rate in England and
Wales for expenditure on entertainment in all its forms, including cultural
activities. By amending legislation (the Local Government (Scotland) Act

1966), the same rate applies to Scotland. They may also spend money on
buildings for the arts and provide and maintain museums and art galleries;
the Arts Councils are authorised to give financial help to house the arts. Many
towns support orchestras and theatres. The Greater London Council which,
as the London County Council, built the Royal Festival Hall, has agreed to
contribute equally with the Government towards the cost of the National
Theatre on the south bank of the Thames.
Many voluntary bodies are concerned with promoting the arts and include
charitable trusts and foundations which give financial support. Industrial patro¬
nage includes continuing support from the independent television companies.
The arts benefit most when the patrons—central and local government,
voluntary bodies, industry, the universities and individuals—combine. The
outstanding example is the Edinburgh Festival Society. Other arts festivals
organised on a similar basis are held in the City of London, Aldeburgh, Bath,
Belfast, Cheltenham, Harrogate, King’s Lynn, Leeds, Norwich and York.
Regional co-operation in arts patronage is growing with support from the
Government which encourages the formation of regional arts associations to
ensure that the whole range of the arts is more widely available to people
throughout the area. Such associations have been established in the north-east,
the north-west, Lincolnshire, the Midlands, the south-w’est, Greater London
and north Wales. Plans are advanced for a regional association covering
central-southern England.
Government support for drama is given through the Arts Councils of Great
Britain and of Northern Ireland which grant subsidies to certain theatrical
managements operating on a non-profit-distributing basis (that is, using
profits to finance future productions), provided that such managements have
given evidence of serious aims and of consistently high standards of practical
competence. The Arts Council of Great Britain operates a scheme to promote
new drama: guarantees may be offered to managements giving the first pro¬
fessional production of selected new plays; and promising authors may be
awarded bursaries. Schemes are also in operation to train stage designers,
producers and those wishing to take up theatre administration.
The British Council makes the British theatre better known abroad by
organising and sponsoring international tours by leading British theatre
companies and individual actors and producers, and by sending overseas
drama lecturers and exhibitions of theatrical design or of books dealing with
the British theatre, and by providing newly published plays through its
overseas libraries.
There are about 200 professional theatres in Britain. The centre of theatrical
activity is in London, where there are some 30 principal theatres in the
‘West End’ and several more in the suburbs, but important developments
are taking place in the regions. In London, with six exceptions (Covent
Garden, Sadler’s Wells Opera at the London Coliseum, the Old Vic, the
Royal Court, the Mermaid and the Aldwych) the theatres are let to some 25
producing managements on a commercial basis for each production.
Among London companies receiving Arts Council grants are the National
Theatre and the Royal Shakespeare Company, the English Stage Company,
which produces contemporary plays mainly at the Royal Court Theatre and
the Mermaid.
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS
207
Professional
Organisations
and Trade Unions
The National Theatre Company was formed in 1963; it will eventually
play in the new National Theatre, to be built on the south bank of the Thames
in London. The capital costs of the theatre will be met by the Exchequer and
the Greater London Council; grants towards the Company’s running costs
are being made by the Arts Council and the Greater London Council.
The Company, whose repertoire consists of classical and modern plays from
all countries, is large enough for simultaneous productions to be undertaken
in London (at the Old Vic Theatre) and in the provinces or overseas.
The Royal Shakespeare Company presents Shakespearean plays at the Royal
Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon, and international classical and
modern plays at the Aldwych Theatre, London. It will eventually have a perm¬
anent London home in the proposed City of London arts centre in the Barbican.
The provincial theatres are served by productions touring either before or
after London presentation, by companies specially formed for touring, and
by local repertory companies. An important development is the growth of
the civic theatre. The term is generally taken to include some companies which
have the use of their own theatres (as in Lincoln, Liverpool, Birmingham and
Dundee) or rent them from a local authority (as at Bristol, Chesterfield and
Edinburgh) and those like the Belgrade Theatre, Coventry, and the Notting¬
ham Playhouse which were built by the city councils. These companies are
assisted by the Arts Council. Many leading dramatists, producers, designers,
actors and actresses are associated with such companies and standards are high.
A number of new theatres have been opened both in London and the
provinces in recent years, including, in London, the Mermaid Theatre and
the completely reconstructed Queen’s Theatre. Coventry’s Belgrade Theatre,
opened in 1958, was the first full-scale theatre to be built by a civic authority
since 1939. Since then civic theatres have been built at Croydon, Eastbourne
and Torquay, and smaller theatres have been opened at Middlesbrough,
Richmond (Yorkshire) and Whitehaven (Cumberland). The Nottingham
Playhouse and the Phoenix Theatre, Leicester, opened in 1963, the Yvonne
Arnaud Theatre at Guildford in 1965 and the Adeline Genee Theatre at
East Grinstead in 1967. A Festival Theatre opened in 1962 at Chichester.
In Northern Ireland the Ulster Group Theatre in Belfast specialises in
Ulster comedy; and the Belfast Arts Theatre presents some international
drama and lighter theatrical entertainment. Also in Belfast the Lyric Players
Theatre, a non-profit-making organisation, presents Irish and international
drama in a small theatre recently built with Arts Council support. Professional
theatres are eligible for grants in respect of specific productions agreed with
the Arts Council of Northern Ireland.
All plays produced in Great Britain are subject to the provisions of the
Theatres Act 1968. This repealed the Theatres Act 1843 which gave the Lord
Chamberlain (the senior officer of the Royal Household) powers to censor stage
plays. There is now no censorship but the new Act makes it a criminal offence
to present or direct an obscene performance of a play in public or in private
(including in theatre clubs), an obscene performance being defined as one
which tends ‘to deprave and corrupt persons who were likely ... to attend it’.
Provision is made in the Act for a defence against a charge of obscenity on the
grounds that the performance was for the public good in the interests of, for
example, drama, opera or literature.
Most managers and artists are members of professional organisations such
as the Theatres’ Advisory Council, the London Theatre Council, the
Provincial Theatre Council, the Society of West End Managers, the Theatrical

Managers’ Association, the Council of Repertory Theatres, British Actors’
Equity (the actors’ trade union) and the League of Dramatists. The trade union
of theatre staffs is the National Association of Theatrical and Kine Employees.
There are thousands of amateur dramatic societies in Britain with an active
membership of some half a million. They are encouraged by local education
authorities, by other public bodies, and by four special organisations—the
British Drama League, the Standing Conference of Drama Associations,
the Scottish Community Drama Association and the Association of Ulster
Drama Festivals. Amateur companies which stage productions in their own
theatres belong to the Little Theatre Guild of Great Britain; for instance,
the Maddermarket Theatre in Norwich and the Questor’s Theatre, Ealing.
Most universities have active amateur drama clubs and societies; an
International Festival of University Theatre, inaugurated by Bristol in 1959,
is held annually.
Training for the theatre is provided mainly in drama schools. Among the
most important are the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (which is grant-
aided and provides a two-year course in all branches of stage work), the
Central School of Speech and Drama, the Rose Bruford Training College,
the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art, the Webber-Douglas
School, the Guildhall School of Music and Drama and the Arts Educational
Schools, all of which are in or near London; and the Old Vic School in
Bristol. In Scotland there is the College of Dramatic Art which is an integral
part of the Royal Scottish Academy of Music in Glasgow and is grant-aided
by the Scottish Education Department. An increasing number of universities
offer courses in drama.
The Society for Theatre Research brings together those interested in the
history and technique of the British theatre. The International Theatre
Institute has a British centre in London. The main purpose of the institute is
to foster international goodwill and understanding by interchange of students,
theatrical companies, personnel and theatrical information.
Many schools and youth clubs put on plays and provide some education in
drama. A drama centre for the London education service is provided at
Toynbee Hall in east London. At Coventry special productions are arranged
for school children and members of the Belgrade Theatre’s staff teach at local
schools. Sheffield’s Theatre Vanguard puts on plays for and by children and
Nottingham has a Youth Theatre Workshop.
A large number of organisations such as the Unicorn Theatre for Children
and Theatre Centre present children’s plays in London and the provinces. The
National Youth Theatre, whose members are all young people, presents
mainly Shakespearean productions in London, the provinces and abroad.
Music in all its forms draws large audiences; and music festivals, orchestral
concerts, choral singing, brass bands, chamber music, opera and ballet are
important features of British cultural life. The increase in musical appreciation
in recent years is shown by the size of audiences for concerts and for broadcast
music. Nearly 85 million gramophone records (of which half were estimated to
be of serious music) were produced during 1967.
The City of Westminster houses the Central Music Library which lends to
other libraries and individuals. Another well-known music collection is the
Henry Watson Music Library at the Manchester Central Library.

Music
Orchestras
Choral Societies
Music Festivals
The Arts Council of Great Britain makes grants to a number of orchestras,
opera and ballet companies, and music societies. The British Council gives
financial assistance to some of the overseas tours of British orchestras, soloists,
and opera and ballet companies; it sponsors recordings of works by British
composers and maintains 102 libraries of British music (scores and records)
in 67 countries overseas and, at its London headquarters, a reference library
of records, scores and books on music.
The National Music Council, representative of many aspects of British
musical activity, is affiliated to the International Music Council which is
associated with UNESCO.
Seasons of orchestral concerts are promoted every year in many of the large
towns and cities of Britain. In London the principal concert halls are the
Royal Festival Hall on the south bank of the Thames, adjacent to wrhich are
the Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Purcell Room which were opened in 1967
for smaller-scale performances; the Royal Albert Hall, Kensington, where
the annual summer season of Promenade Concerts is given; and the Wigmore
Hall, an important recital centre.
Among the leading British orchestras are the London Philharmonic, the
London Symphony, the Royal Philharmonic, the New Philharmonia, the
Royal Liverpool Philharmonic, the Halle (Manchester), the City of Birming¬
ham Symphony, the Bournemouth Symphony, the Scottish National and the
BBC Symphony, Northern and Scottish orchestras. There are also specialised
string and chamber orchestras such as the Northern Sinfonia, the Philomusica
of London, the English Chamber Orchestra and the London Mozart Players.
Many of these receive financial aid from the Arts Council of Great Britain and
local authorities; some of them also receive assistance from commercial
television and other business organisations. In Northern Ireland the Ulster
Orchestra is directly promoted by the Arts Council of Northern Ireland.
The principal choral societies in Britain are the Royal Choral, the BBC
Choral, the Huddersfield Choral, the Halle Choir, the Liverpool Philharmonic
Choir, the London Philharmonic Choir, the New Philharmonia Chorus, the
Bach Choir, the Royal Edinburgh Choral Union and the Belfast Philharmonic
Society. These and many other choral societies are associated with famous
orchestras in major choral works; most of them, together with hundreds of
similar choral and orchestral societies and music clubs, are affiliated to the
National Federation of Music Societies, through which they are supported
with funds provided by the Arts Council. Among societies which specialise
in encouraging the performance of the work of living musicians are the
Society for the Promotion of New Music, the Music Section of the Institute
of Contemporary Arts, and Macnaghten Concerts.
Music festivals in Britain, originating with the Three Choirs Festival held
annually in Gloucester, Worcester or Hereford in rotation, have been in
existence for over 200 years. The famous Edinburgh International Festival
lasts three weeks; other festivals such as at King’s Lynn, last a week or less.
Among the better known are the Royal National Eisteddfod of Wales; the
Llangollen International Eisteddfod; the National Gaelic Mod, held at a
different place in Scotland each year; the Cheltenham Festival, largely devoted
to contemporary British music; the Aldeburgh Festival; the Bath Festival;
the Coventry Festival; the Haslemere Festival; the biennial York Festival;
and the Leeds and Norwich Festivals, which include important choral

music, and which are held triennially. An annual international festival of folk
song and dancing is held by the English Folk Dance and Song Society.
Interest in amateur music-making is encouraged by the work of County
Music Committees (some of which are voluntary and some sub-committees
of local education authorities), which are aided by the Carnegie United
Kingdom Trust and united in the Standing Conference for Amateur Music.
The Rural Music Schools Association is concerned with music-making by
amateurs in country districts; it brings together professional musicians,
teachers, administrators and amateurs.
Professional organisations which look after the interests of music and
musicians include the Musicians’ Union, the Incorporated Society of
Musicians, the Composers’ Guild, and the Songwriters’ Guild.
Regular seasons of opera and ballet are given at the Royal Opera House,
Covent Garden, London, leased by the Government on behalf of the Royal
Opera House, Co vent Garden, Limited, which was formed in 1944 to make
the famous opera house the home of a national opera and ballet, and which
receives a grant from the Arts Council. The Royal Opera House has its own
opera company and two ballet companies (The Royal Ballet) which give perfor¬
mances in London and elsewhere. The opera company numbers about 200
and has a permanent orchestra. The Royal Ballet has a high international
reputation and has made many overseas tours.
Seasons of opera and operetta are also given by the Sadler’s Wells Company
in London; with two permanent opera companies, Sadler’s Wells plays in
London throughout the year, and for about 30 weeks in other centres.
At Glyndebourne, in Sussex, an opera season, for which an international
cast is specially assembled, is held every summer. Other opera companies
include the English Opera Group, noted for its performances of chamber
operas by Benjamin Britten and other composers; the New Opera Company,
formed by members of the Cambridge Opera Group to produce new operas
in London; the Handel Opera Society; the Intimate Opera Company, which
performs works for very small casts in any hall available; and the Welsh
National Opera Company. Scottish Opera presents annual seasons in several
Scottish towns. Opera in Northern Ireland is promoted by the Grand Opera
Society of Northern Ireland and the Studio Opera Group, both receiving a
subsidy from the Arts Council of Northern Ireland. The Arts Council of
Great Britain presents three small operatic groups (Opera for All) which
specialise in introducing opera to audiences in small towns. There are also a
number of amateur opera societies.
Among other ballet companies are London’s Festival Ballet, the Ballet
Rambert (Britain’s oldest ballet company) and the Western Theatre Ballet
which specialises in contemporary works. The work of the Patricia Mulholland
Irish Ballet Company in Northern Ireland, which is sponsored by the Arts
Council of Northern Ireland, combines traditional music, dancing and mime.
Professional training in music is given at colleges of music, of which the Royal
Academy of Music and the Royal College of Music in London, and the Royal
Scottish Academy of Music in Glasgow are grant-aided. There are also
the Trinity College of Music and the Guildhall School of Music and Drama,
both in London, the Royal Manchester College of Music and the Birmingham
School of Music.

The London Opera Centre for Advanced Training and Development
provides some rehearsal and other facilities for the Royal Opera House,
Covent Garden. Its courses last two or three years. The leading ballet schools
are the Royal Ballet, the Rambert Ballet School and the Royal Academy of
Dancing which, with many private schools, have played an important part in
raising British ballet to its present high standard. Other schools offering
general education combined with drama and/or ballet are run by the Arts
Educational Trust and the Italia Conti School.
Young people are encouraged to take an interest in music, opera and ballet.
There are frequent concerts for children and the National Youth Orchestra of
Great Britain, the National Youth Orchestra of Wales and the London
Schools’ Symphony Orchestra are noted for their high standard of perfor¬
mance. A Youth and Music organisation, affiliated to the international
Jeunesses Musicales, encourages opera, ballet and other performances for
young people.
In schools, more children are learning to play musical instruments; and
some 128,000 candidates a year (children and other students) take the exam¬
inations of the Associated Board of the Royal Schools of Music, the largest
proportion (over 60 per cent) choosing the piano as their instrument.
The Royal Ballet sponsors a small group, Ballet for All, to give lecture-
demonstrations to the public and to schools.
Although cinema attendance has been steadily declining in Great Britain since
its peak of 1,635 million in 1946 to 274 million in 1967, and the number of
licensed cinemas has declined from 4,709 to 1,774 over the same period,
British films, actors and creative and technical talent are appreciated both at
home and abroad and frequently achieve success at international film events.
Television offers very large potential audiences for films and provides
opportunities of employment for technicians and actors.
London is one of the most important centres for the making of films for
international markets and export earnings are an important part of total
earnings. The Film Production Association of Great Britain is the trade
association to which many feature film producers belong.
The documentary tradition in short film production in Britain goes back to
1929, when a group of directors began making factual films of a distinctive
and imaginative kind on behalf of the Government, and later for commercial
organisations. The war years saw a big expansion in this field and, since then,
British documentary technicians have continued to produce high quality
factual films which have won numerous international awards. The British
Industrial and Scientific Film Association promotes the use of films in
industry, science and commerce. The Federation of Specialised Film Associa¬
tions, the trade association of documentary, short, industrial, advertising and
cartoon film makers, has about 100 members.
Films from abroad made in languages other than English often draw large
audiences in London and other large cities.
Although over half of British main feature production is supported by United
States interests at present, the Rank Organisation and Associated British
Picture Corporation maintain a substantial interest in production, distribution
and exhibition. Most British film producers are independent but make films
in association with these major interests. There are numerous companies,
many of them small, which produce short films.
212
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Quota System
Cinema Licensing
and Film
Censorship
There is no state-owned film production unit in Britain, but the National
Film Finance Corporation lends money for feature film production. Its
members are appointed by the Board of Trade and its funds are limited by
statute to £8 million. In recent years the Corporation was financially concerned
with about half the main feature films made in British studios, but this
proportion has now fallen in view of the American support available.
There is also a levy on cinema admissions to provide a film production fund.
The money so raised is paid out as a percentage of a film’s takings, so that the
more successful a film is at the box-office, the more it receives from the fund.
Started by the industry in 1950 on a voluntary basis, the scheme became
statutory under the Cinematograph Films Act 1957.
The Government sponsors a wide range of films to inform audiences
overseas about British life and achievements, including documentary films,
television programmes and newsreels; they are produced through the Central
Office of Information (COI), which commissions their production by private
companies. These, together with films acquired from private industry and
public bodies, are distributed throughout the world, in English and many
foreign languages, by British Information Services. The British Council also
distributes overseas a wide range of specialised films mainly on the arts,
education, medicine, science and technology.
Films are also sponsored by the Government, some for specialised
audiences, on such subjects as science, agriculture, health and industry,
as well as films for the general public on, for example, road safety and health
education.
A large number of films are sponsored by industrial concerns and other
organisations, such as the British Travel Association and the British Produc¬
tivity Council. The best of these and industrial films from other countries are
available through the COFs Central Film Library and other agencies.
The Films of Scotland Committee promotes the production of Scottish
films covering the industries and cultural traditions of Scotland.
To help British films to meet the keen American competition, legislation
passed in 1927 introduced the quota system (continued by subsequent
legislation), under which a certain proportion of British films must be shown
in British cinemas each year. The proportion is fixed by the Board of Trade
annually after consultation with the Cinematograph Films Council, any
change being effected by statutory instrument approved by both Houses of
Parliament. For main feature films it has stood at 30 per cent since 1950.
The State takes no part in the censorship of films in Britain, but before it can
be shown a film must be licensed by the local licensing authority. There are
about 700 of these (usually the local authorities or, in some areas, magistrates).
In considering the suitability of films the authorities normally rely on the
judgment of an independent body, the British Board of Film Censors, to
which are submitted all films (other than newsreels) intended for public
showing.
The British Board of Film Censors was set up in 1912 on the initiative of
the cinema industry, to ensure that a proper standard was maintained in the
films offered to the public. The Board, which does not use any written code
of censorship, may require cuts to be made before granting a certificate to a
film; very rarely, it refuses a certificate. Films passed by the Board are placed
in one of three categories: ‘U’ (suitable for universal showing); ‘A’ (more
suitable for adults than children who are admitted only if accompanied by an
adult); and ‘X’ (suitable only for adults; children are not admitted).

of the Film

PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS 213
Film reviews appear regularly in the press and on sound and television
programmes and many organisations are interested in different aspects of the
film. There are numerous private film societies.
The development of the film as an art is promoted by the British Film
Institute, founded in 1933, which is financed partly by an Exchequer grant.
The Institute encourages the making and showing of good films. It also
administers the National Film Theatre in London and the National Film
Archive, runs an annual summer school, and maintains a film library from
which films may be hired, a library of books on the film and an information
service. It makes grants to the Federation of Film Societies, the British
Universities Film Council and the Society for Education in Film and Television.
The National Film Archive contains over 18,000 films, including newsreels
and other miscellaneous items, besides scripts, art designs, posters and about
500,000 photographic stills, selected to illustrate the history and the art of the
film and as significant social and historical records.
The National Film Theatre, on the south bank of the Thames, in London,
shows films of outstanding historical, artistic or technical interest; it holds
a unique position as a cinema offering regular programmes unrestricted by
commercial considerations or by the age or nationality of the films shown.
The British Film Institute promotes the development of regional film theatres
on the lines of the National Film Theatre and is empowered to make grants
towards their recurrent and capital costs.
The Society of Film and Television Arts, formed in 1958 by the amalgamation
of the British Film Academy and the Guild of Television Producers and
Directors, has as its aim to improve the standard of film and television
production and to stimulate public appreciation of the arts.
The National Film Theatre organises an annual London Film Festival, which
includes films receiving their first showing as well as films which have been
successful in international competitive festivals. A council on which leading
British film organisations are represented organises a film festival as part of
the Edinburgh International Festival.
The Cinematograph Act 1952 (which came into force in January 1956)
provided for the making of regulations by the Home Secretary to protect the
health and welfare of children attending film shows. Cinemas which give
children’s shows require a special licence from the licensing authority, which
may impose conditions. There are about 900 children’s cinema clubs which
provide special programmes on Saturday mornings. An important contribu¬
tion to these programmes is made by the Children’s Film Foundation, which
produces and distributes entertainment films specially designed for children
and publishes at intervals a list of films particularly suitable for children and
for exhibition at children’s matinees. The Foundation is a non-profit-making
body set up by the British film industry in 1951 and, under the Cinematograph
Films Act 1957, it receives grants from the British Film Fund Agency.
A number of modern British painters and sculptors have a high international
reputation, winning 72 international prizes since 1949 and commissions for
major works in foreign cities. The growth of interest in the visual arts at
home has been stimulated by an increasingly lively attitude towards display
on the part of museums and galleries, and by the varied activities of many
institutions, societies and private galleries.
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Painting and sculpture receive state support by grants to national institu¬
tions and, indirectly, through purchase grants made to local art galleries and
museums, to local education authorities for art schools and other means of
promoting education in art, and to the Arts Councils, which take an active
part by organising exhibitions and building up their own collections of
contemporary British art. The Government is advised on grants a.nd matters
of policy by the Standing Commission on Museums and Galleries and the
Royal Fine Art Commissions for England and Wales and for Scotland.
Knowledge of Britain’s fine arts is fostered overseas by the British Council’s
exhibitions and lectures. In 1967-68 fine art exhibitions organised by the
Council were shown in 40 countries and the Council v/as also responsible for
British participation in six international exhibitions.

National

Scotland, Wales
and Northern

Other Collections
Over 900 museums and art galleries are open to the public in Britain.
There are 18 national museums and art galleries. Those in London probably
contain between them the most comprehensive collection of objects of artistic,
archaeological, scientific, historical and general interest ever to exist within
one city. They include the British Museum, the Victoria and Albert Museum,
the National Gallery, the Tate Gallery, the National Portrait Gallery, the
Imperial War Museum, the National Maritime Museum, the London Museum
(to be amalgamated with the Guildhall Museum into the Museum of London),
the Wallace Collection, the British Museum (Natural History) and the Science
Museum (see p. 201).
There are six national museums and art galleries in Edinburgh: the National
Museum of Antiquities of Scotland, the National Gallery of Scotland, the
Royal Scottish Museum, the National Portrait Gallery of Scotland, the
Scottish United Services Museum, and the Scottish National Gallery of
Modern Art. The National Museum of Wales, in Cardiff, has a branch at
St. Fagan’s Castle where the Welsh Folk Museum is housed; and in Northern
Ireland there is the national Ulster Museum in Belfast.
Other important collections in London include the Armouries (Tower of
London), the Public Record Office (see p. 219) and the Sir John Soane’s
Museum. In Buckingham Palace there is a small gallery for exhibition of
pictures from the extensive royal collections. Most cities and large towns and
many other towns have a museum devoted to art, archaeology and natural
history, usually owned by the municipal authority but sometimes by a local
learned society or privately by individuals or trustees. Both Oxford and
Cambridge are rich in museums, many of them, as in other towns, associated
with the universities—for example, the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford,
founded in 1683, the oldest in the country, and the Fitzwilliam Museum in
Cambridge. There are important museums and art galleries in Birmingham,
Bristol, Glasgow, Leeds, Leicester, Liverpool, Manchester, Norwich, Read¬
ing Southampton and York. In Northern Ireland there are notable museums
and galleries in or near Belfast (the Ulster Folk Museum and the Northern
Ireland Arts Council Gallery), in Armagh City and in Londonderry.
In recent years there has been a notable development of ‘period-house
museums’, for which outstanding private houses have been taken over by
national and municipal authorities, and of folk museums. Many private art
collections housed in historic family mansions, including those in the owner¬
ship of the National Trust (see p. 172), are open to the public.

In the past decade several new or extensively altered museum buildings have
been opened, including those at Coventry, Derby, Doncaster, Durham (the
Gulbenkian Museum at the university), Leicester (Jewry Wall Archaeological
Museum), Liverpool, Manchester (Whitworth Art Gallery), Scunthorpe and
Sunderland. Developments are planned for museums in Belfast, Bristol,
Cardiff, Hull, London and Newcastle; a new museum has been opened in
Oxfordshire (jointly by the City and County Councils) and there are schemes
involving county council participation in County Durham, Staffordshire,
Pembrokeshire, Rutland and Worcestershire; other developments are being
initiated by local associations for the arts.
A function of the Standing Commission on Museums and Galleries is to
advise the Government on the relationship between national and provincial
institutions. Close relations are fostered by the eight area museum councils
which cover the whole of Great Britain. They are grant-aided by the
Government and help to improve technical facilities.
The Museums Association, to which museums and art galleries and their
staffs throughout the country belong and which also has many overseas
members, is an independent organisation. The Association serves as a central
body for the collection of information and the discussion of matters relating
to museum administration, and as a training and examining body for
professional qualifications.
Temporary exhibitions organised and sent on tour by the Arts Councils, the
Circulation Department of the Victoria and Albert Museum and the Art
Exhibitions Bureau are a regular feature of many museums. All exhibitions at
the Whitechapel Art Gallery in east London are loan exhibitions (mainly of
contemporary works). The National Gallery, the Tate Gallery and British
Museum also have loan exhibitions. The Greater London Council exhibits
modern sculpture in one of its parks every third year and in the summer of
1968 opened a new exhibition gallery, the Hayward Gallery, administered by
the Arts Council, on the south bank of the Thames. Commercial exhibitions of
works by old masters and living artists are held throughout the year in the
galleries of the art dealers of London (largely in the Bond Street area).
The various national art exhibiting societies include the Royal Academy;
the Royal Scottish Academy; the Society of Scottish Artists; the Royal
Society of British Artists; the Royal Society of Painters in Water Colours; the
Royal Society of Portrait Painters; the Artists’ International Association; the
Women’s International Art Club; and the London Group (all associations
of professional painters); and the Institute of Contemporary Arts. Some of
these societies, notably the Royal Academy at Burlington House, have their
own galleries in London. In Northern Ireland there are the Royal Ulster
Academy of Arts, the Ulster Society of Women Artists and the Ulster Arts
Club. Among regional societies are the Newlyn Society of Artists, the Midland
Group of Artists (Nottingham), the Birmingham Society of Artists and the
Penwith Society of Arts, while an increasing number of amateur art societies
throughout Britain hold local exhibitions and encourage local interest in the
fine arts. There are also exhibitions of children’s art, including the National
Exhibition of Children’s Art sponsored annually by the Sunday Mirror.
All national collections are financed from government funds, both those that
are the direct responsibility of the Department of Education and Science (the
Victoria and Albert and the Science Museums) and the Scottish Education
Department (the Royal Scottish Museum) and those run by trustee bodies.
Besides meeting the administrative costs, provision is made for annual

purchase grants which totalled £865,850 in 1968-69. The Government also
provides special ad hoc purchase grants and collections may receive works of
art acquired by the Treasury in lieu of estate duty. The buildings are main¬

by certain trusts and voluntary bodies, particularly the National Art-

The Council of Industrial Design (CoID), set up in 1944 by the Government
to promote higher standards of design in British industry, is concerned with
all aspects of industrial design from durable consumer goods to capital goods.
The CoID, with its Scottish Committee, is a grant-aided body sponsored by
the Board of Trade; its members include industrialists, retail management,
architects, designers and educationists. At the Design Centre in the Hay-
market, London, a selective but changing display of modern British consumer
goods is maintained; exhibits are chosen from Design Index, the CoII)’s
illustrated record of more than 11,000 well-designed products. Special
exhibitions on particular themes are also arranged regularly. An annual awards
scheme, Council of Industrial Design Awards, covering capital goods and
engineering equipment as well as consumer products, was introduced in 1967*
The Duke of Edinburgh also presents his annual Prize for Elegant Design.
The Scottish Committee runs the Scottish Design Centre in Glasgow, and
there are three independent regional design centres, each maintaining a
duplicate of the Index, at Liverpool, Manchester and Nottingham. The CoID
organises temporary exhibitions in regional centres and overseas; arranges
regular conferences and training courses; and undertakes industrial study
tours in Britain. It publishes a monthly magazine, Design, and maintains
extensive reference and photographic libraries.
Other bodies concerned with industrial design include the Royal Society of
Arts (see p. 191), the Society of Industrial Artists and Designers, which is the
representative professional body in Great Britain of designers engaged in
industry and commerce, and the Design and Industries Association (DIA), a
voluntary association of industrial companies, designers, and others interested
in the promotion of good design in industry. The Crafts Council of Great
Britain, the Crafts Centre of Great Britain and the Scottish Craft Centre are
all grant-aided by the Board of Trade. Their aims are to improve craft design
and to promote closer relations between craftsmen and industry.
Formal art education is given in publicly supported art colleges, university
art schools, the Royal Academy Schools and a few private art schools. There
are the colleges, art schools and classes administered by the local education
authorities; and at a senior level there is the Royal College of Art, London,
whose students have usually completed a course at a local education authority
college, and which awards its own degrees. Art is also taught at an advanced
level at the four Scottish Central (Art) Institutions administered by the
Scottish Education Department. University art schools include the Slade
School of Fine Art and Goldsmiths’ College (London), the Ruskin Drawing
School (Oxford), the Reading School of Art, the Department of Fine Art of
the University of Newcastle upon Tyne, and the School of Art of University
College, Aberystwyth.
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS
Architecture
217
The leading academic institutions for the teaching and study of the history
of art are the Courtauld Institute of the University of London, the Department
of Classical Art and Archaeology in University College, London, and the
Warburg Institute, also a part of London University.
In England and Wales three-year full-time courses leading to a Diploma in
Art and Design are available to students who have successfully completed a
foundation course. The Diploma is broadly comparable to a university pass
degree, and is administered by the National Council for Diplomas in Art and
Design (an independent self-governing body set up by the then Minister of
Education in 1961). The Council also administers a scheme of post-diploma
studies in a small number of colleges. In Scotland each of the four schools of
art awards a diploma which is roughly equivalent to the pass degree of a
university.
Art has a place in the curriculum of every type of school, and the Society
for Education through Art, among other activities, encourages the purchase
by schools of original works of art by organising an annual Pictures for Schools
exhibition. A loan scheme for reproductions of works of art which is used
extensively by schools is operated by the Arts Council.
Official responsibility towards the nation’s architecture is concerned with
encouraging the best in new building and preserving the best that has been
inherited from the past.
Several government departments are concerned with architecture and help
to promote good design. The Ministry of Housing and Local Government,
the Scottish Development Department, and the Northern Ireland Ministry of
Development are responsible for approving the layout and design of local
authority housing schemes, and set standards for local authority housing. The
Ministry of Housing and Local Government is responsible for the work of the
National Building Agency (see p. 269) which carries out research and develop¬
ment concerned with new techniques in building. The Ministry of Public
Building and Works is also responsible for the design, building and mainten¬
ance work of all government departments; it also has a research and develop¬
ment group which co-ordinates similar groups throughout the government
service. The Architects and Building Branches at the Department of Education
and Science and the Scottish Education Department carry out research for
school building programmes. The Ministry of Health is implementing a very
large building programme and the Regional Hospital Boards, through their
architectural departments, are responsible for the design and construction of
a large number of hospitals and ancillary buildings.
Government departments are assisted in an advisory capacity by the Royal
Fine Art Commissions for England and Wales and for Scotland, which also
advise planning authorities and other public bodies on questions of public
amenity or artistic importance, including new building developments.
A number of professional, advisory and other societies and institutions
exist to further the interests of architecture, and the Civic Trust (see p. 172)
seeks to promote high standards in architecture and civic planning and to
encourage a wider interest in the appearance of towns and the countryside.
The Minister of Public Building and Works has responsibilities for the
preservation of ancient monuments and certain historic buildings and the
Minister of Housing and Local Government is responsible for administering
the grants available for the repair and maintenance of buildings of outstanding
historic or architectural interest; in Northern Ireland these responsibilities are
vested in the Ministry of Finance.
