In Britain it is illegal for a person to practise under the title of architect
unless registered with the Architects’ Registration Council of the United
Kingdom. Most students train at a full-time school of architecture; there are
28 schools recognised for exemption from the Intermediate and Final
examinations of the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) and five
recognised for the intermediate examination only. In addition to these schools,
which may also have part-time courses, there are six schools of art and
technical colleges which have full-time courses leading to the external
examinations of the RIBA. .
The Royal Institute of British Architects, the leading professional
architectural institution in Britain, has a membership of 22,000 with some
6 000 students. Allied to it are 62 architectural societies covering the whole of
the United Kingdom and countries overseas. The RIBA has one of the
largest and most important architectural libraries in the world. It is concerned
with a wide range of activities covering professional practice science,
technology, statistics, architectural competitions, professional and public
relations; arranges lectures and discussions on a variety of subjects, presents
exhibitions; and, through its Board of Education, controls the training and
examination of architects. The Royal Gold Medal for Architecture
awarded annually by the Queen on the recommendation of the RIBA
Among other associations are the Incorporated Association of Architects and
Surveyors, the Institute of Registered Architects and the Faculty of Architects
and Surveyors. Societies include the Architectural Association, the Archi¬
tecture Club, and several which cover particular aspects of architecture, such
as the Modular Society.
The study of literature is included in the curricula of all schools, colleges
and universities. There are free public libraries throughout the country,
private libraries and a large number of private literary societies. Book reviews
are featured in the press and on radio and television and there are numerous
periodicals concerned in whole or in part with literature. R . .
P Government help is given through the Arts Council of Great Bnta
which supports literature in a number of ways, including bursaries and
prizes for writers, a fund to aid literary projects, and subsidies to festivals o
literature and poetry. Similar provision is made, through the Arts Cou
of Northern Ireland, for bursaries, poetry readings, and aid for publications.
Recognition of outstanding literary merit is given in the form of literary
prizes a number of which are awarded annually, for instance, the Queens
Gold Medal for Poetry, the James Tait Black Memorial prizes for biograp y
and literature, the John Llewellyn Rhys Memorial prize for y°ung intern of
promise, the Hawthornden prize for imaginative writing, Wmston
Spencer Churchill Literary Award for an outstanding work in the history
of5 the English-speaking peoples, the Library Association Carnegie Medal
for an outstanding book for children, the Kate Greenaway Medal for the best
children’s book illustration and the Somerset Maugham award for young
writers.
The British Museum Library in London (over 7 million volumes) is the largest
in Britain. The National Library of Scotland (over 2 million volumes) is in
Edinburgh, and that of Wales in Aberystwyth (nearly 2 million volumes).
Together with the Bodleian Library of Oxford University (over 3* million
volumes) and the Cambridge University Library (4 million volumes) these
comprise the ‘copyright’ libraries of the country and are entitled to receive

a copy of each new book published in Britain: the British Museum Library
must receive a copy, the other libraries may claim one.
In October 1967 the Secretary of State for Education and Science appointed
a committee to consider whether the national library facilities provided by
the British Museum Library, the National Central Library (see p. 220), the
National Lending Library for Science and Technology (see p. 202), the
Science Museum Library, and the National Reference Library of Science and
Invention (see p. 202) should be brought into a unified framework.
The Science Museum, Victoria and Albert and the British Museum
(Natural History) in South Kensington all have large libraries and many
government departments have old-established libraries of considerable size
and importance, for example, those of the Board of Trade, Ministry of
Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and the Ministry of Defence. The Public
Record Office contains the records of the superior courts of law and of most
government departments, as well as such famous historical documents as
Domesday Book. The National Register of Archives (maintained by the
Historical Manuscripts Commission) contains particulars of local and private
records.
Besides the few great private collections, such as those of the John Rylands
Library, Manchester, the Signet Library, Edinburgh, and the London
Library, there are the rich resources of the learned societies and institutions
(for scientific societies and institutions, see p. 190). Examples are the libraries
of the Royal Institute of International Affairs, the Royal Commonwealth
Society, the Commonwealth Institute, the Royal Geographical Society, the
Royal Institute of British Architects (see p. 218), the Royal College of
Physicians, the British Drama League (see p. 208), the Royal College of
Music, Royal Academy of Music, the Central Music Library (administered by
Westminster City Council), the National Library for the Blind and the
National Book League, which also houses the Arts Council library of modern
English poetry.
The great expansion in education in recent years has increased the strain on
library resources at all levels of education. The ancient university libraries of
Oxford and Cambridge are not matched by any of the more recent founda¬
tions, although the combined library resources of the colleges and institutions
of the University of London total over 4 million volumes and the university
libraries of Edinburgh, St. Andrews, Glasgow, Birmingham, Liverpool,
Manchester and Leeds each have over half a million volumes. However,
many universities have succeeded in building up large and important research
collections in special subjects; for example, the Barnes Medical Library at
Birmingham and the Brotherton Library of English Literature at Leeds. The
new universities, including the new technological universities, are also rapidly
building collections.
The importance of good libraries is recognised at all levels of the education
system. School libraries, most of which are maintained by local education
authorities, often receive co-operation from the public library service,
including loans of books. Parties of school children are regularly introduced
to the public library system, which they can use in addition to the school
library.
Britain is served by a complete network of public libraries, administered by
about 470 public library authorities (county councils, county borough councils,
London borough councils, municipal borough councils and urban district
councils). The authorities in Great Britain, which provide more than 11,500
220

Library
Co-operation
Library
Associations
service points, have a total stock of over 95 million books. (These figures
do not include the libraries in the publicly maintained schools.) Nearly
one-third of the total population are members of public libraries.
Under the Public Libraries and Museums Act 1964 the Secretary of State
for Education and Science is charged with the supervision of the public
library service in England and Wales, acting on the advice of the two Library
Advisory Councils, one for England, the other for Wales. Under the Act,
public library authorities are designated and have a duty to provide an
efficient and free lending and reference library service for books and period¬
icals. Outlying areas may be served by mobile libraries, of which over 500 are
in service, and facilities exist for people who are unable to visit a library.
In addition to lending books, about a quarter of the library authorities now
lend gramophone records of various kinds and a growing number are adding
loan collections of works of art, either originals or reproductions. Nearly all
library authorities provide children’s departments and reference sections and
art, music, commercial and technical departments meet the growing and more
specific demands in these fields.
Most library authorities possess a significant collection of books and
documents on the history of their localities. Qualified and specialist staff are
available for consultation in all but the smallest service points.
The public library is often a local cultural centre. Film shows, lectures,
adult education classes, book-week exhibitions, drama groups, gramophone
recitals and children’s story hours are among the many activities. An increasing
number of libraries provide special facilities for these extension activities.
The Public Libraries and Museums Act 1964 gave statutory recognition to
the voluntary system of library co-operation in England and Wales which
had grown up since the first quarter of this century. The ten regional library
bureaux in England and Wales (consisting mainly of public libraries in each
area) aim to be largely self-sufficient in the interlending of current British
books by means of a national system of subject specialisation. They organise
co-operation through their own member libraries and through the National
Central Library, which is responsible for interlending at national and inter¬
national level and has a bookstock of its own of nearly 400,000 volumes built
up by purchase, gift and the operation of the British National Book Centre
exchange scheme with foreign libraries. The combined resources of libraries
available to the National Central Library, which includes university, industrial
and other non-public libraries, amount to over 100 million books and many
thousand sets of periodicals.
There is a growing number of schemes for the exchange of specialist books
and periodicals as well as information. These are organised by associations of
industrial and commercial libraries which combine their resources, normally
through the local public or technical college library.
The Scottish Central Library carries out functions similar to those of the
regional bureaux and the National Central Library. Both Central Libraries
are financed in part by Exchequer grants. In Northern Ireland access to the
stocks of all co-operating libraries is available on application to the Belfast
public libraries, Queen’s University Library and the county libraries.
The principal professional organisation is the Library Association, which was
granted a Royal Charter in 1898 to unite all people engaged or interested in
library work; to promote the better administration of libraries and, inter alia,
to hold examinations in librarianship and to issue certificates of efficiency.
The Association in 1968 had a membership of over 16,000 of whom 1,600

were from overseas countries. It maintains a Register of Chartered Librarians,
publishes books and pamphlets, a Yearbook and an official journal, The
Library Association Record. The Association and its branches, groups and
sections hold regular conferences. There are also associations of libraries of
which Aslib (the Association of Special Libraries and Information Bureaux,
see p. 202) and the Standing Conference of National and University Libraries
(SCONUL) are of major importance.
New books constitute the large majority of all books published in Britain. In
1967 British publishers issued 29,619 separate titles, of which 22,559 were
new books and the rest reprints or new editions. In recent years there has been
a great increase in the number of paperbacked books of all kinds.
The above figures include only a small selection of government publications
by Her Majesty’s Stationery Office, which is the largest publishing organisa¬
tion in Britain. The great majority of books, however, are produced by about
300 of the principal commercial publishers. These include the university
presses, notably the Oxford University Press (including the Clarendon Press)
and the Cambridge University Press.
Using the copies deposited under copyright law in the British Museum, the
British National Bibliography is published weekly, with three, six, nine and
twelve monthly cumulations, listing in a classified order, with indexes, all new
books and new editions, excluding reprints, of books published in Britain.
Leading organisations representing the interests of those concerned with
book production and distribution are the Publishers’ Association and the
Booksellers’ Association; the Book Development Council promotes British
books overseas. The Society of Authors is a professional association of writers.
The National Book League has a membership covering all who are interested in
books: authors, publishers, booksellers, librarians and readers. It encourages
an interest in books and arranges exhibitions in Britain and overseas. Know¬
ledge of British books and periodicals overseas is greatly assisted by the British
Council through the lending and reference libraries (over 180) which it runs or
supplies, and through the many book and periodicals exhibitions which it
sends on tour. (For sales and exports of books in 1967 see p. 294.)
Societies for the promotion of literature include the English Association and
the Royal Society of Literature. The British Academy for the Promotion of
Historical, Philosophical and Philological Studies, generally known as the
British Academy, is the leading society of humanistic studies and receives a
grant from the Treasury.
A number of societies sponsor poetry readings and recitals; the Poetry
Society, the Apollo Society and the Barrow Poets are among the best known.
Poetry also plays an important part in various annual festivals, including the
National Eisteddfod—the bardic festival held in Wales—the Stratford-upon-
Avon Festival of Poetry, the Cheltenham Festival of Literature, and the
biennial poetry festival organised by the Poetry Book Society in London.
Among the specialist societies are the Early English Text Society, the
Bibliographical Society, the Harleian Society, the Saltire Society, and several
societies devoted to particular authors, of which the largest is the Dickens
Fellowship. There are a number of clubs and societies, such as the Book
Society and the Poetry Book Society, which exist to distribute selected new
books to their members.

Earlier
Development
of the Economy
BACKGROUND
Britain ranks about 75th in size among the countries of the world, with
about 0-18 per cent of the world’s land area. In population, approaching
2 per cent of the world’s inhabitants, it ranks tenth. In density of population
it is fourth: of the major countries, only Japan, Belgium and the Netherlands
are more crowded; and there are nine times as many people to the square
mile in the United Kingdom as in the United States. In terms of national
income per head it ranks appreciably below the United States and also below
Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Sweden and Switzerland, and slightly
below France and the Federal Republic of Germany. In world trade, it
ranks third, accounting for nearly one-tenth of the total. It takes about a fifth
of the world’s exports of primary products, and provides about one-eighth of
the world’s exports of manufactured goods.
Britain, from its own soil, provides only about half of the food it needs,
and—apart from coal, low-grade iron ore and natural gas—it has few natural
resources; thus it is the world’s largest importer of such products as wheat,
meat, butter, fodder grains, citrus fruits, tea, tobacco, wool, and hard timber.
In return, it is one of the world’s largest exporters of aircraft, motor vehicles,
electrical equipment, chemicals, textiles and most types of machinery7. No
other major country has such a small proportion of the working population
engaged in agriculture (about 3 per cent).
The United Kingdom is also the central banker of the sterling area, an
area with a quarter of the world’s population. Many countries outside the
sterling area use sterling in their international transactions, and it is the
currency in which about one-third of the world’s trade is conducted.
During the nineteenth century Britain secured a leading position as world
manufacturer, merchant, carrier, banker, and investor and so was able
to support a rapidly increasing population at a rising standard of living.
During the period from 1870 to 1890 British industrial expansion had a
clear lead over that of other countries. Between 1890 and 1914 growing
industrial competition from Europe and North America began to make
itself felt, but its effects on Britain’s staple export industries, particularly
cotton textiles and coal, were offset by the general rise in world trade, by
the continued demand for British textiles from India and other eastern
countries, and by the continued high level of overseas investment.
During the 1920s and 1930s, Britain’s older industries met increasing
competition, for example, coal and iron and steel from other European
countries and textiles from some eastern countries where labour was cheaper.
At the same time Britain failed at first to gain a compensating share of world
trade in the newer types of engineering products. Some countries sought
deliberately to protect nascent and even established industries by tariffs and
(later) quotas and exchange restrictions. The result was heavy unemployment
in Britain’s older industries, the general rate of which averaged 14 per cent of
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY

the Second
World War
The Post-war
Period
Devaluation
of Sterling
223
the employee population in the years 1921-39, reaching a peak of 22 per cent
in 1932, when the slump in world trade was at its worst. In some districts
relying mainly on the most heavily affected industries, the rate was much
higher. Income from invisible earnings (for example, on overseas investments,
shipping and insurance) and relatively cheap imports, particularly food,
however, cushioned the effects of the fall in the volume in exports.
After 1932 levels of production and employment improved, stimulated by
an increase in home investment which was aided by the policy of cheap money,
by some revival in world trade and, after 1935, by the armament programme.
The decade saw a strong expansion in the vehicles, electrical, chemicals and
aircraft industries, while the construction of 3 million houses brought about
a large growth in the building and ancillary industries. By 1937 average real
income per head wras about 14 per cent higher than in 1929.
The second world war is estimated to have run down British domestic
capital by about ^3,000 million, through shipping losses, bomb damage, and
arrears of industrial maintenance and replacements. Some ,£1,000 million
worth of overseas investments were sold, nearly half in North America, and
new external debts of ,£3,000 million were accumulated. By 1944 exports had
fallen to less than one-third of their 1938 volume as a result of the war effort.
Economic conditions in the immediate post-war period led to many of the
war-time restrictions remaining in force. Holdings of gold and foreign
exchange had been greatly depleted to pay for the essential war-time supplies
from overseas, and the export trade had to be rebuilt. Thus, rationing and
other war-time controls could only be relaxed gradually with the expansion
of production and the progress of recovery, this process being largely
completed by about mid-1954. The abolition of quantitative restrictions on
imports, other than from the dollar area, was largely completed by 1955.
Exchange controls on transactions between the sterling area and the rest of
the world wTere also progressively lifted, and in 1958 convertibility of sterling
on current account for all non-residents was introduced.
The past two decades have been a period of rising living standards and of
high levels of industrial production and employment. This has been
accompanied, however, by persistent economic problems, especially inflation
and a tendency for the growth of imports to outstrip the expansion in exports
and foreign exchange earnings generally, particularly in periods of rapid
economic growth. This has meant that the average current surplus on visible
and invisible trade together has not been sufficient to finance Britain’s
overseas expenditure and private investment and its position as banker to the
overseas sterling area. Successive governments have sought to deal with
recurring balance of payments deficits mainly through deflationary policies in
the hope that the resulting margin of spare capacity would lead to an increase
in exports and a fall in imports. Domestic demand was curtailed mainly
through increases in taxation and restrictions on credit while a high bank
rate was needed to maintain overseas confidence in sterling. However, these
policies tended to result in undesirable fluctuations in economic activity and
made it impossible to realise the full growth potential of the economy.
A further serious deterioration in the balance of payments in 1967 and loss
of overseas confidence in sterling was brought about largely by a decline in
exports as a result of slackening economic activity in certain major overseas
markets, by the increased costs of imports, particularly oil, on account of the
Middle East hostilities in June 1967 and by a series of dock strikes in the
224
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
OUTPUT, INCOME
AND
EMPLOYMENT
autumn. To meet the situation the Government decided to undertake a
devaluation of sterling from $2.80 to $2.40 = £1. The primary aim is to secure
a balance of payments surplus of at least £500 million a year, by improving
the competitive position of British exports and by giving industry an incentive
to find home substitutes for the relatively more expensive imports. A number
of fiscal and monetary measures were taken at the time of and following the
devaluation to restrain the growth of consumer demand and public expendi¬
ture, and to reallocate resources in favour of exports. The measures included
a far-reaching review of public expenditure (see p. 230), covering all aspects
of social, economic and external policies.
In November 1967 the International Monetary Fund made available a
standby credit of $1,400 million and in addition new central bank credits in
excess of $1,500 million were also arranged. Following the international gold
crisis in March 1968 further facilities were agreed which brought the total of
credit available to the British authorities (including the standby) to $4,000
million.
THE FRAMEWORK OF THE ECONOMY
The following sections sketch briefly the salient features of Britain’s national
economy in recent years. The source of Tables 11 to 14 is Preliminary Estimates
of National Income and Balance of Payments 1962 to 1967 (Cmnd. 357I)» an<^
Economic Trends, April 1968.
In 1967 Britain’s gross national product at factor cost (the measure of the s
value of total goods and services produced at home and net income from
abroad) is estimated to have totalled £34,025 million. In real terms, that is,
after allowing for price changes, the increase over the ten-year period to
1967 has amounted to just under one-third.
The working population had been rising slowly up to 1966, but fell between
1966 and 1967. Over the ten years to the middle of 1967, there was an increase
of about 1 million (or some \\ per cent) to about 25 million, of whom two-
thirds are males. The expansion of the national income over the same period
has, therefore, been mainly the result of higher productivity. Unemployment
over the past two decades remained very low, on average less than 2 per cent
of the employee population being out of work, but has been somewhat higher
since 1966. It has tended to remain above the national average in Northern
Ireland, Scotland, Wales and the north-east and certain other parts of England
(where special measures are encouraging additional employment), but in
London, the south and the Midlands, where the number of unfilled employ¬
ment vacancies has often exceeded that of registered unemployed, there has
been strong competition among employers for available labour. While some
industries, notably coalmining, the railways, cotton textiles and agriculture,
have undergone a marked reduction in their labour force—of the order of
400,000 in the last five years to June 1967—the needs of the expanding sectors
of the economy have not always been fully met.
Table 11 shows the distribution of total supplies of goods and services
since 1957 at 1958 prices, divided between personal consumption, public
consumption, investment and exports, and the diagram on p. 225 shows
changes in national expenditure between 1957 and 1967 (at 1962 prices).
Manufacturing industry contributes about 35 per cent to the total output
of goods and services, and together with mining and quarrying, construction

public authorities’ current expenditure (26 per cent) has been broadly in line
with the growth of the gross national product (32 per cent), but in the case of
capital formation the rate of increase (72 per cent) has been more than twice
as high.
Gross fixed investment has risen markedly during and since the 1950s. In
1951 fixed investment in the United Kingdom was about 15 per cent of the
gross national product; it has been maintained at a high level in recent years,
reaching over 20 per cent in 1967. Fixed investment in manufacturing, which
accounts for 20 per cent of all fixed investment, in 1967 amounted to £1,425
million at current prices, although compared with 1966 it showed a decline
both in current and in real terms. Investment has, however, been especially

An assessment of the value of the stock of fixed capital in the United
Kingdom at the end of 1966, made by the Central Statistical Office, gives a
total of ,£107,700 million at 1958 replacement cost. This is about 55 per cent
higher than in 1951, on the same basis of calculation. About 30 per cent of
the total was attributable to dwellings and over 22 per cent to assets in manufac¬
turing (excluding textiles) and construction.
Savings and the
Financing of
Investment
The marked growth of investment has been accompanied by a substantial
increase in personal savings which in 1967 amounted to ,£1,924 million (see
Table 13). As a proportion of personal disposable income (7 per cent) personal
savings were about the same as in 1966 and 1962 but well above that of 1957
(5 per cent).
The rise in personal savings has taken various forms. There has been
increased investment by the personal sector itself in new dwellings and fixed
assets. Life assurance premiums and other forms of contractual savings, such
as superannuation funds, have grown almost without interruption for many
years and now contribute over half the total. National Savings have also
increased since the early 1950s, rising by ,£130 million in 1967 to a total of
,£8,464 million. Building societies are able to attract considerable sums of
personal savings, deposits having reached a peak of ,£1,106 million in 1967.
The largest contribution to savings comes from companies. Up to 1959,
these provided about half the total, but the proportion has since fallen to about
42 per cent in 1967. In that year there was a decline of nearly 3 per cent
compared with 1966 on account of increased payments out of income.
Public corporations, as part of the policy of financing a larger share of their
investment needs from their own resources, have raised their savings total
considerably in recent years and the 1967 level accounted for about a tenth
of total savings.

causes of this increase have been the continuing growth of the social services,
especially education, and defence expenditure, which accounted for 16 per
cent of the total current expenditure of the public authorities in 1967
(compared with a peak of 27 per cent in 1953).

Several appreciable increases in taxation rates, imposed partly to reduce
the volume of demand on resources, have raised sharply the inflow of revenue.
Thus the yield from taxes on income in 1967 went up by £641 million,
or just under 15 per cent; and taxes on expenditure brought in an additional
£281 million following an increase of £477 million in 1966. Revenue from
the taxes on income in 1967 accounted for 41 per cent of central Government
receipts, and taxes on expenditure for 37 per cent. National insurance,
national health and other contributions accounted for 15 per cent and the
remainder was from rent, dividends and interest and trading income.
Revenue from rates imposed by local authorities rose by 58 per cent from
1962 to 1967. Rates accounted in 1967 for 36 per cent and grants from the
central Government for 43 per cent of current receipts of local authorities.

While consumer expenditure rose by 72 per cent at current prices between
1957 and 1967 to reach a total of £25,168 million, in real terms (that is, after
discounting the effect of price changes) the increase was only about 34 per
cent. The proportion devoted to food has been falling slightly each year
and now accounts for 22 per cent at current prices (1957, 27 per cent); outlay
on tobacco and alcoholic drinks is about 12 per cent of consumer expenditure.
In real terms expenditure on tobacco was about constant between 1962 and
1967, but substantial increases in taxes over the period caused total outlay to
rise by 22 per cent at current prices. At current prices housing absorbs 11 per
cent of total expenditure, and fuel and light about 5 per cent. Spending on
motor cars and motor cycles rose in 1967, after being at a lower level in the
two previous years. There has also been a substantial growth in spending on
household electrical equipment (except in 1966), fuel and light, and clothing.
Outlays on running costs of vehicles rose from £289 million in 1957 to
£1,166 million in 1967. In general the pattern of consumer spending reflects
the social changes and other developments outlined in Chapter 1. The diagram
below shows the change in consumers’ expenditure since 1958 in real terms and
at current prices.

ECONOMIC POLICY AND PLANNING
The Government’s economic policy is to secure economic growth and stable
employment based upon an adequate balance of payments and thereby to
bring about a continuing improvement in output and living standards. In
order to achieve the substantial balance of payments surplus, which it is hoped
the devaluation of sterling of November 1967 will bring about, a switch in
resources has to be made from home consumption to exports, import saving
and investment. The Government has taken action, therefore, to restrain
home demand in the public and private sectors by means of tax increases and
a reduction in the rate of growth of public expenditure. Along with this, an
effective prices and incomes policy is seen to be essential in preventing the
erosion by rising costs of the competitive advantage gained by devaluation.
At the same time the Government is continuing to encourage structural
changes in industry and by their regional economic policies to bring into more
effective use resources which are not fully employed.
To further strengthen the balance of payments, the Government is encouraging
industry through the Economic Development Committees and other means
to bring about savings in imports, which in the past decade have increased
in volume by over 4 per cent per annum. Likewise, services for exporters (see
pp. 387-9) have been expanded to assist exports which have been rising at only
some 3 per cent per annum over the same period. Invisible exports and
imports (that is, services) were subject to an enquiry in 1966 instigated by
the British National Exports Council and a permanent Committee on Invisible
Earnings has been set up to suggest measures to increase invisible earnings.
All aspects of the Government’s overseas expenditure were included in the
review of public expenditure announced in January 1968 (see below). The
most important items are overseas military expenditure which rose from
.£162 million to £283 million between 1957 and 1967 and economic grant
assistance to less-developed dependent territories which rose from .£49 million
to £86 million; in addition, there are government loans to overseas countries
and multilateral assistance in the form of contributions to international
agencies. Britain also has to make repayments of capital and pay interest in
respect of post-war loans from the United States and Canada, totalling about
£85 million a year.
Exchange control restrictions on the movement of capital from the United
Kingdom to non-sterling countries and increased restrictions on the outflow
of portfolio investment appear to have had a marked effect in 1967. A voluntary
programme to restrict investment in certain developed countries in the
sterling area is also in operation (see p. 394). Britain’s private overseas
investment over the past few years, a large part of which is to the less-
developed countries, has averaged over £300 million a year. Although this is
partly offset by private investment from overseas, mainly from the United
States, in most years the net flow has been outward.
Surveys of public expenditure have been taken annually since 1961 and
forward planning has been undertaken with the object of relating public
expenditure programmes and their demand on national resources to the
expected development of the economy. Reductions in public expenditure
announced in January 1968 following devaluation (see pp. 223-4) will involve a
slowing down (and in some cases a fall) in investment by the public corporations
and the nationalised industries. As a result, public investment and public
consumption are expected to increase at a rate of little more than 2 per cent a

the most important industries, the work of the Ministry of Technology in
fostering the introduction and development of advanced techniques, and the
work of the Department of Employment and Productivity in promoting the
more effective utilisation of manpower, including industrial training pro¬
grammes to meet the need for skilled labour. The Government also uses the
purchasing power of the public sector to assist industry in improving its
efficiency and the Industrial Reorganisation Corporation promotes desirable
amalgamations and reorganisations in industry. Taxation policy is being used
to strengthen manufacturing industry relative to services and other non¬
manufacturing activities with the introduction of investment grants (in place
of tax allowances) and a selective employment tax (see p. 362). This has been
accompanied by special financial assistance to industry in development areas
where resources are under-employed and by incentives to improve labour
mobility including legislation providing for redundancy payments and
improved re-training facilities. Efforts are being made to eliminate restrictive
practices in both sides of industry and legislation against monopolies and
mergers has been strengthened.
Inflation As in many other countries where full employment has prevailed over the past
decade and the demands on resources have been strong, Britain has had to deal
with continuing inflationary pressures. The almost uninterrupted upward
trend in prices has resulted principally from the tendency for money incomes
to rise faster than the volume of production, thus raising costs throughout the
economy.
Since 1956 the average annual rate of increase in domestic incomes has
been about 6 per cent, while the increase in the gross domestic product per
head of the labour force has been only between 2 and 2 J per cent. Retail prices
rose on average by 3 per cent a year between mid-January 1956 and
mid-January 1968; while over roughly the same period average weekly
earnings of manual workers went up by about 5J per cent a year. Company
profits are subject to large cyclical swings, but since 1956 and especially since
1961 they have increased more slowly than employment incomes.
Incomes Policy The Government recognises that a generally stable price level combined with
sustained economic growth can be achieved only within the framework of an
incomes policy designed to keep the rise in money incomes broadly in line
with the long-term rate of growth in national production.
The present Government’s incomes policy since 1964 has been developed
in consultation with representatives of management and workers beginning
with the Joint Statement of Intent on Productivity, Prices and Incomes signed
in December 1964, which formulated the lines of action to be taken by the
Government and by management and unions.
National Board for In April 1965 the National Board for Prices and Incomes (NBPI) was set up
Prices and Incomes to investigate all questions of prices and incomes referred to it by the Govern¬
ment. It sits in private making as thorough an examination of the issues
as possible, using evidence provided both by the parties involved and by out¬
side enquiries. Up to August 1968 the Board had published some 80 reports
on references made to it. It also publishes an annual report on its work during
the year. It has been guided by criteria set out by the Government in a series
of White Papers, the latest of which was published in April 1968 (see p. 233).
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY
Early Warning
System
Prices and Incomes
Standstill
The Prices
and Incomes
Act iq66
Prices and
Incomes Policy
in ig68 and
1969
233
In the autumn of 1965, the Confederation of British Industry and the Trades
Union Congress agreed to co-operate with the Government to establish a
voluntary ‘early warning’ system for prices and incomes, the purpose of
which was to give the Government adequate opportunity of considering
proposals to increase wages or prices and whether to refer them to the NBPI.
Under these arrangements price increases were notified to the appropriate
government department while pay claims and settlements were notified to the
Trades Union Congress or to the Ministry of Labour. A decision to refer had
to be taken within 28 days. Where the Government considered there was a
prima facie case for reference to the Board there was a further stand-still
period while the Board reported. This system remains as part of the Govern¬
ment’s object of establishing a prices and incomes policy on a voluntary basis.
On 20th July 1966 a stand-still on prices and incomes was announced in which,
for a period of 12 months, productivity would be allowed to catch up with
the excessive increases in incomes which had been taking place. The object
for the first six months (up to the end of December 1966) was to avoid as far
as possible increases in prices and incomes altogether; this was followed by a
period of severe restraint in the first half of 1967. In addition to wages and
prices the stand-still also covered other forms of remuneration, such as
directors’ fees, and company distributions.
The Prices and Incomes Act 1966 gave the Government powers of two kinds
which could be brought into operation by Order in Council. Under Part II of
the Act powers could be taken for a renewable period of 12 months to require
notification of increases in prices and charges, company distributions, and
significant improvements in the terms and conditions of employment. Under
Part IV of the Act unrenewable powers could be taken for a period of 12
months from the passing of the Act to require that particular prices and wages
should not be increased or should revert to the level prevailing on 20th July
1966. Part IV of the Act was brought into operation from 6th October 1966
to nth August 1967, although only a limited use had to be made of these
powers, and Part II came into force on 12th August 1967 for a period of 12
months as extended by the Prices and Incomes Act 1967.
A White Paper, Productivity, Price# and Incomes Policy in 1968 and 1969
(Cmnd. 3590), published in April 1968, outlines the current phase of the
policy. It states that for at least two years after devaluation substantial
restraint is required to keep incomes in line with the expected growth of
national output. The Government therefore fixed a ceiling of 3^ per cent
on all wage and salary settlements reached on or after 20th March 1968. As
before, all proposed increases must continue to satisfy the criteria contained
in the White Paper and there is no minimum or automatic entitlement to a
pay increase. Exceptions to the ceiling are considered only for agreements
which genuinely raise productivity and efficiency sufficiently to justify a pay
increase above 3I per cent. Further powers were taken in the Prices and
Incomes Act 1968 for a period of 18 months, that is, up to the end of 1969.
The maximum delaying power on price and pay increases was extended, in
the context of a reference to the National Board for Prices and Incomes,
from seven months under the expiring sections of the 1967 Act to 12 months
in all. The Act also empowers the Government to prevent excessive dividend
distributions and to moderate or phase increases in house rents. It may also,
after reference to the NBPI, require companies to reduce prices. The new
powers are being used only to the extent necessary in so far as the voluntary
arrangements are not being properly observed.

Economic
Planning
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
A framework for longer-term economic planning and consultation between
Government and the two sides of industry has been worked out in recent
years. The Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) was set up in October
1964 with responsibility for framing and supervising the plan for economic
development and for the general co-ordination of action to implement
national planning, and also of all economic policy relating to industrial
expansion, prices and incomes, allocations of physical resources and regional
implications of the expansion programme. In April 1968 responsibility for
the prices and incomes policy was transferred to the Secretary of State for
Employment and Productivity. The DEA works with representatives of
management and unions directly and through the National Economic
Development Council (NEDC), the Economic Development Committees
(EDCs) and with the regional planning bodies dealing with the special
problems of Scotland, Wales and the English regions.
The NEDC was set up in February 1962 originally to examine the economic
performance of the nation with particular concern for plans for the future.
It was reorganised in November 1964 following the setting up of the DEA.
The NEDC brings together representatives of Government and industry
and makes possible wide discussion of planning and policy. It meets
regularly under the chairmanship of the Prime Minister. Other members are
the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the First Secretary of State and Secretary
of State for Employment and Productivity, the Secretary of State for
Economic Affairs, the President of the Board of Trade, the Minister of
Technology, representatives of management and trade unions and the
nationalised industries, independent members, the Chairman of the National
Board for Prices and Incomes, and the Director General of the National
Economic Development Office (NEDO). The NEDC is supported by the
NEDO, which is independent of the Government, whose permanent staff is
headed by the Director General.
The NEDC has set up a number of Economic Development Committees.
With one exception—the EDC for the Movement of Exports—each committee
is concerned with an individual industry and under an independent chairman
is composed of members from management and the trade unions in that
industry. There are also a few independent members on each committee and
representatives from the DEA and the NEDO. The EDCs study and promote
the application of measures to improve efficiency in each industry. They also
assist in planning by advising on the implications for their industries of
developments in the economy and the contribution of each industry to
national growth.
The aim of regional economic planning is to secure a full and balanced
development of the country’s resources and to help achieve a faster and
steadier expansion in national output.
A system of regional economic planning councils and boards established in
Great Britain in 1965 provides the basic machinery for regional economic
planning. The regional economic planning councils consist of about 25 to 30
part-time members appointed for their wide knowledge and experience of
their regions. The councils are advisory bodies with no executive powers,
they assist in formulating plans for their regions and advise on the implementa¬
tion of regional policies and on the regional implications of national policies.
The regional economic planning boards consist of senior civil servants
representing the main government departments concerned with aspects of
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY
235
Northern Ireland
Summary
regional planning in their respective areas. Their functions are to help
formulate plans for the region in co-operation with the planning councils and
to co-ordinate the economic planning work of the government departments.
For purposes of regional planning England has been divided into eight
regions—Northern, Yorkshire and Humberside, East Midlands, East Anglia,
South-East, South-West, West Midlands, and North-West; Scotland has
its own economic planning council and board, and there is a Welsh Council
(supported by an economic planning board) concerned with both economic
and social affairs in Wales.
Each regional economic planning council in England has published a
major report on its region; a development plan for Scotland up to 1970 was
published by the Government in 1966 and one for Wales in 1967.
The present stage is one of formulating medium- and longer-term strategies,
with sub-regional studies of areas with particular problems. The strategies take
into account all the factors including the distribution of population, industry
and employment within the region.
The Northern Ireland Government has set up an economic council, comprising
representatives of both sides of industry and other interests, to examine
means of furthering Northern Ireland’s economic development. As Northern
Ireland government departments have responsibilities for planning in
Northern Ireland, it was not necessary to set up a special planning board.
A plan for Northern Ireland’s economic development up to 1970 was published
in 1965.
Viewed as a whole the British economy has made considerable progress over
the past decade. Its rate of growth, if not so fast as that of some other industrial
countries, has been higher than in any earlier period over the past 50 years.
At the same time relatively full employment has been maintained and consump¬
tion and living standards have improved steadily. Moreover, modernisation of
productive industry and the distributive system have progressed despite
persistent balance of payments difficulties, accentuated by the role sterling
plays as a world reserve and trading currency and a high level of overseas
commitments in the form of development aid and defence.
11 INDUSTRY
The Structure
of Industry
Manufacturing
ORGANISATION AND PRODUCTION
The United Kingdom was the first country in the world to become highly
industrialised, and today fourteen people work in mining, manufacturing and
building for every one engaged in agriculture. It is the world’s third largest
exporter of manufactured goods, and the range of its industrial manufactures
reflects its position as one of the most important workshops of the world.
The pattern of ownership and organisation in industry is varied. Personal,
corporate, co-operative and public enterprise all assume a number of different
forms, and all are important in the economy. Industrial enterprises vary from
the many small workshops to vast organisations such as the National Coal
Board, a public corporation with about 450,000 employees; Imperial Chemical
Industries Ltd., a limited liability company which, with its subsidiaries,
employs some 175,000 persons in the United Kingdom; and the Co-operative
Wholesale Society Ltd., with about 50,000 employees.
Most manufacturing is in the hands of private enterprise. Exceptions include
fissile materials and radioactive isotopes made by the Atomic Energy
Authority, locomotives and rolling-stock built in the workshops of British
Railways, and military equipment and supplies made in establishments of the
defence services. Staff of the Stationery Office do some printing and book¬
binding, while the repair, and to a limited extent the construction, of post
office equipment is carried on in factories run by the Post Office. Certain
factories giving employment to the severely disabled are operated by Remploy
Ltd., a non-profit-making public company financed on the Vote of the Depart¬
ment of Employment and Productivity, which appoints the directors (see p.
411). The Government holds about 49 per cent of the equity of a major oil
company, British Petroleum Limited, and has a controlling interest in a few
other companies.
Surveys of the size of all manufacturing establishments employing more
than 10 persons are made periodically by the Department of Employment and
Productivity; the results of the most recent show that in 1961 nearly a third of
all employees in such establishments are in those employing from 100 to 499
persons, while slightly over a third are in those employing 1,000 or more. A
high proportion of the biggest establishments are in the heavy industries; the
average size of establishments in industries making consumer goods is smaller
than in manufacturing industries as a whole. Comparisons with results
obtained in earlier years suggest a slow but significant trend towards increased
average size of establishments.
The size of establishments is not in itself an indication of the size of manu¬
facturing enterprises, as a single enterprise may own several establishments,
not all of them necessarily engaged in the same or similar activities. The most
recent analysis of manufacturing enterprises by size (employment) relates to
the Report on the Census of Production for 1958. An enterprise, as defined in
the Census, normally consists of either a single firm or a holding company
together with its subsidiaries. Just over half of all employment in British
manufacturing industries in 1958 was accounted for by about 950 large
private enterprises employing 1,000 or more people, the largest 70 or so
INDUSTRY
Building and
Civil Engineering
Mining and
Quarrying
Monopolies and
Restrictive
Practices
237
accounting roughly for a quarter. A further indication of company size is the
value of capital employed (net assets). For a few of the very largest including
the Imperial Chemical Industries group, the figure exceeds £1,000 million;
about 50 companies registered in Britain have over £100 million net assets.
In some industries a small number of big companies and their subsidiaries
are responsible for most of the total production. Examples are oil refining,
non-ferrous metal smelting, the manufacture of motor vehicles and com¬
ponents, aircraft and aero-engines, heavy electrical equipment, bicycles,
tobacco, cement, and basic chemicals. Shares in these companies are usually
distributed among a great number of holders and it is rare for a few large
holders to have a controlling interest. For example, five of the largest public
companies each have more than 100,000 shareholders. With intensified
competition in the economy and in many branches of industry the growing
dependence of profitable operation on concentration and an increasing scale
of production, the trend towards mergers and regroupings has been particu¬
larly marked in the 1960s. Larger units of control have been established in
almost all the leading industries, for example, motor vehicles, aircraft frames
and aero-engines, electrical engineering, machine tools, brewing, textiles,
newspaper and magazine publishing.
A new departure was the setting up of the Industrial Reorganisation
Corporation by the Government in 1966 with resources of up to £150 million
provided by the Exchequer. Its function is to participate in schemes for
concentration, rationalisation and modernisation of industry, in particular the
merging and regrouping of firms into larger units to meet the changing
situation in the markets for many of the most important products, and it has
already been instrumental in furthering large mergers in motor vehicle manu¬
facturing, the heavy electrical, computer and other industries. In 1968 the
Government introduced the Industrial Expansion Act extending their powers
to give financial support to industrial projects calculated to improve efficiency;
to create, expand or sustain production capacity; or promote or support
technological improvements.
An account of some of the principal manufacturing industries is given on
pp. 270-95.
In building and civil engineering, large-scale work is usually carried out by
private contractors, although the Ministry of Public Building and Works is
the largest single employer of building labour while some 45 per cent of the
industry’s output is for public authorities. Building firms may be divided into
those undertaking general building and civil engineering work and those
concerned with highly specialised work, many of which operate outside as
well as inside the building industry. Building is an industry of small firms;
more than three-quarters of the firms employ fewer than 20 employees. For
a fuller account of the building and civil engineering industries, see p. 268.
Much the most important of the British extractive industries is coalmining.
The coalmining industry of Great Britain (see p. 253) is operated as a single
co-ordinated enterprise under National Coal Board direction (see p. 253).
Nearly all other mining and quarrying (iron ore, sand, gravel, chalk, lime¬
stone, salt, tin, slate, oil shale and china clay) is undertaken by private
enterprises, usually owned and operated by limited liability companies. Less
than 65,000 workers are employed, excluding coalmining.
Legislation exists for scrutinising and, if desirable, for the investigation by an
independent administrative body of monopoly situations and for the judicial
examination of restrictive trading agreements.
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Restrictive Trade Practices Act 1956 provides for the registration
and judicial examination of restrictive agreements. It requires the entry in a
public register of the particulars of a wide range of restrictive agreements
(including those relating to common prices, approved lists of dealers and the
limitation of production) which affect the supply or processing of goods for
the United Kingdom market. The Registrar of Restrictive Trading Agree¬
ments is responsible for keeping the register and for bringing the agreements
before the Restrictive Practices Court set up under the Act. The Court, which
includes laymen but is presided over by one of Her Majesty’s judges, is, in
effect, responsible for deciding whether or not an agreement is in the public
interest. If the parties to an agreement fail to satisfy the Court that any
restriction in their agreement produces one or more of seven beneficial
effects set out in the Act, and that the restriction is not unreasonable, having
regard to the balance between the benefit it confers and any public detriment
likely to result from its operation, that restriction must be found contrary to
the public interest. Agreements are void in respect of restrictions so found.
The Court can make orders preventing the parties from operating their
agreement, or from making new arrangements having the same effect. Agree¬
ments relating exclusively to exports are not subject to this procedure but
have to be notified to the Board of Trade. Legislation has been introduced
to exempt from registration agreements of national importance which promote
efficiency or provide for new productive capacity. In addition, the new
legislation provides for improved enforcement procedures.
Under the 1956 Act collective enforcement of resale price maintenance
was prohibited, but individual suppliers remained free to enforce resale
prices in the courts. The Resale Prices Act 1964 made minimum resale price
maintenance unlawful, except in respect of classes of registered goods for
which temporary exemption has been sought under the provisions of the Act.
Where resale price maintenance is prohibited, it is also unlawful to notify
to dealers prices stated or calculated to be understood as the minimum price
which may be charged on the resale of goods in the United Kingdom, or to
seek to maintain such prices by withholding supplies. Suppliers may continue
to practise resale price maintenance on registered goods, pending a decision by
the Restrictive Practices Court as to whether a case for exemption has been
made out against the criteria in the Act. Periodically, the Registrar of
Restrictive Trading Agreements issues lists of classes of goods in respect of
which the Court has refused to make an Order exempting them from the
terms of the Act.
Monopolies and kindred arrangements (other than those within the scope of
the Restrictive Practices Court) may, in circumstances indicated in the
Monopolies and Mergers Acts 1948 and 1965, be referred by the Board of
Trade to the Monopolies Commission for investigation and report. The
Board of Trade, in co-operation with the production departments (see p. 245)
concerned, take appropriate action on reports but no Order can be made
without parliamentary approval. The 1965 Act strengthened and extended the
legislation on monopolies. It reorganised and enlarged the Monopolies
Commission; provided for the investigation, at the reference of the Board of
Trade, of services and of proposed or recently completed mergers; made
special provision for newspaper mergers; and improved and extended the
Government’s powers for taking action on the basis of the Monopolies
Commission reports including new powers to prohibit mergers and break up
undesirable monopolies and mergers.
INDUSTRY
Role of Public
Enterprise
239
Direct State participation in productive and commercial activities is effected
mainly through special statutory bodies set up to deal with a particular
activity. Such bodies, though not part of a government department, are under
a considerable but varying degree of public control (see below). The most
important of these statutory bodies are the public corporations which operate
major industries and services in the public interest. Altogether 10 per cent
of the labour force works for these bodies. Their managing boards and staffs
are chosen for their experience and competence in a particular field; they are
not civil servants, and, although accountable to Parliament for their actions
in a variety of ways, it is they and not the ministers of the sponsoring
departments who are responsible for the management of the corporations.
Certain of the corporations are self-supporting; others receive Exchequer
grants to help them carry out duties with which they have been charged.
The following corporations are now operating or controlling large-scale
industries or services: United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority (see p. 197);
British Overseas Airways Corporation, British European Airways, British
Airports Authority (see pp. 345-7); Bank of England (see p. 367); British
Broadcasting Corporation, Independent Television Authority (see p. 430);
National Coal Board (see p. 253); Electricity Council, Central Electricity
Generating Board, Area Electricity Boards, North of Scotland Hydro-
Electric Board, South of Scotland Electricity Board, Northern Ireland Joint
Electricity Authority, Electricity Board for Northern Ireland (see p. 258);
Gas Council, Area Gas Boards (see p. 263); British Steel Corporation (see p.
272); British Railways Board, British Transport Docks Board, British Water¬
ways Board, London Transport Board, Transport Holding Company (see p.
330), Northern Ireland Transport Holding Company (see p. 342).
The Post Office is to become a public corporation in 1969 (see p. 349).
The extent to which the responsible minister has power over the working
of the boards which have been set up to run the nationalised industries varies
from industry to industry, but two features are common to almost all of them.
First, the minister appoints (and may dismiss) the chairman and members
of each board, and, secondly, he has power to give general directions as to
how the industry should be run, but does not interfere in day-to-day manage¬
ment. It is usually also laid down that the board shall give to the minister
any information, statistics and financial accounts which he may require. In
practice, as the responsible minister is kept fully informed and major policy
decisions are reached in consultation with him, there is very seldom occasion
for him to issue a formal directive.
The minister also has financial powers and responsibilities. The usual
statutory requirement is that the board is required to conduct its business so
that receipts at least balance outgoings taking one year with another. The
responsible minister is usually empowered (subject to Treasury approval) to
say what shall be done with any surplus revenues which may accrue. As
regards finance of capital expenditure, the present system is that such finance
as cannot be met from internal sources is mainly provided, in the form of
interest-earning loans, by the minister from the Exchequer, bank advances
being used only for normal requirements of short-term capital.
It is usual for the minister responsible for each nationalised industry to be
required by statute to take steps to see that the interests of the industry’s
customers are protected. This is generally done by the establishment of
representative consumers’ councils to consider complaints and suggestions
made to them, and to advise the board or the minister on the changes they
think desirable.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Industrial
Association
Financial targets have been agreed by the Government with the different
industries (or are under discussion) ranging from 12-4 per cent gross return
on capital employed to ‘breaking even* after interest and depreciation have
been allowed for. In addition the industries are expected to apply a test
discount rate for new investment of 8 per cent.
Government policy towards the nationalised industries is subject to the
approval of Parliament. Opportunities for parliamentary discussion are
afforded by debates, including debates on their annual reports and accounts,
and by answers to parliamentary questions, which, in principle, are admissible
only if concerned with policy rather than details of administration. A House
of Commons Select Committee on the Nationalised Industries, which
examines the reports and accounts of the nationalised industries and reports
to Parliament, has been in operation since 1957.
From the middle of the nineteenth century, private industrial undertakings
have increasingly entered into voluntary association for a number of different
purposes. Some of the more important of these are classified as: (1) the
provision of common services, the exchange of information, liaison with the
Government, and representation of their members’ point of view; (2) the
regulation of trading practices, sometimes including the regulation of prices
(see p. 238); (3) negotiation with trade unions on wages and conditions of
work. Associations for the first and third of these purposes cover, with
varying completeness, most of British industry, but there are wide sectors of
industry where there are no collective agreements to regulate trading practices.
Employers’ organisations which deal with labour matters usually consist of
firms engaged in the same type of operation or manufacturing process. Trade
associations mainly concerned with representations to the Government,
provision of common services or the regulation of trading practices are built
up round a product or an allied group of products. In an industrial sector
concerned wholly with an allied group of products, a single association may
undertake all the required functions.
There are about 80 national federations and probably altogether about
1,500 employers’ organisations (mostly regional or local, and members or
branches of the national federations) all concerned with negotiation of wages
and conditions of work. The number of manufacturers’ associations concerned
with providing common services is not known precisely, but according to a
survey carried out between 1953 and 1956 by Political and Economic Planning
(an independent research organisation) some 1,300 were in existence, varying
greatly in importance, structure and activities.
The central body representing British industry nationally is the Confedera¬
tion of British Industry (CBI). It is recognised by the Government as a
channel for consultation between government departments and representatives
of private employers as a whole. For its members it acts as an advisory and
consultative body providing them with information and statistics, ascertaining
their collective views and representing them nationally to the Government
and the public and also internationally, for example in the Council of European
Industrial Federations. CBI representatives sit on a number of government
advisory committees, on other statutory bodies and on voluntary bodies
concerned with matters affecting industry.
The CBI membership consists of some 13,000 companies and over 200
trade associations and employers’ federations. Nationalised industries have
joined as industrial associates. The CBI has a regional organisation in the
United Kingdom and is widely represented abroad.
INDUSTRY
24I
In matters of common concern the CBI often acts jointly with the chambers
of commerce. These are open to all kinds of producers and traders and exist
to promote the interests of local industry and commerce. The Association of
British Chambers of Commerce, founded in i860, is the central organisation
to which 95 local chambers of commerce (together with 18 British Chambers of
Commerce operating abroad) are affiliated. In Scotland there is an additional
central organisation, the Council of Scottish Chambers of Commerce, and in
Northern Ireland, the Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce and Industry
to which local chambers are affiliated.
Location The following is a summary of the geographical distribution of British industry
today, grouped by the areas covered by the regional economic planning
machinery (see p. 234).
Greater London and London, lying at the head of ocean navigation on the Thames estuary, is
[he South-east Britain’s capital and main communication centre, probably still the world’s
Region most important financial centre, and one of the world’s three largest cities
(with Tokyo and New York) and three largest ports (with New York and
Rotterdam). It is the main centre in Britain of printing, cinema film produc¬
tion, and the manufacture of clothing, food and drink, furniture, materials for
the arts, precision instruments and many other specialised products. Small
firms predominate in many of these industries and the average size of manu¬
facturing firms (particularly in the central area) is well below the national
average. London is also, especially its outer ring, important for light engineer¬
ing, chemicals and consumer goods and has some heavy engineering plants
and a number of leading research establishments.
Towards the periphery of Greater London and in the new urban develop¬
ment outside it, industry, particularly the electronics and a variety of consumer
goods industries, has been expanding rapidly; some of the largest aircraft
plants are in these areas, for example at Weybridge and Hatfield, as well as
factories, at Dagenham, Luton and Dunstable, of two of the four main motor
vehicle manufacturers. There are other major motor vehicle manufacturing
plants at Cowley, Oxford (population 105,000), some 50 miles north-west of
London. Along the lower Thames and Medway estuaries there are large oil
refineries as well as some smaller shipyards, engineering works and major
concentrations of the paper and pulp and cement industries.
A great part of the Channel coast eastwards from Poole (population 96,000)
and Bournemouth (151,000) consists of built-up areas, which from Brighton
(162,500) eastwards are partly dormitories for people working in London.
Holiday resorts fringe the coast. Portsmouth (218,000) is a naval port with
some shipbuilding and general manufactures. Southampton (209,000) is
Britain’s largest port for ocean-going liners; its industries include ship
repairing, oil refining, cable-making, electronics and synthetic rubber. Dover,
Folkestone and Newhaven are packet ports.
South-zvest England Devon and Cornwall have a considerable tourist trade. Bristol (429,000) is a
leading port and commercial centre with aircraft, aero-engines, tobacco, food
processing, paper, printing and other industries and important non-ferrous
metal and basic chemicals plants at Avonmouth. Gloucester (91,000), originally
an inland port and commercial town, Cheltenham (75,500), originally a resort
town, and the area between and adjacent to them produce a variety of manu¬
factures, including machinery, instruments and accessories and cloth.
Swindon (98,000), besides railway workshops, has important engineering
works. Bath (82,500), originally a resort town and centre of an agricultural
district, has become noted for engineering and other manufacturing.

242
East Anglia
West

East
