North-west
England
Besides being one of the most productive agricultural regions, the eastern
counties possess some sizeable towns. Cambridge (100,000) is a leading centre
of research-based industry; Ipswich (121,000) and Peterborough (66,000) are
noted for diesel engines and engineering generally; and Norwich (118,000)
for footwear and food manufacture. Food canning and freezing, based mainly
on locally grown produce, have developed rapidly. The fishing ports of
Great Yarmouth (52,500) and Lowestoft (49,000) have fish processing plants,
and are also becoming important bases for companies engaged in natural gas
exploitation in the North Sea.
The West Midlands conurbation, which stretches from Birmingham
(1,102,000) to Wolverhampton (267,000) and includes parts of Staffordshire,
Worcestershire and Warwickshire, has an unusually wide variety of industry,
including the manufacture of metals, electrical and engineering products of all
kinds and also jewellery, rubber products, chemicals and domestic metalware.
The largest concentrations of motor vehicle manufacture (including com¬
ponents and accessories) in Britain are in Birmingham and Coventry (334,000).
The smaller conurbation of North Staffordshire, centred on Stoke-on-Trent
(276,000), is devoted chiefly to the manufacture of pottery and china and to
coalmining, although other industries are growing in importance, while
Stafford (51,500) has heavy electrical and other engineering works.
Other industrial centres are Rugby (56,000), electrical engineering;
Worcester (69,000), machinery; Burton-on-Trent (50,000), brewing and
rubber; and Kidderminster (44,500), carpets.
The thriving industrial cities and towns of the East Midlands include Leicester
(283,500) noted for hosiery and knitwear, boots and shoes and machinery for
making these products; Derby (128,500) for general engineering, aero-engines
and man-made fibres; Nottingham (310,000) for hosiery, cycles and a variety
of other engineering products, lace, pharmaceutical products and tobacco;
Northampton (121,500) footwear and engineering; Chesterfield (70,000)
engineering. Corby (45,000), a new town in Northamptonshire, has a steel
industry. Part of Britain’s richest and most highly mechanised coalfield lies
under the north-east of the area. Some of the towns on the coalfield, such as
Mansfield (55,000), have important manufacturing industries, particularly
textiles.
Manchester (617,000) is the commercial hub of the cotton and man-made
fibre textile industries, a very important financial and commercial centre and
a major port. It is also one of the chief centres for electrical and heavy
engineering and the production of machine tools, petro-chemicals, dyestuffs,
and pharmaceutical goods, while it has a wide range of other manufactures.
In the traditional cotton-manufacturing towns man-made fibres are also
processed alone or blended with cotton; the largest of these are Bolton
(157,000), Oldham (111,000), Rochdale (87,000), Stockport (141,000), Burnley
(78,000), Blackburn (102,000), Preston (107,500) and Bury (63,500). In the
majority of these towns engineering industries, notably the manufacture of
printing, paper making, textile and electrical machinery and heavy commercial
vehicles (especially in the Chorley-Leyland area), have been increasing while
the cotton industry has been declining. The Lancashire coalfield also lies in
the Manchester-Wigan area.
The Manchester Ship Canal, which carries a substantial volume of overseas
trade, links Manchester with Merseyside. It passes through Warrington
(74,000) with its metal industries (such as wire-drawing), Widnes (54,500) and
Runcorn (30,000) with their chemicals, and Ellesmere Port (51,000) with its
INDUSTRY
Yorkshire and
Humberside
Northern England
243
oil refinery installations, before reaching the Mersey estuary. St. Helens
(104,000), to the north of the canal, is famous for glass manufacture. Liverpool
(705,000) is the second port of Britain, a great commercial and insurance
centre and, after London, the greatest centre for processing imported food¬
stuffs and raw materials, noted especially for flour milling, soap manufacture,
sugar refining and rubber products. Among its older industries is ship
repairing; shipbuilding is a major industry across the river at Birkenhead
(143,500). Many new industries, including electrical engineering, manufacture
of heavy industrial equipment and, more recently, of motor vehicles, have been
established around Liverpool. Salt, extracted in Cheshire, is used by chemical
works on Merseyside.
Barrow (64,500), in the north-west of Lancashire, is well-known for ship¬
building and marine engineering. Blackpool (151,000) on the coast is Britain’s
most popular holiday resort.
About three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s worsted and woollen indus¬
tries are found in the West Riding of Yorkshire. Bradford (297,000) is the
commercial centre of the wool trade and important for worsted; Wakefield
(60,000) produces both worsted and woollens; Morley (43,500) and Leeds
(508,000) have specialised in cheaper cloths, and Batley (41,000), Dewsbury
(53,000), and Spenborough (38,000) in heavy cloth, but their production is
becoming more diversified. Huddersfield (132,000) has a reputation for fine
woollens and worsteds and Halifax (95,000) for carpets. In most of the larger
centres of the wool industry a variety of engineering products are manu¬
factured. Leeds, the commercial capital of the area, has a large ready-made
clothing industry and important engineering plants. Farther south is the
heavy engineering centre of Sheffield (534,000), famous for its high quality
steels, cutlery and tools. The area’s extensive coalfields provide nearly a
quarter of Britain’s coal; Doncaster (86,000), also with tractor and nylon
manufacturing, and Barnsley (76,000) are the largest towns on the coalfield.
York (106,000) is noted for chocolates and confectionery manufacture and
has important railway workshops, and Hull (296,000), one of the world’s
largest fishing ports and with many manufacturing industries, including
engineering, vegetable oil processing, paints and sawmilling, is the most
important industrial town in the East Riding of Yorkshire.
On the south (Lincolnshire) side of the Humber lie Scunthorpe (71,000),
another important steel-making centre, and the major fishing port of Grimsby
(95,000) which has a food processing industry and also a growing chemicals
industry close by at Immingham.
The greater part of this region (Northumberland, Cumberland, Westmorland,
Durham and the North Riding of Yorkshire) is an area of mountains, lakes and
moors and is relatively thinly populated. Most of its population is concen¬
trated in the coastal strip from the coalfields north of the Tyne to the Tees.
Within this area the main centres are Tyneside, including Newcastle upon
Tyne (252,000), Gateshead (101,500), Tynemouth (72,500), South Shields
(108,000), Wallsend (48,000) and Jarrow (26,900); and Teesside (398,000) and
Hartlepool (97,000). Other large towns are Sunderland (218,000), Darlington
(84,500) and, in the west, Carlisle (71,000).
The whole region is more dependent than other parts of England on
traditional heavy industries, notably coalmining, iron and steel manufacture,
shipbuilding and repairing and chemicals (the complex of chemical plants on
both banks of the Tees is probably the most extensive in Europe), which
together employ nearly a third of the male workers. This proportion has been
244
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Wales
Scotland
Northern Ireland
falling steadily as the result of the region’s efforts, with government help, to
attract new types of enterprise. It is one of the most important areas for the
manufacture of electrical plant, and the many other industries include mining
machinery, rolling mill plant, earth-moving equipment, machine tools, ropes,
paint, glass, clothing and scientific instruments. Atomic energy is important
in Cumberland with its two nuclear power stations.
Nearly two-thirds of the population of Wales and Monmouthshire live in the
two counties of Glamorgan and Monmouthshire. In this area are the coal
mines which, though long worked and operating at increasing depths, still
produce nearly all Britain’s anthracite and much of its steam and other
specialised coals, and employ more workers than any branch of manufacturing
industry. Rhondda (98,000) and Merthyr Tydfil (58,000) are the largest
centres in the coalmining area. The steel industry, with some of the most
modern plants in Europe, supplies almost all Britain’s output of tin plate and
much of its sheet steel. In the past 30 years many new industries have been
established, often on government industrial estates; they include plastics,
synthetic fibres, clothing, electronics, motor vehicle components and light
engineering.
The main urban centres are also the three major ports—Cardiff (289,000),
Newport (113,000) and Swansea (170,500). Milford Haven (13,000), a magni¬
ficent deep-water harbour recently developed, has two major oil refineries.
In North Wales a number of light industries, notably man-made fibres, are
located in the seaside resorts and some other towns, particularly Wrexham
(37,000), and there is a large steelworks in Flintshire.
About three-quarters of Scotland’s population (5-2 million) is concentrated in
the central Lowlands between the Firth of Clyde and the Firth of Forth. The
principal cities in this area are Glasgow (961,000) and Edinburgh (468,000).
Clydeside, which includes Glasgow, is Britain’s largest shipbuilding and
marine engineering centre; it also has a great variety of general engineering
enterprises and other industries. The steel industry, sited mainly in north
Lanarkshire, produces a wide range of products. The widely dispersed
electronics equipment industry is represented by a growing number of firms
in such centres as Glasgow, north Lanarkshire, Dundee and central Fife, as
well as in Edinburgh, where this and other modern industries are expanding
alongside the long-established engineering, printing and brewing industries.
Motor car manufacture has been established in Renfrewshire and in West
Lothian there has been a major expansion of commercial vehicle building.
Outside the central Lowland belt there is considerable industrial concen¬
tration in and around Dundee (184,000) and Aberdeen (183,500) and a number
of towns outside these areas have attracted light industries in recent years.
Dundee’s traditional manufacture, jute, has been supplemented by office
machinery, clocks and watches, refrigerators and electronic products. In
north-east Scotland is the largest concentration of whisky distilleries.
Most of northern Scotland is mountainous and much of southern Scotland
is hilly and rugged. These regions are sparsely populated, but the Scottish
Highlands possess significant resources of hydro-electric power (see p. 260).
There are high-quality tweed and knitwear industries both in the valley towns
of the southern uplands and in the Highlands and Islands.
Although the area of Northern Ireland is relatively small and it lacks minerals,
there is substantial and growing industrialisation, particularly in and around
Belfast, the capital city (399,000). Britain’s largest single shipyard is in
INDUSTRY
245
Belfast; other long-established activities include the manufacture of textile
machinery and other engineering products; ropes, twine, tobacco and clothing.
Northern Ireland has also long been an important centre for textiles—it is
particularly well known for linen. The textile industry is now extensively
diversified; Northern Ireland is one of the most important areas in Europe for
man-made fibre production and provides about one-fifth of Britain's output.
There has also been extensive development in car components, oil-well
equipment, electronic instruments, telephone switchgear, toys, shoes, carpets
and synthetic rubber.
Relations
between the
Government
and Industry
The Government can influence industrial activity in a number of ways 
through fiscal and monetary policy, through the level of public expenditure,
through the placing of government contracts, through the policies of publicly
owned enterprises, by physical controls, by inducements, by exhortation and
by the provision of services, information and advice. Apart from labour
legislation (see Chapter 16) and certain export and import controls over a
small range of products (see Chapter i5)> there are few physical controls over
industry the main ones are the use of the legislation concerning monopolies
and restrictive practices already described (see p. 237) Rnd the operation of
powers to control new industrial and office building and changes in land use
(see p. 249). There is a close and growing association between industry and the
Government through such channels as the National Economic Development
Council and its Economic Development Committees (see p. 247).
Within the Government, the Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) has
general responsibility for the allocation of national resources and the co¬
ordinating of policies for industrial efficiency and regional development.
Policies for productivity, prices and incomes and manpower are the concern
of the Department of Employment and Productivity. The department through
which the Government s day-to-day relations with trade and industry are
chiefly conducted is the Board of Trade (which has regional offices in certain
principal industrial centres) and its responsibilities cover a wide range of
industries and materials. Other departments concerned with particular subjects
of concern to industry generally are the Treasury, which is responsible for
fiscal and monetary policy; and the Department of Education and Science,
which is responsible for the promotion of education and for civil science,
operating in the main through the research councils. The Ministry of Techno¬
logy is responsible for the application of advanced technology in industry
generally; it has set up nine regional offices linking 70 industrial liaison
centres and maintains a number of research establishments offering a range of
services to industry (see p. 202).
For particular industries a system has grown up whereby a particular
government department acts as the main point of contact, the ‘production’ or
‘sponsor department’, for each major industry. The Ministry of Technology
is the sponsor department for the mechanical and electrical engineering
industries and for those manufacturing electronic equipment, computers,
machine tools, telecommunications equipment, shipping, aircraft and aero¬
engines. Other sponsor departments include the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food, the Ministry of Public Building and Works and the
Ministry of Health.
There are separate departments of the Northern Ireland Government for
matters within the competence of the Northern Ireland Parliament. The
Ministry of Commerce deals with industry, especially the encouragement of
industrial development.

The Central Statistical Office, which is attached to the Cabinet Office,
provides a comprehensive statistical service. Although departments themselves
compile statistics relating to their particular responsibilities, and may publish
them in their own standard publications, the comprehensive statistical
publications are prepared by the Central Statistical Office and its co-ordinating
role is to be considerably extended. (For the principal regular series of
statistics published, see Bibliography p. 47^’)
Industrial production (mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction,
and gas, electricity and water) was in the first half of 1968 some 4 per cent
higher than a year previously, about 34 per cent more than in 1959 and about
double the pre-war level. The course of production and employment from
1961 to 1967 is shown in Table 16.
Between 1958 and 1967 output rose fastest (see below) in the chemicals and
allied industries (71 per cent), in paper, printing and publishing (45 per cent)
and in engineering and allied goods (33 per cent); in gas, electricity and water
(56 per cent) and construction (45 per cent).
The size of the labour force has scarcely changed in the last five years and
the increases in production have been due mainly to a variety of factors
influencing productivity, including advances in products, machinery, processes
and methods of work; the rate of fixed capital formation; more intensive
competition and sales promotion; and improved management.

Productivity
247
Gross fixed capital formation at home has been well maintained. In 1967
it amounted to over 20 per cent of the gross domestic product and was estimated
to be over 50 per cent greater than in 1959. Part of this rising investment is
linked with the introduction of new techniques and equipment and in
particular of machines and instruments which lessen the demand for human
skill and supervision though they may require more skill from fewer people.
This process of automation is giving rise to far-reaching changes in the pattern
of industry and in the internal organisation and labour requirements of business
enterprises and has already been responsible for consequential increases in
production and efficiency which, in the long run, are likely to be very large.
Much investment, however, still consists of replacements, additions and
improvements of a more traditional kind.
Both the long-term and the short-term growth of productivity thus depend
most directly on the decisions of individual undertakings. But though the
promotion of productivity is regarded as primarily a matter for industry,
government departments and educational and research establishments also
have an important contribution to make. Government budgeting and financial
policies also have a strong influence on the extent and direction of demand,
and government purchasing policies take account of national industrial
objectives. Leading industrialists have been recruited as advisers to the DEA
to help overcome specific obstacles to efficiency and industrial expansion.
They work principally through the Economic Development Committees
(EDCs). Each covers a particular sector of industry and brings together
management, union and government representatives.
Within industry employers’ organisations often provide technical assistance,
conduct market surveys, and support schemes of vocational education and
training, and many trade unions organise special training schemes and courses
to promote understanding of modern management techniques. Changes in
working methods to facilitate higher output feature in a number of produc¬
tivity agreements negotiated between management and workers. Private
consultants specialising in management and work study are available to advise
firms on measures to increase their productive efficiency; there are also many
specialist institutions, both public and private, concerned with various aspects
of productivity. The British Productivity Council (BPC) was established by
both sides of industry to stimulate interest in methods of raising productivity.
It is an independent body on which are represented the Confederation of
British Industry, the Trades Union Congress, the Association of British
Chambers of Commerce, and the nationalised industries; its work is financed
by contributions from these bodies and by a government grant-in-aid. Most
of the BPC’s work is done through 130 local productivity committees and
associations throughout the country, but it is also responsible for special
countrywide campaigns such as the Quality and Reliability Year in 1967. The
local organisations arrange meetings, inter-factory visits, courses, conferences,
film shows and exhibitions.
The British Standards Institution (BSI) is a voluntary non-profit-making
body incorporated by Royal Charter. It prepares and promulgates standards
in respect of, inter alia, quality, performance, dimensions, testing methods and
codes of practice. Voluntary acceptance of such standards by manufacturers,
buyers and sellers reduces unnecessary variety and simplifies the specification
of requirements. The BSI is governed by a council consisting of representa¬
tives of the main organisations of employers and workers, professional
institutions and the larger government departments.
1
248
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The government department primarily concerned is the DEA (see p. 245).
The DEP’s responsibilities (see p. 245) include industrial training policy, and
its Industrial Relations Service advises on personnel management and
industrial relations. The Board of Trade administers the government grants
to the BPC and the Council of Industrial Design. The Ministry of Technology
is charged with extending the introduction of automatic control systems and
advanced techniques into industry, sponsors the BSI, the British Calibration
Service1 and the National Computing Centre, supports the National Dai.a
Processing Service, and provides technical advisory services. It is also
concerned directly with research into such factors as productivity measurement
techniques, group technology, production engineering and fatigue among
operators.
A number of other departments have responsibilities which bear on pro¬
ductivity. The Department of Education and Science and the Scottish
Education Department are responsible for the technical colleges, at which
courses are available in such subjects as work study and industrial engineering.
The Ministry of Power and the British Productivity Council sponsor the
National Industrial Fuel Efficiency Service.
Management In Britain, as elsewhere, there is a growing awareness of the importance of
management as a subject requiring special skills and knowledge. This has been
reflected both in a change in the general educational qualifications of recruits
and in the spread of systematic education and training for management.
The British Institute of Management (BIM) is the central national manage¬
ment body, independent, non-political and non-profit-making. Its purpose is
to study and promote scientific management, including management education
and training, throughout industry, commerce, and public administration. The
Industrial Society works to promote better use of human resources; it advises
members and conducts conferences and courses.
Management studies and education for management are expanding rapidly
in Britain and have become a recognised feature of higher education (see
p. 159). Graduate Business Schools have been established in London and
Manchester. Training courses for higher management are held at certain
universities; by some firms of management consultants; and at the Administra¬
tive Staff College, Henley-on-Thames, and Ashridge College of Management,
Berkhamsted. The larger firms, especially those with wide responsibilities,
often provide general management courses for senior executives, and
systems of informal training within an organisation are numerous. There are
also bodies concerned with specialised branches of management, for example,
the Institute of Personnel Management, the Institution of Works Managers,
the Institute of Office Management and the Institute of Marketing.
The growing number of professional personnel working as management
consultants—now over 3,000—and the use of the services of independent
management selection firms in the appointment of senior staff are indications
of the interest in the science of management in Britain.
Encouragement Under the Industrial Development Act 1966 cash grants were introduced in
of Expansion place of certain tax allowances for capital expenditure on plant or machinery
in Selected used in the manufacturing, extractive and construction industries. The grant
Industries scheme, which is administered by the Board of Trade, also covers capita

expenaiture on computers, ships, hovercraft and mining works. The standard
rate of grant is 20 per cent. In order to maintain a greater incentive to invest¬
ment in development areas (see below) the rate of grant is 40 per cent. A
separate system of grants and loans to encourage hotel development was
announced in March 1968.
Government
Help for
Industry in
Development
Areas
Some parts of Britain have long been less prosperous than others. Their rate of
economic expansion has been below average and their level of unemployment
above average as a result of the decline of some traditional industries or the
lack of job opportunities. For many years unemployment has remained a
persistent problem in Scotland, Wales and the north-east and some other
parts of England. This regional imbalance has been aggravated by the tendency
for new industries to concentrate in the Midlands and the south-east where, as
a result, the demand for labour is high and there are increasing problems of
congestion. An important aim of the Government’s regional policy is to
achieve a better distribution of industrial development between the different
parts of the country. The Government has in recent years taken important
measures aimed at securing balanced economic development.
Government aid to areas of high unemployment began in the 1930s and
has been developed in various ways since the end of the second world war.
Since August 1966 large parts of Britain have been designated as ‘development
areas where industrial development is to be encouraged. They cover northern
England, Merseyside and nearly the whole of Scotland, Wales, Cornwall and
north Devon and contain a fifth of Britain’s working population. The Board
of Trade provides businessmen with detailed information on industrial
location within the development areas and offers a wide variety of inducements
to new or expanding businesses in these areas, the first priority being given
to smaller ‘special areas’.
Besides the capital investment grants there is a wide range of financial and
other inducements available under the Local Employment Acts 1960-66 to
encourage industry to expand in the development areas. The Board of Trade
may build factories for leasing at favourable rents or sale on deferred terms;
make building grants of 25 per cent (and 35 per cent in special cases) of the
cost of an industrialist s own factory; make grants towards unusual expendi¬
ture incurred as a result of siting a project in a development area; and make
loans for the general purposes of an undertaking (for example, working
capital, plant and machinery, etc.). Factory building and estate management
are undertaken on the Board of Trade’s behalf by the English, Scottish and
Welsh Industrial Estates Corporations; premises administered by the three
Corporations total over 60 million square feet and give employment to over
250,000 people.
Assistance from other government departments includes 85 per cent capital
grants to local authorities for clearing derelict or neglected sites and for
improving basic services; and help from the DEP with the cost of training
additional labour in development areas and of transferring workers in
connection with establishing new enterprises.
Employers in the manufacturing industry in development areas are entitled
not only to refund of selective employment tax (see p. 362) but also to a
premium of 7s. 6d. a week for every full-time male adult employee. In addition
they receive regional employment premiums of 30s. a week. (Lower rates for
women, part-timers, boys and girls apply to both premiums.)
Since 1948 control of new industrial building has been exercised through
the use of a system of Industrial Development Certificates. Any application

Councils to

under the normal town and country planning machinery for planning
permission for industrial development involving more than 5,000 square feec
of floor space (or 3,000 square feet in the Midlands and south-east) must be
accompanied by a certificate from the Board of Trade certifying that the
development in question can be carried out consistently with the proper
distribution of industry. In considering applications the Board of Trade is
required to have particular regard to the need for providing appropriate
employment in the development areas. In practice this obligation has led th^
Board of Trade normally to refuse certificates for projects outside the
development areas unless satisfied that the project could not reasonably be
undertaken in a development area or in Northern Ireland. Subject to this
priority, the control is also used to encourage dispersal of industry to new or
expanded towns taking population from the more congested areas. Under the
Control of Office and Industrial Development Act 1965 the Board of Trade
also controls office developments of over 10,000 square feet in the Midlands,
East Anglia and the south-east other than the Metropolitan area of London
where the limit is 3,000 square feet.
Under its own legislation Northern Ireland provides for the payment of
investment grants at 40 per cent of the cost both of new plant and machinery
and of new buildings for the manufacturing, construction and extractive
industries in Northern Ireland. There is also provision for assisting firms by
means of loans to carry out major schemes of re-equipment, to move to
another area in particular need of industrial development or to undertake a
rehousing of their business in association with a major scheme of modernisa¬
tion and reorganisation. Help under the investment grants legislation L
largely made without regard to how much employment is created as a result.
As an alternative means of assistance the Northern Ireland Government
continues to use its comprehensive and flexible powers authorised under the
Industries Development Acts for projects which offer a reasonable amount of
employment. In such cases capital assistance of 45 per cent would normally
be available instead of the 40 per cent referred to above. For those projects
which offer exceptionally attractive returns in employment or location within
Northern Ireland, the assistance offered could include tenancy of a govern¬
ment-built factory at a very low rent, grants towards operating costs in the
initial stages, and grants towards costs of removing existing machinery and
installing it in a factory in Northern Ireland. The regional employment
premium and selective employment premium apply also to Northern Ireland.
Since 1945, 240 new firms have been established in Northern Ireland wit-
government assistance, developments which at present are employing some
64,000 persons. The Ministry of Commerce is the Northern Ireland
government department concerned with the administration of industrial
development policies. The Northern Ireland Economic Council was set up in
1965 to assist in furthering economic growth. The chairman is the Minister
of Commerce and the membership includes representatives of industry,
commerce and the trade unions.
Certain regions and areas in England have industrial development associa¬
tions concerned with promoting local industry. These are sponsored mainly
by local authorities, trade associations and individual firms.
Several voluntary associations are concerned with Welsh industry. The
Development Corporation for Wales, founded in 1959, is the most prominent.
In Scotland, the Highlands and Islands Development Board, set up by
statute in 1965, works to stimulate the economic and social development of
INDUSTRY
Rural Industries
251
the seven crofting’ counties (see p. 310)- It provides grants and loans to
industrial, commercial and other enterprises; it may also acquire land,
provide management and other advisory services and set up and carry on
businesses. The Scottish Council (Development and Industry), a voluntary
association, promotes the general economic development of Scotland.
Encouragement is given to the development of rural industries. Much of this
work is done under the aegis of the Development Commission1 with finance
from the Development Fund, notably advice and guidance to small businesses
in rural areas and country towns and loans for assistance to tourism. In
England and Wales this service is provided by the Council for Small
Industries in Rural Areas acting in consultation with the Rural Community
Councils; in Scotland by the Scottish Council for Small Industries in Rural
Areas. Another service provided by the Commission in Wales has been the
financing of small factories to stimulate rural industries and to combat rural
depopulation.
Under the Finance Act 1968 hotels in certain rural parts of the develop¬

FUEL AND POWER
The main primary sources of energy currently used in Britain are coal,
petroleum and, to a lesser extent, nuclear energy, natural gas and water power;
secondary sources produced from these are electricity, town gas and coke.
Coal, mined within the country, still represents slightly more than half
primary energy consumption, although the amount of coal used and its share
of the total energy market has been falling. Oil, on the other hand, virtually
all imported, has expanded rapidly, its share of total energy consumption
having risen from one-fifth in 1958 to over one-quarter in 1961, and to over
one-third in 1967. With nuclear power and North Sea natural gas likely to
make an increasing impact over the coming years, Britain is changing from two
fuels to four. A programme for nuclear power stations has been in progress for
more than a decade and nuclear power now provides a significant and
increasing share of electricity supplies although it still represents under 5 per
cent of total energy requirements. The share of natural gas, until recently
only imported in liquefied form, is even smaller, but it is expanding more
rapidly from supplies from the North Sea discoveries. Water-power resources
are very small and cannot be developed much further. Trends in primary
energy consumption are shown in Table 17 and in the diagram on p. 252.
The fuel and power industries, with the exception of petroleum, are under
public ownership. General responsibility for the effective and co-ordinated
development of fuel and power resources lies with the Minister of Power.
Research is undertaken by the fuel and fuel-using industries. The Minister
of Power also has an Advisory Council on Research and Development.
The fuel and power industries in Britain employ in total about 850,000
people, or 3J per cent of the working population; their capital investment in
1968-69 will be in the region of £860 million, about one-sixth of total invest¬
ment; their annual turnover is about ^2,700 million; and the value of their

from the Development Fund, established by the Development and Roads Improvements
Fund Acts 1909 and 1910. At the present time the Fund may be used to help and
expand agriculture and rural industries (including accommodation of tourists) and also
to promote the development and improvement of fisheries.

The responsible ministers—the Minister of Power in Engand and Wales

Domestic Coal Consumers’ Councils were set up on 1947 and Area Electricity
and Gas Consultative Councils (supported by district committees) were set up
in 1948 and 1949 respectively. Each consists of a chairman and from 20 to 30
unpaid members appointed from nominations put forward by interested
bodies, mainly local authorities.
COAL
The National
Coal Board
Pattern and
Trends in
Supply and
Demand
Coal has been worked in Britain for over 700 years and an organised coal¬
mining industry has been in existence for over 300 years, some 200 years
longer than in any other country. British coal exports dominated the world
market until about 1910. By 19JS—the peak production year—the industry
was producing 287 million tons of coal, exporting 94 million tons and
employing over a million workers.
In 1947 the coal mines passed into public ownership by means of the Coal
Industry Nationalisation Act 1946, which set up the National Coal Board as
a statutory corporation to manage the industry.
The National Coal Board (NCB) consists of a chairman and between eight
and eleven members appointed by the Minister of Power. The NCB has an
almost complete monopoly to extract coal in Great Britain, and is also
empowered to license private operators to work small pits and open-cast sites.
It has no monopoly in distribution, and retail sales remain largely in private
hands, but it has, however, some retail depots and makes bulk sales to large
industrial consumers.
The NCB is responsible for the day-to-day running and the commercial
management of the industry, but is answerable to the minister (and through
him, to Parliament) for its efficiency. The minister has power to issue
directives on matters affecting the public interest, and to authorise borrowings
to finance capital investment.
The 376 collieries in operation at the end of March 1968 were grouped into
17 areas, each controlled by a director who is responsible to the national
board. A typical area produces 10 million tons of coal a year, employs more
than 20,000 men and has a turnover of about ^55 million.
Coal consumption in Britain increased by an average annual rate of nearly
4 million tons between 194? an<^ I95^> sales fell sharply, however, between
1956 and 1959 and large stocks of coal accumulated at pit heads. Growing
competition from oil, increasing efficiency in the use of coal and reduced
requirements of the gas, steel and other industries contributed to the fall in
demand. Undistributed stocks at the end of 1967 were 27-7 million tons. The
fall in consumption is shown in Table 17.
Over two-fifths of total output is consumed by the electricity authorities
and over one-quarter by domestic and industrial users together. Coke ovens
and the gas industry are other large users. Consumption by the electricity
industry has increased by 22 per cent since 1961 to 67 million tons in 1967,
whereas the requirements of all the other main classes of consumer have
254
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Production and
Manpower
TABLE 18
Coal
Statistics
1950-67
declined. In the case of domestic users this fall has been slightly offset by
increased purchases of solid smokeless fuels.
Coal exports have declined, at first due to increased internal consumption
and, later, to keener competition and the switch to other types of fuel in the
most important markets overseas. Exports fell from the post-war peak of 19
million tons in 1949 to i-8 million tons, valued at £S-6 million, in 1967. The
principal markets are in Western Europe and the Republic of Ireland.
It has been estimated that Britain’s workable reserves of coal will last for
about 200 years at current rates of consumption. However, the very fact that
the British industry was developed so early has meant that many of the best
seams of coal are now worked out 5 every year coal has to be mined from deeper
and thinner seams and productivity can be maintained only by a high level of
re-equipment and constant modernisation.
The main coal-bearing areas are: (1) the Yorkshire, Derbyshire and
Nottinghamshire field, which produces about 48 per cent of the total output,
(2) the Durham and Northumberland field, (3) the South Wales field, and
(4) the Scottish field. Other important coal-bearing areas are those of
Lancashire and the West Midlands (Staffordshire and Warwickshire).

According to forecasts by the Ministry of Power, the fall in coal consump¬
tion shown in Table 17 is likely to continue, but the Government is taking
measures to support consumption with the aim of holding the demand for
coal at around 155 million tons by i97°- The NCB plans to improve the
competitive position of coal by restricting production to the most efficient
pits. The Board estimates that by mid-1970 the number of collieries will be
reduced by one-third to 253 and that manpower in 1971 will be 277,000
compared to 354,000 in May 1968. Productivity has risen by over one-third
since 1961, and over four-fifths of output now comes from new or recon¬
structed collieries, some with a daily output of 6,000 tons and a few of up
to 8,000 tons; at mechanised faces output averages 6-7 tons per shift as
compared with 3-8 tons at non-mechanised faces, the average for all faces
being over 5! tons. In 1967, output per manshift at NCB mines rose to over
1-9 tons, with 26,000 fewer workers. Among measures contributing to higher
INDUSTRY
255
Capital
Investment and
Financial
Structure
Research
PETROLEUM
productivity are new designs for loading and mechanical handling, improved
layouts for pit-bottoms and the extension of horizon mining. Experimental
remotely controlled longwall faces have proved successful at two Midlands
collieries and are being installed in others. The Bevercotes colliery in the
East Midlands, the first in the world to be planned as a fully mechanised and
automated pit from the coal face to the surface, was opened in 1967.
The NCB raises capital, including working capital, by borrowing from the
Exchequer. At present there is a statutory limit of £900 million on such
borrowing. Within its limit the Board may, with the permission of the Minister
of Power, borrow temporarily (by way of overdraft or otherwise). The greater
proportion of investment, however, is financed from internal resources.
Capital expenditure by the industry totalled £462 million from 1947 to
1955 and about £790 million in the nine years 1956 to end-March 1964. At
the end of the 1964-65 financial year the total capital debt to the Exchequer
amounted to about ^960 million. In 1965 legislation was enacted to effect a
capital reconstruction involving the writing off of £415 million of the existing
debt. As a result, the total debt to the Exchequer at the end of March 1968
amounted to £695 million.
Under the nationalisation statute, the NCB has been required to break even
on its current account (taking one year with another) after meeting all proper
charges including provision for reserves. It has made surpluses in some years
and deficits in others. In certain areas, such as Scotland, Lancashire and Wales,
deficits have been persistent, and profits from the areas of high productivity,
for instance, the Midlands, have been inadequate to cover the losses sustained.
By March 1966 the accumulated deficit on the current account had reached
^115-6 million which was included in the £415 million to be written off (see
above). Interest payments and depreciation provisions will be reduced as a
result. In the year ending March 1968 the NCB made an operating profit of
£34-6 million, and after payment of interest there was a surplus of ^0-4
million.
To assist the redeployment of manpower and the elimination of uneconomic
colliery capacity, the Coal Industry Acts 1965 and 1967 authorise the Ministry
of Power to make grants equal to two-thirds of relevant expenditure up to a
maximum aggregate amount of £45 million over the four years to 1971.
The NCB has two research organisations: a Coal Research Establishment,
at Stoke Orchard, near Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, providing facilities for
fundamental research; and a Mining Research and Development Establish¬
ment, near Bretby, Derbyshire, for the investigation of underground problems,
developing new machines and testing equipment. In 1959 the Board set up a
department concerned primarily with the further development of new
processes for making smokeless fuels.
A number of autonomous research associations receiving grants from the
NCB and the Ministry of Technology include the British Coal Utilisation
Research Association, the British Coke Research Association and the Coal Tar
Research Association. Much of the work of other bodies, such as the Safety
in Mines Research Establishment (SMRE), is closely related to the Board’s
problems; the SMRE carries out research on explosions and fires, pneumo¬
coniosis, engineering and metallurgy.
The petroleum industry in Britain dates back to 1850, when Dr. James Young,
a Glasgow chemist, succeeded in obtaining lamp oil and lubricants from
256
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Indigenous
Production
International
Trade
Consumption
natural mineral oil occurring in the Derbyshire coal measures. The Scottish
shale deposits, yielding similar products, were first worked in 1858 and ceased
production in 1962.
Sources of crude oil within Britain meet only 1 ton in every 1,000 of total
United Kingdom requirements, the remainder being imported from overseas.
Annual production of crude oil from indigenous oilfields now totals about
80,000 tons. Prospecting for crude petroleum has so far led to the estab¬
lishment of several small oilfields, notably in Nottinghamshire (Eakring,
Egmanton and Bothamsell), in Leicestershire (Plungar), in Lincolnshire
(Gainsborough) and in Dorset (Kimmeridge).
Seismic prospecting in the North Sea has been going on since 1962. Under
the Continental Shelf Act 1964, the Minister of Power, by a system of licensing
for exploration and production, controls those activities in the areas over the
shelf appertaining to the United Kingdom. Britain’s share of the North Sea
shelf amounts to about 100,000 square miles. Licences covering about 42,000
square miles were issued in 1964 and 1965 (one being in the Irish Sea).
Drilling, which started in 1964, has proved the existence of four major fields
of natural gas capable of commercial production, one of which (West Sole)
started deliveries to the Gas Council in March 1967; production from the
field has already exceeded 100 million cubic feet per day. A substantial
field of natural gas was also located in 1966 in North Yorkshire, near
Scarborough.
British and British-Dutch oil companies have been responsible for developing
the oil resources of many countries to mutual advantage, especially in the
Middle East, Far East, Africa and Caribbean areas.
Today these companies produce more than one-third of all oil entering into
international trade, with a tanker fleet (partly owned by them and partly on
charter) amounting to nearly a quarter of the world’s tanker tonnage. (United
Kingdom registered tanker tonnage is about 12 per cent of the world’s total.)
In 1967 the United Kingdom imported 73-5 million tons of crude oil valued
at £489 million, the largest single item among imported products. Events
in the Middle East and Nigeria in 1967 resulted in Iran (23 per cent) replacing
Kuwait as the largest supplier, followed closely by three countries—Libya,
Saudi Arabia and Venezuela.
Deliveries of petroleum products for inland consumption in 1967 totalled
78-1 million tons, having risen by four-fifths since i960. An outstanding
feature has been the continued rapid advance in the use of black oils. Fuel oil
consumption (excluding refineries) had been expanding by about 9 per cent
a year from i960 to 1966 but the increase in 1967 was only 5 per cent to 30-6
million tons. Demand for gas and diesel oils (excluding those used in road
vehicles) rose by a further 0-5 million tons to 8-i million tons in 1967. Sales
of motor spirit have expanded by an annual average of 6-8 per cent since
i960 and totalled 12-1 million tons in 1967.
The most important uses of gas and diesel oils in 1967 were for non¬
industrial central heating, agricultural tractors and the railways. Electricity
generation accounted for about 24 per cent of total fuel oil consumption,
excluding that used in oil refineries; the steel industry accounted for 14 per
cent; and non-industrial central heating for a further 12 per cent. Of the
remainder, the largest users were the cement, paper-making, general chemical,
glass, engineering, brickmaking and textile industries.

Refineries
Oil Pipelines
Research
ELECTRICITY
SUPPLY
Before 1939 three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s supply of petroleum
products was refined overseas, as it was considered more economical to
refine at the source of production. Since the second world war the industry
has favoured the siting of refineries in the consuming areas.
At the end of 1967 rated refinery capacity in Britain amounted to 84 million
tons a year. Of the 19 refineries in operation, three have a capacity of under
0-2 million tons. The seven largest are situated at Fawley, near Southampton
(16-5 million tons); Stanlow, in Cheshire (10-5 million tons); Isle of Grain
(10 million tons) and Shellhaven (10 million tons), both on the Thames
Estuary; two at Milford Haven in Pembrokeshire (6-3 million tons and 5-1
million tons); and at Llandarcy near Swansea (8 million tons). Other important
refineries are located at Belfast, on the Firth of Forth (Grangemouth), at
Billingham-on-Tees, Heysham (Lancs) and Coryton (Essex). These, and
other projects in hand or planned (notably on Humberside and Teesside,
both of which will become important refining areas), will bring Britain’s total
capacity to over 100 million tons a year by the end of 1968.
Output of refined products (excluding refineries’ own consumption) has
risen steadily; from 4 million tons in 1948 to 25! million tons in 1954, 40
million tons in i960 and the peak total of 67 million tons in 1967. There is a
substantial external trade in refined products which tends to follow trading
and seasonal requirements and the commercial arrangements of the major oil
companies. Exports from Britain, mainly in the form of heavier products
to European countries, were valued at £114 million in 1967; imports of
refined products (including liquefied gases) amounted to £227 million.
Three main crude oil pipelines are in operation in Britain between harbours
capable of berthing very large tankers and refineries: in west Scotland, from
Finnart to Grangemouth; in South Wales, from Angle Bay, Milford Haven,
to Llandarcy; and in north-west England, from Tranmere to Heysham.
Pipelines carry refined products from refineries to major marketing areas; for
example, from Stanlow to the Manchester area, from Fawley to Staines and
London Airport, and from the Isle of Grain to Walton-on-Thames and London
Airport. Nearing completion is a pipeline system to feed refined products to
north London and the Midlands from refineries and installations on the Thames
and Mersey; a similar line is planned from Milford Haven to the Midlands and
Manchester. Pipelines carrying petrochemical feedstocks run from Stanlow
to Carrington, near Manchester, from Fawley to Severnside, near Bristol, and
from Teesside to Fleetwood and Runcorn. The Pipelines Act 1962 is designed
to secure the orderly development of privately owned industrial pipelines.
Research into problems of petroleum technology is carried out mainly by the
leading oil companies, which have also endowed research at the universities
on a substantial scale. Research centres are situated at Sunbury-on-Thames
(the British Petroleum Company), Thornton, in Cheshire, and Woodstock,
in Kent (Shell), and Abingdon, in Berkshire (Esso). The first of these covers
the full range of petroleum research and development, from geology and
production to product utilisation and petroleum chemicals. In general, the
remainder are concerned with the evolution of new and improved fuels and
lubricants and the development of new uses for petroleum products and of
new products based on petroleum, especially chemicals.
A public supply of electricity was first provided in Britain in 1881, at
Godaiming, Surrey. From its earliest days a measure of public control has
258
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Present
Structure
England and Wales
Scotland
been a feature of the industry. In 1919 the Electricity Commissioners were
created as a supervisory body and to promote reorganisation on a national
scale through voluntary agreement. In 1926 the Central Electricity Board
was set up to construct and operate a national grid inter-connecting individual
power stations, thus co-ordinating generation and transmission. In 1943 the
North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board (NSHEB) was established as a
public corporation to develop the water-power resources of the Highlands.
In 1948 all municipal and private undertakings (other than those in Northern
Ireland) were acquired under the Electricity Act 1947 an^ vested in the
British Electricity Authority and 14 regional boards, except in the north of
Scotland where they became the responsibility of the NSHEB. Two
subsequent Acts (1954 and 1957) effected a measure of decentralisation and
gave the industry its present structure. Electricity supply employs about
255,000 people, including 5,400 in Northern Ireland.
In England and Wales, electricity is generated and transmitted by the Central
Electricity Generating Board (CEGB) and distributed by 12 separate Area
Electricity Boards; co-ordination is effected by the Electricity Council. In
Scotland, two boards—the NSHEB and the South of Scotland Electricity
Board (SSEB)—both generate and distribute electricity. In Northern Ireland,
the Belfast Corporation and the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland generate
and distribute electricity, and the Londonderry Corporation distributes only.
The Electricity Council is the central body of the supply industry with
responsibility for general policy and programmes and for advising the
Minister of Power; it is also responsible for a number of common services,
principally capital financing, research and industrial relations. The Council
consists of a chairman, two deputy chairmen, the chairman and two designated
members of the CEGB, the chairmen of the 12 Area Electricity Boards and
not more than three other members. The CEGB controls the operation and
maintenance of power stations and the main transmission system (the national
grid) and supplies electricity in bulk to the 12 Area Boards. The CEGB
consists of a chairman, a deputy chairman and between six and eight
members. Each of the 12 Area Electricity Boards acquires bulk supplies of
electricity from the CEGB and is responsible for distribution networks and
sales of electricity to its area consumers.
Area Consultative Councils were set up under the Electricity Act 1947 in
the area of each Board to represent the interests of consumers; their chairmen
are ex officio members of their respective Area Boards. The Minister of Power
appoints the chairmen, deputy chairmen and members of the Electricity
Council, the CEGB, the Area Boards and the Consultative Councils; approves
each Board’s capital development programmes and the industry’s research
programme; and approves, in consultation with the Treasury, the industry s
borrowing requirements. The Electricity Act 195? requires each Board,
and not merely the industry as a whole, to pay its way taking one year with
another.
The boundary separating the areas covered by the two Scottish Boards runs
roughly from Dumbarton on the Firth of Clyde to Newburgh on the Firth of
Tay. Members of both Boards and of the respective consumer consultative
councils are appointed by the Secretary of State for Scotland; each Board
comprises a chairman and between four and eight members. The Secretary of
State’s responsibilities in relation to the Boards are similar to those of the
Minister of Power.

In Northern Ireland electricity is generated at power stations in Belfast and
at Ballylumford and Coolkeeragh. Those in Belfast are operated by the city
corporation and the remainder by the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland.
Generation is co-ordinated by the Northern Ireland Joint Electricity
Authority, set up by statute in 1967. The output of the stations has, since
1948, been purchased in bulk and re-sold to distributors—the Belfast
Corporation for Belfast and district, the Londonderry Corporation for the City
of Londonderry, and the Electricity Board for the rest of Northern Ireland.
As Britain has abundant supplies of coal, together with good rail and water
transport for moving it, most of its electricity is produced by coal-fired steam
generating stations. Hydro-electric development on any scale is comparatively
recent, water-power resources being relatively small and in remote areas.
Since 1965, nuclear energy has become increasingly important.
The output capacity of the generating stations of the electricity boards in
Great Britain at the end of 1967 totalled 46,622 megawatts (MW), an increase
of over one-quarter since 1963.
In the years 1963 to 1967 an annual average of over 2,500 MW of
generating capacity was installed, including 2,500 MW in 1966 and 3,800 MW
in 1967. About 25,000 MW of capacity will come into operation in England and
Wales in the period 1968-72 inclusive. The SSEB’s plans provide for its total
capacity of 3,293 MW at the end of 1967 to be increased to 5,600 MW by 1970.
Sales of electricity in Northern Ireland (where, of the total installed
generating capacity of 918 MW, 360 MW is in oil-fired and the remainder in
coal-fired thermal stations) amounted to 2,800 million kilowatt-hours in 1967.
Generation by the public supply in Great Britain exceeded 187,000 million
kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 1967; conventional steam power stations provided
86 per cent of the total and hydro-electric and nuclear stations about 3 per
cent and 11 per cent respectively. The high rate of expansion of output,
which has been a feature of the industry since its earliest years, was not
maintained during 1966 and 1967, although the total of electricity generated
in 1967 was still nearly 50 per cent higher than in 1961.
Generation of electricity outside the public supply system is relatively
small—under 20,000 million kWh in 1967. The major sources outside the
fuel industries themselves are the chemical, iron and steel and paper industries
and the nuclear power plants of the Atomic Energy Authority (AEA).

There are 12 oil-burning power stations, or parts of stations, operating in
Great Britain (excluding old stations converted to oil-firing to conform with
clean air legislation). They are mainly situated on river estuaries and thus
able to be fed conveniently from oil refineries. Oil-fired stations of 2,000
MW are under construction at Fawley, on Southampton Water, and at
Pembroke, South Wales. A dual-fired station of the same size, to burn either
coal or oil, is being built at Kingsnorth, Kent.
The electricity authorities are the largest consumers of primary fuel in
Britain, and although most of their electricity generation is based on coal, oil
consumption rose from a negligible quantity in 1955 to over 5'5 million tons
in 1962; consumption in 1967 was 7-3 million tons. Average thermal efficiency
(that is, the ratio of the electrical energy output to the heat energy input of the
fuel consumed) of conventional steam stations in England and Wales rose from
20-75 per cent in 1947 to 27-87 per cent in 1967 as new plant was brought into
use. The 20 most efficient stations, containing much of the newest plant, had
an average efficiency of 32-93 per cent in 1967.
Striking advances have been made in the design of steam-generating plant.
A cross-compound generating unit with an output capacity of 55° MW came
into operation in 1963 at Thorpe Marsh, near Doncaster. Forty-seven single¬
shaft units of 500 MW are being installed in 13 stations. The first came
into operation at the Ferrybridge ‘C’ station, Yorks, in 1966. Others were
completed during 1967 West Burton (near Retford, Notts), Eggborough
(Selby, Yorks), and Ratcliffe-on-Soar (Notts). Station capacities are also
increasing. By 1971, ten stations, each with capacities of 2,000 MW, with four
500 MW single-shaft generating units, will be in service. Three larger
generating units, of 660 MW\ will be installed at Drax (\orks), which may
have a final capacity of nearly 4,000 MW. For locations see map, inside back
cover. In Scotland, a 1,200 MW station at Cockenzie was commissioned in
1968 and one of 2,400 MW (four generating units of 600 MW) is under
construction at Longannet.
Large gas turbine units of 55 MW and 70 MW, based on aero jet engines,
have been introduced since 1965 for peak load operation. The CEGB and
SSEB have installed 919 MW of such units. Smaller gas turbines have been
introduced at new stations to safeguard the auxiliary supplies to the large new
steam units, and also to provide capacity for peak operation. Auxiliary units
of this kind in service at the end of 1967 totalled 452 MW, and by 1972 will
exceed 1,100 MW.
Hydro-electric generation is confined to Scotland and Wales, and most of the
water-power so utilised is drawn from high-level reservoirs with their own
natural catchment areas. The setting up of the NSHEB in 1943 marked the
beginning of an era of intensive water-power development m the Highlands.
In 1967-68, 3,225 million units were sent out by the NSHEB from water¬
power, compared with 322 million in 1949. At the end of March 1968 there
were 50 main hydro electric conventional stations in operation in the north
of Scotland with a total installed capacity of 1,047 MW and the largest—the
Loch Sloy station—has a capacity of 130 MW. The Cruachan pumped
storage section of the Awe scheme, with an installed capacity of 400 MW
from four reversible-pump-turbines, came into full operation at the end of
1967. The Board published in 1968 plans for a 300 MW pumped-storage pro¬
ject at Foyers, Loch Ness. It will have two 150 MW reversible-pump-turbines.
In addition, there are stations generating electricity by water-power in the south
of Scotland (122 MW) and in Wales (472 MW). The latter includes the 360
INDUSTRY
26l
MW pumped-storage station at Ffestiniog, which was completed in 1963.
(In pumped-storage schemes electricity generated in off-peak periods is used to
pump water to higher levels from which it descends at peak periods to operate
turbo-generators.)
Nuclear Power Some 11 per cent of Britain’s public supply generation was in nuclear power
Stations stations in 1967 and the proportion is expected to rise to about 13 per cent by
1970. Britain has so far produced as much electricity by this means as the
rest of the world put together.
The AEA itself has five main stations which produce electricity for the
national grid: Calder Hall, in Cumberland (198 MW electrical output);
Chapelcross, Dumfriesshire (191 MW); the Advanced Gas-Cooled Reactor
(AGR) at Windscale, Cumberland (34 MW); the experimental fast breeder
station at Dounreay, Caithness (14 MW); and the Steam Generating Heavy
Water Moderated Reactor (SGHWR) at Winfrith, Dorset (100 MW).
Others are owned and operated by the electricity authorities. Under the
first commercial programme, originally announced in 1955 but since twice
modified, nine stations with a total capacity of nearly 5,000 MW should be
in operation by 1969. So far eight (over 3,600 MW) have started operation:
Berkeley, in Gloucestershire (276 MW output capacity), and Bradwell, in
Essex (300 MW), were both commissioned in 1962; Hunterston ‘A’, in
Scotland (300 MW), in 1964; and in the following year Hinkley Point ‘A’, in
Somerset, Trawsfyndd, in Wales (both 500 MW), and Dungeness ‘A’, in
Kent (550 MW); Sizewell, in Suffolk (580 MW), was commissioned in 1966;
Oldbury, in Gloucestershire (600 MW), in 1968; and Wylfa, in Anglesey (1,180
MW), should be completed by 1969. These stations, like Calder Hall and
Chapelcross, are all magnox stations—graphite-moderated, carbon-dioxide
cooled using natural uranium metal fuel elements canned in magnesium.
Under a second programme announced in 1964 and extended in 1965, a
further 8,000 MW of nuclear capacity is planned by about 1975. The first
station in this programme, Dungeness ‘B’, due to begin operating in 1970, is
based on the AGR at Windscale which uses slightly enriched uranium
dioxide fuel canned in stainless steel, a logical development of the magnox
system. When in full operation with a net electrical output of 1,200 MW, it
will be the most powerful in the world, and the first in Britain to produce
electricity more cheaply on base load than the best contemporary coal stations.
The second and third stations, Hinkley Point ‘B’ and Hunterston ‘B’, are
under construction, and will come into service in 1972 and 1973 respectively.
The fourth station at Seaton Carew has been authorised.
A large prototype fast reactor (PER) of 250 MW capacity is being built by
the AEA, to be completed in 1971, at Dounreay where in October 1962 the
experimental fast reactor became the first of such type to produce electricity
for public use and to operate at a high power level.
Transmission Main electricity transmission lines—the national grid—supply most of the
and country. By 31st March 1967 those of the CEGB totalled 17,528 circuit miles,
Distribution of which 1,314 miles were 400,000 volt, 3,973 miles 275,000 volt, 11,650 miles
132,000 volt and the remainder were 66,000 volt and below. In Scotland there
were some 4,350 circuit miles of main transmission lines at the end of March
1967, of which 1,300 circuit miles operated at 275,000 volts and the remainder
at 132,000 volts. Energy movements on the grid in England and Wales are
controlled through the eight operational areas, set up for that purpose and
distinct from the regions in which the generating side of the industry is
organised; each area has a separate control, and the operations are
262
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Capital
Investment
Research
co-ordinated by a National Control in London. The grid in Scotland is operated
from the control centres at Pitlochry (NSHEB) and at Kirkintilloch (SSEB).
To reduce the number of new transmission lines needed to meet the
country’s increasing power demands, most of the new ‘supergrid’ of main
transmission lines now operating at 275,000 volts are, since 1965, being up¬
rated to operate at 400,000 volts. The development of the grid system has
made the British system the largest integrated power network in the world.
Twin cross-Channel cables laid between Dungeness and Boulogne, capable
of transmitting up to 160 MW at 200,000 volts (direct current), have been
in operation since 1961; by this means advantage is taken of the differences
between France and Britain in the timing of peak loads.
A direct current transmission link to reinforce supplies in the London area
is being installed; due for completion in 1970, the scheme—the first of its
kind in the world—will have a capacity of 640 MW.
In England and Wales the Area Electricity Boards distribute to consumers
electricity acquired mainly from the CEGB, supplemented from other
sources, such as industrial plants and the nuclear power stations of the AEA.
There are over 17-5 million consumers. Industrial concerns are the biggest
users of electricity. The principal domestic uses of electricity are for lighting,
cooking and for space and water heating, but the demand for numerous other
domestic purposes is rising steadily.
The NSHEB has about 450,000 consumers, many in remote areas. The
SSEB supplies about 1-5 million consumers.
About 10 per cent of the annual gross fixed capital formation of the United
Kingdom in 1967 was attributable to the electricity supply industry. The
industry in recent years has based its capital needs for five years ahead on an
average annual increase in demand of about 7 to 9 per cent; its plans up to
r973-74 are based on an average annual growth of 7-2 per cent.
Capital expenditure of the electricity supply industry has been expanding
very rapidly: from ^249 million in 1956 it rose to £364 million in 1961 and
£694 million in 1967. More than two-fifths of the industry’s capital require¬
ments have been financed from internal resources. The statutory limit to
borrowings by the industry in Great Britain is £4,980 million.
The Electricity Council, in consultation with the Minister of Power, is
responsible for drawing up a general programme of research, comprising:
direct research carried out by the Electricity Boards themselves, supported
by co-operative research with selected industrial research associations and by
research contracts placed with universities and other organisations. The
Council itself is empowered to conduct research. It is advised by the Elec¬
tricity Supply Research Council. Collaboration on research between the supply
industry and the plant manufacturers is co-ordinated by the Power Engin¬
eering Research Steering Committee set up in 1966.
The main research establishments of the industry are run by the CEGB and
comprise the Central Electricity Research Laboratories at Leatherhead,
Surrey, the Berkeley Laboratories in Gloucestershire, concerned with
nuclear problems, and the Engineering Laboratories at Marchwood, on
Southampton Water. In 1965 the Electricity Council established a research
centre at Capenhurst, Cheshire, at which intensive research is being under¬
taken on distribution problems (to supplement the work undertaken at the
Central Electricity Research Laboratories) and on appliances and methods of
electricity utilisation.

INDUSTRY 263
Both Scottish electricity boards carry out research and experimental work
either on their own or in co-operation with other electricity authorities. The
NSHEB undertakes a side range of research and development work, both
independently and in conjunction with the universities and manufacturers.
The SSEB has recently extended its own research activities and, with the
NSHEB, is associated with those of the Electricity Council and CEGB.
Public supply of gas in Britain dates from 1807, when Pall Mall, London,
was first lighted with gas. In 1812 the London and Westminster Gas Light
and Coke Company received a Royal Charter to supply gaslight in London.
In the early years of the industry gas was used almost exclusively for lighting,
provided by a growing number of company and municipal undertakings.
The gas industry in its present form developed in the main during the
period between the two world wars when increasing competition from
electricity had to be met, and by 1939 the industry had become mainly a
supplier of heating rather than lighting.
The Gas Act of 1948 brought the industry in Great Britain, in which about
123,000 persons are at present employed, under public ownership and control
on 1 st May 1949. The assets of 991 undertakings, of which 269 belonged to
local authorities, were vested in 12 Area Gas Boards. The central body is
the Gas Council, appointed by the Minister of Power. It is both a co¬
ordinating council and, since the enactment of the Gas Act 1965, a trading
body. It consists of a full-time chairman and deputy chairman, the 12 chair¬
men of the area boards and up to five other members. Its general duties are to
advise the Minister on questions affecting the industry and promote the
efficient performance of their duties by the area boards. It also has specific
duties relating to finance, labour relations and research.
The Area Gas Boards, which have a large measure of financial and opera¬
tional responsibility and are similar in most respects to the central bodies
of the other publicly owned corporations, are responsible for the local
manufacture of gas and its distribution to consumers. Each of the Area Gas
Boards, appointed by the Minister of Power, consists of a full-time chairman
and deputy chairman, in some cases one or more full-time members, and
usually five or six part-time members, including the chairman of the Area
Consultative Council. There is no common pattern of organisation; each
board is fully independent and has devised its own subordinate structure.
Each is required to pay its way, taking one year with another. The operations
of the area boards have resulted, in the 18 years up to 31st March 1967, in an
aggregate disposable surplus of approximately .£75 million before taxation.
In Northern Ireland the gas supply industry remains in the hands of a
number of municipal undertakings and statutory and non-statutory companies.
The chief method of gas production in Britain used to be by carbonising coal
but oil-based production is expanding markedly; more than half of gas
supplied in 1967 was derived from oil, and 4-1 million tons were used, four
times the amount in 1962. The gas industry used about 17 million tons of
coal (25 million tons in 1958) and another 24 million tons were carbonised
in coke ovens other than those of the gas industry.
About one-third of the output of gas from coke ovens is sold to gas under¬
takings for general distribution; the remainder is mainly consumed at the
ovens or at steelworks. There are about 13 million consumers, the total having
shown no significant change since 1955. Manufactured gas and gas acquired

from coke ovens and other sources for distribution is about 4,500 million
therms1 annually.
In 1967 the quantity of gas produced in Northern Ireland was about
29 million therms, most of it for household use.
Three-fifths of all gas sold by gas boards is for household use and the remainder
for industrial and commercial purposes. Total consumption has been rising at
an average rate of about 7 per cent per annum since 1961, after a period when
growth was almost negligible. Sales reached a level of about 3,750 million
therms in 1967.
About 40 per cent of the domestic load is used for cooking and space heating
and water heating account for the largest part of the remainder. Most homes
in Britain are supplied with gas, except in some rural areas where, owing to
difficulties in storage and transmission, mains gas is not economic, and bottled
gas, derived from petroleum, is widely used.
Gas is used extensively in industries which require the control of temperatures
to a fine degree of accuracy, for example, in the pottery industry and in
certain processes in the manufacture of iron and steel products. In 1966-67
sales of gas to industry totalled 908 million therms.
Production of coke at gas works in 1967 was 6-2 million tons (a fall of one-fifth
in two years) and at coke ovens 15-3 million tons, reflecting the increasing use
of oil. The gas industry and coke ovens jointly produce about 2 million tons
of crude coal tar and about 80 million gallons of crude benzole a year. These
latter by-products yield materials widely employed in the newer branches of
the chemical industry.
Under the Gas Act 1948, borrowing by the Gas Council and the Area Gas
Boards was limited to £250 million. In 1954 the industry’s borrowing powers
were increased to ^450 million, in i960 to £525 million, in 1963 to £650
million, in 1965 to £1,200 million and in 1968 to an interim limit of £1,600
million with provision for a further increase to £2,400 million.
The industry had been spending about £50 million a year on capital
investment in the period 1955 to 1961 but since 1961-62 expenditure has
increased sharply; in 1967-68 it reached £272 million and £300 million is
planned for 1968-69. Between vesting day (1st May 1949) and the end of
March 1968 about £1,500 million had been invested in fixed assets.
Considerable integration, by the linking of works for the transmission of gas
through gas grids and long-distance mains, has enabled production to be
concentrated in the most efficient units.
To maintain its competitive position, the gas industry has investigated
new and more economic methods of production and new sources of gas
supply. There have been significant developments in the gasification of oil.
The introduction of processes using light distillates in large units producing
gas at high pressure has permitted savings in both capital and running costs.
The work done in the Gas Council’s Midlands Research Station led to the
introduction of two new methods of manufacture, the Gas Recycle Hydro-
genator and the Catalytic Rich Gas processes, both of which enable a high
calorific value gas to be manufactured entirely from light distillate feedstock
