without the need for enrichment from any outside source. The first plants
incorporating these processes were put on stream in 1965. Gas made from
oil, gas purchased from refineries and natural gas now amount to over half of
the total supply available and the proportion is steadily increasing.
Since 1964 deliveries of natural gas from the Sahara have been made in liquid
form to Britain. A pipeline system distributes the gas from a terminal on
Canvey Island to 8 of the 12 Area Gas Boards.
The first productive well in the North Sea was discovered in 1965. Four
major gasfields have now been located as well as a number of smaller structures.
The Ministry of Power has estimated that production could exceed 3,000
million cubic feet per day by 1975 and the Gas Council is switching over
entirely to natural gas within the next ten years.
The first pipeline to pump natural gas to the shore, at Easington in
Yorkshire, was put on flow early in 1967. The second pipeline, which comes
ashore at Bacton in Norfolk, came on flow in August 1968.
The Gas Council expects gas consumption to increase by some 12 per
cent a year up to 1972 and therefore substantial expansion is required. The
need to provide additional storage capacity, and the strengthening of the
distribution system will also give rise to substantial investment.
The Gas Council has a research committee which advises on research policy
at the four research centres. Research is also carried out on behalf of the Gas
Council at a number of universities and colleges.
Efficiency in the use of fuel, among both industrial and domestic users, has
been assisted by various bodies representing producers and consumers and
by the technical advisory services of the fuel and power industries.
The Coal Utilisation Council consists of representatives of the National
Coal Board, solid fuel distributors and appliance manufacturers and distri¬
butors. Originally formed in 1932, it informs and advises domestic users
on the best use of solid fuel, including the choice of installation and the
operation of solid fuel appliances.
A non-profit-making company, the National Industrial Fuel Efficiency
Service, was formed in 1954 and sponsored by the fuel and power industries
to promote fuel saving in industry. In addition to consultancy work, it provides
advice and services to all non-domestic fuel users in a variety of forms, from
‘spot’ inspection to full-scale surveys and regular visits on a contract basis.
WATER SUPPLY
Britain’s water resources are, with progressive development, sufficient for
domestic and industrial requirements. The sources of water are often distant
from the areas where supplies are needed, however, and water undertakings
are therefore mainly concerned with abstraction, storage, treatment and
distribution. Supplies are obtained partly from surface sources such as
mountain lakes, streams impounded in upland gathering grounds and river
intakes, and partly from underground sources by means of wells, adits and
boreholes. Unlike other public services in Great Britain, such as electricity and
gas, water supply remains in the hands of a large number of undertakings.
Ministerial responsibility in England and Wales is shared by the Minister of
Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of State for Wales; in
Scotland it lies with the Secretary of State for Scotland; and in Northern
Ireland with the Minister of Development.
266
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
England and
Wales
Organisation
Present Supplies
It was not until the nineteenth century that the provision of water supplies
became a general public service, largely due to the efforts of Edwin Chadwick
and his colleagues who demonstrated the dangers arising from inadequate
water supply and sanitation. The Public Health Act 1848 laid the basis for
a long series of statutes dealing with public health. From the middle of the
nineteenth century onwards a number of water undertakings were set up
to provide water to the expanding urban population, and the water supply
system developed rapidly, although in piecemeal fashion and with some
overlapping and waste.
Local authorities have a duty as sanitary authorities to ensure that water
supplies are adequate for the needs of their areas, and they may do this
either by operating water undertakings themselves or by ensuring that other
bodies are providing adequate supplies. Over one-fifth of the water consumed
is supplied by statutory water companies. The householder receives his
domestic water supply at a comparatively small charge, varying in different
areas, which he usually pays by way of a water rate levied, like other rates,
on the value of his house. Industrial users are charged in most cases according
to actual material consumption.
The Minister of Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of
State for Wales have a duty to promote the conservation and proper use of
water supplies in England and Wales and are advised by the Central Advisory
Water Committee on general questions relating to water and organisation of
supplies. Since the passing of the Water Act 1945, over 800 smaller water
authorities in England and Wales have been absorbed by larger authorities or
by the creation of joint boards in order to improve the efficiency of the water
supply industry. There are now some 270 statutory water undertakings of
which about two-thirds are local authorities. A number of private proprietors
without statutory powers also provide small supplies.
The largest undertaking in Britain is the Metropolitan Water Board, which
supplies over 360 million gallons daily to 6J million people in the London
area. It consists of 39 part-time members who are the elected representatives
of the various local authorities within the Board’s area of operations, together
with one representative each from the Thames and Lee Conservancies.
Public water supplies in England and Wales—reaching over 99 per cent of
the total population—now total some 2,629 million gallons a day, out of a total
estimated abstraction of 5,000 million gallons a day (excluding water used for
cooling in connection with electricity generation). Capital expenditure by
water undertakings, which averaged about £58 million a year in the period
1961-65, has risen to over £75 million a year. Interest, with running costs,
are largely met from annual income.
The provision of piped supplies for rural districts has been assisted by
grants under the Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Acts 1944 to 1965. By
March 1968 schemes costing over ^108 million had been completed or were
in progress with the aid of grants under these Acts.
The Water Resources Act 1963, which came into full operation in April
1965, created a new administrative structure consisting of 27 river authorities
and a central Water Resources Board to meet the growing domestic, industrial
and farm irrigation needs. The river authorities, the Thames Conservancy
and the Lee Conservancy Catchment Board have a majority of members
appointed by the county and county borough councils in their areas. The
remainder are appointed by ministers mainly for their knowledge of land
drainage, fisheries, the public water supply, and water in use in industry and
in agriculture. The authorities manage the water resources of river basins
INDUSTRY
Scotland
Northern
Ireland
Measurement
of Resources
267
and carry out other functions in respect of land drainage, flood control,
administration of fisheries and prevention of pollution. They are responsible
for assessing water resources and requirements, controlling and developing
resources and securing regulation by a system of licensing. Special arrange¬
ments exist for the Greater London area, where the full range of river authority
control is not necessary. The work of the river authorities is co-ordinated by
the Water Resources Board, an expert advisory body which reports to the
Ministry of Housing and Local Government. Its duties include the review of
national water resources and requirements, the encouragement of the transfer
of water between areas according to need, the co-ordination of proposals of
river authorities for capital investment and the initiation of research. From
1969 water conservation is to be financially self-supporting, the cost being met
from charges levied by river authorities on the abstractors and users of water.
The administrative arrangements for water supply and distribution in
Scotland were reorganised by the Water (Scotland) Act 1967 under which
the functions of 200 local water authorities were transferred to 13 regional
water boards, as from 16th May 1968. The Act also established the Central
Scotland Water Development Board which supplies water in bulk to its seven
constituent regional water boards; it does not supply direct to individual
consumers. All the members of these boards are members of town or county
councils.
The water problem in Scotland is broadly similar to that in England and
Wales except that there is not the same need to allocate water between
competing interests and less reliance needs to be placed on underground
sources. The Secretary of State for Scotland is responsible for general
oversight and co-ordination and has a general duty to promote the conservation
of water resources in Scotland; and to require regional water boards to
provide supplies of wholesome water everywhere in their districts, where
this can be done at reasonable cost; at present, they supply about 97 per cent
of the total population. The Scottish Water Advisory Committee advises the
Secretary of State on general questions relating to resources and supplies.
The Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Act 1944, as amended, makes
available to Scottish local authorities grant assistance up to a maximum of
£45 million towards the cost of water supplies and sewerage schemes in
rural areas.
Northern Ireland has abundant supplies of water for both domestic and
industrial consumption. Under the Water Supplies and Sewerage Act
(Northern Ireland) 1945, water supply authorities must provide a supply of
wholesome water to houses and schools in their areas where this could be
done at reasonable cost; the Minister of Development may make grants
towards the costs of schemes undertaken by these authorities. Most households
have now been, or soon will be, connected to a piped supply and present
daily supplies of around 90 million gallons will shortly be considerably
increased.
Information on the yield, behaviour and quantity of the nation’s surface
water resources is provided in the Surface Water Year Book of Great Britain,
published annually by Her Majesty’s Stationery Office. This publication
contains particulars of the run-off and related rainfall from a large number of
rivers, streams and reservoired areas. The Water Resources Board is respon¬
sible for the gauging, collation and publication of hydrological information:
268
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Barrages
Pollution
Structure
the field work of surface water measurement is done by river authorities, water
undertakings and other bodies. Detailed studies of the resources and use of
water in specified areas have been published in the series of Hydrological
Surveys which cover approximately half of England and Wales, General
information on rainfall, published annually in British Rainfall, is the
responsibility of the Meteorological Office, while advice on ground water is the
responsibility of the Water Resources Board. The Hydraulics Research Station
of the Ministry of Technology at Wallingford and the Water Research
Association’s station at Medmenham carry out research into problems of the
design and calibration of gauging weirs and flumes for the measurement of
surface water, and into other hydraulic problems.
Full-scale feasibility studies are being made of barrages across Morecambe
Bay and the Dee estuary. A preliminary ‘desk study’ has also been carried out
at Solway Firth, and one is in progress for the Wash. Barrage projects involve
dams across or within tidal estuaries to form a lake of fresh water.
Each river authority is responsible for the control of pollution of rivers
and certain tidal waters in its area and its approval must be sought before
polluting effluents are discharged. Control of pollution in the tidal Thames
is exercised by the Port of London Authority. In Scotland nine river purifica¬
tion boards have been set up. The Secretary of State for Scotland is advised
by the Scottish River Purification Advisory Committee on questions affecting
the cleanliness of Scottish rivers. In several ports the petroleum companies
co-operate in the prevention of oil pollution from tankers and refineries.
The Water Pollution Research Laboratory at Stevenage investigates
problems connected with the treatment of polluted water, the treatment
and disposal of sewage and industrial waste water, and the effects and
prevention of pollution of surface water and underground water. Research is
carried out with general supervision and advice from the Water Pollution
Research Board.
CONSTRUCTION
The construction industry includes firms engaged on the construction,
alteration, repair and maintenance of buildings, highways, airfields, drainage
and sewerage systems, waterworks, docks, harbours and canals, sea defence
works, electrical wiring, heating and other installation work, open-cast coal
prospecting and mining, and structural work connected with thermal and
hydro-electric power stations and telecommunications. About i-8 million
people are engaged on construction in both the public and private sectors.
They represent about 7 per cent of the total labour force and their net
output provides about 7 per cent of the gross national product.
The construction industry is gradually adopting metric in place of Imperial
weights and measures; the change is due to be completed in 1972.
Constructional work is carried out both by private contractors and by public
authorities who employ their own labour. Over five-sixths of the work is
done by private firms. Although there are over 80,000 firms in the industry,
more than a fifth of them are one-man businesses. At the other end of the
scale are over 220 firms each with more than 600 employees.
Public authorities as a whole employ about 370,000 operatives but a very
large proportion of these are engaged on repair and maintenance work which
local authorities, for example, carry out with their own labour.
INDUSTRY
Output
Housing
Civil
Engineering
Projects
269
Over 40 per cent of operatives are occupied on building maintenance,
valued at over £1,100 million annually. The total labour force includes about
800,000 skilled craftsmen, who have been trained for four or five years under
the industry’s apprenticeship schemes. A further 112,000 are employed as
apprentices.
Some firms are vertically integrated, owning quarries and workshops,
mechanised plant and standard builders’ equipment; some undertake respon¬
sibility for projects from initial design to finished building. All but the
smallest projects are generally carried out under professional direction, either
by architects or, in the case of the more complicated civil engineering projects,
by consulting engineers. The functions of the latter, acting on behalf of a
client, embrace advice on the feasibility of projects, the drawing up of plans
and the supervision of the constructional work by the contractor.
The Ministry of Public Building and Works (see p. 55) is responsible for
all the construction programmes undertaken directly by the Government
(except for roads), including work for the armed services, both at home and
overseas. It is also responsible for co-ordinating research and development
throughout the government service and seeks to influence methods and
techniques in the building industry as a whole.
The output of the industry has been rising steadily over many years. The
value of work done in 1967 amounted to £4,232 million, of which £617
million represented work carried out by the labour employed directly by
public authorities. Private contractors carried out the remaining £3,654
million (£2,906 million on new work and £748 million on repair work).
About 450,000 houses were started in 1967 and some 405,000 were completed,
of which 201,000 were for private owners. Of the £1,172 million of new
housing carried out by private contractors, £586 million, or just under half,
was for private owners and the remainder for public authorities. Increasing
use is being made of industrialised building methods employing prefabricated
components.
The National Building Agency, which was set up by the Government in
1964, is an independent advisory body, managed by a board of directors
appointed by the Minister of Housing and Local Government and the
Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales, and financed by a government
grant and the fees which it earns. Its main function is to encourage the
adoption of advanced methods of housebuilding, especially industrialised
building methods, as well as to provide technical advice and services, in
particular to local authorities. The Ministry plans that eventually 40 per cent
of local authority housebuilding should be industrialised; the current
percentage is about 30.
Britain was the first country to develop civil engineering as a large-scale
modern industry and the first to provide techniques, finance and equipment
to carry out major civil engineering projects throughout the world. Prominent
figures in the early development of civil engineering included John McAdam,
pioneer in road construction; Thomas Telford, builder of roads, bridges,
canals, docks and railways; George and Robert Stephenson and Isambard
Kingdom Brunei, pioneers of railway building.
Among important construction projects in hand in the United Kingdom in
1968 were several major conventional power stations and nuclear power stations
(seep. 261); the 14-mile Victoria Tube line in London, costing £81 million; and
270

Overseas
Constructional
Work
Research
large-scale housing developments, such as the Thamesmead (London) project
to house 60,000 people, and the new town being built at Craigavon, Northern
Ireland. Projects for road construction, bridges and tunnels included over 100
miles of motorways under construction (see p. 335), a ^6 million high-level
bridge over the Clyde, and the .£20 million second Mersey Tunnel.
British constructional firms have been as active overseas as in the United
Kingdom. British consulting engineers, in particular, have built up a tradition
of knowledge and integrity which has caused their standards to become
international practice and their services to be in world-wide demand.
A British firm acts as consultant to the World Bank on the Indus Basin
irrigation scheme, the largest in the world, and several firms were involved in
the design of the Mangla Dam, Pakistan, which forms part of it. Other projects
included a new port at Dammam, to cost between £10 million and £12 million,
for the Saudi Arabian Government, and a £14-6 million university for the
Government of Libya.
Among important construction projects by British contractors in hand in
overseas countries during 1968 were: a new township for the Government of
Bahrain, costing £6 million; a £9-3 million deepwater harbour at Dubai in the
Persian Gulf; bridges in Uganda and Zambia; a new capital for British
Honduras; and a £5 million road scheme in Malawi.
It has been estimated that the total value of work carried out during the
year ending in March 1968 by over 100 British contractors, operating in 104
countries, was £182 million, compared with £172 million in the previous
year, and that the value of new contracts obtained was £232 million, compared
with £170 million in the previous year. Consulting engineers had projects
worth about £1,600 million in hand on 1st January 1968.
The Directorate-General of Research and Development in the Ministry of
Public Building and Works is responsible for co-ordinating research and
information services to increase efficiency in the building industry. The
Building Research Station was originally set up in 1921, thus making Britain
the pioneer of organised building research, and is concerned with research into
all aspects of building. It became part of the Ministry in 1967.
The Construction Industry Research and Information Association was
formed in 1967 to extend to the whole industry the research activities
previously undertaken by the Civil Engineering Research Association and to
provide an information and advisory service. It is financed jointly by the
Government and the industry.
The Heating and Ventilating Research Association, an industrial research
organisation , deals with problems of heating and ventilation of large buildings.
The major construction firms have research departments working on plant,
materials and methods. Other bodies concerned with research include the
universities and colleges of technology. Most of the producers of primary
building materials have trade associations which maintain research institutions
chiefly devoted to seeking new and more efficient use for their materials:
the Timber Research and Development Association and the Cement and
Concrete Association are examples.
MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIES
Britain’s manufacturing industries supply a wide range of products, many of
which are of major importance in world trade. Output has increased by over

The metal manufacturing industries employ 591,000 persons. Of these,
337,000 are in the iron and steel industry, 112,000 in the manufacture of iron
castings, 58,000 in the manufacture of light metals, and 84,000 in the copper,
brass and other base metal industries. Exports of iron and steel products and
non-ferrous metals in 1967 had an aggregate value of £435 million.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Iron and Steel
Britain pioneered the application of coal to the smelting of iron ore from the
seventeenth century onwards and British inventors were responsible for the
discovery of the processes which led to the great expansion of steelmaking in
the second half of the nineteenth century. Today Britain is the world’s fifth
largest steel producing nation. Output of crude steel in 1967 totalled 23-9
million ingot tons, 1-7 per cent less than in 1966. Capacity utilisation in 1967
averaged 77 per cent, compared with 79 per cent in 1966. Total capacity at the
end of 1967 was about 31 million tons. Pig iron production in 1967 amounted
to 15-2 million tons.
Net deliveries of finished steel amounted to 20-9 million tons in 1967. The
4-1 million tons of iron and steel products which were exported had a value
°f L229 million; the United States (^34-4 million), Sweden (^14-4 million)
and the Republic of South Africa (^11-9 million) were the main overseas
buyers.
The main producing districts are: South Wales (26 per cent of total crude
steel output); the north-east of England (16 per cent); Lincolnshire (12 per
cent); Sheffield and district (12 per cent); Scotland (11 per cent); and
Lancashire and Flintshire (10 per cent). South Wales concentrates mainly on
the manufacture of flat products, especially sheet steel and tinplate; the
output of the north-east coast and Scotland is predominantly of heavy steel
products (plates, sections and rails), although a wide strip mill for sheet
production is now in operation in Scotland.
During the period 1955-66 over ^1,170 million was spent on major
development schemes. Capital expenditure reached a peak in 1961 of almost
^200 million, due mainly to the strip mill expansion programme, falling back
to £42 million in 1966. The emphasis is increasingly on improving efficiency
rather than raising total capacity. Britain has some of the most modern plant
in Europe, and by 1967 steel production by the converter processes had
increased from 8 per cent of output in i960 to nearly 29 per cent; steel
from electric furnaces had increased from 7 per cent to 14 per cent; and the
share of the older open hearth process had fallen from 85 per cent to 57 percent.
Output per blast furnace has risen markedly in recent years, due both to an
increase in average size and to improvements in efficiency, such as improved
preparation of raw materials, the injection of fuel and oxygen, and the use of
higher blast temperatures. Industry-wide scientific and technological research
is carried out by the British Iron and Steel Research Association, and the
British Steel Corporation. Total annual expenditure by the industry is about
£13 million.
Outstanding development projects completed in the last few years include
wide strip mills at new integrated works at Newport (Monmouthshire) and
at an existing works in Scotland; a new plant at Stoke-on-Trent, which is
based entirely on continuous casting for supplies of semi-finished steel; an
advanced unit for the mass production of alloy and special carbon steels at
Sheffield; the world’s largest electric melting shop and a new steelworks in
which a linked three-computer system controls production planning through¬
out, both at Rotherham.
The iron and steel industry has been subject to some form of public
supervision since 1932. The Iron and Steel Act 1967 brought into public
ownership 13 major steel companies together producing well over 90 per cent
of Britain’s crude steel and employing some 70 per cent of the manpower in
the industry. Their shares and securities wTere vested in July 1967 in the
British Steel Corporation. The Corporation’s specific duties include pro¬
moting the efficient and economic supply of iron and steel products, exports,
INDUSTRY
273
Iron Castings
Non-Ferrous
Metals
mechanical
ENGINEERING
and research and development; it is statutorily responsible for the finances of
the nationalised industry. The Corporation’s first Report on Organisation,
published in August 1967, announced the establishment of four geographical
producing groups (Midland, Northern and I ubes, Scottish and Northwest,
and South Wales), which compete with one another in terms of cost and
quality. The remaining private sector includes some 200 companies accounting
for about one-third of the value of the industry’s sales.
Output of iron castings totalled 3-55 million tons in 1967, 0-5 million tons
less than the record level of 1965. The main users of iron castings are the
general engineering industry, the motor vehicle industry, the manuiacturers
of pressure pipes and fittings, the building and associated industries and the
steel industry. The engineering industry accounts for nearly one-third of the
total tonnage sold and about one-half of the industry s turnover. There are
about 1,200 firms in the iron founding industry with some 112,000 employees.
Exports are included in the total of steel exports in the previous section.
The non-ferrous metals industry is the largest in Europe and as a consumer
of aluminium, copper and lead Britain is second only to the United States
among western countries. Output in 1967 included: aluminium, 37>500 tons
of virgin metal and 176,000 tons of secondary metal; refined copper, 35,000
tons of virgin copper and 140,000 tons of secondary metal; lead, 124,000 tons
of secondary metal refined from scrap and 61,000 tons of virgin lead refined
from imported lead bullion; zinc, 103,000 tons of slab metal; and tin, 26,000
tons. Mining in Britain is confined to the working of lead and tin ores on a
small scale, although detailed investigation is taking place into the possibilities
of a considerable expansion of tin mining.
In 1967 exports of non-ferrous base metals were valued at ^155rnillion.
The main products exported, including semi-finished products, were copper
and copper alloys (^74-9 million), nickel and its alloys (^32-1 million),
aluminium and its alloys (^18-1 million) and tin and its alloys (3^14-7 million).
The Federal Republic of Germany (£26-6 million), the United States
million), Italy, the Netherlands, France, and Sweden were the largest
purchasing countries. Indirect exports are also substantial.
Nearly half of the industry is situated in the Midlands; other centres
include South Wales, London, Tyneside and Avonmouth. Firms are engaged
in smelting, casting and fabrication by rolling, extrusion and drawing and the
techniques of powder metallurgy and pressure diecasting are also employed.
The Government proposes to establish a large-scale aluminium smelting
industry in Britain, and has invited proposals from industry for the building
of three smelters in areas of above-average unemployment.
New uses for non-ferrous metals with special properties are emerging to
meet the increasingly specialised demands of industry, such as the production
of nuclear energy (uranium, zirconium, beryllium), jet aircraft (niobium,
magnesium, titanium) and electronic apparatus (selenium, silicon, germanium,
tantalum). Scientific and technological research for the industry as a whole is
conducted by the British Non-Ferrous Metals Research Association.
Mechanical engineering comprises a wide range of industries, including all
types of machinery, machine tools, engineers’ small tools, mechanical handling
equipment, construction equipment, industrial plant, ordnance and small
arms, watches and clocks, and scientific instruments. \ chicle engines are
included in the section on vehicles (p. 280). The number of employees is

cent between 1958 and 1967. The aggregate value of the main products
of all sections other than tractors, small arms, scientific instruments and
watches and clocks was £2,264 million in 1967. Exports of non-electric
machinery were valued at £1,036 million in 1967, slightly less than in 1966.
There are over 300 firms, employing 35,000 people, in the agricultural
machinery industry, including three very large firms with more than 1,000
workers. In 1967 output, excluding tractors, was valued at £49-2 million and
exports were worth £22*3 million; the main overseas markets were France,
the Republic of Ireland, the United States, and South Africa.
The number of self-propelled combine harvesters, forage harvesters, pick¬
up balers and grain driers in use has increased in Britain in recent years.
Deliveries in 1967 included 2,700 combine harvesters, 7,100 milking machines,
12,000 pick-up balers and 1,600 grain and grass driers.
The bulk of British tractor output and exports consists of agricultural tractors.
Some 186,000 agricultural and industrial wheeled tractors were delivered in
iQh?, 141,000 (76 per cent) for export. In addition, 31,200 small market
garden tractors were delivered. Exports of new agricultural and track-laying
tractors were valued at £95 "3 million in 1967. Agricultural tractor production
is dominated by two large organisations. Tractors are exhibited at the annual
Royal Smithfield Show and Agricultural Machinery Exhibition in London;
Britain has one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world (see p. 305).
Metal-working Britain was the birthplace of the modern machine tool industry. The industry’s
Machine Tools output today ranges from watchmakers’ lathes weighing a few pounds to
machines weighing hundreds of tons, and to electronically controlled machine
tools giving accuracies of one-ten-thousandth part of an inch. Over 1,500
numerically controlled machine tools have been installed in Britain. The
Government, through the Ministry of Technology, is assisting the industry in
various ways, including pre-production purchase schemes and the encourage¬
ment of stock-building.
The value of deliveries of metal-working machine tools rose by 6 per cent
in 1967 to £158 million (the highest ever recorded), compared with £149
million in 1966. Exports in 1967 had a value of £45-7 million; and of the
orders on hand at the end of December 1967 (£90 million), 45 per cent w’ere
for export. The United States (£10-9 million), Canada (£4-8 million),
Australia (£4-1 million) and France (£3 million) were the main overseas
markets in 1967. Ten major groups account for over half the industry’s output
although the high degree of specialisation makes it possible for the small firm
to flourish. The industry is centred mainly in the Midlands, Yorkshire and
Lancashire, and to a lesser extent near London and Glasgow. There are
99,000 persons employed.
The Machine Tool Trades Association of Great Britain is the representative
body of most manufacturers and importers, and is responsible for the
International Machine Tool Exhibitions held in Britain every four years, the
next being due in 1972. The industry is served by its own research body,
the Machine Tool Industry Research Association, and its customers by the
Production Engineering Research Association.
Industrial Britain manufactures a wide range of industrial engines. Deliveries of engines
Engines (including parts) had a value of £147-2 million in 1967 and exports (including

One of the oldest of Britain’s mechanical engineering industries, the textile
machinery industry’s range of output embraces all stages in textile manufac¬
turing processes. Deliveries in 1967 were valued at ^112-5 million and
exports (including products of some associated industries) at £79-6 million.
Principal markets were the Pakistan (j£8-6 million), the United States
(£5-5 million), the Soviet Union and the Federal Republic of Germany (^4-9
million).
The industry, which has 49,000 employees, comprises many firms and is
situated mainly in Lancashire, Yorkshire, Northern Ireland, Dundee, Leicester
and Nottingham. It makes a wide range of machines and accessories for the
manufacture and processing of yarns and fabrics from all types of natural and
man-made fibres.
Almost every industry makes use of mechanical handling equipment; the
products of the industry range from individual units and accessories to
complete operating systems. The value of deliveries in 1967 was £130-5
million, the main products being cranes and bridge transporters, lifts,
escalators, conveyors, elevators and hoists. In addition, British firms produced
14,300 powered industrial trucks, including 10,500 fork-lift trucks. Exports
of mechanical handling equipment (including industrial and works trucks) in
1967 were valued at £44 million. There are many small firms in the industry;
in all, 61,000 people are employed.
Almost the whole range of plant required by the construction industry is
produced. These include crawler tractors, motor graders, scrapers, trenchers,
dozer equipment, dumpers, excavators and loading shovels, and crushing,
pulverising and screening plant. The labour force numbers 38,500.
The value of deliveries from the industry was £164 million in 1967; by far
the most important single item was earth-moving machinery (with a value
of £93-7 million), while other important products were crawler tractors
(£35-5 million), and concrete mixing machinery (£io-i million). Deliveries
of contractors’ plant for export in 1967 totalled £73-4 million; France, Spain,
Australia and Sweden are important markets.
The office machinery industry has been expanding rapidly and is now second
in size only to that of the United States. In 1967 the value of deliveries of
office machinery was £78-3 million including £44-2 million for export.
Deliveries in 1967 included 99,000 standard typewriters and 231,000 portable
typewriters. The value of deliveries of accounting and similar machinery was
£48-5 million, of which £30 million was for export, and of other office
machinery £19-8 million, of which £10 million was for export. Exports of all
office machinery (including electronic computers and data processing equip¬
ment) were valued at £78-5 million. The most important overseas purchasers
were the Federal Republic of Germany (£12-1 million), France (£9 million),
the United States (£8-5 million) and Canada (£3-9 million). British subsi¬
diaries or associates of United States firms are prominent in the office
machinery industry. There are 51,000 persons employed.

The manufacture of engineers’ small tools and gauges is an expanding
industry; deliveries increased in value from £55 million in 1959 to £91 million
in 1967; the main products were hard metal-tipped tools (£13-6 million),
other metal cutting tools (^40-7 million), jigs and fixtures (^17-9 million) and
press tools, moulds, etc. (^12-4 million). Export deliveries in 1967 totalled
£16 million. The industry has a labour force of 70,000 persons.
British industry manufactures almost every type of industrial plant and
steelwork, and 184,300 are employed in this branch. Of particular importance
are steam-raising boilers, lime and cement kilns, gas and coke oven plant,
sintering plant, metallurgical furnaces and plant, chemical and mineral oil
refining plant, nuclear reactors, water and sewage treatment plant, and
steelwork for bridges, buildings, etc. The industry has several large-scale
enterprises. In 1967 the aggregate value of deliveries (including rolling mills)
totalled £553 million.
British companies delivered water tube boilers to the value of £86-5 million
in 1967 compared with £91-7 million in 1966; shell boilers and other boiler-
house plant accounted for a further £47-1 million. Water tube boilers of
advanced design and of large steam-raising capacity are produced for power
stations, whereas shell boilers are used for steam-raising and heating in
factories and buildings. Exports of vapour generating boilers in 1967 amounted
to £10-9 million.
The steelworks plant industry provides, in association with firms producing
rolling mills, almost all Britain’s requirements as well as plant for export.
The value of deliveries in 1967 was £37-4 million; rolling mills and ancillary
equipment accounted for a further £27-6 million. This industry consists
of a small number of firms, most of which are business associates or members
of a consortium. Spain, India, South Africa and Canada are a few of the
countries in which British firms are undertaking major steelworks plant
projects.
The manufacture of specialised equipment for the chemical and oil refining
industries has expanded rapidly in recent years. Deliveries of chemical plant
were valued at £123 million in 1967 compared with £128-3 million in 1966
and £86-4 million in 1965. Britain ranks second to the United States as a
supplier of equipment for the petroleum industry. The range of chemical
plant produced includes distillation columns, heat exchangers, high-vacuum
drying equipment, and plant for the manufacture of chemicals from all
feedstocks including petroleum.
Three major consortia consisting of leading firms in the heavy electrical
engineering, civil engineering, boiler, instrument, and associated industries,
build nuclear power stations for the United Kingdom electricity authorities
(see p. 261). The Atomic Energy Authority grants them non-exclusive
manufacturing licences and is working in close collaboration with them in
research and development.
In addition to the mechanical engineering firms described in preceding
sections, there are about 1,750 enterprises whose principal product is a type
of machinery not so far mentioned. The main products include: mining
machinery, printing and book-binding machinery, refrigeration appliances,
space heating, ventilation and air-conditioning equipment, pumps and pump¬
ing machinery, industrial valves and cocks, compressors, scales and weighing
machinery, portable power tools, food preparing machinery and many other

This industry makes a wide range of equipment and appliances, extending
from domestic and commercial refrigerators of varying sizes to industrial
refrigeration equipment for cold stores, manufacture of chemicals and
other products, ice-making plant and refrigeration plant for ships. Total
deliveries of refrigerating machinery had a value of ^54-3 million in 1967;
772,000 domestic refrigerators were for the home market and 148,000 were
exported.
The value of deliveries of space heating, ventilating and air-conditioning
equipment has been rising recently but fell slightly in 1967 to £77-5 million.
Exports were valued at £9-9 million.
Industrial valves controlling the movement of liquids and gases are a vital
component in many industrial processes, particularly in the chemicals, oil and
electric power industries. The value of deliveries of pumps and valves in 1967
was £149-3 million and that of air and gas compressors and exhausters £44-5
million. Exports of pumps and centrifuges totalled £50-1 million and exports
of industrial valves £23 million.
The value of deliveries of other major products in 1967 was: mining machinery,
£69-8 million (one-sixth more than in 1966); food and drink machinery,
£45-2 million; packaging machinery, £26-8 million; and other machinery,
£307-2 million. Important export products in 1967 included: food and drink
processing machinery, £14-3 million; cigarette-making machinery, £11-5
million; paper-making machinery, £17-7 million; and printing and book¬
binding machinery, £20-4 million.
The industry manufactures photographic, scientific, surgical and industrial
instruments; it has a labour force of 138,400 persons. A rapidly expanding
sector is that making industrial process measuring and control instruments—
an essential element of automation in industry—deliveries of which amounted
to £66-3 million in 1967, compared with £41-3 million in i960. The value of
deliveries of other broad categories was: optical instruments, £11-4 million;
electric, electronic, and nucleonic instruments, £28-1 million; and nautical and
aeronautical instruments, £28-6 million. The total deliveries for 1967
amounted to £181 million.
Export deliveries of scientific instruments have been rising markedly,
amounting to £52 million in 1967, compared with £27-9 million in i960. The
Scientific Instrument Research Association conducts research on behalf of the
industry.
Deliveries of photographic equipment in 1967 totalled £ 1 o 1 • 1 million, including
£38-6 million for export. The main products in 1967 were: film (other than
cinematograph film), £33-5 rnillion; sensitised paper and cloth, £21-7 million;
and cinematograph film, £13-5 million. Deliveries of photographic cameras
were valued at £3 million.
The present industry is largely a post-war development. It employs 14,000
people, the great majority skilled craftsmen, and many of its factories are
located on new industrial estates in the older industrial areas, particularly in
Scotland. Sales in 1967 included clocks (£7-3 million), watches (£5-1 million)
and time switches (£8-9 million); export sales were valued at £3-9 million.

Behind the firms manufacturing the major products outlined in this section
are nearly 4,000 enterprises, employing 248,000 people, whose main functions
are to supply parts and components, to conduct research and development
work, and to undertake general sub-contracting and repair work. (Some enter¬
prises are included because the mixed character of their work makes it
impossible to classify them under any single industry.) They include some
very large undertakings: several with more than 5>000 employees. Ball and
roller bearings, and chains, are important products; exports of the former
were valued at ^15 million in 1967* an(i exports of chains at ^5'5 mihi°n'
The electrical engineering industry is engaged in the manufacture and installa¬
tion of a wide variety of electrical equipment, including all types of generating,
transmission and distribution equipment; motors; telecommunications
apparatus; domestic appliances; and specialised laboratory and electronic
equipment. Annual output rose in volume by nearly three-fifths between 1958
and 1967, and the total value of production in 1967 was estimated at almost
£2,000 million.
Exports of electrical machinery, apparatus and appliances in 1967 were
valued at £345 million. Products are exported to all parts of the world; in 1967
South Africa (£34-5 million), Australia (£23-5 million), the United States
(£23-1 million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£18-7 million), Canada
(£16-1 million) and the Netherlands (£13-2 million) were the main markets.
Altogether the industry employs a labour force of 906,000. Its leading
representative organisation is the British Electrical and Allied Manufacturers
Association; scientific and technological research on behalf of the industry as
a whole is carried out by the Electrical Research Association.
British scientists and engineers have been responsible for many of the basic
advances in the generation and transmission of electric power. The experi¬
ments of Michael Faraday pointed the way to the production of electricity
as a source of cheap and abundant power. Sir Charles Parsons produced and
patented the first turbo-dynamo, the forerunner of the giant turbo-generating
sets of today. The industry is supplying the plant for the large-scale expansion
programme of the electricity authorities in Britain and builds all types of
equipment for overseas countries.
In 1967 deliveries of electrical machinery were valued at £457 million,
comprising £160-6 million worth of rotating electrical machinery (motors,
generators and rotary converters), £62-7 million worth of transformers for
lighting, heating and power, £200 million worth of switchgear and comrol
gear and £33-7 million worth of other electrical machinery.
Exports of generators, motors, converters, transformers and rectifiers
amounted to £55 million in 1967, the main purchasers being South Africa
(£7-9 million) and Australia (£7-4 million). Switchgear, starting and control
gear exports were valued at £34 million.
About 600 firms manufacture electrical machinery, although mergers are
taking place and there are several firms with over 10,000 employees. The total
labour force numbers 230,000. Manufacture takes place in many areas,
including Manchester, Rugby, Tyneside, Stafford and Larne (Northern
Ireland).
Production of electronic equipment is one of the most rapidly expanding of
British industries. United Kingdom scientists and inventors have made many
basic contributions to electronics—the thermionic valve, the development 01

Total deliveries of electronic equipment were valued in 1967 at ^852-4
million, including ^172-7 million for export. (Indirect exports incorporated in
ships, aircraft and machinery are considerable.) Computers are the most
important product of the capital equipment sector which accounts for two-
fifths of total output. Britain has the largest indigenous computer industry
outside the United States and has supplied almost 1,200 installations in the
United Kingdom. The merger in 1968 of the two major British computer
concerns created a single group, responsible for almost all domestic output.
Deliveries, which have more than doubled in the last three years, were valued
at ^94 million in 1967 and exports at ^35-3 million.
Deliveries of radar and navigational aids were valued at £84 million in 1967,
five times the i960 level, and over one-third of total output was exported.
Three-quarters of the world’s radar-fitted merchant ships use British equip¬
ment, as do most of the world’s civil airports outside the American continent.
All-weather landing systems and inertial (automatic) navigation systems are
amongst recent developments. Other important items of capital equipment
include electronic control equipment (^44-7 million), radio communications
equipment (£42-6 million) and electronic measuring and testing equipment
(^35•6 million).
The consumer goods sector of the industry manufactures radio and television
sets and radiograms. The industry is dominated by several large firms. Output
of television sets in 1967 fell to 1-3 million (including 32,000 colour television
sets); the total sales value of £56-4 million was almost all in the home market.
Production of radios and radiograms numbered 1-53 million in 1967 and total
sales were worth £19 million.
The industry produces cables and wires for the distribution of electric power,
for telegraph and telephone networks and for many other purposes; its
products include submarine cables and cables insulated by a great variety of
materials. It is supplying the high voltage cable to carry the expanding output
of electric power in Britain (see p. 259). The value of deliveries in 1967
was £243 million, slightly below the peak total of 1966. Exports of electric
cables, wires, etc., were worth £28-3 million; the main purchasers were South
Africa and Hong Kong.
The industry has a labour force of 61,000 persons and includes three firms
with over 5,000 employees.
Britain is one of the largest exporters of telegraph and telephone equipment.
Shipments overseas had a value of ^38-3 million in 1967. Research and
development work is done by firms in the industry in co-operation with the
Post Office; in future all new small and medium-sized exchanges installed in
Britain will be electronic (see p. 352). The industry employs 95,000 persons,
and three firms are responsible for almost all output.
Deliveries of other electrical goods in 1967 included domestic electrical
appliances, £154-5 million; electrical equipment for motor vehicles, cycles
and aircraft, £85-8 million; batteries and accumulators, £58-8 million;
electric lamps, £36-6 million; and other electrical goods, £95-8 million. In
terms of volume, deliveries included: 1-3 million electric blankets, 1-5 million

In both size and value the largest section of the vehicle industry comprises the
manufacture of cars and commercial vehicles.
The industry was at one time located mainly in the Midlands and London
areas, but during the past decade manufacturing and assembly plants have
been established on Merseyside, in Wales and in Scotland.
Car and commercial vehicle output is dominated by the four largest firms
(British Leyland Motor Corporation, Ford, Rootes and Vauxhall), who
account for over 95 per cent of complete vehicle production; the balance is in
the hands of smaller, specialist producers of heavy commercial vehicles,
omnibuses, coaches, limousines and sports cars. The principal trade associa¬
tion is the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), which
holds a motor show annually in London and a Commercial Motor Exhibition
every two years. The Motor Industry Research Association carries out
collective research on vehicles and components.
Car output in 1967 totalled 1-55 million units, compared with i-6 million
units in 1966. Exports in 1967 amounted to 500,000 cars with a value of
^211 million. The United States (^44-2 million) was again the largest single
purchaser; South Africa (^13*4 million), Canada, Belgium and Denmark
were the other main markets. About one-fifth of all exports went to EFTA
member countries and one-seventh to the EEC.
Production of commercial vehicles, including chassis, increased from 146,000
in 1946 to 385,000 in 1967. Exports in 1967 of new commercial vehicles
numbered 132,000 with a record total value of ^113-7 million. South Africa
(£14-6 million), Australia (£11-8 million), Pakistan (£4-9 million), New
Zealand (^4-4 million) and EFTA countries (£16-6 million) were the mam
markets for commercial vehicles. Since 1961 Britain has been the world s
largest exporter of commercial vehicles.
Exports of parts and accessories for cars and commercial vehicles in 1967 had
a value of ^140 million; engines and parts for motor vehicles were valued at a
further £53-2 million. Caravan and trailer exports totalled £9-5 million.
Deliveries of bicycles have declined in recent years, but in 1967 amounted to
1-4 million, the same total as the previous year. About 75 per cent of British
manufacturing capacity is in the hands of a single group of companies, and
output is concentrated in the Nottingham area. About 905,000 cycles worth

j£7-2 million were sent overseas in 1967; the United States {£2 million) was

is the first major technical change in the bicycle for 60 years.
Deliveries of all types of motor cycle amounted to 105,000 in 1967. The total
included 26,000 mopeds (80 per cent more than in 1966), 540 motor scooters
and 10,000 three-wheeled vehicles. Manufacture is dominated by two large
groups. Exports of motor cycles and parts totalled ^14-6 million in 1967, with
the United States by far the biggest market.
The British Railways Board has its own workshops which supply British
Railways and certain other users in Britain; private firms build locomotives,
carriages and wagons for British Railways, for industrial users and for export.
Deliveries in 1967 included 134 electric locomotives, of which 133 were for
export, 221 diesel and diesel-electric locomotives, 536 coaching vehicles and
2,572 wagons. Deliveries of locomotives by private firms in 1967 were valued
at £16 million. The total value of exports of railway vehicles and parts in 1967
was £15-8 million; Kenya (£2-9 million), South Africa and Zambia were the
largest purchasers.
Almost all the aircraft produced by the British industry today are based on
civil and military applications of the gas-turbine aero-engine, first developed
by Sir Frank Whittle. The most notable turbo-prop aircraft in current
production and operation are the Hawker Siddeley 748, of which 180 have
been sold or are on order, and the Skyvan light transport aircraft. A second
generation of jet airliners, the medium-haul Trident and the longer-haul
Vickers VC 10, entered airline service in 1964, followed in 1965 by a third, the
BAG One-Eleven, the world’s first jet transport designed to operate economic¬
ally on short-haul routes. Other civil aircraft in production include the HS125
executive jet, the Beagle range of light aircraft, using piston and turbo-prop
engines, the Handley Page Jetstream executive airliner seating up to 18
passengers, and the Islander, an economical feeder-line aircraft. The Concorde,
the world’s first supersonic airliner, is being developed jointly by Britain and
France; the first prototype is expected to fly before the end of 1968.
The industry produces a wide range of military aircraft. It is also engaged
on work on rockets, earth satellites and other aerospace requirements,
including the Blue Streak and Black Arrow satellite launchers.
Hovercraft, a new type of transport vehicle invented in Britain, are being
increasingly used throughout the world. More than 50 have been built in
Britain up to mid-1968 and a number of types, including a 70-ton version, are
in production or under development.
In 1967 exports of the aerospace industry totalled £185 million. Exports of
new aircraft and parts in 1967 (excluding electrical equipment) had a value of
£97-8 million, compared with ^130 million in 1966. Leading buyers included
the United States (£23-6 million) and France (^8-9 million). In addition,
exports of instruments were worth £4 million, and tyres ^i-i million.
The construction of aircraft is dominated by two large airframe manufac¬
turers and one helicopter concern, though there are a few important smaller
companies outside these groups. Besides extensive research work by the
industry, research on a substantial scale on problems of aircraft and their
engines is carried out by the Government, chiefly at the Royal Aircraft
Establishment and the National Gas Turbine Establishment, both at Farn-
borough, and the Royal Aircraft Establishment at Bedford.

The British aerospace industry has over 50 collaboration agreements with
overseas governments and companies, including the joint development of a
300-seat European air-bus.
Aero-Engines Aero-engines and parts provided some 3^830 million in export earnings from
1946 to 1967. In 1967 exports of new and used engines and parts totalled
^87-6 million (23 per cent more than in 1966); major customers were the
United States (£25-8 million), France (^16-5 million) and Canada (^7-2
million). Thirteen different British jet engines power over 30 types of aircraft
currently in production overseas. Famous engines in production include the
economical Dart and Tyne turbo-props, the Conway and Spey turbo-jets and
the revolutionary Pegasus lift-thrust engine for vertical take-off and landing
(VTOL) aircraft. A series of advanced technology turbofan engines, currently
under development, has secured large overseas orders. The power plant for
the Concorde is a further development of the Olympus.
One company is responsible for almost all aero-engine production.
Shipbuilding The building of large ocean-going vessels is concentrated in four main areas:
and Marine the river Clyde in Scotland, the north-east and north-west coasts of England
Engineering and Belfast in Northern Ireland. Numerous yards around the coast build
smaller vessels such as fishing vessels, yachts and harbour craft.
Co-operative research into shipbuilding and marine engineering is under¬
taken by the British Ship Research Association with its headquarters and a
research station on the river Tyne.
Merchant
Shipbuilding
Ship Repairing
A gradual fall in tonnage launched from the 1955 peak of 1-5 million tons was
halted in 1964, and launchings in 1967 totalled 1-3 million gross tons, 213,000
tons above the 1966 level. British launchings were the third largest in the
world in 1967 accounting for 8-2 per cent of the world total, compared with
7-6 per cent in 1966. Nineteen oil tankers, totalling 259,600 gross tons, were
launched in 1967. Launchings also included 24 bulk carriers totalling 657,000
gross tons and 13 cargo ships between 10,000 and 12,300 gross tons. At the
end of 1967 orders on hand for merchant vessels of 100 gross tons and over
were 180, totalling 2-1 million gross tons with a value of £230 million. Of
these vessels, 50 (0-7 million gross tons) were for export.
Modernisation in British shipyards over the last few years has involved the
replanning of yards, the erection of large prefabrication shops for welding
massive sections under cover, the installation of heavy-lift travelling cranes,
and much other reconstruction. A new port, under construction at Belfast,
will be capable of building the largest vessels required in the future.
Large-scale mergers on Tyneside and Clydeside, and plans for re-grouping
in other areas, have resulted from proposals of the Shipbuilding Industry
Board, established in 1965.
There are many specialist ship-repairing establishments and most of the
larger shipbuilding firms also carry out repair work; about one-quarter of
ship-repairing activity is concentrated on the north-east coast of England.
Repair yards and dry docks are situated in all the large ports.
Marine Engineering Many of the larger shipbuilding yards maintain or have closely associated
engine building works, constructing various types of marine slow-speed diesel
engines, usually under licence. One firm designs large low-speed diesel engines
and there are two independent builders of these engines. Steam turbines of
the highest powers are also built.

The group of industries manufacturing metal products not already described
consists of a large number of companies with a total labour force of 569,000
in 1967; the main groups were tools and implements (24,000 persons), cutlery
(12,600), bolts, nuts and screws (44,000), wire and wire manufactures (43,000),
cans and metal boxes (36,000), jewellery, plate, and refining of precious
metals (28,000), and other metal industries (379,000). The total value of
exports in 1967 was about £153 million.
The production of cutlery and flatware is centred mainly in the city of
Sheffield and the industry’s reputation has been built up on the skill of its
craftsmen. Mass-production methods are, however, extensively used except
in the case of some of the highest quality wares, although firms remain mainly
small. The value of sales of cutlery and flatware in 1967 was ^14-2 million,
including export sales of £3-8 million.
This industry, located mainly in the Midlands, Lancashire, Yorkshire, South
Wales and London, produces a wide range of domestic utensils, such as
saucepans, buckets and dustbins, mainly from aluminium and wrought steel.
The value of sales in 1967 was £22-5 million, of which ^2-8 million were
sales for export.
The manufacture of hand tools is one of the oldest British industries, covering
the manufacture of such tools as files, saws, hammers, axes and spades;
Sheffield, Birmingham and other Midland towns are the most important
centres. The value of sales of implements and tools, other than machine tools
and portable power tools, was ^40-8 million in 1967, of which ^11-9 million
worth were exported; the totals included sales of hand tools, at home and for
export, valued at ^36-3 million and £11-6 million respectively.
The making of jewellery, gold and silver ware and the refining of precious
metals is an industry in which British craftsmen are heirs to along tradition.
Most of the firms in the industry are small. The law requires that gold and
silver plate shall not be sold until it has been hall-marked at one of the Assay
Offices situated in London, Birmingham, Sheffield and Edinburgh. The
Birmingham office, located in the main centre of the jewellery industry, is by
far the most important. The total value of sales of jewellery, goldsmiths’ and
silversmiths’ wares and electro-plated nickel silver wares in 1967 was £26-6
million, of which £4 million was for export.
The chemicals industry, with a labour force of 464,000, comprises the manu¬
facture of: chemicals, dyestuffs, fertilisers and pesticides (225,000 employees),
pharmaceutical and toilet preparations (77,000 employees), explosives and
fireworks (27,000 employees), paint and printing ink (46,000 employees), oils,
fats, soap and detergents (36,000 employees), synthetic resins and plastics
(39,000 employees), polishes, gelatine and adhesives (15,000 employees). The
industry is capital intensive; the fixed capital expenditure of the industry,
excluding mineral oil refining, amounted to over ^835 million during the five
years 1962-66 and totalled £169 million in 1967. The value of exports in 1967
was £493 million, or 9-4 per cent of total British exports. Production in the
general chemicals industries rose by 75 per cent between 1958 and 1967.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Over half the output of the inorganic chemicals industry consists of a limited
number of relatively simple chemicals, such as sulphuric acid, caustic soda,
chlorine and ammonia, produced in very large quantities and serving as basic
materials for industry. Sulphuric acid has the largest production of any
chemical and 3-2 million tons was produced in 1967. The remaining output of
this sector consists of a very wide range of chemicals of varying complexity.
Substantial quantities of inorganic chemicals are used in the manufacture
of such products as fertilisers, detergents, paint, glass and metals. About
one-sixth of output is estimated to be exported directly.
Production of organic chemicals (which include coal-tar chemicals) rose
by 189 per cent between 1958 and 1967. To an increasing extent petroleum is
the raw material used and it is estimated that in 1967 petroleum-based
chemicals accounted for 75 per cent of the total output of organic chemicals;
deliveries of feedstock for the petroleum chemical plants totalled 4-6 million
tons in 1967 compared with i-i million tons in 1959. The most important
products (by weight) in 1967 were ethylene (638,000 tons) and propylene
(378,000 tons). The main outlets for organic chemicals are plastics materials,
solvents, synthetic rubber, man-made fibres and detergents. Consumption of
dyestuffs is geared to demand by the textile industry; about 32,000 tons of
synthetic dyestuffs were produced in 1967.
Exports of chemical elements and compounds amounted to ^117-8 million
in 1967. Exports go to a large number of countries including, in 1967, the
Netherlands (£14-4 million), the United States (^6-7 million), Australia
(^6-i million), France, Sweden, South Africa and Canada.
The first plastic, Parkesine (later called Celluloid), was produced and patented
in Britain in 1865 by Alexander Parkes; other British discoveries include
polyethylene. Plastics manufacture is one of the fastest growing sections of the
economy. Output of synthetic resins has increased by 180 per cent since 1958
and total production in 1967 was 1,107,000 tons (an increase of 9 per cent over
1966), of which 271,000 tons consisted of thermoplastic resins.
Expansion in recent years has mainly been in thermoplastic materials, of
which the most important are polyethylene (used in coverings and packaging—
notably for foodstuffs), polyvinyl chloride (known as PVC and used for a
wide range of industrial purposes and consumer goods) and polystyrene
(a cheap non-inflammable material used for toys, light mouldings and many
consumer goods). One of the newer thermoplastic materials is polypropylene,
a versatile material which can be fabricated as mouldings, films and fibres.
Rapid expansion of capacity for all the main types of plastics materials is
planned. Exports in 1967 amounted to 402,000 tons, valued at £94 million.
The main purchasers were Australia (^10-5 million), South Africa (^8-8
million), the Netherlands (j£6-i million) and Sweden (£5-6 million).
The first general purpose synthetic rubber to be manufactured on a com¬
mercial scale in the United Kingdom was marketed in 1958. High styrene
rubbers for shoe soles and flooring, and nitrile rubbers for use where oil
resistance is required, are in large-scale production, and neoprene rubber is
manufactured in Northern Ireland. Production in 1967 amounted to 200,000
tons, much of which came from the styrene-butadiene plant at Hythe, near
Southampton. Exports of synthetic rubber and latex totalled 54,000 tons.
The development of artificial fertilisers owes much to the pioneer work of
the British scientists Sir John Lawes and Sir Joseph Gilbert. Two firms

predominate in the production of fertilisers and there are a large number of
firms marketing compound fertilisers from the principal constituents—
nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium. To encourage use, sales on the home
market are assisted by government subsidies paid to the farmer (see p. 308).
Output of nitrogenous fertilisers (in terms of nitrogen content) has been

nitrogenous, was £8-4 million in 1967.
Manufacturers’ sales of paint and varnish during 1967 amounted to over
93 million gallons (including 15 million gallons of emulsion paint) valued at
^133 million. Britain is one of the largest exporters of paints in the world;
exports of pigments, paints, varnishes and related materials in 1967 amounted
to £34 million. The industry’s indirect contribution to exports in the form of
surface coatings for finished goods is also considerable.
In recent years many improved techniques have been introduced, in
particular, new ranges of synthetic resins and pigments; quick-drying paints
and paints needing only one application have been developed.
The whole range of drugs is produced in the United Kingdom, including
antibiotics, sulphonamides, anti-malarial drugs, anti-histamine products,
anaesthetics, vaccines, sera and naturally occurring drugs. Research expendi¬
ture totalled ^12 million in 1967.
Notable British contributions to the development of new products include:
the discovery of penicillin by Sir Alexander Fleming and its evaluation by Sir
Howard Florey and E. B. Chain; the evaluation of sulphapyridine (M & B 693)
by Sir Lionel Whitby; the discovery of griseofulvin; and, more recently, the
isolation of the penicillin nucleus and the development of several semi¬
synthetic penicillins and the cephalosporin antibiotics. Several of the larger
pharmaceutical companies in Britain are subsidiaries of overseas firms.
In 1967 exports of medicinal and pharmaceutical products rose by 7 per
cent to the record level of ^73-4 million, of which j£i9'8 million worth were
antibiotics. The largest purchasers were the Republic of Ireland (^4-9 million),
France (^3-8 million), Australia (£3-7 million) and the United States (^3-2
million).
Notable discoveries by the British crop protection industry include the
insecticidal activity of BHC (benzene hexachloride), the first selective weed¬
killer, MCPA, and more recently Gramoxone, a non-residual general herbicide
based on paraquat. Sales of pesticides and allied products were valued at
£28 million in 1967, 6 per cent higher than in 1966; herbicides (£17 million)
were the largest single category. Exports of insecticides, fungicides and
weedkillers in 1967 totalled £14-7 million, 8 per cent more than in 1966.
Sales of toilet preparations were valued at j£iii million in 1967, including
export sales of about ^15 million; home market sales of hair preparations
totalled about £26 million. Petroleum is the source of the principal raw
materials used in the manufacture of organic surface-active agents in deter¬
gents; the other main constituent, polyphosphates, is derived from inorganic

sources. Sales of synthetic detergents amounted to 387,000 tons in 1967,
including 58,000 tons for export. Deliveries of soap totalled some 320,000 tons;
two companies supply about 90 per cent of home sales. Sales of polishes in
1967 were valued at £17-5 million, including floor and furniture polishes
worth ^8-4 million. Exports of perfumery and toilet preparations, soap and
associated products were valued at £43-4 million.
The textile industries in 1967 had a labour force of 702,000 persons, including
42,500 employees engaged in the production of man-made fibres, 84,000 in
the spinning and doubling of cotton, flax and man-made fibres, 79,000 in the
weaving of cotton, linen and man-made fibres, 160,000 in the woollen and
worsted trades, 128,000 in hosiery and knitted goods, 62,000 in textile
finishing and 40,500 in carpets. Over half the employees are women. The
total value of textile exports in 1967 at £250 million was somewhat less than in
1966. Production of textiles rose by 14 per cent between 1958 and 1967.
Considerable vertical integration is taking place within the industry, connected
with the increasing use of man-made fibres. Four multi-fibre, multi-process
groups, founded under the leadership of man-made fibres manufacturers,
control the bulk of Britain’s spinning and warp knitting activities.
A new statutory body, the Textile Council for the Man-made Fibres, Cotton
and Silk Industries, was established in 1967, superseding the Cotton Board.
It is financed by a levy on the industry.
Scientific and technical research for the industry is carried out by the
Cotton, Silk and Man-made Fibres Research Association.
Cotton was Britain’s chief consumer goods industry and cotton piece-goods
its largest export during the nineteenth century. Increasing low-cost compet¬
ition has cut progressively into British markets and a global limit has been
placed on imports of cotton goods from most countries during 1966-70.
Output in 1967 consisted of: 384 million lb. of single cotton yarn, 125 million
lb. of spun man-made fibre and mixture single yarn, 213 million lb. of
doubled yarn, 62 million lb. of textured yarn, 744 million linear yards of
woven cotton cloth, and 530 million linear yards of man-made fibre and
mixture cloth. In 1967 exports of cotton yarn and woven fabrics (excluding
man-made fibres) amounted in value to ^34-2 million, including woven
fabrics worth ^23 million, for which the Irish Republic and South Africa
were the most important markets.
Most of the industry is located in Lancashire, the north-east of the county
being mainly concerned with weaving and the south-east with spinning.
Manchester is the commercial centre and Liverpool is the chief port of entry
for raw cotton. Under legislation to assist the reorganisation of the industry,
Exchequer funds have paid for two-thirds of the cost of removing surplus
capacity, and also provided grants of about one-quarter towards the cost of
approved re-equipment and modernisation schemes.
The wool textile industry, one of the largest in the world, is the most ancient of
Britain’s staple industries and has been important since medieval times. There
are two main branches—woollen and worsted. The small or medium-sized
business predominates, with only a few large firms. While the West Riding of
Yorkshire is by far the most important producing area, Scotland and the West
of England remain famous as specialised producers of high-quality woollen
cloth. In recent years an increasing amount of man-made fibre has been
blended with wool.

In 1967 output included 203 million lb. of wool and hair tops and 305
million lb. of woollen yarn. Deliveries of worsted yarn amounted to 198
million lb. and of woven fabrics to 294 million square yards. In addition,
large quantities of raw wool are scoured and cleaned in Britain. Consumption
of raw wool in 1967 was 360 million lb., compared with 509 million lb. in 1959.
Exports in 1967 included wool yarns (j£i8 million), woollen fabrics (£35-4
million) and wool worsted fabrics (^22-2 million). The main buyers of woollen
fabrics were the United States (^3-8 million), Canada and the Federal
Republic of Germany. Raw wool (cleaned or scoured in Britain) and other
animal hair and tops exported had a value of ^45 million. Research is carried
on mainly by the Wool Industries Research Association.
Much of the early development of viscose rayon and acetate took place in
Britain. Production is spread throughout the country with Northern Ireland
of growing importance. Large firms predominate in the industry. There has
been a rapid expansion of output in recent years, the 1967 record total of
955 million lb. being 8 per cent higher than in 1966 and 16 per cent
more than in 1964. Output consisted of 517 million lb. of staple fibre and
438 million lb. of filament yarn in 1967. Of the staple fibre, 189 million lb.,
and of the continuous filament, 239 million lb., were of fully synthetic
materials.
Two main types of man-made fibres are manufactured: those made from
cellulose (such as rayon) and those produced by fully synthetic processes from
chemical substances (such as nylon). Viscose rayon is still the most widely
used of all man-made fibres and output in 1967 totalled 42-9 million lb.
The world’s largest rayon staple factory is at Greenfield (North Wales), with
an annual output of over 200 million lb., while other large rayon plants are at
Grimsby, Preston and Wolverhampton. Almost all the rayon produced in
Britain is made by a single company and its subsidiaries.
Production of nylon, the first fully synthetic fibre, in the form of nylon 66,
started in Britain in 1941; another type of nylon (nylon 6) has been
manufactured since 1963. Total productive capacity for nylon has increased
from 160 million lb. a year in 1964, to almost 400 million lb. at the end of
i967-
Terylene, a polyester fibre, was invented in Britain during the second
world war. It is resistant to fading and is particularly suited to blending with
wool. Annual manufacturing capacity totals about 100 million lb. A group
of fibres of growing importance are the acrylic fibres: Courtelle (a British
discovery) and Acrilan are examples. Synthetic elastomerics or spandex
fibres, which are man-made textile fibres having inherent properties of stretch
and recovery, are now produced commercially.
Exports of man-made fibre yarns had a value of ^39-7 million in 1967,
and woven fabrics £17-5 million. Switzerland, Sweden and South Africa
were the most important purchasers of yarns.
The hosiery and knitwear industry is predominantly one of small-scale
enterprises. The industry is widely distributed, with Scotland and the east
Midlands as the two most important centres. Sales of knitted goods were
valued at £238 million in 1967 including £127 million worth of outerwear
and million worth of socks and stockings. Exports of knitted clothing
and accessories were valued at ^21-i million in 1967; the largest buyers were
the United States, Switzerland and Sweden. Exports of knitted fabrics
amounted to £j-2 million. The British Hosiery and Knitwear Export Group
