The linen industry is concentrated in Northern Ireland (the greatest linen¬
manufacturing region in the world), with most of the remainder in Scotland.
Broadly speaking, the Northern Ireland industry concentrates on yarns
and the lighter types of fabrics, while in Scotland production is largely of
coarse linens and canvas, although household types are also produced.
Northern Ireland manufacturers produced 42 million linear yards of cloth
in 1967, while weavers in Great Britain delivered 24 million square yards,
including 15 million square yards of sailcloth and canvas. Exports in 1967
included £7-5 million worth of linen fabrics and £2-3 million worth of flax
yarns and linen thread.
Jute is manufactured on a large scale in the Dundee area—the centre of the
world’s oldest jute industry—and 15,000 people are employed in all. Jute is
used in the manufacture of carpets, cordage, ropes and woven into fabrics for
a wide range of uses in the packaging, carpet, upholstery, building and motor
car industries. Research is being undertaken into new uses, for example,
plastics reinforcement. In 1967, 112,000 tons of raw jute were used, and
exports of jute fabric and yarn totalled £1-7 million.
Sales of finished lace goods amounted to ^14-4 million in 1967. The most
important lace product is from the warp knitting machines, with sales valued
at £7-5 million. Exports were worth £3-6 million in 1967.
In addition to the products mentioned above, British textile firms manufacture
a wide range of other goods, including many special yarns and fabrics, net,
household textiles such as blankets, tablecloths and curtains, and floor
coverings other than carpets. Sales of narrow fabrics (including elastic machin¬
ery belting and ribbon) totalled £44 million in 1967, including export sales
of £5-8 million. Sales of floor coverings of linoleum, vinyl and other
synthetic materials were valued at ^3^'4 million m I9^7> jus^ under one-sixth
were for export. The cordage industry is the largest in Europe. Exports of
ropes, cordage, nets and netting in 1967 were valued at ^4-2 million.
In 1967 total sales of all types of carpets and rugs amounted to 120-1 million
square yards, valued at ^169-5 million. Exports in 1967 ha(i a value of j£i4'4
million; Australia (£2-2 million) was the largest single market.
There are over 100 enterprises engaged in the manufacture of carpets,
including several large firms. In addition to the manufacture of woven carpets
such as Axminster and Wilton, over two-fifths of total sales by quantity in
1967 were of tufted carpets, a form of carpeting in which the pile, usually
containing a high proportion of artificial fibres, is inserted into a pre-woven
backing. Axminster-type carpets account for about 40 per cent of the value of
exports. The principal manufacturing centres include Kidderminster (in
Worcestershire), Halifax and Dewsbury (in the West Riding of Yorkshire),
Glasgow and Kilmarnock (in Scotland) and several towns in Northern
Ireland. About a third of the carpets produced (by quantity) are made
predominantly of wool and a growing proportion of traditional woven carpets
contain some man-made fibre.

There are 555,000 employees in the clothing, leather and footwear industries.
Some 400,000 are in the clothing industry, 99,000 in the footwear trade and
56,000 in leather, leather goods and fur manufacture. The aggregate value of
their exports in 1967 was £93 million.
The British clothing industry is the largest in Europe and total deliveries
of made-up clothing have increased by 30 per cent since 1958. Exports in 1967,
excluding knitted goods, were valued at £63-5 million; the United States
(£>5'3 million) was the main purchaser. Exports of women’s outerwear rose
sharply in 1967. Substantial quantities of clothing are also sent by parcel post.
Although there are some large firms employing mass-production methods
on an increasing scale, the typical firm is small. The principal manufacturing
centres are London, Leeds and Manchester, but several firms are also situated
on industrial trading estates throughout the country. Fashion is important in
the production of haute couture models and throughout the ready-to-wear
industry. The Clothing Export Council, representing over 200 companies,
organises promotions for various sectors of the industry.
Leather tanning is one of Britain’s oldest industries. In 1967, 11,100 tons of
sole and other heavy leather and 389 million square feet of upper, lining and
other light leathers were produced. Britain is one of the world’s leading
exporters with exports in 1967 valued at ^22-1 million. The United States is
the largest single market (£4-5 million in 1967), followed by Canada (£2-3
million) and Italy.
Tanneries are situated in most parts of Britain, but there are important
concentrations in Lancashire, Cheshire, Yorkshire, the north Midlands and
the London area. Many different types of leather are produced, ranging from
the heavy types for industrial uses, such as machinery belting, to high quality
leather for footwear, leather goods, gloves and clothing. The British Leather
Manufacturers’ Research Association is the foremost of its type in the world.
The British footwear industry is the third largest in the world. In 1967
manufacturers’ sales of footwear totalled 190 million pairs. Exports of all
types had a value of ^19-9 million; the United States (£4-4 million), the
Soviet Union and Canada were the largest markets.
Factories are located throughout Britain. Some areas concentrate on
production of particular types; for example, the Rossendale Valley region
of Lancashire on slippers, and Leicester and Norwich on women’s and girls’
shoes. The Shoe and Allied Trades Research Association enjoys a world-wide
reputation in all matters connected with shoemaking.
The food, drink and tobacco industries employ 850,000 persons in the
production of a great variety of goods. The value of their combined exports
in 1967 was ^296 million. Exports of alcoholic and other beverages accounted
for £139 million; sugar, sugar preparations and honey for ^23 million;
cereal and cereal preparations for £40 million; fruit and vegetables for
£13-2 million; and coffee, cocoa, tea and spices for £14-9 million.
The household consumption of bread, which has been falling, averaged about
2 lb. 8 oz. per head per week in 1967. The trend is heavily towards concen¬
trating production in large mechanical bakeries; well over two-thirds of the
bread is made in these bakeries, which specialise in sliced and wrapped loaves;
four groups have a dominant position. In the smaller bakeries production of

cake and other flour confectionery is usually allied to bread production. There
are 159,000 employees in the bread and flour confectionery industry; a further
43,000 are employed in grain-milling.
There are 51,000 employees producing biscuits, and annual output has been
over 500,000 tons in recent years. Weekly consumption of cakes and biscuits
per head in Britain was 11-9 oz. in 1967. British biscuits have gained a world¬
wide reputation, and, despite the problem of import restrictions in several
overseas markets, exports in 1967 were valued at £8 million.
The chocolate and sugar confectionery industry, which has 95,000 employees,
is composed of a small number of very large manufacturers and many medium¬
sized and small firms. The main ingredients used by the industry are sugar,
cocoa beans, glucose, milk, nuts and fats. Production of chocolate
and sugar confectionery was 664,000 tons in 1967. Consumption of choco¬
late and sugar confectionery in the United Kingdom is far higher than in
any other country, being equivalent to 7-9 oz. per head per week.
The value of exports in 1967 of cocoa preparations (including chocolate)
was ^12-5 million and of sugar confectionery, £12 million. The United
States and Canada were the main markets for cocoa preparations. Over 30 per
cent of total world exports of chocolate and sugar confectionery come from
Britain, the world’s largest exporter of these products.
Among the fruit and vegetable products manufactured are jam, marmalade,
sauces and vinegar. The labour force numbers 73,000. Output of jams and
marmalade, which fell from 329,000 tons in 1949 to about 215,000 tons in
1956, has since remained little changed, totalling 201,000 tons in 1967. Straw¬
berry, raspberry and blackcurrant jams are the most popular. Exports of jams
and marmalade in 1967 were valued at £1 - 9 million.
In 1967, 733,000 tons of canned vegetables were produced. The British
Navy wras using canned foods in 1813, but rapid development in the industry
did not take place until after 1935. Processed and fresh peas (265,000 tons)
and beans in tomato sauce (258,000 tons) are the vegetables most in demand
as canned products. In addition, output in 1967 included 81,000 tons of
canned and bottled fruit, and 267,000 tons of canned soup. Strawberries are
the most important single fruit used for canning, followed by rhubarb and
apples. Sales of prepared fruit pie fillings are increasing.
Sales of frozen foods are rising in Britain, and nearly 98,000 tons of
vegetables and 1,000 tons of fruit were preserved by this method in 1967; peas
accounted for 64 per cent of all quick-frozen vegetables. Sales of dehydrated
products, including accelerated freeze dried foods, are also increasing.
The industry comprises the curing of bacon and ham, the canning and
preserving of meat and fish, the manufacture of sausages and pies and the
preparation of extracts and pastes. The labour force numbers 88,000. Output
of canned meat and meat products in 1967 rose to 111,000 tons, but the
quantity of bacon and ham cured fell to 202,000 tons. There has been a rapid
expansion of quick-frozen fish output, and some 83,000 tons were produced
in 1967; small quantities (6,300 tons in 1967) are also canned. Exports of fish
and fish preparations had a value of £9-5 million in 1967 and those of meat
and meat products were worth £10-2 million.
The industries producing beer, spirits, wines, cider and soft drinks have a
labour force of 162,000. Exports were valued at £139-1 million in 1967.
Beverages
INDUSTRY
29I
Whisky
Gin
Brewing and
Malting
Soft Drinks
Tobacco
Exports of whisky (almost all of it Scotch whisky) reached the record level of
43-1 million proof gallons with a value of £122-4 million in 1967; over half
went to the United States (^64 million or 23-7 million proof gallons). Scotch
whisky was first distilled in the fifteenth century. It is blended from 20 or
more different types, some from malted barley and some from other grains.
Whisky requires several years to mature, and the 124 million proof gallons
(a record) of Scotch whisky produced in the 1967 distilling year will not be
on sale for some years. Stocks of whisky amount to more than 610 million
proof gallons, representing ten years’ consumption. About four-fifths of
annual sales are to overseas buyers.
Production of gin in Britain has risen steadily since the early 1950s. The main
distillers are in London and one company accounts for a large proportion of
total output. Although the larger manufacturers also own distilleries abroad,
exports had a value of £9-8 million in 1967.
There are 96,000 employees in the brewing and malting industry. In recent
years there has been a strong tendency towards the creation of larger brewery
units, partly to secure wide distributive outlets for the products of the large
brewing groups, many of which market beer throughout the country. In 1967,
30 million bulk barrels of beer were produced, the highest for some years,
and consumers’ expenditure on beer amounted to £942 million. Exports in
1967 of malt beer were 296,000 bulk barrels, worth £2-7 million. Firms are
experimenting with new methods, including continuous brewing processes,
and automated batch production plants are well established.
The main raw materials used in brewing are malt, hops and some sugar.
Malt is made almost entirely from home-grown barley. Some brewers make all
or part of their own malt, others purchase it from independent maltsters who
also supply distillers, vinegar brewers, and malt extract manufacturers. British
malt is used by brewers throughout the world, and exports in 1967 amounted
to 48,000 tons, worth £2-4 million.
The soft drinks industry has expanded markedly in the last decade although
sales are liable to be affected by the weather. Output in 1967 included 61
million gallons of concentrated liquid, and 294 million gallons of unconcen¬
trated drinks. Though there has been some amalgamation in recent years,
there are still several hundred firms supplying regional markets. There are two
very large firms among about 20 producing widely advertised brands which
are marketed on a national scale. There is also some degree of specialisation by
firms in the production of various types, such as carbonated drinks, cola-based
drinks, squashes and cordials, tonic waters and ‘mixers’, and comminuted
drinks (in which the whole fruit is used).
The tobacco industry manufactures almost all the cigarettes and other
tobacco goods sold in Britain. In 1967 consumers’ expenditure on these
goods amounted to ^1,511 million (of which about 69 per cent was tax
revenue) and, in addition, exports worth £23-8 million (of which cigarettes
accounted for 90 per cent) were shipped to a large number of overseas
markets; Kuwait, Hong Kong and Singapore were the most important. The
main centres of production are in and around Bristol, Liverpool, London,
Manchester, Newcastle, Nottingham, Glasgow and Belfast. The two biggest
manufacturing groups account for a large proportion of total output. The
industry has 41,000 employees.
The tobacco industry used 285 million lb. of unmanufactured tobacco
in 1967 (5 per cent more than in 1966), all of which was imported. In 1967

the main sources were the United States, Canada and India. Total consump¬
tion of tobacco in Britain in 1967 amounted to 255-6 million lb., including
221-3 million lb. consumed in cigarettes, 29-6 million lb. in pipe and hand
rolling tobacco and 4 million lb. in cigars. In 1967, 119,100 million cigarettes
were consumed, 1,400 million more than in the previous year; 66 per cent of
the total were tipped compared with 16 per cent in i960.
This group comprises the manufacture of bricks, fireclay, refractory goods,
pottery, glass, cement, abrasives, asbestos and other building materials. The
industries have a combined labour force of 348,500, which includes 67,000
in the bricks, fireclay and refractory goods trades, 79,000 in the glass industry
and 62,000 in the pottery industry.
Firms in the industry manufacture such items as bricks, roofing tiles, chimney
pots, fireclay ware and heat-resisting products including furnace and kiln
linings. Brickmaking, one of Britain’s oldest industries, was introduced by
the Romans, and manufacturing methods vary from traditional hand fabri¬
cation to highly mechanised systems. In 1967 about 7,212 million building
bricks were produced in Great Britain, 43 per cent of which were of the
Fletton type, made mainly in the Bedford and Peterborough areas. Refractory
goods (firebricks, silica bricks, magnesite bricks and chrome-magnesite bricks)
are manufactured mainly for home use. Exports of refractory construction
materials in 1967 were worth ^5-7 million.
The pottery industry is a long-established and complex industry, largely
located in the Stoke-on-Trent area of Staffordshire. Much of its raw material
is indigenous, such as china clay, ball clay and china stone from Devon and
Cornwall. It supplies nearly all home needs for domestic and industrial pottery.
The largest section of the industry, about half, makes domestic pottery,
sub-divided into china, earthenware, stoneware, jet and Rockingham; the
other main divisions are glazed tiles, sanitary ware and electrical ware, and
such specialised industrial products as acid-proof stoneware, porous ceramics
and laboratory porcelain are also manufactured. Among famous makes of
British pottery are Wedgwood, Spode, Royal Worcester, Royal Doulton,
Minton, Coalport and Royal Crown Derby. Total sales of domestic pottery
were £44-9 million in 1967 including export sales of ^18-4 million, the highest
ever; the United States and Canada are important markets.
The industry employs 65,000 people, of whom 35,500 are women. There
has been considerable re-equipment; gas or electrically fired kilns have
replaced almost all the coal-fired kilns and new decorating techniques and
automatic and semi-automatic machinery have been introduced.
Britain’s glass industry is the third largest in the world. The section of the
industry devoted to the manufacture of plate and sheet glass in their various
forms is organised for quantity production, much of it in the form of the
‘float’ glass process, which was developed in Britain and has been licensed
to glass makers throughout the world. Its use for internal decoration and as
a finish for internal and external walls has greatly increased in recent years.
Large quantities of safety glass are produced for the motor industry. Other
products include glass bricks, tubular glass (produced on a large scale),
mirrors, lamp and bulb glass, scientific and medical glassware, glass fibres,
and all types of glass containers (often made by fully automatic machinery).
A traditional product is hand-made lead crystal glassware of very high quality.

PAPER, PRINTING

Direct exports of glass and glassware reached the record value of ^25-9
million in 1967. Those of glass were worth £15-4 million, the most important
markets being Australia, South Africa, the United States and Canada. The
figures included ^4-1 million of float glass.
Collective research is undertaken by the British Glass Industry Research
Association, and much research work is also carried out by the Department
of Glass Technology of Sheffield University.
The cement industry of the United Kingdom is chiefly concerned with the
manufacture of Portland cement. Invented by Joseph Aspdin and patented
in 1824, this material and the methods of its production have been the subject
of continuous technical improvement and intensive research. The capacity
of the industry, which has 18,000 employees, has expanded substantially.
The Dartford-Gravesend district of Kent is an important producing area.
Annual output totalled 17-3 million tons in 1967.
The paper, printing and publishing industries have 633,000 employees,
including 95,000 in the manufacture of paper and board, 63,000 in the pro¬
duction of cardboard boxes and packing cases, 144,000 in the publishing of
newspapers and periodicals and 260,000 in other types of printing and
publishing.
The manufacture of paper in Great Britain was not firmly established until
1678, but records show that some paper was produced as far back as 1492.
The British paper and board industry is the largest in Europe. Total
production in 1967 of all types of paper and board amounted to 4-4 million
tons. Of this, newsprint accounted for 700,000 tons, board for 1-3 million
tons and other paper for the remainder. Exports of paper, board and
manufactured paper items were valued at £54 million in 1967. The main
purchasers were the Republic of Ireland, South Africa and Australia.
Wood pulp is the main raw material, but large and increasing quantities
of waste paper are also used. A £20 million integrated pulp and paper mill,
the first in Britain, was opened at Fort William, in the Scottish Highlands,
in 1966. Two-thirds of the timber it uses is home-grown.
There are a few very large groups in the industry and many medium-sized
and small firms. The large groups hold considerable interests abroad, includ¬
ing pulp and paper producing mills in the United States, Canada and other
parts of the Commonwealth and Europe. Sales of household paper products,
including facial tissues, have risen sharply. Sales of cardboard boxes and
cartons were valued at £106-8 million in 1967 while those of fibre board pack¬
ing cases totalled £98-6 million. Sales of manufactured stationery totalled
£72-3 million in 1967. Wallpaper manufacturing is dominated by one firm; a
recent development has been the introduction of plastic and plastic-coated
wall coverings. Research is undertaken by the Research Association for the
Paper and Board, Printing and Packaging Industries.
The printing industry produces an immense range of goods, from national
newspapers and periodicals to books, catalogues and greetings cards. The
industry includes many very small enterprises. Mergers in recent years have
led to the formation of large groups in the newspaper, magazine and book
publishing sections. Four large firms each employ more than 7,500 persons.
General printing, publishing, engraving and bookbinding remains essentially
an industry of small firms.

Publishers’ turnover in 1967 is estimated at £126 million, of which export
sales accounted for a record total of £54 million, forming a higher proportion
of output than in any other country. Consumers’ expenditure on books, news¬
papers and magazines totalled almost ^400 million in 1966. Book titles
published in 1967 totalled nearly 30,000, about 22,500 of them new ones.
Popularity of paper-backed books has increased rapidly in recent years.
According to the overseas trade returns, exports of printed matter, manu¬
scripts and typescripts were valued at ^55-8 million in 1967, including books
(£28 million), and newspapers and periodicals (£9-6 million), but these
figures do not include parcel post shipments, which are possibly as large again
as the recorded totals. The United States and Australia are the most important
overseas markets. The Book Development Council was formed in 1965 to
promote the supply and use of British books overseas. Firms have introduced
the latest developments in high-speed printing equipment, including elec¬
tronic engraving machines and advanced processes of photographic reproduc¬
tion, and some newspapers are now set by computer.
Other manufacturing industries include the timber and furniture group, with
301,000 employees, rubber manufacture, with 128,500 employees, and a group
of miscellaneous manufactures which embrace some 206,500 employees,
including 91,000 employed in plastics moulding and fabricating.
Britain’s rubber manufacturing industry is the oldest in the world, dating
from 1819. Macintosh invented waterproof garments, and Dunlop in 1888
devised the pneumatic tyre. Tyres and tubes represent more than half the
output of the industry but firms also make a variety of other rubber manu¬
factures, the most important being rubber footwear, conveyor belting, cables,
hose, latex foam products, and other vehicle components and accessories.
The British industry is one of the largest in the world. In 1967 its consump¬
tion of rubber totalled 381,000 tons, comprising 168,000 tons of natural
rubber, 186,000 tons of synthetic rubber and 27,000 tons of reclaimed rubber;
the proportion of synthetic rubber used is increasing. In 1967, 209,000 tons
of rubber were used in the production of tyres and tyre products. Tyre
manufacturers include several subsidiaries of United States and other overseas
companies. Tyres and tubes exported were valued at £31-3 million; this
figure excludes large indirect exports on vehicles. Direct exports of all rubber
manufactures (including tyres) in 1967 were worth £53-8 million, with
Sweden, Australia, Denmark and the United States as the main markets. In
addition, the industry exported about £3-9 million worth of rubber footwear
and j£i-4 million of rubber gloves and other miscellaneous products.
London is the largest centre for furniture manufacturing, but High Wycombe,
in Buckinghamshire, is important for domestic furniture.
Deliveries of domestic furniture rose by 19 per cent in volume between 1958
and 1967, and in the latter year their value was £152 million. Exports of all
furniture were worth ^14-7 million in 1967. There are numerous enterprises
manufacturing furniture in Britain (including domestic, upholstered, office,
school and other furniture) with a total labour force of 94,000. The bedding
industry employs 18,000 people; sales of new bedding in 1967 were valued at
£34-6 million. Many firms are small but in recent years there has been a
tendency towards concentration.
Scientific research and technical information services are provided by the
Furniture Development Council and the Furniture Industry Research
INDUSTRY 295
Association. The Council is concerned with the management problems of the
industry and produces an annual statistical and economic review.
The brush industry is located throughout Britain, and embraces highly
mechanised establishments as well as small craft units. The value of sales in
1967 was ^20-7 million, of which £2-3 million was for export.
The timber industry employs 191,000 people. Britain is mainly dependent
on imported supplies of timber (valued at £191 million in 1967) but sawmill
output of home-grown timber together with the output of home-grown
pitwood totalled about 50 million cubic feet in 1967. Other products include
plywood and chipboard.
Toys, Games
and Sports
Equipment
The number of people engaged in manufacturing toys and sports equipment
in Britain is 40,000. Sales of toys in 1967 were worth ^58-8 million and
exports had a value of £17-8 million. The United States and the Federal
Republic of Germany were the main overseas markets. Current trends are
towards increased production of small-scale precision models of vehicles and
toys linked to television characters.
The value of manufacturers’ sales of games was £4-7 million and that of
sports equipment ^17-9 million, of which £6-5 million was for export.
12 AGRICULTURE,
FISHERIES AND
FORESTRY
AGRICULTURE
Although Britain is a densely populated, industrialised country relying on
imports for half its food supply, agriculture remains one of its largest and
most important industries. It occupies about 734,000 people in Great Britain
or just under 3 per cent of those in civil employment, provides about 3 per
cent of the gross national product, and uses 48 million of the 60 million acres
of land.
In Northern Ireland 2-7 million of the 3-3 million acres of land are in
agricultural use, and the corresponding proportions for employment and
gross output are 11 per cent and 14 per cent.
Land used for farming is conventionally divided into improved land suitable
for cultivation (crops and grass) and rough grazing, nearly all of which is
hill or mountain land with a native herbage of coarse grasses, rushes, bracken,
heather or scrub trees. Rough grazing has a low potential output—usually
assessed at about one-sixth of that of agricultural land—but is valuable for
sheep. In England and Wales only about one-sixth of farming land is classified
as rough grazing. In Northern Ireland the proportion is about one-quarter,
but in Scotland it is about three-quarters. In the United Kingdom as a whole
there are 31 million acres under crops and grass. Improved land and rough
grazing together represent 81 per cent of the land area. The rest is mountain
and forest, or put to urban and kindred uses. The area available for farming
is gradually decreasing to meet the needs of housing and industry; however,
the loss is more than outweighed by the increase in output from what remains.
The soils of the country are extremely varied. Many of those in the west
and north, overlying hard rocks, are poor and thin. The lowlands and river
valleys are usually fertile, varying in texture from clay to sandy loam, silt
and peat. Clay soils everywhere necessitate under-drainage, and as all are
constantly leached by rainwater, lime has to be applied at regular intervals.
In hill country the area of improved land is often small, but is usually supple¬
mented by grazing on a comparatively large area of hill land.
For manv centuries the bulk of land in Britain lay in estates ranging in size
from a few hundred acres upwards, comprising farms of varying sizes let to
tenants. Social changes of the past half-century have completely changed the
pattern of rural life in England and Scotland. Estate duties have been a
principal factor in the breaking up of estates. Most surviving estates are still
owned by private individuals or family trusts, but the Crown, local authorities,
and other corporate bodies hold considerable areas. Of the farms sold, many
have been bought by the tenants already in occupation. About half the farms
in Great Britain today are owner-occupied.

Ownership
of Farms

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 297
There are about 430,000 agricultural holdings in the United Kingdom,
giving an average size of about no acres. Slightly over half are part-time
holdings, the occupiers generally having another source of livelihood besides
farming. A recent survey has shown that there are about 220,000 full-time
holdings, and about half the industry’s total output comes from the 42,000
holdings classified as large ‘commercial’ farm businesses. A further 66,000
fall within the category of small ‘commercial’ businesses, which are able to
operate as viable enterprises. Of the remaining 112,000 full-time holdings,
farming is in general on too restricted a scale for commercial viability, and
amalgamations are being encouraged.
The average size of full-time holdings in England and Wales is between
145 and 150 acres of crops and grass. In Scotland the crops and grass area of
the 24,000 full-time farms averages 158 acres although the average for the
32,000 part-time and other holdings is only 14 acres.
In Northern Ireland the land is divided into about 66,000 holdings, almost
all of which are owner-occupied. About 40 per cent of these holdings are
either very small or let in conacre (seasonal lettings for crops or grazing), so
that the number of effective farm businesses is about 40,000, of which rather
more than half provide a full-time occupation for the owner. The typical
farm size is between 40 and 70 acres of crops and grass.
Most British farms produce a variety of products; the pattern varies from
farm to farm. In England the farms devoted primarily to arable crops are
in the eastern part of the country, in East Anglia, Kent, Lincolnshire, and
the East Riding of Yorkshire. Potato and vegetable growing on a substantial
scale marks the farming of the Fens (south Lincolnshire and Cambridgeshire),
the alluvial areas around the rivers Thames and Humber and the peaty lands
in south Lancashire. Elsewhere, horticultural crops are widely dispersed
amongst agricultural crops. In Scotland the rich lowlands of the east coast
are also primarily arable.
Interspersed between these arable areas, and also in the Midlands, the
south-east of England and the north-east of Scotland, there are large tracts
where, although much of the land is kept under the plough, the rearing and
fattening of cattle is an important enterprise. In the south-west of Scotland
dairying is extensively practised, but most of the north-west is devoted to
rearing sheep on rough hill land. The parts of England bordering the Pennine
hills and most of Wales are also sheep-rearing areas, though a good deal of
dairying, based on purchased feedingstuffs, is also done there. Dairy farming
is widespread throughout much of the rest of Britain. In Northern Ireland
mixed farming is practised, the most important products being milk, fat and
store cattle, pigs and eggs, with sheep and stock raising in the hill areas.
Oats and barley are widely grown, mainly for livestock feeding, and the only
important cash crop is potatoes, both ware and seed.
There are three main categories of grassland in the United Kingdom—
temporary grass, permanent grass and rough grazing. Temporary grass may
be part of an arable rotation, providing a break of from one to seven years
between tillage crops, or it may be part of an all-grass system where its
advantages over permanent grass are that it can provide early and late season
grazing and often heavier crops.
Since the end of the second world war there has been an increase of about
1 million acres in the area of temporary grass and the total arable area is
about 51 million acres more than it was pre-war. In England and Wales nearly

one-half of the 24 million acres of crops and grass (excluding over 3 million
acres of rough grazing) is under permanent grass, one-third under cereals and
one-sixth under temporary grass. About three-quarters of all agricultural land
in Scotland is in rough grazing and of the 4-3 million acres of crops and grass
about one-quarter is in permanent and two-fifths in temporary grass. Exclud¬
ing about 620,000 acres of rough grazing the crops and grass area of Northern
Ireland is about 2 million acres, of which over half is under permanent and
over one-quarter under temporary grass.
Farmers everywhere are exposed to the vagaries of the weather, of pests and
diseases, and of the market; but over the past 30 years much has been done
in Britain to mitigate these risks. This has been partly due to the advance of
science, partly to self-help by farmers’ organisations, but largely to govern¬
ment action. The role of the Government as guarantor and provider of
technical and advisory services, is described on pp. 305-14.
The steady expansion in productivity which has taken place over the last 25
years is summarised in Table 21. Total cattle stocks rose steadily each year
between 1953 and 1961, and after a slight decline between 1961 and 1964,
have increased in each of the three subsequent years. The milk-producing herd
reached its peak level in 1962, thereafter suffering a temporary decline with
some recovery since 1964. Numbers of sheep and lambs, which had been
increasing fairly steadily, fell in 1967, while those of pigs and poultry have
expanded considerably over the past decade, though pig numbers showed a
temporary reduction in 1966-67. Production of wheat at some 4 million tons a
year has more than doubled since the end of the second world war, while
barley output at over 9 million tons a year is now almost five times the 1946
figure. There has been a marked fall in the production of oats. Potato produc¬
tion is being maintained from a steadily declining acreage. Between i960 and
1967 output of pigmeat increased by nearly one-quarter, and eggs by nearly
one-fifth and these, together with the increase in beef and milk output,
resulted in higher consumption of feedingstuffs, mostly from home resources.
Imports of concentrated feeds have in fact fallen in recent years, from
6-i million tons in 1960-61 to 5-2 million tons in 1967-68.
The index of agricultural net output (all holdings) at constant prices has
risen steadily. By 1953-54 it was about 56 per cent above the immediate
pre-war average. Based on the average of 1954—55 to 1956-57—I00> it was
112 in 1959-60 and 136 in 1966-67; 144 is forecast for 1967-68.
Since 1939 the population of the United Kingdom has increased by over
7 million, or about 15 per cent. In spite of this growth Britain now produces
about half of its total food requirements or two-thirds of all that can be grown
in temperate climates; this latter figure comparing with about one-half before
the second world war. Home production of the principal foods is shown as a
percentage by weight of total supplies in Table 22.
Table 23 shows how the level of the main food supplies passing into
consumption has changed since before the second world war and within the
last decade. The main trends reflected in the table are that consumption of
bulky foods (carbohydrates), such as flour, tends to decline, while that of
high-protein foods, such as meat and eggs, continues to increase with greater
availability and rising living standards.

The possibilities of wheat growing, which is mainly confined to England,
have been changed radically by the advent of new strong strawed and heavy
yielding varieties, mainly from Europe. These permit the liberal use of
fertilisers, and spring dressings of nitrogen have become accepted practice.
Crop yields of 2 tons per acre are no longer unusual. About 3-8 million tons
were harvested in 1967, with average yields estimated at 33-3 cwt. per acre.
The two main markets for barley are for malting and for animal feeding
purposes. Malting barley commands a higher price than feeding barley, but
the disparity has now decreased. New varieties have helped to enlarge yields.
Since i960 the acreage under barley has increased by almost 80 per cent and
production has more than doubled.
The widespread use of combine harvesters has necessitated the installation
of drying and storage facilities on many farms. Such equipment is also widely
used on a co-operative basis.
Fodder Crops
Sugar Beet
Potatoes
Dairy Farming
Livestock
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 301
In England and Wales the total acreage of fodder crops continues to decline
because in many cases farmers can provide winter feed more economically
by increased grass production and improved methods of conservation. In
Scotland the decline in the acreage of fodder crops has been less rapid and
the acreage of turnips and swedes is now greater than in England.
Beet is grown mainly in East Anglia and Lincolnshire where most of the beet
sugar factories are situated. The crop is grown under contract to the British
Sugar Corporation, which takes the entire output at guaranteed prices and
also provides technical advice and assistance. Precision drilling is the usual
method of sowing and more than three-quarters of the crop is mechanically
harvested.
Early potatoes are grown in England and Wales in numerous, widely scattered
districts with favourable soils and climate. The crop is marketed during the
summer months and reaches the consumer within a few days of lifting. Main
crop varieties, which are normally stored before sale, are grown chiefly in the
Fen counties, Norfolk, Essex, Lincolnshire and Yorkshire. In Scotland, early
potatoes are grown in coastal areas of Ayrshire and Wigtownshire, main crop
potatoes being grown mostly on the eastern side of the country; a substantial
part of the industry is concerned with supplying seed potatoes to English
and foreign growers. In Northern Ireland both ware and seed potatoes are
produced, and about two-fifths of the crop is shipped to Great Britain and
abroad. The long-term trend is for the area planted with potatoes in the
United Kingdom to diminish and for yields to increase. The acreage has
declined from 829,000 acres in i960 to an estimated 708,000 acres in 1967.
The yield in 1967 was 10 tons per acre, slightly below the record of io-i tons
per acre in 1965. Although cultivation and harvesting is largely mechanical
much hand labour is still necessary for planting and grading.
Milk is much more valuable when sold on the liquid milk market than when
converted into cheese, butter or other milk products. In Great Britain milk
is produced primarily for liquid consumption, but in Northern Ireland the
greater part of the milk is used for manufactured products. Average
consumption per head is about 5 pints per week.
Average yields per dairy cow have increased during the last decade by more
than 10 per cent and now average over 800 gallons a year. Freedom from
tuberculosis has reduced herd wastage, and through the artificial insemination
(AI) centres, operated by the Milk Marketing Boards and other organisations,
the influence of a relatively small number of high-potential bulls is widely
disseminated. It is estimated that about two-thirds of Britain s total cattle
are bred by AI. The Friesian breed is dominant in the dairy herds of England,
Wales and Northern Ireland, but in Scotland the Ayrshire breed is the most
numerous. Milk production has also been stimulated by advances in grassland
management, intensive grazing techniques and new methods of making high
quality hay; new methods of conversion into silage are being exploited. Most
dairy farmers practise some degree of intensive grass management, but hay of
the traditional type remains the basic winter feed; it is supplemented with
purchased concentrates.
Clean dairy farming methods and hygienic standards for equipment and
buildings used in milk production are prescribed by regulations made and
enforced by the appropriate ministers.
A great number of specialised breeds of livestock have been developed over
the centuries in Britain. It has been found that they meet the needs of breeders
302
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Beef Cattle
Sheep
Pigs
Poultry
in most countries and substantial export sales are made to buyers seeking
to replenish and improve their herds with British animals.
In the hill regions hardy herds of beef cattle are kept, especially of the Galloway
breed and its crosses; in marginal land and lower areas the sires used are
predominantly of the Aberdeen Angus, Beef Shorthorn and Hereford
breeds. Nowadays much beef derives from the dairy herds, some females
being mated to beef sires, the majority by AI. There is a large and complex
trade in store cattle (increased by animals imported from the Irish Republic)
whose general movement is from the upland west to grazing areas in the
Midlands and arable areas in the east.
Britain has outstandingly good pastures for sheep. Moreover, veterinary
research has provided vaccine and sera protection against nearly all the
epidemic diseases to which sheep are subject. More than 30 breeds and
innumerable crosses are to be found in Britain, each breed having originated
within a circumscribed area.
In the hills, and especially in the Highlands, winter conditions are usually
severe. Draft ewes and lambs are brought from the hill areas every autumn
to swell the lowland flocks, usually in two stages: firstly, to farms at inter¬
mediate altitudes, where they are mated with rams of a larger and more
rapidly maturing breed; then, the cross-bred progeny pass on in due course
to the more genial lowland conditions and especially to the Midlands and the
south and east of England, where they become crossed again with Down
rams for fat lamb production. The hill breeds bring in hardiness and the
lowland sires fecundity and early maturity.
Although wool is of considerable importance to the sheep farmer the main
purpose is the production of fat lambs, in response to the change in the
preference of consumers away from mature sheep.
Pig production in Britain is carried on by the general farmer and the
specialist pig producer, with most pigs coming from the general farm.
Increasing attention is being paid to factors which affect efficiency including
an increasing concentration of pigs into larger herds. The most frequently
used breeds are the Large White and the Landrace though considerable cross
breeding takes place. Pig improvements are fostered by the Meat and Live¬
stock Commission and by leading commercial firms through schemes for
progeny and performance testing, litter recording and other development
work. Attention is now focused on utility qualities, such as size and weight
of litters, and on food consumed per pound of liveweight gain.
Carcases are used for curing as bacon, for sale as fresh pork and for manu¬
facturing into sausages and other processed forms. In terms of pig meat,
about 30 per cent is used for bacon and 70 per cent for pork and manufacturing.
Specialist techniques and intensive husbandry have been introduced over a
large part of the poultry industry and considerable concentration has occurred.
There are now several flocks of over 100,000 birds and only a small pro¬
portion of total production is in the hands of the smallest producers. Over 70
per cent of the laying birds on farms are in flocks of 1,000 or more. With the
rise in the poultry population and in the yield of eggs per bird (now averaging
over 200 eggs a year), the estimated production of eggs has more than doubled
the 1938 level and for several years nearly all eggs consumed in Britain have
been home-produced. About 225 million special table chickens, or ‘broilers’,
were produced in 1967.

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 303
Horticultural crops occupy only a small fraction of the cultivated land of
the country—about 2^ per cent of the area under crops and grass—but
their value in terms of output per acre is very high. The total value of
horticultural crops sold in 1967-68 is estimated at about £194 million,
compared with some £384 million for farm crops in the United Kingdom.
About 410,000 acres are under vegetables and about 230,000 acres under
fruit.
Market gardening has grown up around all the large centres of population,
notably in the Lea Valley, near London, and in more rural areas with favour¬
able soil or climatic conditions—in Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire, Hampshire
and Kent, and in a concentration of smallholdings around Evesham, in the
Avon valley. Districts with mild climates, such as the Penzance region of
Cornwall, have been favoured for the production of selected early crops. More
recently, selected vegetable crops, particularly brassicas and peas, have been
grown in increasing quantities as an alternative to potatoes.
Specialised horticultural holdings range from a few acres up to about
300 acres, and many have glasshouses, frames or forcing houses. Use of
fertilisers, particularly of an organic nature, is very heavy, and much of the
field work is mechanised. The larger holdings normally have specialised
packing sheds, with washing and grading machinery, and irrigation plants.
Growers, however, often join together in co-operatives for marketing their
produce and many of these provide grading and packing facilities.
Britain has some 4,000 acres of glasshouses, about half of the area being
used primarily for the cultivation of tomatoes, the main centres of which
are the Lea Valley in Essex and Hertfordshire, and the Worthing district in
Sussex. In the Lea Valley, on a narrow belt of gravel and brick earth, over
500 acres are covered with glass. Production of tomatoes is estimated at about
75,000-80,000 tons annually and the value of all glasshouse crops (including
flowers) at some ^35 million to ^40 million per year.
Hard fruits grow well in many parts of England and Wales, the chief risk
associated with their culture being late frosts. The main centres are in the
south, south-west and east of England, and Kent in particular. Dessert apple
production, particularly Cox’s Orange Pippin, has increased in recent years
while that of cooking apples has declined. About 23,000 acres of varieties of
cider apple are grown mainly in Devon, Herefordshire and Somerset for the
cider-making industry. In Northern Ireland there are 7,000 acres of cooking
apples—Bramley Seedlings—mostly concentrated in County Armagh. Plums
and soft fruits are grown in many counties; concentrations of plums are found
in Kent and Worcestershire, of blackcurrants in Norfolk, Kent and Hereford,
of cherries in Kent and of strawberries in the Wisbech area, Kent and Hamp¬
shire. Raspberries are exceptional in that of some 8,300 acres grown in Britain
over four-fifths are in Scotland, mainly in the Blairgowrie district of Perthshire
and in Angus.
Hop-growing for the brewing industry is confined to two main areas, in
Kent and Sussex and in Herefordshire and Worcestershire. Capital outlay
and cultivation costs are very high, but crops per acre average about 12 cwt.,
worth some ^450. The total annual value of the crop is about £8^ million.
Estimates of farm expenses and sales and the aggregate net income of agri¬
cultural producers are prepared annually by the agricultural departments
(see Table 24). They show that Britain’s farming is based on livestock; two-
thirds of farmers’ income is derived from the sale of animals or their products.
The aggregate net income of farmers rose from £393 million in 1960-61 to

industry has averaged ^260 million during the past five years.
Rising items in farm outlays are machinery and equipment, amounting
currently to about one-sixth of total expenses. Feedingstuffs contribute almost
one-third. Since 1956 wages have risen by nearly 80 per cent, offsetting the
manpower economies made possible by mechanisation.
Until 1958 rents tended to lag behind other costs. This was due partly to
the reluctance of landlords to put up the rents of satisfactory tenants, and
partly to the terms of reference given to arbitrators. These terms were
modified in the Agriculture Act 1958 and since i960 rents in England and
Wales have gone up by over two-thirds.
The capital required for land and buildings may be provided by the farmer,
if he is an owner-occupier, or by the landlord, if the farm is let to a tenant.
Each year ‘fixed capital’ totalling about £75 million is added to the value of
land and buildings (annual gross investment in fixed assets exceeds £185
million). The bulk of the capital required to stock and run the farms is
provided by the occupiers. Bank advances are an important source of outside
capital, both fixed and working; about half the total bank advances to agri¬
culture are believed to be for short-term purposes. Agricultural merchants are
also an important source of short-term credit. Mortgage loans form the chief
source of long-term credit and are provided by building societies, insurance
companies, private sources, and specialised financial institutions (see p. 309).
Accounts of some 2,200 farms in England and Wales, analysed by university
agricultural economists in 1966-67, show average valuations of occupiers’
capital ranging from over £10 to more than £55 per acre. In Scotland a similar
sample of 800 accounts shows a wide range in tenants’ capital per acre, from
about ^3 on hill sheep farms with extensive rough grazings to between ^50

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 3°5
and £60 per acre on lower ground farms. In Northern Ireland average valua¬
tions of occupiers’ capital range from over £80 on the smaller, more intensive
farms to £40 per acre on the larger farms. On all types of farms investment
in machinery is a heavy item: on dairy farms it averages £ij per acre and on
arable farms nearly £20 per acre; on stock-rearing farms it may amount to
£9 per acre.
Britain has one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world, with nearly half a
million tractors in 1967, or one to every 36 acres of arable land. Power-take-off
implements now characterise arable farming; and some 65,000 combine
harvesters were in use in 1967. A wide variety of machines for harvesting and
preservation of grass are employed. Milking machines are installed on all
except the smallest farms, many with mechanical means of handling milk.
Over 90 per cent of the farms in Great Britain have an electricity supply
and accompanying equipment. There are about 1,050 farmers’ machinery
syndicates through which farmers have the use of expensive equipment
without tying up their own capital.
Research, development and testing of farm machinery are carried out by
the National Institute of Agricultural Engineering.
The range of net incomes between individual farms is very wide, varying
with the type and size of farm, quality of land, and managerial ability of the
occupier. The average net income for farms of different types is within the
range of ^5 to £15 per acre with the exception of pig and poultry farms and
horticultural holdings, which are more intensive in their use of land. Net
income per acre on dairy and arable farms has nearly always been higher than
on stock-rearing farms, which are generally larger than the other types and
are situated on poorer land.
By the beginning of the 1930s the need for some form of State assistance
to agriculture had become pressing; it was during this time that the
Government initiated the various forms of protection and financial assistance
for agriculture.
During the second world war and the immediate post-war years, agri¬
cultural production was closely controlled by the State, with County War
Agricultural Executive Committees, composed of landowners, farmers and
farm workers, acting as the Government’s local agents.
Government policy today is founded on the Agriculture Act 1947- The
main objective, as set out in Section 1 of the Act, continues to be a stable
and efficient agricultural industry capable of producing such part of the
nation’s food and other agricultural produce as in the national interest it is
desirable to produce in the United Kindom, and of producing it at minimum
prices consistent with proper remuneration and living conditions for farmers
and workers in agriculture and an adequate return on capital invested in
the industry’. To this end, the Government is empowered to provide, for
the main agricultural products, guaranteed prices determined in the light of
annual reviews (see p. 306).
The Agriculture Act of 1957 assured farmers that the prices guaranteed
under the 1947 Act would not be steeply reduced, and at the same time
provided grants towards the cost of bringing fixed equipment up to date.
The Agriculture and Horticulture Act 1964 gave the Government powers
to introduce minimum import prices for agricultural and horticultural
3°6

Machinery of
Government
CURRENT
SUPPORT POLICY
Annual Review
products. These powers have been used in the case of cereals. In the same
year an understanding with overseas suppliers on the sharing of the bacon
market became effective.
Under the selective expansion programme announced in 1965 the agri¬
cultural industry is expected to increase production to meet the major part
of the growth in demand for temperate foodstuffs by 1970 and to release
substantial manpower resources. The main emphasis in expansion is on the
production of meat, particularly beef. A substantial part of the increased
demand for cereal feed would be grown at home.
The functions of government in relation to agriculture are mostly exercised
by the agricultural ministers, that is to say, for England and Wales the
Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, for Scotland the Secretary of
State for Scotland, and for Northern Ireland the Home Secretary, who is the
minister responsible for United Kingdom aspects of Northern Ireland
agriculture, local aspects being the responsibility of the Northern Ireland
Minister of Agriculture. The agricultural ministers are assisted by advisory
committees composed of general agriculturists, scientists and other specialists.
The headquarters of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food is
divided functionally, each division being responsible for a particular subject
or service. Its relations with individual farmers are conducted mainly through
its local offices, grouped in England in regions, each administered by a
regional controller working in close collaboration with the regional heads of the
technical services. Local offices in Wales are grouped under a Welsh Secretary
with similar functions and with special responsibility for Welsh affairs.
In Scotland most of the agricultural functions of the Secretary of State are
discharged through the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries. The
Secretary of State for Scotland also appoints the members of the Crofters
Commission (see p. 310) and the Red Deer Commission, which deals with the
conservation and control of red deer.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture is responsible for imple¬
menting agricultural policy inaugurated by the Northern Ireland Government.
It is organised on similar lines to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and
Food, for which it acts as agent in the administration in Northern Ireland
of United Kingdom agricultural schemes.
In November 1966 an Economic Development Committee (see p. 234) for
agriculture was established, comprising representatives of farmers, workers
and landowners, as well as official members.
In February each year, in accordance with the 194? ACF t^ie agricultural
ministers review the economic condition and prospects of the industry.
Between annual reviews, a special review may be held if the ministers consider
it warranted, but this has seldom been necessary. In holding reviews, the
ministers are required to consult with representatives of agricultural pro¬
ducers—in practice, the three farmers’ unions in the United Kingdom. The
ministers consider such factors as production trends and market requirements,
world market prospects, the cost of subsidies, the trend of profits in the
industry as a whole, the increasing efficiency of the industry and changes in
production costs, trading relations (especially with the Commonwealth) and
the national economic situation. In the light of their conclusions, they
determine guaranteed prices for fat cattle, fat sheep, fat pigs, eggs, wool,
milk, cereals, potatoes and sugar beet. These guarantees apply to livestock
and livestock products for the ensuing 12 months, and to crops to be
Price
Guarantees
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 307
harvested in the current year. Various grants in aid of particular kinds of
production or farming practice (known as ‘production grants’) are also
considered. Any changes in ‘relevant’ production grants (broadly, those
payable to occupiers rather than landowners) are taken into account. The
Government’s conclusions and its decisions on changes in guaranteed prices
and relevant production grants are published as a White Paper.
The long-term assurances provided for in the 1957 Act require the total
value of the guaranteed prices and relevant production grants in any year to be
maintained at not less than 97^ per cent of their value in the preceding year,
after allowing for changes in costs. In addition, the guaranteed price (adjusted
for any change in the basis of the guarantee) for each commodity must be
not less than 96 per cent of that of the previous year. For livestock and live¬
stock products—where farmers’ decisions need time to take effect—there is
a further provision that reductions in the guaranteed price for any product
must not total more than 9 per cent in a period of three years. The cost of
government support to the industry in 1967-68 was about £262 million; the
estimate for 1968-69, adjusted for the effect of the 1968 review decisions,
forecast an increase to about £317 million.
The general policy of the Government is to use methods of agricultural
support that allow the ordinary channels of trade to flow freely. The form of
guarantee most generally used is the deficiency payment, which means that
the Government makes payments to producers, related to the differences
between the average market price realised and the guaranteed price, for
output eligible for the guarantee.
The deficiency payments schemes for cereals and fatstock are administered
directly by the agricultural departments. Storage incentives are paid to
growers who sell their wheat and barley after the harvest period. ‘Standard
quantity’1 arrangements for wheat and barley were introduced for the 1964
crop but that for wheat was abolished in 1968. Deficiency payments for
fatstock are made weekly to individual producers on certified sales on a
liveweight or deadweight basis, but there may also be a balancing payment at
the end of the year for cattle and sheep if the average return to producers falls
short of the annual guaranteed price.
For most of the remaining commodities the Government operates the
guarantee through the appropriate marketing board, which takes account of
any payments from or to the Government in deciding what to pay producers
for their produce. In the case of milk there are five boards, and the full
guaranteed price is paid only on a ‘standard quantity’ relating to the volume
of liquid milk sales plus a reasonable reserve. Milk produced in excess of
the standard quantity is sold for manufacturing considerably below the full
guaranteed price. The retail price of liquid milk is determined by the
Government so as to cover the full cost of the guarantee and, taking one year
with another, there is no Exchequer subsidy. For eggs, a subsidy is paid to
the British Egg Marketing Board on all first-quality eggs sold to the Board
through packing stations. A deficiency payment is made for potatoes in years
1 The Agriculture Act 1947 postulates that the guarantees should be related to the
volume of agricultural produce which, in the national interest, it is desirable to produce
domestically (see p. 305). This is effected by including standard quantities in the
guarantee arrangements for milk, pigs, barley, potatoes and sugar beet. Standard
quantity’ agreements vary in form but, in general, the basic guaranteed price deter¬
mined in the Annual Review is related to a specific quantity of produce marketed
annually on a national basis; if this quantity is exceeded, the producers’ average unit
return falls.

in which the growers’ average price for potatoes for human consumption
(excluding new potatoes) is less than the guaranteed price; payment is made
to the Potato Marketing Board for the benefit of growers in Great Britain
and to the Ministry of Agriculture, Northern Ireland, for the benefit of
growers there.
For wool a fixed price is guaranteed to the British Wool Marketing Board
for every pound of fleece wool it buys from producers. This enables it to
fix in advance a schedule of producers’ prices, based on types and quality,
after making allowance for the Board’s marketing costs.
Under the Sugar Act 1956 and the Agriculture Act 1957 the British
Sugar Corporation contracts to buy the whole of the sugar beet crop
produced from a specified acreage (at present 443,000 acres) at a scale
of fixed prices, determined as a result of the annual review and related to
sugar content. Refined sugar produced by the Corporation is sold, under
market-sharing agreements with the refiners, at a price based on the world
price.
The Sugar Board buys Commonwealth sugar under the Commonwealth
Sugar Agreement and sells it commercially. The deficits or surpluses which
result from the transactions of both the Corporation and the Board are
ultimately reflected in the Board’s accounts. When these accounts show a
deficit a levy is charged on all sugar, imported or home-produced, entering
the British market, including the sugar content of composite sugar imports,
and when there is a surplus a distribution payment is made correspondingly,
so that taking one year with another the Board balances its accounts.
The price supports outlined above relate only to current production. To
increase productivity, however, the Government offers to farmers a wide
range of inducements, known as production grants, for improvements to land,
crops, livestock and equipment. In 1967-68 the Exchequer’s contribution in
the form of production grants was ^114 million. The form taken by these
schemes varies considerably but they fall into three main categories. Firstly,
improvements to land fertility, which include a subsidy on fertilisers and
lime and grants for field drainage, farm water supply and for ploughing certain
kinds of land; the Exchequer cost of these improvements currently runs at
nearly £47 million a year. The second type of inducement is aimed at main¬
taining and improving breeding herds of cattle and sheep (particularly in
upland areas) and includes a calf subsidy on animals suitable for beef
production; the total cost is about ^45 million a year. The third type consists
of a contribution towards farm improvements generally but with particular
reference to farm buildings, silage, roads, drainage, fences and other equip¬
ment. A special business management scheme exists to help small farmers
improve the efficiency of their holdings. A grant is also available to farmers and
growers to encourage the keeping of farm business records as an aid to sound
management decisions. Under the Agriculture Act 1967 a hill land improve¬
ment scheme was introduced which provides for 50 per cent grants for various
improvements designed to increase the productivity of hill land.
Under the Agriculture Act 1967 the Government is empowered to make
grants to meet 50 per cent of the approved costs of voluntary amalgamations
of small farms with other land to form commercial units; and to pay lump
sums or annuities to farmers who give up such holdings for amalgamation.
Where an owner wishes to dispose of an uncommercial holding the Govern¬
ment may buy it outright for this purpose.

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 309
Horticultural produce, because it is perishable and liable to seasonal variation
in quantity and quality, does not lend itself to a system of guaranteed prices.
Hitherto the principal means of support has been tariffs on imports, but
greater emphasis is now being placed on the need to strengthen the com¬
petitive efficiency of the industry so as to reduce its dependence upon tariffs.
To this end grants of one-third are available to meet the capital cost of a wide
range of buildings, plant and equipment used in the production, storage,
preparation for market and transport of horticultural produce. Additionally,
small-scale horticulturists who are prepared to undertake a three-year
programme for improving the efficiency of their businesses may qualify for a
grant of up to ^500. The cost to the Exchequer of these schemes is about
million a year.
Special arrangements for the agricultural and horticultural industries have
been made under the investment incentives procedure which replaced invest¬
ment allowances in 1966. Broadly speaking, the Minister of Agriculture in
England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the Secretary of State in Scotland
are empowered to pay grants of 10 per cent of approved expenditure on fixed
equipment, plant and machinery, agricultural tractors and self-propelled
harvesters, and 5 per cent supplements to other improvement grants with a
basic rate of 45 per cent or less. For expenditure incurred between January
1967 and December 1968 grants have been paid at 15 per cent for tractors and
self-propelled harvesters, and at 12J per cent for fixed equipment.
A number of facilities for specific purposes enjoy government encouragement
and support.
In England and Wales finance for the purchase or improvement of agri¬
cultural property is available from the Agricultural Mortgage Corporation
Ltd. (see p. 372). The Corporation’s funds are derived mainly from public
issues of stock, but it receives a measure of government support. Similarly
in Scotland, loans for agricultural purposes secured on agricultural land in
Scotland are granted by the Scottish Agricultural Securities Corporation Ltd.
Improvement loans for carrying out improvements to agricultural land and
buildings are also available to landowners from the Lands Improvement
Company, whose funds are provided privately.
In Northern Ireland loans are available to farmers from the Agricultural
Loans Fund, administered by the Ministry of Agriculture and financed out
of public funds. Half of the loans issued are short-term for agricultural
machinery and the remainder are medium- or long-term loans for such
purposes as the purchase of livestock and the erection and improvement of
farm buildings and farm dwellings.
Under the Agriculture Act 1967 the Government can make loans in Great
Britain to help finance the purchase of land acquired for approved amalgam¬
ations of small farms (see p. 308), and approved remodelling expenditure.
These loans may be granted up to 90 per cent (100 per cent for certain small
amalgamations) of the valuation of the combined unit determined by the
Agricultural Mortgage Corporation Ltd. in England and Wales and the
Scottish Agricultural Securities Corporation Ltd. in Scotland, who act as the
Government’s agents.
Since 1892 county councils and county borough councils in England and
Wales have had powers to provide land for smallholdings. County councils are
obliged by Statute to provide smallholdings and the Minister of Agriculture
310
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Crofting
Arterial
Drainage and
Sea Defence
is empowered to contribute towards their losses. In England and Wales,
about 13,750 smallholdings are provided by local authorities and about
1,100 by the Ministry. The Minister may also make loans for working
capital to tenants of statutory smallholdings. In this way they can be helped
to obtain livestock, machinery, implements and other necessary items;
tenants must, however, have available at least 25 per cent of the capital
required.
Land settlement in Scotland has always been carried out by the central
Government, which now owns and maintains about 420,000 acres of land
settlement estates, with some 3,600 holdings.
In the seven Scottish crofting counties—Argyll, Caithness, Inverness,
Orkney, Ross and Cromarty, Sutherland, and Shetland—much of the land is
farmed by crofters, tenant farmers whose holdings are generally either
rented at a cost of not more than £50 a year or have an area not exceeding
75 acres.
In these counties there are about 19,000 crofts, which produce about
one-quarter of the total agricultural output of the area. The special problems
of the crofting counties, which had for some time been suffering from a
declining population, led to the setting up, in i955> a Crofters Commission
whose functions are to reorganise, develop and regulate crofting in the
crofting counties, to promote the interests of crofters and to keep under review
matters relating to crofting. The Commission’s statutory powers include
supervising the letting of crofts and (if the crofters agree) the reallocation of
land to form viable and self-contained communities; it also acts as the
Secretary of State’s agent in administering development grants and loans.
Land drainage (including flood protection) in England and Wales is the
responsibility of 27 river authorities (see p. 266), two catchment and 372
internal drainage boards. Local authorities also have general drainage powers.
There are no comparable authorities in Scotland, where arterial drainage of
agricultural land is the owners’ responsibility. River authorities have powers to
maintain and improve watercourses scheduled as main rivers. Their work
is concerned with the improvement of land drainage by increasing the capacity
and efficiency of rivers and erecting pumping stations, the prevention of
inland flooding and the erection of defences to protect low-lying areas from
coastal flooding. River authorities also have powers relating to water resources
generally, freshwater fisheries and river pollution.
Internal drainage boards are concerned with very much smaller areas and
their work is chiefly in low-lying agricultural districts. Their main function is
to keep the land drained in their area by improving the main drains and,
where necessary, by pumping from low-lying land.
Drainage authorities derive their income directly or indirectly from local
authority funds. The Government pays grants towards the cost of the
improvement schemes. Grants to river authorities vary from 10 per cent to
80 per cent according to the financial position of the authority, with an
additional premium for sea defence works. Internal drainage boards receive
grants at a flat rate of 50 per cent. Local authorities receive grants varying
from 20 per cent to 50 per cent. In Scotland 50 per cent grants are available
to owners of agricultural land.
In Northern Ireland the Ministry of Agriculture is the drainage authority
in respect of watercourses designated by the Drainage Council as main or
minor watercourses.

,and Tenure
MARKETING
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 3II
In Great Britain about half, and in Northern Ireland almost all, farms are
owner-occupied. The traditional form of tenancy in England and Wales runs
from year to year; in Scotland longer leases for terms of 10 to 14 years are
more common, although most tenants farm on a year-to-year basis. The
tenancy agreement may be either written or verbal (in Scotland it must be
written if the period of the lease exceeds one year) and may (but need not)
include provisions about such matters as rights of cropping, liability for repair
and maintenance, and compensation for tenant’s improvements.
In order to protect the respective interests of landlords and tenants and to
eliminate uncertainty as to their rights and liabilities, a code of landlord and
tenant relationships has been written into legislation. The Agriculture Acts
1947 (England and Wales) and 1948 (Scotland) lay down the basic rules of
good estate management and good husbandry for owners and occupiers
respectively. The Agricultural Holdings Acts 1948 (England and Wales)
and 1949 (Scotland) contain more detailed provisions concerning the rights
and obligations of landlords and tenants.
The Acts provide for any tenancy of agricultural land, with the exception
of certain short-term lettings to which exemption can be given by the Minister
or Secretary of State, to continue in force from year to year until terminated
by a valid notice to quit. With certain exceptions the tenant can contest it
by serving a counter-notice; the notice to quit then becomes inoperative
unless the landlord can satisfy an independent body (in England and Wales
the Agricultural Land Tribunal and in Scotland the Scottish Land Court) that
his claim for possession is in the interests of sound estate management or good
husbandry or that the land is required for certain purposes specified in the
Acts.
The Acts lay down a code of compensation to which the tenant is entitled
on termination of the tenancy. Rent is a matter for negotiation between
landlord and tenant and may be varied by agreement at any time or, failing
agreement, by arbitration at intervals of not less than three years in England
and Wales and five years in Scotland.
Agricultural products are marketed mainly through private trade channels
such as corn merchants, livestock auctions and markets, and bacon factories;
or through producers’ co-operative organisations. For certain commodities,
however, marketing arrangements are influenced by boards operating under
the Agricultural Marketing Act 1958 (which consolidated earlier legislation).
These marketing boards are producers’ organisations with statutory powers
to regulate the marketing of particular products. The schemes under which
they are constituted and operate must be approved by Parliament and
confirmed by a poll of the producers. Most of the members of the boards are
elected by the producers but a minority are appointed by the minister or
ministers concerned. Further safeguards serve to protect consumers and other
interests affected by schemes and the public interest generally.
Marketing boards fall into two broad categories: first, those which have
powers to trade as the first selling agency for all producers not specially
exempted or, alternatively, to exercise a comparable influence by controlling
all contracts between producers and first buyers; and, secondly, boards
which maintain only a broad control over marketing conditions, leaving
producers free otherwise to deal individually with buyers. The boards for
eggs, hops, milk and wool fall into the first category and the potato board into
the second. Northern Ireland has its own marketing boards, based on local
legislation, for milk, pigs and seed potatoes.

The Home-Grown Cereals Authority, established to improve the marketing
of home-grown cereals, operates a scheme of bonuses and provides market
intelligence. It has reserve trading powers.
The Meat and Livestock Commission, established under the Agriculture
Act 1967, is charged with improving the production, marketing and distribu¬
tion of livestock and meat in Great Britain. It has a range of executive functions
extending from breeding to retail distribution, one of the most important
of which is to evolve a general scheme of carcase classification. It is not
empowered to trade in either livestock or meat.
Grants of up to one-third are available for the modernisation of major
wholesale horticultural markets; Co vent Garden market is being moved to a
new site in south London, which should be in operation in the early 1970s.
National statutory grades are being introduced to improve the competitive
position of home produce as against imported supplies and to speed its transit
through distributive channels. By May 1968 grades had been introduced for
apples, pears, tomatoes, cucumbers and cauliflowers.
The Apple and Pear Development Council publicises home-grown apples
and pears to increase sales.
In 1962 the Government earmarked ^i|- million to assist the financing of
research and development in the marketing of agricultural and horticultural
produce. By March 1968 grants totalling about £1-2 million had been
approved, the majority of applications have come from producer groups and
more than half relate to livestock or meat. The grant ceiling has been raised
to j£2 million and the scheme extended to March 1971 ass^ marketing
developments other than those of a co-operative nature.
The Agriculture Act 1967 provided for the setting up of the Central Council
for Agricultural and Horticultural Co-operation to promote and develop
co-operation in agriculture and horticulture and to administer a scheme of
grants. The Agricultural and Horticultural Co-operation Scheme 1967
incorporates and extends grants for the co-operative marketing of agricultural
and horticultural produce.
The day-to-day work of treating animal disease is the responsibility of the
veterinary profession in private practice. The State veterinary service,
inaugurated in 1865 and covering Great Britain, deals with situations beyond
the control of the individual veterinary surgeon. Centred on London and
Edinburgh, it is able to deal promptly with outbreaks of notifiable diseases.
For many years Britain has been free from many serious animal diseases,
including rinderpest, sheep scab, glanders and rabies. The campaign to
eradicate swine fever has been successful. A major epidemic of foot and mouth
disease was experienced towards the end of 1967 but was combated success¬
fully by stringent slaughter. In i960 the whole of the United Kingdom
became a bovine tuberculosis attested area. The incidence of bovine tuber¬
culosis is now very low; all cattle are tuberculin tested at regular intervals and
reactors to the test are slaughtered, compensation being paid to the owners.
In 1967 the Brucellosis (Accredited Herds) scheme was introduced as a first
stage towards eradication of the disease.
The work of the service is backed by the extensive facilities of the Central
Veterinary Laboratory at Weybridge, Surrey, and those of its subsidiary
laboratory at Lasswade, near Edinburgh. In addition, there are 19 investiga¬
tion centres with well-equipped laboratories in England and Males. These
centres perform work requiring specialist knowledge and give advice on
