AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 313
disease problems to private practitioners. In Scotland a similar service is
provided by the investigation centres of the three Scottish agricultural colleges.
In Northern Ireland the veterinary services are organised similarly to those
in Great Britain but are administered separately by the Northern Ireland
Government. Animal Health Control policies and the geographical situation
have kept the country free from nearly all the major epizootic diseases. A
scheme for the eradication of brucellosis is expected to be completed by the
end of 1968. The full-time veterinary service is supplemented by the central
veterinary laboratory at Stormont, Belfast.
The State plant health service is responsible for statutory controls designed
to limit the spread of plant pests and diseases present in Britain and prevent
the introduction of new ones from abroad. It also issues the health certificates
required by other countries to accompany plant material imported from
Britain. Voluntary certification schemes are operated to encourage the develop¬
ment of healthy, vigorous and true-to-type planting stocks, particularly of
crops subject to degenerative diseases.
It has been recognised that effective safeguards are needed against the dangers
arising from uncontrolled use of pesticides. The Regulations made under the
Agriculture (Poisonous Substances) Act 1952 provides protection for workers
using the more toxic chemicals. The voluntary Pesticides Safety Precautions
Scheme, operated by the Government with the full backing of the industry,
ensures that new pesticides for use in agriculture and food storage, or new
methods of using existing pesticides, are not introduced until enough experi¬
mental work has been done on their attendant hazards (including contamina¬
tion of food and harm to wild life) to allow the Government to make
recommendations for their safe use. Products approved for safety may then
be submitted through the Agricultural Chemicals Approval Scheme for
efficiency approval. There is also a voluntary Veterinary Products Safety
Precautions Scheme on similar lines.
A key role in the administration of both these schemes is played by the
Government’s Advisory Committee on Pesticides and Other Toxic Chemicals.
Reports of this Committee, published in 1964, concluded that there was no
evidence that the use of the persistent organochlorine pesticides presented
any immediate hazard to human beings and animals, apart from certain
species of predatory birds. This Committee also recommended in its review
that the voluntary safety precautions schemes should be replaced by compul¬
sory licensing arrangements.
In England and Wales free technical advice on all agricultural and horticultural
matters is available through the Ministry’s National Agricultural Advisory
Service (NAAS), which is organised on a regional and county basis. Every
county has a county agricultural adviser and is divided into districts, in each
of which there is a district agricultural adviser who can call on an extensive
system of specialist advisers. In Northern Ireland advisory work is organised
by the Ministry of Agriculture, with a county organisation similar to the
NAAS. In Scotland the advisory services, also similar in scope to the NAAS,
are based on the three agricultural colleges.
The Agricultural Land Service, through its qualified land agents, surveyors
and architects, provides a service without charge to owners and occupiers of
both agricultural and horticultural land needing advice on problems arising
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
from the ownership of land, and investment connected with it. The services
include general advice on the design, layout and construction or improvement
of all types of farm buildings as well as roads, fences and effluent disposal.
The Service also provides professional advice and services to the Ministry
of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food.

Basic agricultural research in Britain is described on p. 196. In England and
Wales, research and advice on farm economics are combined in the Provincial
Agricultural Economics Service, which comprise ten university Departments
of Agricultural Economics and which is co-ordinated by the Ministry of
Agriculture, Fisheries and Food. In Scotland, agricultural economists are
on the staff of the three agricultural colleges. The agricultural departments
in England and Wales and Scotland have economics and statistics units.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture also has an Economics and
Statistics Division. Nine other Research Divisions, including a Biometrics
Division, deal with different aspects of agricultural research and development.
Agricultural There are four types of institution which provide full-time education in
Education agricultural subjects: universities; non-maintained agricultural colleges, in
England and Wales, county agricultural colleges and institutes; and in
Scotland, farm schools. Twelve universities in Britain provide degree and
postgraduate training in agriculture. A National College of Agricultural
Engineering was established in i960 at Silsoe, Bedfordshire, and it offers
degree and postgraduate courses in agricultural engineering.
Two-year diploma courses and some specialised courses are given at the
four non-maintained agricultural colleges and at three of the county agricul¬
tural colleges and institutes in England and Wales; three agricultural colleges
in Scotland give two-year to three-year diploma courses and also offer two-
or three-term certificate courses. In Northern Ireland there are three
agricultural colleges and two more are planned. In England and Wales a new
pattern of sandwich-type diploma courses is expected to start at selected
agricultural colleges and institutes in the autumn of 1969.
There are 31 county agricultural colleges and institutes in England and
five in Wales run by local education authorities. They provide residential
courses in general agriculture, dairying, horticulture, poultry husbandry and
rural domestic economy. Local education authorities also provide short
courses and classes for farmers, farm workers, horticulturists and domestic
producers. _ . .
There are nine farm schools in Scotland, run by local education authorities,
providing courses—mainly residential—of from one to three years duration
for boys and girls of from 12 to 16 years. There is one residential agricultural
school in Northern Ireland, which provides short courses for boys and girls
over 15 years of age. .
Courses in land management are available at the Universities of Cambridge
and London and at the Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester.
FISHERIES
The sea fishing industry is of especial importance to the economy of Scotland.
It is also an important single source of employment in some of the major
fishing ports. The industry falls into three main divisions, concerned res¬
pectively with white fish, herring and shellfish. The major element of the
Fishing Ports
Methods of
Sea Fishing
The Fishing
Fleet
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 315
catch (about 85 per cent by weight) is white fish: the catches of herring and
shellfish, although important, are relatively small. White fish are demersal fish
(such as cod, haddock, plaice, turbot and sole) which live on or near the sea
bed, and also pelagic fish (such as pilchard, mackerel and sprats) which live
mainly in intermediate waters or near the surface. Herring is a pelagic species
and constitutes a separate fishery. Shellfish include Crustacea (such as
lobsters, nephrops and crabs) and molluscs (such as escallops, mussels, cockles
and oysters).
The white fish section of the industry is made up of three main groups:
the distant water, the near and middle water, and the inshore fisheries. The
distant waters are those round Iceland and in the west Atlantic, Greenland,
Bear Island and the north coast of Norway, and the Barents Sea; the middle
water grounds lie around the Faroe Islands; and the near water grounds are
those in the North Sea, the Irish Sea and in the coastal areas around Britain.
The herring fishing grounds are mainly within 60 miles of land. The inshore
waters also yield considerable quantities of shellfish.
The principal fishing ports in England and Wales are Hull, Grimsby, Fleet-
wood, Milford Haven, North Shields and Lowestoft. In Scotland the chief
centres for white fish are Aberdeen, Granton, Fraserburgh, the Moray Firth,
the West Coast and Shetland Islands; herring landings are made mainly at
the east coast ports of Aberdeen, Fraserburgh and Peterhead, the west coast
ports of Ullapool, Mallaig, Oban, Tarbert and Ayr, and in Shetland Islands.
In Northern Ireland the fishing ports are Ardglass, Portavogie and Kilkeel.
The chief methods of catching fish are by trawling, seining, lining, and ring
and drift netting. Trawling is carried out throughout the year in the distant
and near waters for all species of demersal fish. Seining is also used for
catching demersal fish all the year round, mainly in the North Sea, the
Minches, the Firth of Clyde, and the Irish Sea. There are about 650 Scottish
and Northern Ireland seiners, and about 155 operating from English ports.
The pelagic fisheries are seasonal. There is summer fishing for herring
based on the Shetlands, the east coast ports of Scotland, and the north-east
coast ports of England. Other seasonal fisheries take place off the west coast of
Scotland, in the Isle of Man area and off southern Ireland.
The inshore fisheries comprise a great diversity of types of vessels and
methods of capture; in addition, there are extensive fisheries for crabs,
lobsters, shrimps, mussels, escallops, cockles and oysters, and, off Scotland,
north-east England and in the Irish Sea there are valuable catches of
‘Norway lobsters’ (nephrops or Dublin Bay prawns).
Distant water vessels, which operate mainly from Hull, Grimsby and
Fleetwood, numbered 182 at the end of 1967. They are mostly over 140 feet in
length and most of them make voyages of 17 to 23 days to fishing grounds in
the Arctic Circle. Partly due to the introduction of freezer trawlers and
factory vessels, there has been an increasing tendency to fish the waters
bordering Newfoundland, Labrador and Greenland. These vessels spend
from one to three months at sea and freeze, in some cases as fillets, much or
all of their catch immediately it is taken. At the same date, near and middle
water vessels numbered 398; they are between 80 and 140 feet long and most
of them work nearer home, making voyages of from a few days up to more
than two weeks, although some of the larger vessels fish regularly off the
Faroes and seasonally as far afield as Iceland. Included in the near water group
Supplies

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
are vessels engaged in drift net fishing for herring; these vessels usually make
daily voyages. The inshore group consists mainly of vessels of under 80 feet
which, except for seiners, are seldom at sea for longer than two or three days
and more usually make daily landings, often fishing within sight of land.
In the British fishing industry in 1967 there were about 19,000 fishermen
in regular employment and some 5,000 occasionally employed; about two-
fifths of the former and one-third of the latter were from Scottish ports. In
Northern Ireland there are about 500 regular fishermen.
In 1967 landings of fish, both demersal and pelagic, by British fishing vessels
totalled 890,000 tons (700,000 tons of demersal fish, 149,000 tons of pelagic
and 41,000 tons of shellfish), valued at about £61 million. Landings at British
ports by foreign vessels totalled about 165,000 tons of fresh and frozen fish
(including 48,000 tons brought direct from the fishing grounds), valued at
about £1*] million. Cod accounted for 40 per cent of the total value of wTet
fish (that is, fish other than shellfish) landed by British vessels; haddock (15
per cent) and plaice (5 per cent) were the other most important sources of
earnings to the industry.
Imports of all types of fish (fresh, frozen, salted, canned or otherwise
preserved) in 1967 amounted to about 213,000 tons valued at £67 million,
including 39,000 tons of canned salmon to the value of £27 million and other
canned fish worth £12 million.
Weekly disposals of fresh, frozen and cured fish (excluding shellfish and
imported canned fish) in Britain averaged about 16,000 tons landed weight
in 1967. Although consumption had been declining slightly, on an edible
(fillet) weight basis, it was 16-6 lb. per head in 1967 in comparison with a peak
total of 28-7 lb. in 1948 (see Table 23).
Processing and packaging of fish—curing, kippering, canning and quick-
freezing for consumer packs—are the subject of continuing research and
development. The growth of quick-frozen fish production has altered
radically the structure of the industry. With the increase in quick-freezing
(which now processes about one-fifth of all white fish landings), new export
outlets have opened up for white fish, which in 1967 accounted for just under
half the total exports of fish and fish preparations, valued at £<)-5 million.
The expansion of markets abroad for quick-frozen fish, mainly in Europe,
was checked in 1967; herring exports, however, showed a slight recovery.
A valuable by-product of the industry is the manufacture of fish meal for
animal food and to a much lesser extent for fertilisers. Home production of
white fish meal and herring meal in 1967 was 80,000 tons.
The main commercial freshwater catches are salmon, sea-trout and eels. In
Scotland and Northern Ireland, fixed nets along the coast and sweep or
draught nets in rivers and estuaries are used; in England, drift nets are used
for catching salmon in the sea, and draught nets and fixed traps in estuaries.
In England and Wales the value of the salmon catch is approximately
,£275,000 a year, in Scotland it amounts to over £2 million, and in Northern
Ireland to some £200,000. In Northern Ireland, eels worth about .£320,000
a year are captured by long lines and by eel nets placed in river weirs.
The principal inland wholesale distributing centre for fish is Billingsgate
Market in London, which handles about 300 tons a day, but other large
cities also have central fish markets. The principal method of distribution is
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 31?
through wholesalers, located at the ports, who buy at the auctions and sell
to inland wholesalers; the port wholesalers prepare the fish for onward ship¬
ment. Special express fish trains transport the catch daily from some ports to
inland centres, but increasing use is being made of road transport. Retail
sales are handled by some 25,000 to 30,000 fishmongers and fish friers; the
latter use about a third of the landings of white fish.
Trawler-owning companies have entered into the marketing and distribu¬
tive system. This process has been encouraged by the growing popularity of
quick-frozen consumer packs, which are sold by other retail outlets, such as
grocers, as well as by fishmongers.

The government departments mainly responsible for the administration of
legislation concerning the fishing industry are the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food, the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland
and the Ministry of Agriculture for Northern Ireland. The safety and
welfare of crews of fishing vessels are provided for under the Merchant
Shipping Acts administered by the Board of Trade, under whose aegis a
committee of enquiry into deep-sea trawler safety was set up early in 1968.
The Herring Industry Board was set up under the Herring Industry Act
x935 reorganise, develop and regulate the herring industry; subsequent
amending Acts have also been passed. The Board consists of a chairman and
three other members, all part-time and independent of the industry, who are
appointed jointly by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, the
Secretary of State for Scotland and the Home Secretary. The Board, whose
activities are financed partly by levies and licence fees and partly by govern¬
ment grants and loans, is advised by the Herring Industry Advisory Council,
consisting of 33 members representing all sections of the industry and
consumers.
The functions of the Board include the promotion of sales of herring, both
at home and abroad, and the application of the benefits of technical progress
to the industry, including the adoption of new methods of catching, processing
and distributing herring. The Board administers the government grant and
loan schemes which provide for assistance towards the purchase of new fishing
vessels, and the improvement of existing vessels. Fishermen may also obtain
loans from the Board towards the purchase of second-hand vessels under
80 feet in length and towards the cost of new nets and gear. Up to 31st March
1968 £1,897,000 in loans and £1,059,000 in grants had been advanced.
The White Fish Authority and the Committee for Scotland and Northern
Ireland of the Authority were set up under the Sea Fish Industry Act 1951.
The function of the Authority is to reorganise, develop and regulate the white
fish industry, and that of the Committee to advise the Authority about the
exercise and performance of its functions in Scotland and Northern Ireland.
The Authority is composed of a chairman and six members, and the Scottish
Committee of five members and a chairman who is a member of the
Authority. They are appointed jointly by the Minister of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food, the Secretary of State for Scotland and the Home
Secretarv. The White Fish Industry Advisory Council was also set up under
the 1951 Act to advise the Authority about the exercise and performance of its
functions. It consists of 52 members representing the various interests of the
fishing industry.
The White Fish Authority administers government grant and loan
schemes for the purchase of new fishing vessels and engines and the improve-
3i8
Operating
Subsidies
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
ment of existing vessels. It also administers loans for the purchase of nets and
gear and processing plants. Up to 31st March 1968, £20 million in loans and
£31 million in grants were approved for these purposes by the Authority. Its
other activities are financed by a levy on first-hand sales of fish.
The system which has been in force for some years is that subsidies have been
authorised which vary according to the class of vessel used; they are paid at
the rate of so much per day at sea according to the length of the vessel or at
so much per stone of fish landed, which varies according to the kind of fish,
from certain vessels under 60 feet in length. No subsidy is paid for shellfish.
Subsidies for white fish cost X2‘59 million in 1967-68 and those for herring
£226,000.
Under a new scheme of government financial assistance to the deep-sea
fishing industry, announced in July 1968, account will be taken both of fluctua¬
tions in the industry’s profitability and of the need to preserve an incentive
to efficiency. It is proposed to introduce the new form of subsidy for three
years initially. There will be a basic subsidy of £2 million adjusted by reference
to operating profits in the preceding year. The total annual subsidy will be
limited to £4. million, and payment will be related to the operating efficiency
of vessels, not as at present to their classification.
FORESTRY
The estimated total area of productive woodland in Great Britain is 3-28
million acres, or about 6 per cent of the total land area. If account is taken of
areas of scrub and old felled areas, including those cut down in the second
world war, the total rises to 4-35 million acres, or yf per cent of the land area;
about half of the area is in England, two-fifths in Scotland, the remainder in
Wales. The high proportion of unproductive woodland is largely a legacy of
two wars and, while rehabilitation of these areas continues to proceed, it is
unlikely that all areas (for instance, because of remoteness and poor site
conditions) will be replanted. A measure of the extent of rehabilitation is
provided by the fact that the area of unproductive woodland has been reduced
by 300,000 acres since 1945.
The area of productive forest managed by the Forestry Commission, at
1-65 million acres, represents 50 per cent of the total. The annual rate of
productive forest expansion is currently about 46,500 acres by the Commission
and about 30,000 acres by private woodland owners. The Commission’s
programme includes considerable planting in upland areas, especially in
Scotland, and consists mainly of conifers because of the difficult site conditions
encountered. The major species used are Sitka spruce, Lodgepole pine,
Scots pine and Norway spruce. In the older woodlands and taking the country
as a whole, the most common coniferous trees are Scots pine, Sitka spruce,
Norway spruce and the larches, while, among the broadleaved, beech and
oak occur widely.
Except for the period of the two world wars, when much over-felling took
place, home woodlands have until recent years made only a limited contribu¬
tion to the nation’s total requirements of wood and wood products. Britain
imports 90 per cent of its needs by volume, and a higher proportion still by
value, the total import cost of wood and wood products averaging £512 million
over the years 1962 to 1967.

Forestry
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 319
The Forestry Acts 1919 to 1945 established the Forestry Commission as the
national forestry authority charged with promoting the interests of forestry,
the development of afforestation and the production and supply of timber in
Great Britain. As more and more of its coniferous woods reach the production
stage the Commission has assumed an increasingly important role as a
timber seller. The Commission consists of a part-time chairman, four
full-time executive commissioners and five part-time commissioners. The
Commissioners comply with directions given by the forestry ministers, who
are the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and the Secretaries of
State for Scotland and Wales. Northern Ireland has its own separate
organisation (see p. 321).
The Commission’s total estate covers some 2-8 million acres and includes
1-9 million acres of forest land, of which about i-6 million are under trees
in over 400 forests distributed throughout England, Scotland and Wales. All
these forests are covered by management plans, which provide for such work as
planting, road construction, thinning, fire protection, and timber production.
As already stated, a substantial amount of the Forestry Commission’s new
planting is carried out in Scotland, much of it in the Highland counties. The
poorer types of land are being used, such as sour, peaty soil which is unsuitable
for agricultural purposes, but has become suitable for forestry as a result of
advances in the technique of deep ploughing.
Production of coniferous timber from Commission woodlands, mainly by
way of thinnings, is expected to rise from about i-i million tons in 1967 to
about 2-7 million tons by 1980. Some of this kind of produce is meeting
traditional requirements of the coal mines but much is taken by the paper
pulp industry and by factories established to make chipboard.
The Forestry Fund was constituted under the 1919 Forestry Act; from it is
paid all the expenditure of the Forestry Commissioners and into it are paid
amounts voted annually by Parliament, together with the Commission’s
receipts from sales of produce, rentals and other sources. In 1967 drawings
from funds voted by Parliament amounted to ^15-3 million, and receipts
were ^6 million.
Privately owned woods comprise nearly two-thirds of the total forest area in
Great Britain and contain most of the mature and semi-mature timber. The
size of woodlands in individual ownership ranges from a few acres to several
thousand acres, and a high proportion of the private woodland area is in small
ownership (that is, owners of up to about 250 acres).
Impetus was given to the effective management of private woodlands
by the introduction of the Dedication of Woodlands Scheme, initiated in
1947. Under this scheme, owners are invited to put their land permanently
to timber production and to manage their woods in accordance with a plan
agreed with the Forestry Commission, in return for the provision of planting
and management grants and technical advice. By September 1967 the total
area dedicated was 875,000 acres. In addition, there are woodlands covered
by the Approved Woodlands Scheme under which a planting grant, but
no management grant, is paid; and these bring the total area managed
under agreed plans to more than 1 million acres. Woodland owners are
represented, in their relations with the Forestry Commission, by the Forestry
Committee of Great Britain, which co-ordinates the work of two associations
of woodland owners: the Timber Growers’ Organisation (for owners in
England and Wales) and the Scottish Woodland Owners’ Association.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
There are a number of forestry co-operative societies providing for
landowners and farmers the services of skilled staff, centralised purchasing
facilities, and a central agency for the disposal of forest produce. The Forestry'
Commission also co-operates with the principal forestry societies, such as the
Royal Forestry Society of England and Wales and the Royal Scottish Forestry
Society, in disseminating technical knowledge.
In 1959 the Home Grown Timber Marketing Corporation was established
by timber merchants to promote the use of home grown timber.
Under the Forestry Act 1967 the Commissioners maintain national com¬
mittees for England, Scotland and Wales, composed partly of Forestry
Commissioners and partly of persons outside the Commission. These
committees act in an advisory capacity, particularly as to the social, recreational
and amenity aspects of the Commissioners’ activities and relationships with
other land users. The Commissioners also maintain a regional advisory
committee for each Conservancy.
Other bodies have been set up to provide for consultation on the marketing
and utilisation of home grown timber. The Home Grown Timber Advisory
Committee (HGTAC) is a statutory body and includes representatives of
associations of landowners and timber merchants, under an independent
chairman. In 1949 the Forestry Commissioners set up the Advisory Committee
on Utilisation of Home Grown Timber (now a sub-committee of the HGTAC)
to advise on measures designed to promote utilisation of produce from
British woodlands.
A voluntary scheme was agreed upon in 1961 for consultation on proposals
for afforestation of land within National Parks (see p. 172)* The Timber
Growers’ Organisation and the Country Landowners’ Association undertook
to advise their members to notify the park planning authorities about their
planting proposals.
Forestry The Forestry Commission maintains three forester training schools: in
Education and England, at Parkend in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire; in Wales, near
Research Betws-y-Coed in Caernarvonshire; and in Scotland at Faskally, near Pitlochry
in Perthshire. Northerwood House in the New Forest, Hampshire, is the
Commission’s educational centre, and is used for practical courses for
Commission staff and for university students, landowners and agents,
planning officers, school teachers and others.
An Agricultural, Horticultural and Forestry Industry Training Board and a
Furniture and Timber Industry Training Board have been set up to provide
for training in forestry for employees of private woodland owners and in the
home-grown timber trade.
Higher education in forestry is provided at several universities; a
proportion of graduates is recruited by the Commission as forest officers.
The Commission’s Forest Research Station at Alice Holt Lodge, near
Farnham, Surrey, was opened in 1946. Expenditure on research work at this
station and in experimental areas in many forests in Great Britain amounted
to ^7i7)DOO in 1967. This sum included grants for special forestry research
work to various institutions and to university departments including the
Commonwealth Forestry Institute at Oxford, which is also financed b\
the university, the Commonwealth Office and overseas governments.
Research into the qualities of home grown timber is carried out by the Forest
Forestry in
Northern
Ireland
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 321
Products Research Laboratory at Princes Risborough, Bucks, and also by
grant-aided research associations.
When the Government of Northern Ireland was formed in 1922, the new
Ministry of Agriculture became the forest authority working with similar
powers and duties to those conferred on the Forestry Commission by the
Forestry Act 1919. At that time the Ministry took over some 4,000 acres
for afforestation, of which 700 acres had been planted.
Forest policy is carried out under the authority of the Forestry Act
(Northern Ireland) 1953, which replaced earlier legislation. This Act pro¬
vides the Ministry with powers to acquire and manage land, and to give
financial and technical assistance for private planting. It introduced measures
for the protection of all woodlands, whether owned by the State or privately
owned, against destruction by over-cutting, fire or depredation by animals.
The State forest area has grown steadily and at a greatly accelerated pace
since the end of the second world war. By 1968 over 140,000 acres had been
acquired, of which about 90,000 acres had been planted. The present
afforestation programme provides for the creation, as soon as possible, of an
area of 150,000 acres of productive forest.
Financial provision is made by sums voted annually by Parliament and
from receipts from forest produce and other sources. About 1,200 people are
employed in field labour and ancillary work. The area of exploitable private
woodlands is at present about 35,000 acres, and private planting, which is
gaining impetus, is assisted by schemes for the supply at a low cost of young
trees from the Ministry’s nurseries, by grants towards the cost of the estab¬
lishment of new plantations, and by free technical advice.
Pomeroy Forestry School at Pomeroy House, Co. Tyrone, provides
training and refresher courses for forestry workers, school teachers and
others interested in trees and forestry.
13 TRANSPORT AND

Technical
Trends
Inland and overseas transport and communications employed 6-8 per cent
of the total labour force in the United Kingdom in June 1967. Of the i-6
million persons so occupied, 31 per cent were engaged in road passenger
transport and road haulage contracting, 19 per cent in railways and 27 per
cent in postal services and telecommunications; sea and air transport absorbed
respectively 6 per cent and 4 per cent; port and inland water transport
and miscellaneous transport services and storage absorbed 13 per cent.
Transport and communications contribute about 8 per cent of the gross
national product and are responsible for the same proportion of the nation’s
gross fixed capital formation.
SHIPPING
Of the world’s active sea-going tonnage of 100 gross tons1 and over 12 per
cent is registered in the United Kingdom, making the British merchant fleet
one of the largest in active employment. The British shipping industry is,
however, exposed to severe international competition. The position has been
made more difficult by the prevalence among competitors of such practices as
flag discrimination and the use of ‘flags of convenience’. While from 1957 to
1967 Britain’s merchant fleet increased by 9 per cent from 19-9 million to
21-7 million gross tons, the total tonnage of all other countries, excluding the
US Reserve Fleet, increased by too per cent, from 76-4 million to 152-5
million gross tons. After being positive until about 1959 the balance of
payments for shipping services remained adverse until 19645 but has since
shown increasing surpluses, rising to ^69 million in 1967. Shipping makes one
of the largest contributions to Britain’s foreign exchange earnings; it was
responsible for an estimated £246 million net contribution in 1967.
During recent years, steam has steadily given way to diesel power, nearly
59 per cent of all tonnage being diesel-driven in 1967- I*1 a variety of ways
technological change has been proceeding more rapidly under current
conditions. Vessels are becoming obsolete over a shorter period and as they
do so are being replaced by larger ships, whose building costs per ton tend to
be lower, and, equipped with labour-saving devices, their greater speeds and
faster turn-round facilities can reduce operating costs. The tendency to
greater average size has been the most marked in tankers and dry bulk cargo
ships. Vessels are specially built to carry ore, vegetable oils, cement, wine
and various kinds of chemicals. Particularly for the shorter sea routes, many
ships have been designed to carry fully loaded road vehicles, pallets and
containers. Two British consortia have been set up to build and operate

specialist container ships, as containers involve less handling in port and
ensure faster carriage from door to door. The first British deep-sea cellular
container ships are due to be in service in 1969.
The two largest liners to be built in the United Kingdom in recent years, the
Oriana (42,000 g.t.) and the Canberra (46,000 g.t.) came into service in i960
and 1961 respectively on the services from Britain to Australia and across the
Pacific to North America. The Queen Elizabeth 2 (58,000 g.t.), built for the
transatlantic passenger route and for cruising, was launched in September
1967, and will go into service early in 1969.
Of the 21-7 million gross tons of merchant shipping of 100 gross tons and
over registered, but not all owned, in the United Kingdom on 30th June 1967,
tankers accounted for 7-8 million gross tons and 12 per cent of the world’s
sea-going tanker tonnage.
In June 1967, 17-8 million gross tons of trading vessels of 100 gross tons and
over were both owned and registered in Britain.1 The usual employment of
this fleet has been analysed by the United Kingdom Chamber of Shipping as
follows: 7-2 million gross tons were employed as foreign-going passenger and
cargo liners; 3-4 million gross tons as foreign-going tramps; 6-4 million gross
tons as foreign-going tankers; and o-8 million gross tons in coasting and trade
with ports between the Elbe and Brest (home trades).
About half of British-owned shipping registered in the United Kingdom
consists of ocean-going passenger-cargo and cargo liners, mostly the latter.
Practically all these ships are owned by large liner companies. Many operate
wide networks of scheduled cargo and passenger services which, between
them, cover every ocean. The 3-4 million gross tons of ocean-going tramp
ships are operated by a large number of private owners, some having only a
small number of ships and some only one ship.
Examples of major British liner shipping companies operating scheduled
services from the United Kingdom are: the Cunard, to North America; the
Royal Mail, to South America; the Blue Funnel, to Australia and the Far
East; the Peninsular and Oriental (P. & O.) and the British India lines, to
India, Australia and the Far East; the Union Castle, to South and East Africa;
Elder Dempster, to West Africa; Furness Withy, to North America and the
West Indies; the New Zealand line, to Australia and New Zealand; and Shaw
Savill and Albion, to Australia and New Zealand. These and the other major
liner companies have for the most part amalgamated to form a small number
of major groups, of which the largest and best known are the P. & O., the
Furness Withy, the Ocean S.S., and the British and Commonwealth groups.
Over two-thirds of the total tanker fleet belong to the oil companies,
although there are a few important independent United Kingdom tanker¬
owning companies.
A Government guaranteed loan scheme to benefit British shipowners
ordering from British shipyards was introduced in 1967.
The main organisations concerned with the activities, interests and common
problems of the industry are as follows:

Lloyd’s Register is an organisation (distinct from the Society of Lloyd’s, see
p. 375) which surveys and classifies ships with particular regard to their
safety and operational efficiency. It will accept responsibility for surveying
and giving technical advice on vessels of all flags from the initial stages of
building, at regular intervals during their service, and after casualties. A
satisfactory Lloyd’s classification is a guarantee to an underwriter that he may
accept the risk of a vessel, and this forms a strong link between the Register
and the Society of Lloyd’s.
The representative body speaking for shipowners generally (excluding, for
the most part, owners of fishing vessels) is the Chamber of Shipping. There
are a number of local associations of shipowners centred around the main port
areas. Other organisations represent companies specialising in a particular
trade or type of cargo.
The British Shippers’ Council, formed in 1955, represents the shipping
interests of exporters and importers in matters of both national and inter¬
national concern.
The British Shipping Federation Limited is the employers’ organisation
concerned with labour relations and the regulation of employment throughout
the Merchant Navy. It is responsible for the administration of the Merchant
Navy Established Service Scheme, under which shipowners engaging crews
for ships of 200 gross tons and above engage them through the Merchant Navy
Establishment Administration unless they are prepared to offer two-year
Company Service contracts.
The National Maritime Board is composed of equal numbers of representa¬
tives of the shipowners and seafarers and is responsible for all negotiations of
wages and conditions of service in the Merchant Navy.
British shipping companies operating liners have associated with each other
and with the companies of other countries operating on the same routes in a
series of ‘conferences’ designed to secure standardisation and stability of rates,
and to maintain frequency and regularity of services. The essential principle
of a conference is the establishment of a common tariff of freight rates or
passenger fares from each port of departure. Each conference meets from
time to time to review and revise existing rates, or to compile new ones. Some
of the conferences are connected by rate agreements, or have joined together
to form wider groupings. There are over 60 conferences dealing with trade to
and from the United Kingdom.
The Baltic Mercantile and Shipping Exchange, which originated in one of
London’s seventeenth-century coffee houses, is the world’s largest market
for the chartering of ships of all nationalities. Shipbrokers and merchants’
representatives meet here to arrange the chartering of dry-cargo tramp ships
for the carriage of goods to and from all parts of the world.
The Board of Trade is the government department responsible for most
matters connected with merchant shipping. Under the Merchant Shipping
Act 1894 and subsequent legislation, it administers many regulations for
marine safety and welfare, for instance: certifying the load-line (or Plimsoll
line) that shows that a ship is not overloaded; ensuring that standards of
safety are observed in ship construction; ensuring the provision of adequate

TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 325
life-saving, fire-fighting and radio equipment; and dealing with the discipline,
professional standards, health and accommodation of seamen. Most of the
work which these responsibilities entail is carried out by the officers of the
Marine Survey and Mercantile Marine at the ports. There is also a Registrar-
General of Shipping and Seamen, in whose office at Cardiff a complete record
of all British ships and seamen is kept.
Abroad, certain parts of the Merchant Shipping Acts, in particular those
provisions dealing with the engagement and discharge of crews outside the
United Kingdom, are administered by H.M. Consuls and by officers of
Commonwealth Governments.
The discharge of oil into British territorial waters was first restricted in 1922.
Britain is a party to the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of
the Pollution of the Sea by Oil which came into force in 1958. The nations
ratifying this convention (now numbering over 30) agree to prohibit their
national fleets from discharging persistent oil within a certain distance of
any coast (originally 50 miles but under amendments in 1962 extended in
many areas to 100 miles or more) and also in extensive areas of the north-east
Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean, the whole of the North Sea, and around
Australia. The provisions were given legal effect for British ships under the
Oil in Navigable Waters Act 1955 which also prohibits the discharge of any
kind of oil from British and foreign vessels into British territorial waters.
Amendments to the 1954 Convention were agreed in 1962 and came into
force on 18th May 1967; the Oil in Navigable Waters Act 1963, applying the
amendments to British ships, became effective on the same date. The
Convention as amended prohibits ships of 20,000 gross tons and over, built
after 18th May 1967, from discharging persistent oil anywhere at sea.
Over 300,000 vessels pass through the Dover Strait every year. To reduce
the number of collisions recommended one-way routes were marked in 1967
by navigational aids provided by the French and British lighthouse authorities
—a scheme worked out by the joint Institutes of Navigation of France,
the Federal Republic of Germany and Britain and agreed by the Inter-
Governmental Maritime Consultative Organisation, a United Nations agency
with headquarters in London. Further routing along the English Channel
and elsewhere is under consideration.
The Board of Trade administers the Coastguard Service. This is primarily a
life-saving organisation which keeps watch at danger points around the coast
for vessels in distress and renders assistance either by coastguard rescue
equipment or by informing other authorities who may be able to give help.
There are some 550 regular coastguards and about 7,000 part-time auxiliary
coastguards. During the year ended 3tst March 1968 life-saving action was
taken on 2,499 occasions. There is close liaison between the Coastguard
Service and the Royal National Life-boat Institution. The latter maintains
lifeboats and fast inshore rescue boats around the coast of the United Kingdom;
it is supported entirely by voluntary contributions, and depends largely for its
operation on voluntary workers. From its foundation in 1824 to the end of
1967 the Royal National Life-boat Institution saved over 89,000 lives. Life¬
boats and inshore rescue boats were launched 2,143 times in 1967 and
rescued 1,101 people.
The general lighthouse authority for England and Wales, the Channel
Islands and Gibraltar is the Corporation of Trinity House, which received its

first Royal Charter in the sixteenth century and is administered by a Board
of ten Elder Brethren, elected from the Royal Navy and the Merchant Navy.
Lighthouses in Scotland and Ireland are the responsibility respectively of the
Commissioners of Northern Lighthouses and the Commissioners of Irish

Trinity House is also the chief pilotage authority, licensing some 750 pilots
in 41 districts in England and Wales, including London, Southampton and
Milford Haven. In some cases the harbour authority or local council is the
pilotage authority. The Board of Trade also has certain responsibilities in
connection with lighthouses and pilotage.
At the end of 1967 there were about 108,000 United Kingdom personnel
and 30,000 aliens employed by the merchant fleet; of these, masters, deck and
engineer officers numbered 37,000.
The Board of Trade holds examinations for, and issues certificates of
competency to, ships’ officers as master, first mate and second mate of
foreign-going ships, or master and mate of home trade ships and as first-class
engineer and second-class engineer. Officers may not normally serve on board
ships in these grades unless they hold the appropriate, or a higher, certificate.
Radio officers are required to hold certificates of competency in radio¬
telegraphy issued by the Postmaster General on the results of an open
examination.
A seaman may not be rated as A.B. (Able Seaman) in United Kingdom
registered ships unless he holds a certificate of competency as A.B. granted
by the Board of Trade, or an equivalent certificate. To obtain this certificate
a seaman must, among other qualifications, have served three years at sea on
deck, have obtained a certificate of efficiency as lifeboatman and have passed
a qualifying examination.
Seamen qualify by seniority for promotion to the rating of petty officer.
Service as a deck rating qualifies for the purpose of admission to the examina¬
tion for a second mate’s certificate.
The Merchant Navy Training Board promotes the instruction and studies
of apprentices, cadets and ratings who are preparing for their examinations
for the various certificates of competency.
A /i million residential school was opened at Gravesend in May 1967 to
provide training for at least two-thirds of the boys entering the Merchant
Navy. It is the largest establishment of its kind in the world.
Wages and conditions of employment are negotiated by the National Maritime
Board. Minimum wages and holidays with pay are guaranteed for both officers
and ratings. Moreover, the Merchant Navy Established Service Scheme,
introduced by the Board in 1947, has removed a great deal of the uncertainty
formerly associated with a seafaring life. Officers and men can now take
two-year contracts, not only with individual shipping companies but with
the industry as a whole, and get special benefits between voyages in addition
to the normal unemployment insurance benefit.
There are over 300 sea ports in Britain. In 1967, 159 million tons of imports,
including 94 million tons of petroleum and petroleum products, passed
through the ports and 37 million tons of exports and re-exports, including
3 million tons of coal. Coastal traffic amounted to 108 million tons, principally
petroleum and coal.
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
327
As a result both of the anticipated increase in the country’s trade and of
technological changes affecting sea-going traffic (such as the shift to larger
tankers and bulk carriers implying a need for more deep-water berths,
demand for the development of mechanical handling methods, packaging of
general cargo in standard sizes and container and ‘roll-on, roll-off’ services)
large-scale modernisation of the ports system became necessary. Con¬
sequently capital investment in ports has risen from about £18 million
a year in the early 1960s to £36 million in 1966 and to over £50 million in
1968.
National Ports The National Ports Council, set up in 1964 as a statutory body under the
Council Harbours Act of that year, is financed by a levy on harbour authorities and is
primarily an advisory body, with the executive powers for the carrying out of
its recommendations vested in the Minister of Transport. It advises the
Minister on major port developments, and has various responsibilities in
relation to research, training and charges. Its main task is the preparation and
supervision of long-term national planning for the ports as a whole. In the
interests of improved port organisation the Council is encouraging the
amalgamation of harbour authorities in an estuary into a single port authority;
such authorities are now in existence on the Clyde, Tees, Tyne, Forth,
Humber and at Southampton, the two latter being administered by the
British Transport Docks Board (see p. 330).
Principal The Port of London, with 92 miles of waterway and about 4,000 acres of
Ports dock estate, including 36 miles of quayage, is the largest port in the Common¬
wealth and, with New York and Rotterdam, is one of the three largest ports
in the world. The Port of London Authority operates four main groups of
docks. A further group of older up-river docks was closed in 1968, and
facilities down-river, notably at Tilbury, are being extensively developed.
About 56 million tons of cargo were handled in 1967. Among the chief
commodities handled are petroleum, coal, timber and grain. Other imports
include textile fibres, scrap, sugar and meat. Vehicles, machinery and food¬
stuffs predominate among exports.
Liverpool is the second largest port in the United Kingdom. It handles a
large proportion of Britain’s exports to the Far East. There are extensive
facilities for dealing with imports of grain, sugar, wool and other specialist
cargoes. In 1967, over 28 million tons of cargo passed through the port.
Other major ports are Hull and Immingham on the Humber, the port of
Clyde (or Clydeport) which includes the docks at Glasgow and at Greenock
(now being developed as a container port), Manchester (an inland port reached
from the Mersey via the Manchester Ship Canal), Bristol on the Bristol
Channel, and Southampton on Southampton Water. Other estuaries impor¬
tant for shipping are the Firth of Forth on the east coast of Scotland (Grange¬
mouth and Leith), the Tyne (Newcastle), the Tees (Middlesbrough and the
Hartlepools), the Stour and Orwell on the East Anglian coast (Harwich,
Felixstowe and Ipswdch). Among the smaller ports which have been growing
rapidly are Felixstowe, Grangemouth, and Shoreham on the south coast. The
major oil importing centres are London, the Medway, Milford Haven,
Southampton, Liverpool, Manchester, and Finnart on the Clyde; Port
Talbot and Newport in South Wales, the Tees, the port of Clyde and Liver¬
pool are the main ore handling ports; London, Liverpool, Bristol and Hull are
among the chief grain importers; and London, Hull, Liverpool and Garston
are the main timber ports. Dover is Britain’s most important port for short-sea

voyage passengers, and Southampton for travellers by ocean liner. Grimsby,
Hull and Aberdeen are the largest fishing ports.
A ^27 million development scheme is in progress at Tilbury, London; it will
provide some two miles of new quays and on completion in 1969 will make
Tilbury a major container terminal. Another major scheme, costing over
£20 million and including deep-sea container berths, is under construction at
Seaforth, Liverpool. Container facilities have also been provided at South¬
ampton, Harwich, Greenock (port of Clyde), Felixstowe and Grangemouth.
Work is continuing on a ten-year development plan at Hull, including
improvements costing over ^7 naillion at King George Dock, new deep-sea
oil and coal terminals are being provided at Immingham; and a £17 million
deep-water harbour is nearing completion at Port Talbot, to serve as an ore
terminal for the British Steel Corporation.
The Minister of Transport makes grants of 20 per cent of approved capital
expenditure to statutory and other harbour authorities and persons carrying
out harbour operations.
Since 1948 about a third of the total port capacity has been Government
owned; the British Transport Docks Board (see p. 330) owns the majority of
such ports, which include Southampton, Hull, Immingham, Newport, Cardiff
and Swansea. The Government has proposed that the major ports should be
reorganised on the basis of public ownership by I970,
In 1967 shipping arrivals and departures at BTDB docks totalled over
87 million net registered tons (including fishing vessels), and the total cargo
handled was about 51 million tons.
Certain ports and docks used largely for the cross-channel services of the
railways are administered by the British Railways Board: examples are
Folkestone, Holyhead, Heysham, Stranraer and Parkeston Quay (at Harwich).
Other ports are controlled by public trusts on which are represented users
of the port (such as shippers, importers and shipping companies), local
authorities and companies. Examples of ports under public trusts are London
(Port of London Authority), Liverpool (Mersey Docks and Harbour Board),
and Belfast (Belfast Harbour Commissioners).
The powers and responsibilities of the port authorities are, in the main, set
down in private Acts of Parliament, other local legislation, and orders made
under the Harbours Act 1964. A model set of clauses dealing with many of the
details is set out in the Harbours, Docks and Piers Clauses Act 1847. Some of
the new estuarial authorities (see p. 327) are being, or have been, set up by
means of harbour reorganisation schemes under the 1964 Harbours Act.
Most ports are represented on the Dock and Harbour Authorities Associa¬
tion, formed in 1917 to represent the common interests of port authorities in
their relations with government, shipowners and traders.
About 120,000 people are employed in the operation of ports in the United
Kingdom. At the end of 1967 there were 55,000 dock workers registered with
the National Dock Labour Board, concerned primarily with loading and
unloading cargo. The remainder included administrative, clerical and
technical staff, and pilots, lightermen and customs officials.
Because arrivals and departures of ships are liable to occur at irregular
intervals without conforming to set schedules a system of largely casual labour
has always existed at the docks in the past. However, a start was made on
‘decasualisation’ in 1941 when war-time controls were imposed. In 1947 the
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
329
National Dock Labour Board was established, with members appointed by
the Minister of Labour and representing both employers and workpeople, to
administer a scheme under which registered workers received a guaranteed
minimum wage for attendance even when no work was available.
In September 1967 new arrangements were introduced, under which each
registered dockworker was placed in employment with a licensed employer on
a permanent basis in accordance with the recommendations of the 1965
Devlin report (see Bibliography, p. 479).
Tanker Most of the oil tankers coming to the United Kingdom to discharge crude oil
Terminals are berthed at special tanker terminals which are near the oil refineries and are
owned and operated by the oil companies. The maximum deadweight tonnage
of fully laden tankers that some of the most important terminals can accom¬
modate at present is: Finnart (Clyde) 100,000; Isle of Grain (Thames estuary)
65,000; Coryton (London) 85,000; Tilbury Reach (London) 47,000; Thames
Haven (London) 100,000; Tranmere (Liverpool) 100,000; Milford Haven
(Pembroke) 100,000; and Fawley (Southampton) 100,000. Long pipelines
connect Finnart with the refinery at Grangemouth on the Firth of Forth, and
Angle Bay (Milford Haven) with the refinery at Llandarcy (near Swansea).
Facilities are being extended to accommodate larger vessels; Finnart and
Coryton will be able to accept tankers of 200,000 tons. Following dredging
Milford Haven will be able to take 255,000-ton vessels.
Two deep-water oil terminals, to cost ^3 million, are being built at
Immingham to serve two new oil refineries.
INLAND TRANSPORT
The dense passenger and freight traffic of Great Britain1 is carried mainly
by road and rail, although coastal shipping and, to a lesser extent, inland
waterways and pipelines are important in carrying certain types of freight,
particularly bulk cargoes. A small but increasing proportion goes by air.
Part of the inland transport system of Great Britain is nationalised; namely,
the railways, passenger transport in the London area, a large proportion of
road passenger and some road haulage services, most of the inland waterways
and some of the vessels on them. Road haulage is largely, and coastal shipping
almost entirely, in the hands of private enterprise.
In the third quarter of 1967 there were over 14 million vehicles licensed for
use on the roads. Of these, 10-3 million were motor cars and 1-3 million motor
cycles. Road goods vehicles numbered i-6 million, of which 2 per cent were
operated by nationalised transport services, which also owned 30 per cent of
the public road passenger vehicles.
In 1965, 61 per cent of freight, in terms of ton-mileage,2 travelled by road,
22 per cent by rail, 16 per cent by coastal shipping, and 1 per cent by pipeline.
Long-term Since 1945 the rapid growth of private and commercial motor traffic, causing

period 1966-75 an increase of over 50 per cent is forecast for total passenger
mileage, with demand for public transport diminishing and travel by private
transport still rising fast. Freight ton-mileage may rise by over 10 per cent,
fuel and steel traffic fall by 15 per cent as a result of structural and technological
change, while other freight traffic is expected to grow by some 30 per cent.
The Buchanan report, published in November 1963, was the result of a
study group set up to examine the problems of traffic in urban areas. It
estimated that Britain would have 40 million vehicles on its roads by a.d. 2010
and proposed radical measures to rebuild and adapt cities and roads to handle
the growth of traffic. It is now expected that the number of vehicles on the
roads will double by 1990.
The railway network has been reduced by nearly a third in recent years,
but it was decided in 1967 to fix a basic network of some 11,000 route-miles
for modernisation and development.

Statutory Boards
Financial Changes
The present role and structure of the nationalised transport undertakings are
the result of a series of legislative measures, starting with the 1947 Transport
Act under which they were taken into public ownership. In accordance with
this Act the British Transport Commission (BTC) was established on
1 st January 1948 and assumed control of Britain’s railways, all railway-owned
steamships, docks, hotels and road transport interests, most of the country’s
canals (including all those owned by the railways), certain rivers (as navigation
authority) and the whole of the London passenger transport system. It was
also to arrange for the gradual acquisition of privately owned long-distance
road haulage firms.
Changes of policy following the coming into power of a Conservative
Government in 1951 were put into effect under the Transport Act 1953 which
modified the functions of the BTC. The Transport (Disposal of Road Haulage
Property) Act 1956 provided for the completion of the denationalisation of
road haulage, a process begun under the 1953 Act. Later it was decided that
the activities of the BTC were so large and diverse that they could not be
run effectively as a single undertaking. The Transport Act 1962 therefore
dissolved the BTC and set up four boards, for British Railways, London
Transport, British Transport Docks and British Waterways. Each of these
was responsible to the Minister of Transport, who appointed the members.
The cross-channel shipping services operated by British Railways and
certain ports and docks used for them passed to the British Railways Board.
The hotel property of the BTC was transferred to British Transport Hotels
Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary, first of the BTC and later of the British
Railways Board.
Road passenger and haulage undertakings, such as British Road Services,
the Tilling Bus Group, the Scottish Omnibuses Group, Road Freight
Shipping Services, Thomas Cook and Son and other holdings, were operated
as companies incorporated under the Companies Act, with their own boards;
they were grouped under a Transport Holding Company, responsible to the
Minister of Transport.
The Treasury assumed responsibility for outstanding British Transport Com¬
mission stock (amounting to about £1,450 million) and the four boards and the
Transport Holding Company assumed debts to the Minister broadly
equivalent in aggregate to the total BTC stock and existing debt in respect
of loans previously made by the Minister for capital purposes. Of the
BTC’s accumulated deficit on revenue account 1948-62, £392 million had
New Transport

already been met by grant, and the balance of the total deficit of £875 million
was written off. A further £704 million of the railways’ capital debt was put
into ‘suspense’ account, leaving the new Railways Board with an active debt
to the Minister of Transport of ^857 million.
A White Paper, Transport Policy (Cmnd. 3057), published in July 1966,
set out the Government’s plans to integrate and modernise the national
transport system. These plans are to be put into effect under the provisions
of the 1967 Transport Bill,1 which will considerably alter the transport pattern
laid down by the 1962 Act. The Bill provides for a capital reconstruction and
reorganisation of British Railways; the setting up of Passenger Transport
Authorities to control and co-ordinate local transport arrangements; three
new nationalised bodies—a National Bus Company, a Scottish Transport
Group and a National Freight Corporation; a new licensing system and safety
provisions for road haulage operators; and new grants for public transport.
Britain was the pioneer of railways. The opening of the Stockton to Darlington
Railway in 1825, and of the Liverpool and Manchester line in 1830, when
George Stephenson’s famous ‘Rocket’ locomotive was used, began a century
of widespread railway development. The great period of railway building
was from 1840 to 1875.
The railways first came under centralised government direction during the
first world war, and afterwards some 130 private companies were amalgamated
into four large regional groups under the Railways Act 1921. Thereafter they
suffered from the prolonged industrial depression and growing competition
from road transport, and following the second world war the Transport Act
1947 brought the railways under public ownership as a single enterprise,
British Railways, operated under the overall management of a Railway
Executive established as the agent of the BTC. Under the Transport Act 1962
the British Railways Board was set up and came into existence on 1st January,
1963, with sole responsibility for managing railway affairs.
In spite of technical and operational advances the Board’s financial position
has remained unsatisfactory, and under the provisions of the 1967 Transport
Bill a large part of the capital debt of the British Railways Board is to be
written off, reducing it from ^ 1,562 million to £300 million. Services which
are judged to be socially necessary but which cannot be expected to pay their
way are to be costed separately, and a subsidy paid by the Government, based
on an assessment of net losses likely to be incurred over a period of three years.
Grants are estimated to total £55 million a year at first. Grants not exceeding
a total of £50 million may be paid to the Railways Board during 1969-1973, on
a tapering off basis, towards the cost of maintaining surplus track and signalling
equipment pending their elimination. In view of these special arrangements,
the Board is expected to be able to pay its way by 1971; deficit grants from
the Government are to cease. British Railways’ deficit in 1967 was £I53
million, substantial improvements in efficiency having been almost entirely
absorbed by rising costs.
The new National Freight Corporation, to be set up to integrate the publicly
owned freight services, will take over from the Board the assets (depots,
vehicles, warehouses, containers and other equipment, though not the actual
trains) used in the freightliner and sundries services, and the Board’s other

and the Railways Board (51 per cent and 49 per cent of the shares respective¬

The Corporation will have a statutory duty to make the maximum economic
use of rail. The Railways Board will make a charge for providing and hauling
the trains, and profits will be divided between the Board and the Corporation
in proportion to their respective holdings.
The Freight Integration Council will consist of the chairmen of British
Railways and the National Freight Corporation, representatives of the trade
unions, independent members and an independent chairman. It will help
to co-ordinate the activities of the two bodies, and report periodically to the
Minister of Transport.
The National Freight Corporation will take over the freight interests of the
Transport Holding Company.
The process of rationalisation arising from changing public transport require¬
ments is reflected in the reduction of over 5,000 miles of standard-gauge route
since 1961. A total of 837 million passenger journeys was made and 200 million
tons of freight traffic conveyed on British Railways in 1967. The railway
operating deficit in 1967 was £90 million, while there was a surplus of ^8
million on other activities—ships, harbours, hotels and letting of land. At the
end of 1967, 318,000 people were employed by the railways, a reduction of
121,500 in four years, made possible by the contraction of the industry, and
improvements in equipment, technique and working methods.
In 1967 British Transport Hotels Ltd. managed 32 hotels, the catering
facilities on trains (including Pullman trains), as well as refreshment rooms at
199 stations, by agreement with the British Railways Board.
British Railways’ subsidiary, British Rail Hovercraft Ltd., set up in 1966,
runs regular hovercraft services across the Solent to the Isle of Wight, and
across the Channel between Dover and Boulogne. The 165-ton Mountbatten
(SRN-4) hovercraft, the largest hovercraft in the world, is used for cross¬
channel journeys.
The Railways Board and the shipping subsidiaries of the National Freight
Corporation will have between them a fleet of about 100 vessels, providing
passenger and freight services on most of the important routes between
Great Britain and the continent and the Republic of Ireland, as well as
many domestic services.
In 1955 the BTC produced a modernisation plan which was designed to
transform virtually all the services offered by the railways. The plan has since
been modified in the light of ensuing economic and technical developments.
Capital expenditure has been substantial over the past few years and amounted
to £97 million in 1967.
In spite of the considerable injection of new capital over the period 1955-62
British Railways incurred a steadily increasing overall deficit (including
interest charges), which rose to a peak of more than ^150 million in 1962.
The new Railways Board was given the task of preparing a scheme for re¬
organising the railways in such a way that they could be run as a commercially
viable undertaking. In March 1963 a Report on the Reshaping of British
Railways (‘Beeching Report’) was published and was accepted in principle by
the then Government. Its proposals included the withdrawal of passenger
services from about a third of the country’s railway system. These little-used
lines carried only 1 per cent of the total passenger traffic.
Modernisation
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 333
Other important proposals, most of which have since been put into effect,
were for the improvement of inter-city passenger services, with the emphasis
on speed, reliability and comfort; the introduction of express freight services
(‘freightliner’ trains) to link all the main industrial areas; increased mechani¬
sation in the carrying of coal (the railways most profitable traffic), and the
continuing replacement of steam by diesel and electric traction.
As promised in the White Paper on Transport Policy (see p. 331)’ a basic
network of railway routes, secure from closure, was announced in March
1967. The network covers 11,000 route-miles. The position of the remaining
2,000 is subject to review.
On main lines in 1955 there were about 18,000 steam, 7 main line diesel and
71 electric locomotives. At the end of 1967 the corresponding figures were
362 steam, 4,742 diesel and 341 electric locomotives. In addition, there were
3,988 diesel and 7,492 electric passenger-carrying multiple units.
Passenger services have improved in speed and comfort with the replace¬
ment of steam by electric or diesel traction, which has also helped to reduce
operating costs. The replacement of steam locomotives was completed in 1968.
The replacement of out-of-date passenger coaches by new stock, with improved
amenities, is still proceeding.
On certain sections of the London—Bristol—South Wales line and of the
London-Edinburgh line passenger trains are permitted to run at up to
100 m.p.h. Similar speeds are also in operation on the London Midland
Region’s services on the electrified line between London and Manchester and
Liverpool, introduced in 1966. This electrification scheme was the largest
modernisation project undertaken by British Railways and included station
reconstruction, bridge works, a new colour-light signalling system and new
rolling stock. The total cost was 160 million. The final stages of the scheme
involving extension of the electrified route to Birmingham and Wolverhampton
via Rugby and Coventry and to Manchester via Stoke were completed in 1967.
Other electrification projects completed since 1966 include a £61 million
extension to the Glasgow suburban service, and the £15 million London to
Southampton and Bournemouth scheme.
There has been considerable development of motorail services (carrying
both passengers and cars), and in 1966 the world s first car-train terminal was
opened in London.
The efficiency of freight services is being improved as new and modern type
freight vehicles come into service and as facilities for concentrating freight
traffic at fewer and better equipped and sited marshalling yards and terminals
are completed. To exploit the trend towards greater use of standardised
containers an inland freight depot has been set up at Lawley Street, Birming¬
ham, for customs clearance of imports and exports. Freightliner services
using specially designed containers and rolling stock now link most of the
main centres. The first freightliner ran in November 1965. Traffic carried by
freightliner trebled in 1967.
The London International Freight Terminal, opened in 1967, links the
British Railways’ container port of Harwich with the main freightliner network.
The first fully cellular container ships built in a British yard were used in
British Railways’ new container service, opened in 1968, between Harwich and
Zeebrugge.
Efforts are being made to secure more bulk products traffic. Oil is being
moved from refineries under long-term contracts, while coal is being fed
direct from collieries to power stations in ‘merry-go-round’ trains, on which
coal is loaded and discharged automatically from a new type of high-capacity

wagon. Long-term contracts have also been signed for the carriage of cars,
china clay, milk, grain and newspapers. ‘Steel liner’ trains have been running
from South Wales since 1967.
British Railways’ workshops have recently been reorganised and modernised.
There are now 16 works, employing some 35,000 people, mostly on repairs and
construction of rolling stock.
A Railway Technical Centre has been established at Derby; it covers 20
acres and will eventually employ about 1,500 people. Work on very high-speed
passenger trains is in progress.
The British and French Governments have agreed to the construction of a
rail Channel Tunnel (either a bored tunnel or an immersed tube). The
construction cost is estimated at about £170 million (at 1966 prices). It is
expected that the Tunnel will be open in the mid-1970s.
The advent of the motor vehicle made it necessary for the Government to
set up a central road authority; accordingly, the Road Board was established
by the Development and Road Improvement Funds Act 1909. In 1919 the
Board’s responsibilities were taken over by the newly established Ministry of
Transport.
In April 1967 Great Britain, had over 200,000 miles of public highway.
There were 8,793 miles of trunk roads including 461 miles of motorway,
20,250 miles of principal roads, and over 173,000 miles of other roads. Roads
are classified according to their traffic value, those of purely local traffic
importance remaining unclassified. Under the Local Government Act 1966
the classification of important roads other than trunk roads into classes I, II
and III (still retained for certain purposes) has been superseded, as far as the
making of grants for road building is concerned, by two categories of ‘principal’
roads, roughly equivalent in mileage to the Class I roads, and others. On maps
and signposts the trunk and principal roads can usually be identified by the
letter ‘A’ (or, in the case of motorways, ‘M’) in front of a route number. Trunk
roads are the main arteries of national traffic and the whole cost of their
upkeep is met from Exchequer funds. The Minister of Transport is the
highway authority for trunk roads in England and on these roads he
administers expenditure, which is provided wholly from central government
sources, although for many purposes he employs local authorities as his
agents. The highway authority for principal roads is, in general, the council
of the county or county borough in whose area the roads lie. The Minister
makes specific grants towards approved expenditure on construction and
major improvement of these roads and contributions from public funds
towards maintenance and other expenditure is made through grants to local
authorities. The Secretary of State for Scotland has corresponding responsi¬
bilities for roads in Scotland and the Secretary of State for Wales for roads
in Wales. Roads, other than trunk and principal roads, are entirely the
responsibility of the local authority in whose area they lie.
A large and steadily expanding road-building programme has been in progress
since 1955. Public expenditure on new and improved roads in Great Britain
is estimated at over £275 million in 1968-69. The current programme includes
a considerable mileage of motorways constructed for the use of limited classes
of traffic under powers granted by the Special Roads Act 1949 (consolidated in
the Highways Act 1959). In addition, over 400 miles of new or improved
high-class all-purpose trunk roads are under construction or proposed.
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
335
The motorways form part of a programme designed to provide a national
network of modern through routes. At the same time, work done under this
programme is eliminating some of the worst bottlenecks in urban areas and
thus helping to give free outlets from the big cities and from other main
sources of traffic to the trunk routes.
Motorways It is planned that 1,000 miles of motorways should be completed by the
early 1970s. At the end of May 1968, in England and Wales, 525 miles had
been opened for traffic and construction had started, or tenders had been
invited, for a further 119 miles. The lines of an additional 332 miles had been
fixed and draft schemes published for 111 miles. It is expected that some 720
miles of motorways will be in use by 1970. Among the motorways in England
and Wales open to traffic or under construction in May 1968 were:
Mi—London to Yorkshire (Leeds and Doncaster). The length of this
motorway is 206 miles including the Mio, M18 and M45 spurs, and
provides links between London, Birmingham and the Midlands, and
Yorkshire. It was almost completed in 1968.
M2—Medway motorway, London to Dover. The 25 miles of this motorway
came into use in 1963.
M3—London to Basingstoke. Construction of part of this 40-mile motorway
began in 1968.
M4—London to South Wales. The projected length of this road, which
will link London with Newport, is 140 miles. In the east, 24 miles are in
use from Chiswick to Maidenhead, including a one-mile spur to London
Airport; a section of 38^ miles of road from Newport (Monmouthshire) to
Tormarton (Gloucestershire) including the bridge over the Severn was
completed in 1967.
M5—Birmingham to Bristol. Of this 114-mile motorway eventually reaching
to Edithmead (22 miles beyond Bristol), the first 26 miles running south
from Birmingham were opened in July 1962, followed by a further 6 miles
of the northward link with the M6 in 1965. There will be a connection
with the M4 north of Bristol. The 21-mile Ross Spur (M50), opened in
i960, links the M5 with the existing road system leading from Ross-on-
Wye (Herefordshire) to South Wales.
M6—Birmingham to Carlisle. The projected length of this road is 230 miles
(including the links in the Midlands with Mi and M5); the 125^ miles
linking Darlaston with Lancaster are open to traffic. It includes the 8-mile
Preston bypass, the first section of motorway in Britain, opened in 1958.
The southward link connecting Darlaston and Dunston (14J miles) was
completed in 1966.
M62—Lancashire to Yorkshire. A 6-mile stretch from Stretford to Eccles
bypass was finished in i960. Six miles between Rochdale and Hudders¬
field and a further six miles, all in Yorkshire, are under construction.
Draft schemes have been published for 34 miles of the Mu from London
towards Cambridge, and the 26-mile M23 from London to Crawley. Part of
the route of the M56 North Cheshire Motorway has been settled.
In Scotland about 115 miles of motorways are planned including motorways
between Glasgow and Edinburgh, Edinburgh and Stirling, Edinburgh and
Perth, and a 20-mile section between Glasgow and Carlisle (the first 9-mile
section, the Hamilton bypass, was opened at the end of 1966). Altogether
about 30 miles of motorway are now open.
