Notable schemes for improving existing trunk roads include that for the
Great North Road (Ai) between London and Newcastle, which is nearing
completion and will provide dual carriageways throughout. Improvements on
the A40 route, linking London with Gloucester and South Wales via Oxford,
include a i3|-mile bypass around High Wycombe, in Buckinghamshire, built
to motorway standards. The first stage of this was completed in 1967, and the
remaining stretch in 1968.
A large programme of bridge and tunnel building has been undertaken in
recent years. The £2-3 million Medway Bridge, which is part of the M2 and
one of the largest prestressed concrete structures of its kind in the world, was
completed in 1963 and the suspension bridge across the Firth of Forth, one of
the longest bridges in the world, was opened in 1964. The Severn Bridge,
incorporating major advances in suspension bridge design, and the 7,000-ft.
bridge across the Firth of Tay, were opened in 1966. Tinsley Viaduct, near
Sheffield, a two-level viaduct over 3,000 feet long, was opened in two stages in
1968. Under construction is a £6 million high-level bridge over the Clyde.
The second Blackwall Tunnel (under the Thames) costing ^8 million and
the £13 million Tyne Tunnel between Wallsend (Northumberland) and
Jarrow (Durham) were opened in 1967. The £11 million Dartford-Purfleet
tunnel (under the Thames) has been open to traffic since the end of 1963.
Work on the £20 million second Mersey Tunnel began in 1967 and is due for
completion in 1970.
Research on roads is carried out at the Road Research Laboratory (see p. 189).
Its aims are to find more economical ways of designing, constructing and
maintaining roads and of facilitating the flow of traffic on them and to reduce
road accidents. The layout of roads, their traffic, the safety features of road
vehicles and the behaviour of road users are investigated, and new methods,
materials and processes are developed for building roads and providing
them with a smooth, safe and durable surface. The Laboratory has a Tropical
Section, which undertakes research and advice on road problems overseas.
In 1967 there were over 14 million motor vehicles licensed to use Great
Britain’s roads. Of these, i-6 million were goods vehicles and 94,000 were
public road passenger vehicles (that is, buses and taxicabs).
The first world war greatly stimulated the development of motor vehicles
and road transport began to make itself felt as a serious competitor of the
railways. The first step towards government regulation of public road
transport was the passing of the London Traffic Act 1924, which gave the
Minister of Transport power to control the number of buses and their
journeys in London; this was followed in 1933 by the setting up of the London
Passenger Transport Board (see p. 342).
The Road Traffic Act 1930 ended the licensing of public service vehicles
(that is, buses and coaches) by local authorities and set up instead traffic areas,
of which there are now eleven, covering the whole country and each under
the control of three traffic commissioners (except for the London metropolitan
area, which has one) appointed by the Minister. The commissioners regulate,
by means of a licensing system, all public road passenger transport services,
and they sanction routes and time-tables in order to secure proper co-ordina¬
tion of services and eliminate unnecessary competition; they may also control
fares.

Organisation of
Road Haulage
State-owned
Services
Size of the
Industry
The Road and Rail Traffic Act 1933 established a system of licensing for
road haulage vehicles designed to restrict vehicle operations to proved needs
and to eliminate wasteful competition which will remain in partial operation
until the new licensing system proposed in the 1967 Transport Bill is fully
operational. A licence has to be secured from the licensing authority (the
chairman of the appropriate body of traffic commissioners) before a goods
vehicle can be used on the road. There are three types of licence: the ‘A’
licence for general public haulage; the ‘B’ licence for public haulage limited to
certain goods or certain areas and covering also the carriage of the licensee’s
own goods; and the ‘C’ licence for the carriage by traders solely of their own
goods. Applications for ‘A’ and ‘B’ licences are examined by the licensing
authorities to see if they are necessary in view of existing transport services,
and competitors may raise objections. The ‘C’ licence is granted on
application, as of right. Regulations concerning the fitness and loading of
vehicles, the keeping of records, and driving hours and rest periods of their
employees have been made more severe under recent legislation.
A new licensing system is to be introduced under the 1967 Transport Bill,
with the aims of improving safety and promoting a fuller use of rail traffic
when this does not impose higher costs on industry. It is proposed that over
900,000 goods vehicles not exceeding 3J tons gross loaded weight (30 cwt.
unladen), formerly mostly holding ‘C’ licences, be exempted from licensing
altogether. Operators of goods vehicles of over 3! tons will need to hold a
‘quality’ licence, certifying that they can and will provide or receive adequate
maintenance facilities, and control loading and the hours worked by their
drivers; that they have adequate financial resources to enable them to maintain
vehicles properly; and that they or an employee hold a ‘transport manager’s
licence’ entitling them to manage the vehicles of a transport undertaking. A
new form of ‘quantitative’ control will apply to all goods vehicles of over 16
tons gross weight engaged in hauls of over 100 miles or carrying certain bulk
materials, such as coal, over any distance. The British Railways Board and the
National Freight Corporation will have the right to object to the granting of
any quantitative licence on the grounds that they can offer a rail service at
least as good in terms of speed, reliability and cost.
From September 1956 to January 1963 the nationalised road haulage services
were controlled by British Road Services (BRS), a division of the British
Transport Commission, and operated through five companies, which together
owned about 16,000 vehicles: British Road Services Ltd. (general haulage);
BRS (Bickfords) Ltd. (special traffic and some contracts); BRS (Contracts)
Ltd.; BRS (Parcels) Ltd.; and BRS (Meat Haulage) Ltd. Under the Transport
Act 1962, these organisations have been operating as companies incorporated
under the Companies Act, with their own boards. They have been grouped
together under the Transport Holding Company, responsible to the Minister
of Transport. The road haulage interests of the Holding Company are to be
transferred to the National Freight Corporation (see p. 331).
The number of licensed vehicles in the road goods transport industry has
shown only a relatively slow growth, from 1-4 million in i960 to 1-5 million
in 1967, when 1-3 million were on ‘C’ licence. Of the other 240,000 vehicles,
with ‘A’ and ‘B’ licences, about 19,000 are operated by British Transport
Holding Company subsidiaries. There are only a few operators with large
fleets of vehicles in any of the licence categories. ‘C’ licence vehicles include a
large number of small vehicles used locally in the delivery of groceries and

other goods. Other vehicles in this class are engaged in long-distance carriage
of traders’ own goods.
With the exception of the London transport system road passenger transport
in Great Britain is being run prior to the coming into force of the provisions
of the 1967 Transport Bill by about 5,000 operators, 95 of them being local
authorities owning and operating ur an bus and trolleybus services. About
4,700 are independent operators of coaches and, of these, 3,600 have not
more than 5 vehicles. Most of the remainder operate both bus and coach
services and belong to three main groups—Tilling, Scottish Omnibuses and
British Electric Traction, all controlled by the Transport Holding Company.
There are some 250 concerns operating fleets of over 24 vehicles, about
one-third of which are local authorities, the largest being the Corporations of
Birmingham, Glasgow and Manchester.
The 1967 Transport Bill proposes that Passenger Transport Authorities
(PTAs) should be set up to control and co-ordinate the different forms of
transport in any particular area. PTAs are first to be set up in Greater
Manchester, Merseyside, the West Midlands and Tyneside. The relevant
local authorities will appoint most of the members, but each may have two or
three appointed by the Minister of Transport. Each may appoint its own
chairman, with the Minister’s approval. The PTAs will control policy and
finance, will be answerable to the local authorities, and will appoint profes¬
sional executives—Passenger Transport Executives—to be responsible to
them for day-to-day operations. The Executives will operate some services
themselves and enter into agreements with other bodies, such as British
Railways, or the National Bus Company to operate others. They will take over
all municipal bus undertakings in their areas.
The National Bus Company is to be formed to take over the former bus
operating and manufacturing subsidiaries of the Transport Holding Company
in England and Wales, and is to operate through locally based subsidiaries.
A separate Scottish Transport Group is to be set up to control bus and
shipping services in Scotland, and is to take over the interests of the Transport
Holding Company in these fields, operating through subsidiaries.
Capital grants are to be made by the Government towards the cost of
investment in public transport, at rates of up to 75 per cent of approved cost.
Eligible schemes will include improvements or extensions of railway lines,
new fixed track rail and bus systems, terminals, and car parks. Grants at the
rate of 25 per cent will be available towards the cost of new types of buses
approved by the Ministry of Transport. Grants may also be paid through a
new Rural Bus Grants scheme, and for a time to PTA executives towards the
cost of rail services covered by agreement with the Railways Board.
Britain has the highest density of road traffic in the world. Road accident
statistics are compiled and published by the Ministry of Transport, the
Scottish Development Department and the Welsh Office from reports made
by the police. In 1967, 7,319 people were killed on the roads and about 363,000
injured. The fatal accident rate in Britain is better than that in most other
European countries, but slightly worse than in the United States.
Modern roads, designed for present-day traffic and segregating pedestrians
from vehicles, are safer than the roads they replace and surveys have shown
they result in a marked fall in casualties. The more important measures
directed primarily towards road safety include speed limits of 30 and 40 m.p.h.
in and around built-up areas and 50 m.p.h. on certain trunk and important
Control of Traffic
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 339
classified roads in rural areas; a 70 m.p.h. speed limit on all motorways and on
ordinary main roads where no lower limit applies; the provision of pedestrian
crossings—some illuminated by flashing beacons and marked with conspicuous
white stripes (‘zebra’ crossings); and the system of road markings and traffic
signs (which are being replaced by greatly improved signs over the next few
years). Modifications in speed limit policy are at present under consideration.
The Road Safety Act 1967 made it an offence to drive with more than a
prescribed level of alcohol in the blood; a sharp fall in casualties has resulted
since these provisions came into force in October 1967.
The safety of vehicles, both in design and use, is controlled by regulations;
a system of vehicle testing, which applies at present to vehicles three or more
years old, is being gradually extended. Recent regulations have required the
fitting of seat belts in cars registered in or after 1965, and enforce a high
standard of safety in tyres. Heavy goods vehicles were previously subject to
a separate procedure of spot checks but the Road Safety Act 1967 established
a system of annual tests and stricter requirements in respect of the condition
of vehicles. Government testing stations will come into full operation
in October 1968.
All drivers of motor vehicles, including motor cycles, motor scooters and
powered pedal cycles, unless they have either held a full British licence or
passed the driving test in the last ten years, are required to pass the test before
being granted a full licence to drive. Until they pass the test they must obtain
a ‘provisional’ licence which necessitates their displaying ‘L’ (Learner) plates
on their vehicle, and in all cases where vehicles are constructed to carry
passengers, other than pillion passengers, learner drivers must be accompanied
by a qualified driver (a person who holds a current driving licence for the
same type of vehicle as that driven by the learner). A learner driver of a motor
cycle is restricted, until he passes the driving test, to a machine not exceeding
250 c.c.
The Road Traffic Acts, which embody the law relating to road users, are
enforced by the police and the courts. A person convicted of any of the 26
most serious offences is liable to be disqualified from driving for a period. The
standard of conduct for all road users and a summary of the requirements of
the law is set out in easily understandable form in the Highway Code. A
failure to observe the code does not of itself render a person liable to criminal
proceedings but may be taken into account in any such proceedings.
A National Road Safety Advisory Council was set up by the Minister of
Transport in 1965 to keep under review the road accident situation in Great
Britain and methods of accident prevention, and to report on other matters
affecting road safety.
National campaigns to persuade people to take greater care on the roads
are conducted by the Ministry of Transport and the Royal Society for the
Prevention of Accidents, acting as the Government’s agent and with the
participation of the local authorities. The police and education authorities
also help by arranging courses of instruction, especially courses for children.
In a White Paper published in 1967 (see Bibliography, p. 480) the
Government announced further proposals for reducing accidents. T. hese
include the setting up of a central road safety unit within the Ministry of
Transport, extension of local authority activity in safety matters, publicity
and training campaigns, and a review of pedestrian safety.
The Road Traffic Regulation Act 1967 permits the employment of traffic
wardens (with strictly limited powers), and provides for fixed penalties (the
‘ticket’ system) for parking offences. The Act also empowers local authorities

INLAND

The System
to regulate traffic and control parking to reduce congestion and improve
safety. In 1965 the Greater London Council became the traffic authority
(formerly the responsibility of the Minister of Transport) for the whole of
Greater London. Several extensive schemes for the improvement of road
safety and the relief of traffic congestion are being undertaken: these include
‘fly-overs’ at road junctions; new outlet roads from cities; and the designation
of certain stretches of trunk roads as ‘clearways’, on which waiting on the
carriageway is (with certain exceptions) prohibited. In most town centres
street parking is permitted for limited periods only, and in London and some
other towns on payment at parking meters. Disc schemes are in operation at
Cheltenham, Devizes and Harrogate. More off-street facilities are being
provided.
Increasing use is being made of traffic management to promote the smoother
and more rapid flow of traffic. In i960 a Traffic Management Unit was set
up in London by the Minister of Transport. This was superseded in 1965 by
a Traffic Advisory Unit, with the object of making available to all traffic
authorities the experience gained in London and elsewhere since i960. The
main measures introduced are comprehensive control of street parking and
comprehensive one-way working systems. Others include the banning of turns,
particularly right turns, peak hour clearways and ‘tidal flow’ arrangements.
A computer-controlled system to regulate traffic was installed in west London
in 1968. Computer-controlled systems are also operating in Glasgow and
Liverpool.
Local authorities in the larger urban areas are now required to prepare and
implement traffic and transport plans, striking a balance between the claims
of moving traffic and pedestrians, public transport and amenity.
In 1761 James Brindley completed the Bridgewater Canal to take coal from
the collieries owned by the Duke of Bridgewater at Worsley to Manchester.
This marked the beginning of canal building in modern Britain, with which
the names of Brindley, Telford, Rennie, Jessop and other great engineers are
associated. Canals played an important part in promoting industrial and
commercial expansion in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.
The whole canal system was practically complete by 1830. As a result of
developing competition from the railways, however, about one-third of the
canal mileage had passed to the control of the railway companies by the middle
of the nineteenth century. During the two world wars government control of
railways included railway-owned canals. Under the Transport Act 1947, most
of the country’s canals passed to the British Transport Commission in
January 1948. From 1955 the canals were managed separately by the water¬
ways division of the Commission, known as British Waterways; under the
Transport Act 1962, control has been vested in the British Waterways Board
since 1st January 1963. This control is confirmed by the Transport Bill 1967,
under which a substantial grant-in-aid is to be paid to enable the Board to
maintain an extensive network of amenity waterways.
There are about 2,500 miles of navigable inland waterways in Great Britain,1
some 2,000 miles of which belong to the British Waterways Board; the
remainder are mainly still in the hands of local authorities or private com¬
panies. Many of the Board’s canals are narrow waterways which can generally
be used only by boats not exceeding 7 feet in width, capable of carrying a load
1 In Northern Ireland, the only inland waterway which is still used for commercial
transport purposes is the Lower Bann Navigation.
Development
LONDON
TRANSPORT
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 341
varying from 25 to 30 tons; the remainder are broad waterways and canalised
rivers some of which can be used by craft of up to about 750 tons capacity.
The Caledonian and Crinan canals in Scotland are broad waterways. Of the
2,000 miles of inland waterways under the control of the British Waterways
Board some 400 miles are major commercial waterways. A substantial
additional mileage (1,100 miles, to be known as ‘cruiseways’) is to be main¬
tained for recreational purposes; an advisory council has been set up.
Engineering, maintenance and estate work is directed from the Board’s
headquarters at Watford, Hertfordshire, through regional offices at Leeds
and Gloucester. Commercial activities are directed from London. In Scotland
the canals (other than the Caledonian, which is run by a manager) are, for
engineering purposes, under the control of an area engineer-in-charge at
Glasgow; estates work is supervised centrally from Watford.
In 1967 total traffic on British waterways amounted to just over 7 million
tons, of which 3-1 million tons were coal, 1-5 million tons liquids in bulk
and 2-5 million tons general cargo. Some 96 per cent of the total traffic is
carried on about 400 miles of broad waterways, which are mainly canalised
rivers.
Although the British Waterways Board is the largest single carrying
operator, most of the traffic is handled by independent carriers or by traders
in their own craft. The Board at the end of 1967 owned 12 tugs and 722
carrying craft, with a carrying capacity of 31,721 tons, including 28 power-
driven craft with a carrying capacity of 3*829 tons. It operates 4 docks and
25 warehouses.
The Board continues to improve facilities on its commercial waterways, most
of which link important industrial districts with ports. These waterways are
the main navigations and broad canals in the Yorkshire-Humberside area,
the Trent, Weaver and Lee Navigations, part of the river Severn, including
the Gloucester and Sharpness Canal, and the Weston, Caledonian and
Crinan Canals.
The total revenue of the British Waterways Board in 1967 amounted to
j£4-7 million, of which only -£560,000 arose from the Board’s own freight¬
carrying activities. The sale of water for industrial and agricultural purposes
is an important source of revenue and brought in ,£700,000. British Waterways
encourages pleasure boating and receipts rose to .£115,000. Income from
fishing rights was ,£23,000.
London is, with Tokyo and New York, one of the world’s three largest cities.
The area known as Greater London, within a radius of about 15 miles from
Charing Cross, contains about 7-8 million people.
London’s passenger transport system, in its modern sense, began in 1829
when the first omnibus, horse-drawn, appeared on the London streets. The
first regular tram service, also horse-drawn, began in 1870. In 1863 the first
underground steam railway, the Metropolitan, was built by digging a great
trench for the line and roofing it over. In 1870 the world’s first tube railway,
the Tower Subway, was constructed under the river Thames; it was cable-
operated and ran for only a few months. The first electric tube railway in the
world, the City and South London Railway, was opened in 1890, and this was
followed in 1900 by the opening of the Central London Railway. Shortly
afterwards the steam-operated underground lines were electrified. Meanwhile
horse-drawn buses and trams were being replaced by motor buses and
electric trams.

The London
Transport
System
PUBLIC
TRANSPORT
IN NORTHERN
IRELAND
Until 1933 there were many separate undertakings providing passenger
transport facilities in London, but in that year they were all vested in a single
public corporation, the London Passenger Transport Board. In 194^5 with
the establishment of the British Transport Commission, the London Trans¬
port Executive took over control as an agency of the Commission.
Under the Transport Act 1962 the London Transport Executive was
replaced by a financially independent board, the London Transport Board.
Exchequer loans have financed the Board’s external capital needs. From 1965
the Board has been running a deficit (^10-9 million in 1967), due mainly to
competition from the private car. In 1966 and 1967 it was necessary for the
Government to subsidise the Board.
A basic reorganisation of transport in London is to take place, involving a
reconstruction of the Board’s capital, and the transfer of responsibility for
its activities to the Greater London Council. The Council is to become the
statutory transport planning authority for London, and to appoint the
members of a new statutory body, to be responsible for the day-to-day
management of transport services.
The London Transport undertaking operates all road and rail passenger
transport services in the London area with the exception of the London lines
of British Railways and the taxicabs. (Some 7,600 taxicabs that ply for hire
in the streets are privately operated by companies or owner-drivers and are
licensed annually by the metropolitan police. There are about 12,200 licensed
cab drivers.) London Transport’s operations at present extend beyond Greater
London to cover an area of 2,000 square miles (known as the London Passenger
Transport Area) within a radius of about 25 miles from Charing Cross and
with a population of ioj million. Between 1956 and !9^7 number °f
passenger journeys made annually on the London Transport system fell
from 3,914 million to 2,640 million, largely owing to increased private
motoring and changes in leisure habits, such as the increase in television
viewing.
London Transport’s railway network stretches 18 miles from north to south
and 32 miles from east to west. In 1967 the total length of the railway oyer
which London Transport trains operated was 244 miles, of which 88 miles
were underground. London Transport trains served 273 stations, and its
buses and coaches travelled over 3,200 miles of roads. To carry traffic over
all this area London Transport owned 4,031 railway cars and 7,819 buses and
coaches. The total staff employed was 73,000.
Improvements carried out by London Transport have included complete
renewal of the bus and coach fleet, replacement of trams and trolleybuses by
diesel buses, extension and modernisation of parts of the Underground
system, and the introduction of automatic fare collection and automatic
trains. One-man operation of buses is being introduced over a period of years.
In 1962 work started on the building of a new 10^-mile tube railway between
Victoria Station and Walthamstow, in north-east London. It is estimated
that the work will cost about ^65 million. The northern section of the line
was opened in 1968, and the remainder will be opened in 1969. A £16 million,
3-|-mile extension from Victoria to Brixton in south London should be ready
in the early 1970s.

1968. Under the Transport Act (Northern Ireland) 1967 the Ulster Transport
Authority was wound up and its assets and liabilities transferred to a new

1,728 miles of Class II roads, 2,869 miles of Class III roads and 8,004 miles of

The Ministry of Development is directly responsible for the trunk road
system and bears the entire cost of maintenance and reconstruction work on
these roads. In addition to major reconstruction schemes on trunk roads, an
extensive system of motorways is planned including an urban motorway
system in Belfast. About 42 miles of motorway were in use by the middle of
1968.
The Ministry of Development administers the Road Fund (the proceeds of
motor vehicle taxation, driving licence fees, etc.), from which grants are paid
to the local authorities (county, county borough, borough and urban district
councils) who are responsible for the other roads. The rates of grant range
from 90 per cent for major improvement works on Class I roads to 25 per cent
for maintenance work on the unclassified roads.
Gross capital expenditure on all roads in the financial year to 31st March
1968 was £15-8 million, and expenditure on maintenance and minor improve¬
ments was about £5-8 million. Gross capital expenditure in the five-year
period 1969-73 is expected to be about £75 million, compared with about
£58 million in the five-year period to 1968. Expenditure on maintenance and
minor improvements in the five-year period to 1968 was £22-6 million.
CIVIL AVIATION
British airmen were among the first to carry mails (at the time of the
Coronation of King George V in 1911) and among the first to operate regular
mail and passenger services, which were inaugurated on 25th August 1919,
when a daily passenger service was opened between London (Hounslow)
and Paris (Le Bourget).
In April 1924 four small British companies merged to form Imperial Airways
Limited and this company pioneered the commercial development of inter¬
continental air routes. By 1929 there was a through service from England to
India. The first passenger service to Australia started in 1935.
The British Overseas Airways Corporation, a public corporation, took over
the undertakings of Imperial Airways Limited and British Airways Limited in
M
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
1940. British European Airways was established under the Civil Aviation
Act 1946 as a separate public corporation to cover the United Kingdom
and Europe. In addition to the two nationalised corporations, there are about
30 independent air transport operators.
The Role of the
Government
Air Services
Licensing
The Air Trafisport
Licensing Board
(ATLB)
General responsibility for the development of United Kingdom civil aviation
was transferred in 1966 from the Ministry of Aviation to the Board of Trade.
Under the post-war nationalisation legislation the air corporations had a
statutory monopoly of British scheduled services, and independent operators
were confined, broadly, to charter work. From 1949, and increasingly from
1952, the independents were allowed to develop new scheduled services,
provided they secured ministerial approval and operated, technically, as
associates of the corporations. The Civil Aviation (Licensing) Act i960
abolished the corporations’ monopoly and provided for a licensing system,
administered by an Air Transport Licensing Board, to which the nationalised
and independent operators could apply on an equal footing for licences for
scheduled or charter services, or for revocation or variation of existing licences.
The ATLB is an independent body of six to ten members appointed by the
Board of Trade. Its main function is to consider and decide on applications for
licences (or their revocation or variation). The ATLB must have regard to an
applicant’s financial resources, staffing, organisation, the need for the proposed
services, the adequacy of, and possible effect on, existing services, and any
objections or representations made by interested parties. It also has the
general duty of furthering the development of British civil aviation.
There is provision for appeals on ATLB decisions to the Board of Trade,
which appoints independent commissioners to hear appeals publicly and report
with recommendations upon them. In the period from its inception to 31st
March 1968 the ATLB received some 10,000 applications for air service
licences of various kinds, including charters and package holiday tours, ot
which some 9,000 were granted.
In 1967 the Government set up a committee to enquire into the affairs of
the civil air transport industry, including the methods by which it is regulated
and controlled.
The
Corporations:
Constitutions
and Functions
Finance
Ministerial Control
The constitution and functions of BOAC and BEA are laid down in the Air
Corporations Act 1967 which consolidates, with certain exceptions, the
provisions of the Air Corporations Acts 1949 an<^ 19^^* Each corporation
consists of 5 to 11 members, including the chairman. The chairman of each
board is a member of the other.
As a result of BO AC’s capital reconstruction in 1966, £35 million ‘Exchequer
Dividend Capital’ on which a variable dividend, related to each year’s earnings,
is payable, was created, together with a reconstruction reserve of some £30
million and appropriate loan capital. The introduction of Exchequer
Dividend Capital (now £50 million and known as Public Dividend Capital)
is experimental. The statutory limit on BOAC’s total borrowings is £90
million, which can be increased by Order to £120 million. BEA’s borrowing
limit is ^210 million, which can be increased by Order to £240 million.
The Board of Trade has certain statutory powers and duties in respect of the
air corporations, including the power, very seldom used, to give directions
of a general character as to the exercise and performance of their functions,
in relation to matters affecting the national interest. With the approval of the
Treasury, the Board has power to make Exchequer advances within the limits.

laid down by Parliament. The Board of Trade is responsible for approving
the lines of the corporations’ capital expenditure. The Board also sets, after
consultation with the corporations, their financial targets and, in BOAC’s
case, approves the amount payable annually as dividend. There is also close
consultation on overseas traffic rights and air safety. Day-to-day matters
concerning the corporations’ activities are the responsibility of the commercial
management of BOAC and BEA.
Total capacity-ton-miles offered on all services has more than trebled since
1959, and had risen to 2,751 million capacity-ton-miles in 1967. In 1955,
2-5 million passengers entered or left the United Kingdom by air, compared
with 5-7 million who arrived or departed by sea; in 1962 there were for the
first time more air than sea passengers, and by 1967 the figures had risen to
14-3 million by air and 9 million by sea.
BOAC is engaged on long-haul airline operations. Its scheduled services link
Britain with Europe, the Middle East, the Far East, Australasia, Africa and
North and South America, and it also provides complete round-the-world
services. It co-operates closely with airlines of several other Commonwealth
countries; it also has financial interests in nine companies operating local and
regional services in the Far and Middle East and in the Caribbean in areas
adjacent to BOAC’s main routes; and in a number of hotel companies in areas
attractive to business and holiday travellers.
The capacity offered on BOAC’s own scheduled services reached 1,456 million
capacity-ton-miles at the end of March 1968, having risen by 12-7 per cent
over the previous year. Over half of this capacity was on the western routes
to North and South America. The overall load factor in 1967-68 was 52 per
cent; the break-even load factor (the figure at which operating costs are
covered) was 44 per cent. The Corporation’s fleet, made up entirely of pure
jets, consists (June 1968) of Super VC jos (14 with a further 3 on order),
VC 10s (12), Boeing 707-420$ (18) and Boeing 707-320C& (3 with another
2 on order). Eleven Boeing 747s are also on order and are due to enter into
service in the early 1970s.
The VC 10, introduced into service in 1964, operates on African, Middle
East and Far East routes. The Super VC 10 (a larger and more powerful
aircraft than the standard version) went into service in April 1965 on trans¬
atlantic routes. The Boeing 707-320C took over the transatlantic all-freighter
operation in January 1966. BOAC has reserved delivery positions on eight of
the Anglo-French Concorde aircraft and on six of the projected US Boeing
SSTs (supersonic transports).
BOAC is building its own passenger terminal at Kennedy International
Airport, New York, to be completed by the autumn of 1969. The Corporation
opened a new round-the-world jet service across the South Pacific to Australia
in April 1967. It is making a substantial investment over a period of ten
years on the installation of an advanced airline computer system to control
a wide variety of international activities, including accounting and flight
planning. The first stages, controlling seat reservations, came into operation
in 1968.
BOAC had another profitable year in 1967-68 when it earned a group
operating surplus of £20 million and net profits of £22-5 million after interest
on borrowings and taxation. Of its gross revenue (^150 million) £99 million
was earned in foreign currencies.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
BEA operates a network of services to over 80 places in Britain, Europe,
North Africa and the Middle East. Its services in Britain include a number
which cannot be operated on a commercial basis but which meet a vital
social need; these include services to the Highlands and Islands of Scotland.
BEA maintains a close working relationship with BO AC, whose aircraft, by
agreement, use a number of European stopping points. BEA also co-operates
with other airlines in order to create ‘through travel’ facilities. It has a
financial interest in several associated companies, most of which collaborate
with BEA in providing a network of services.
For the year ended 31st March 1968, the increases in capacity offered, and
passenger-miles and freight-ton-miles flown on scheduled services were 4
per cent, 1 per cent and 8-7 per cent respectively over the previous year; in
the same year some 7-3 million passengers were carried, an increase of 0-2
per cent.
BEA’s fleet consists (March 1968) of Trident is (23), Comet 4BS (12),
Viscount 802s (20), Viscount 806s (18), Argosys (5), Vanguard 951s (5),
Vanguard pyys (14), and Herons (2). BEA took delivery of the first of 15
Trident 2s in April 1968 to replace the Comets, and has ordered, at a cost of
£80 million, 26 of an enlarged version, the Trident 3. BAC One-Elevens,
of which 18 are on order, are due to come into service towards the end of 1968.
In 1967-68 the corporation had an operating surplus of £2 million but there
was a net loss of £1 • 8 million after payment of interest on borrowings. Recent
difficulties have included the effects of financial restrictions in Britain,
particularly on travel abroad, and political upheavals elsewhere.
The
Independent
Airline
Companies
Although the two State corporations had a statutory monopoly up to 1961
there has been a significant expansion in recent years not only of the number
of passengers and volume of freight carried but also in the diversity of services
operated by the independent operators. As well as a wide network of domestic
and international services they provide vehicle ferry services; specialised air
cargo facilities; and enable travel agents to offer low-cost all-in holidays abroad.
They have also been responsible for transport of Service personnel and
supplies overseas. The independent companies compete with BEA over
several domestic routes, including the busiest internal route in Europe, from
London to Glasgow. In 1967-68 they carried some 6-6 million passengers. A
large programme of aircraft re-equipment has been carried out. Jet airliners on
domestic routes in Britain were first introduced by British United Airways
in 1966.
In addition to the public transport operators there are a large number of
companies engaged in miscellaneous aviation activities such as crop-spraying,
aerial survey and photography, and flying instruction.
Overseas
Trade by Air
Air Freight
The proportion of Britain’s overseas trade carried by air is increasing steadily.
In 1956, 1-7 per cent of imports and 2-9 per cent of exports (by value) were
carried by air. In 1967 the corresponding percentages were 10 and 11, and
the total value of exports, imports and re-exports by air was £1,244 million.
The chief export items are expensive machinery and parts, aircraft and vehicle
parts, and electrical and electronic products; furs and skins account for a large
proportion of the total value of re-exports.
At Heathrow, London, freight traffic is increasing at an annual rate of oyer
19 per cent and totalled 276,000 tons in 1967. Scheduled services of British
Private Flying
Aerodromes
Development
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 347
airlines carried about 319,500 tons of freight in 1967, compared with 196,000
tons in 1959.
The estimated number of aircraft on the United Kingdom register used for
business and private purposes is over 800, while approximately 600 are
owned by clubs, groups and training schools. About 16,000 student and
private pilots hold licences. About 130 companies use private aircraft and
some 80 companies are members of the Business Aircraft Users’ Association.
The Board of Trade has a general responsibility for civil aerodromes. It may
itself establish and maintain airports, and local authorities may also do so
subject to its approval. Aerodromes which are municipally or privately owmed
and which are used for the public transport of passengers and/or flying
instruction are subject to government licensing, inspection and regulation.
The Board of Trade is also responsible for navigation facilities at a number
of main municipal airports.
The British Airports Authority, an independent statutory body operating
on a commercial basis, took over on 1st April 1966 the ownership and manage¬
ment of London’s two major airports (Heathrow and Gatwick), Prestwick in
Scotland, and Stansted in Essex. At these airports the Board of Trade is
responsible for the provision of navigation services and may direct the
Authority to take measures to control noise and vibration.
There are approximately 124 civil aerodromes in the United Kingdom;
in addition, 53 Service aerodromes are available for civil use. Those under
civil control include 14 directly controlled by the Board of Trade, 3 in the
Channel Islands and 1 in the Isle of Man administered by the local island
governments, and 41 aerodromes licensed for public use, of which 25 are
owned by municipalities. Three of the Board of Trade’s aerodromes and 27
others are designated Customs airports; limited customs facilities are available
at a further six aerodromes.
Aircraft and passenger movements at the principal airports have risen very
markedly in the last five years, and in 1967 United Kingdom civil airports
handled 24-7 million passengers. The number of movements of aircraft
engaged on commercial transport operations was 565,800.
For international scheduled services Heathrow and Gatwick are the main
airports, and Heathrow is the largest and busiest airport in Western Europe.
The number of passengers handled at Heathrow has increased from 5-4
million in i960 to 12-6 million in 1967. A new terminal building designed to
handle domestic and short-haul international operations of BEA and the
British independent airlines was completed in 1968, and extensions are being
made to several other buildings. To accommodate the rapid expansion
expected in freight movements, £23 million is being invested in a new cargo
terminal and associated developments, due to be completed in 1969. New
facilities are planned for handling Boeing 747 (jumbo jet) aircraft from 1970
onwards. There are plans to build a rail link between Heathrow and central
London (Victoria).
The airport at Gatwick, 25 miles south of London, was opened in June
1958 as the second airport for the London area. Built alongside the main
London to Brighton railway, Gatwick airport was the first in the world to
contain road, rail and air transport in one unit. In 1967 it handled nearly
2 million passengers. Extension of the existing runway and construction of a
second runway are being considered.

A privately owned helicopter terminal (or ‘heliport’) is in operation at
Battersea on the south bank of the Thames.
Prestwick airport in Scotland has been developed to accommodate large
jet aircraft and a new passenger terminal building and freight area were
brought into use in 1964. The freight facilities have been extended and
further improvements are planned. A ^4! million airport at Abbotsinch, near
Glasgow, was opened in May 1966, taking over services from Renfrew. Owned
and run by the Glasgow Corporation, it is expected to handle over 2 million
passengers a year by 1970.
Both Manchester (Ringway) and Glasgow (Abbotsinch) handled over a
million passengers in 1967; Belfast (Aldergrove), Southend, Edinburgh
(Turnhouse), and Birmingham each handled over 500,000.
The hovercraft, a vehicle which rides on a cushion of air over both land and
water surfaces, has been in regular public passenger service around the coasts
of Britain since 1965. Large-capacity passenger and car ferry craft (165 tons)
were introduced in 1968 as an extension to the present cross-channel services
to France, making an all-year-round service possible. A hovercraft terminal
is being built at Pegwell Bay, near Ramsgate.
The role of the Government in promoting air safety lies in research and in
setting up and supervising standards for both aircraft and personnel.
Research on aircraft design and construction is done at the Royal Aircraft
Establishments at Farnborough and Bedford, which are exceptionally well
equipped with testing facilities.
The Board of Trade determines the policy and legislative requirements for
the safe operation of civil aircraft, analyses accidents and initiates preventive
measures and research in flight safety.
All aircraft registered in the United Kingdom must have a valid certificate
of airworthiness issued (or rendered valid) by the Board of Trade on the
recommendation of the Air Registration Board, which was set up in 1937 and
consists of 18 members, two of whom are appointed by the Board of Trade—-
one as an independent and one as an experienced professional pilot, the others
being representatives of constructors, operators and insurers of aircraft. No
aircraft built in Britain is granted a certificate of airworthiness unless it has
been constructed in accordance with British Civil Airworthiness Require¬
ments, a code compiled and frequently reviewed by the Board. Continued
airworthiness is ensured by regular inspection and by requiring aircraft to be
maintained in accordance with a schedule approved by the Board.
Every operator of aircraft above a certain weight used for public transport
must possess an Air Operator’s Certificate which is granted by the Director of
Aviation Safety when he is satisfied that the operator is competent to secure
the safe operation of his aircraft. The Director is advised by the Board of
Trade’s flight operations inspectors (who are experienced airline pilots) on
all matters affecting the operation of aircraft, except aircraft maintenance,
which is the responsibility of the Air Registration Board.
Each member of a flight crew must hold the appropriate official licence. Flight
operations inspectors check the standards maintained by the operators, which
must be adequate for purposes of the Air Operator’s Certificate.
In order to supplement the diminishing supply of well-trained pilots for civil
airlines from the Royal Air Force, the College of Air Training was set up at
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
349
Air Traffic
Control and

Technical

Eurocontrol
Hamble in i960. It is sponsored and financed by the Government and the
two airways corporations. Commercial pilots must attend a course of training
approved by the Board of Trade. Such courses have been approved at the
training schools at Carlisle, Elstree (near London), Oxford and Perth, in
addition to Hamble.
Responsibility for policy, planning and execution of both civil and military
air traffic control over the United Kingdom and the surrounding seas rests
with the National Air Traffic Control Services organisation, under the joint
control of the Board of Trade and the Secretary of State for Defence.
In 1950 a system of airways covering the main traffic routes with control zones
around the major airports was introduced. Subsequently, the airway system
has been revised and extended to meet traffic requirements. There are three
main air traffic control centres: at London for southern England, at Preston
for the north of England and Wales, and at Prestwick for Scotland and the
Atlantic Ocean to 30°W.
A variety of radar installations and other equipment provide the means by
which the system can accept the increasingly heavy load of air traffic. Britain
was the first country to use radar for the control of civil air traffic, and the
Instrument Landing System (ILS) is installed at all its major airports. During
the next few years virtually the whole of the airspace over the United Kingdom
above 5,000 feet will be brought under surveillance by the latest types of
primary and secondary radar equipment, which will provide data to be used in
two air traffic control centres, located at West Drayton (near London) and
Prestwick. A subsidiary centre will be located at Manchester to deal with
traffic in the Manchester terminal control area. Extensive use will be made in
these centres of automatic data processing and other advanced electronic
techniques.
The Board of Trade provides radio navigational aids to help pilots navigate
in all weather conditions. In addition, the Board of Trade supports the Decca
Air and Marine Navigator System now operating over a wide area of the
United Kingdom and northern Europe, which can be used, by arrangement
with the Decca Company, by any aircraft fitted with the appropriate receiving
equipment.
Britain has pioneered in the development of all-weather landing systems.
The Blind Landing Experimental Unit of the Royal Aircraft Establishment
at Bedford and private industry have worked towards fully automatic blind
landing, which has now been achieved with passenger-carrying aircraft.
Britain is a member of Eurocontrol, a European international agency con¬
cerned with the traffic control problems arising from the increasing use of
high-flying, high-speed jet aircraft. Set up in 1963 it provides control at the
higher flight levels for civil aircraft and for military aircraft operating
according to civil procedures.
THE POST OFFICE
The Post Office, founded in 1657, provides the postal and public tele¬
communications services of the United Kingdom. Although at present a
government department it is in effect a nationalised industry. It is to become
a public corporation, probably in 1969.1
1 Details of the prospective change were given in a White Paper, Reorganisation of the
Post Office (Cmnd. 3233), published in March 1967. As in other nationalised industries,
the board will be appointed by and responsible to a minister.
350
Organisation
Finance

Counter
Services
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The present political head of the Post Office is the Postmaster General (see
p. 54). In March 1968 the Post Office had 413,000 employees and 25,000 post
offices.
The Post Office Act 1961 recognised the commercial character of the Post
Office by separating its finances from the Exchequer and giving the Postmaster
General sole responsibility for them. The Post Office makes its own investment
plans, subject only to the same need for broad government approval as
applies to other nationalised industries. Like them, it is expected to aim at
an adequate return on its capital and to contribute suitably to the financing of
its investment. For the five years from 1 April 1968 its financial targets have
been fixed at a return of 2 per cent on total expenditure for the postal side, and
a return of 8J per cent on net assets for telecommunications. The postal and
telecommunication services are now separately managed.
Table 25 gives recent figures of income, profit and capital. Nearly all the
capital is invested in telecommunications, which are rapidly drawing ahead
of the postal services in size and profitability.
The development of postal communications in Britain can be traced from
the time when horsemen carried dispatches to the Tudor Court up to modern
airmail transport. The first dispatch of mails by train was made in 1830
between Liverpool and Manchester. The inauguration of the penny post
(the uniform charge for any inland distance being prepaid by means of
postage stamps, which originated in Britain) in 1840 was followed by a rapid
extension of the scope of the postal services. The registered post, ensuring
additional safety for valuable mail, was introduced in 1841. The money order
system, which had operated as a private venture from 1792 to 1838, was
supplemented in 1881 by the issue of postal orders for fixed amounts.
Letterboxes had been instituted in London in 1855, and in 1883 the parcel
post was introduced. In 1919 the Post Office inaugurated its own motor
transport fleet and the first mail was carried by air in Britain in 1911.
Table 25 gives statistics of items of inland and overseas mail carried. Each
year about 7,500 tons of mail are carried by air within the United Kingdom.
Out of the 534 million items of overseas mail carried in 1967-68, 66 per cent
was carried by air, compared with 51 per cent in 1955-56. The air parcel
service now operates to all countries in Europe and to over 190 countries
outside Europe.
Several new highly mechanised sorting office buildings were opened in
1967 and 1968. Over the next ten years £50 million is to be spent on conveyance
and sorting equipment and research into new techniques. About half of this
sum will be spent on letter coding and automatic letter-sorting machines.
Letter segregating and facing machines are being installed at over 60 centres.
Postal address coding was extended to a number of large towns in 1967 and
1968. A two-tier letter service was introduced in 1968 consisting of a more
highly priced service for first-class mail and a cheaper one for less urgent items.
A Postal Consultancy Service offers facilities to overseas countries to aid
them in the planning and mechanisation of their services.
At the post office counter, besides making use of its postal and telegraph
facilities, the citizen can draw his pension and his family allowance, buy a
licence for his dog, sound radio or television receiving set, renew his car
licence and buy national insurance stamps. Post offices at present offer a wide
range of facilities for savings and investments (see p. 370). When the Post
Office ceases to be a government department (see p. 349) these facilities will

agent for other government departments or local authorities. The value of
some important items is shown in Table 25.
All private telegraph systems in Britain were transferred to the control of
the Postmaster General in 1870. Teleprinter-working for the transmission
of inland telegrams was introduced generally in 1928 and conversion to the
present automatic switching system was completed in mid-1954. It is now
one of the most up-to-date systems in the world and gives direct connection
between any of the 400 or so larger telegraph offices. The overseas telegraph
services were shared until 1950 between the Post Office and Cable and
Wireless Ltd. This company was brought into public ownership in 1947.

Telex Service
Telephone
Services
The Post Office, which acquired the British services, operates all overseas
telegraph services from the United Kingdom, except those offered by foreign
telegraph companies. Cable and Wireless Ltd. continues to operate its cable
and wireless services in many dependencies and foreign countries.
Telegraph services to overseas countries are operated from Electra House in
London, the world’s largest overseas telegraph office, and from nine other
London and provincial area telegraph offices. Direct connection via the Centex
system between these British offices and the larger towns in Belgium, t ranee,
Germany, Holland, Luxembourg, Italy and Norway minimises delivery delay.
In addition, the Post Office is well to the fore in the development of telegraph
message relay techniques for services beyond Europe.
The Telex Service (opened in England in 1932) combines the speed of the
telephone with the accuracy of the printed word. Calls may be made direct
between the rapidly increasing number of telex users in Britain (about 25,000
by the end of 1968) and also to well over 300,000 subscribers throughout the
world. Britain is linked to over 130 countries by telex. For call charging
purposes Britain is divided into 50 charging areas, each with its own telex
centre. The United Kingdom telex service is fully automatic and immediate
connection is made by direct dialling to any subscriber in this country, and to
many subscribers in Europe, New Zealand, the United States and Canada.
Other overseas calls are connected by operators at the International Telex
Exchange in London which provides a teleprinter service to over 120 countries
abroad. Inland and overseas telex traffic is growing annually by about 20 per
cent; the Post Office is planning for a system of about 80,000 United Kingdom
subscribers by 1980.
The Post Office’s remotely controlled high frequency radio station at
Leafield, Oxfordshire, became fully operational in 1966. It is the most
advanced of its kind in the world and handles overseas public radiotelegraph,
radiotelephony and telex services as well as broadcasting news services overseas.
When the Post Office bought the property of the National Telephone Com¬
pany in 1912 it became the owmer of almost the whole telephone service.
Hull Corporation was the only municipality to exercise its option of operating
its own service under licence from the Postmaster General; this service (and
the service in the Channel Islands, also operated under licence) is connected
to the Post Office trunk network.
At the end of March 1968 there were 6,118 local telephone exchanges and
just over 12 million telephones. On that date, only 192 exchanges remained
to be changed to automatic working. Trunk dialling by subscribers began in
Bristol in December 1958; by March 1968 the facility had been extended to
1,742 exchanges, serving 76 per cent of all subscribers; by 1970 it will be
available on over 90 per cent of all telephones. The introduction of the new
group routing and charging equipment brings the advantages of quicker
service, automatic accounting and cheap long-distance calls of short duration,
and constitutes the most radical reform of the telephone service since the Post
Office assumed national responsibility for it. Telephones in London have
been given all-figure numbers in which exchange names are replaced bv
figures, and numbers in other large cities are being similarly changed.
Electronic exchanges are now being ordered for all new exchanges with
from 200 to 2,000 lines. The first operational electronic exchange in Europe
was opened at Ambergate, Derbyshire, in December 1966. Similar equipment
for larger exchanges is being tested.

Pulse code modulation systems are to be used to increase the circuit
capacity of lines on short-distance routes between exchanges. By December
1969 nearly 1,000 will have been installed. A new time-division electronic
switching system for interconnecting routes equipped with pulse code
modulation systems was used experimentally during 1968.
International subscriber dialling operates between London, Edinburgh,
Birmingham, Glasgow, Liverpool, Manchester and most of Western Europe;
it is planned to extend it to Italy and other European countries.
Operator-connected calls are handled at the London Continental Exchange,
from which nearly 2,000 direct telephone circuits give service to European
countries and at the London International Exchange, which is linked by
transatlantic cables to the US and to the Commonwealth cable network. High
frequency radio is used for calls to other destinations and communications
satellites carry an increasing proportion of intercontinental telephone calls.
The various overseas circuits are also used to send and receive pictures, and
special circuits are used for broadcast transmissions.
A radio tower, 620 feet high, in London provides microwave radio links for
carrying long-distance telephone and television circuits. There are over 100
Post Office communications masts and towers in use, including a tower of
500 feet in Birmingham.
Several specialised services are available by telephone, including the ‘999’
emergency dialling service enabling subscribers to be connected as quickly
as possible, and free of charge, to the police, ambulance or fire brigade
services; the speaking clock; and a recorded weather forecast, motoring
information, recipe, cricket, and ‘Dial a Disc’ services. In London a recorded
service provides details in English, French, Spanish and German of important
events taking place in and around the capital on the day of the call and a
similar service (in English only) is provided in Edinburgh during the summer.
A public radiotelephone service, introduced in 1959, enables the users of
vehicles fitted with suitable radio equipment to make calls to, or receive them
from, any telephone in the United Kingdom network.
In March 1968 there were 104,000 private circuit stations not connected with
the public exchange networks. These are associated with circuits rented for
private use for telephone conversations, teleprinter connections, photo¬
telegraphy, television, music, or for the transmission of signals which
represent data for computers or operate other devices.
The first transatlantic telephone cable, TAT 1, connecting Britain with Canada
and the United States, was laid in 1956. Many submarine telephone cables
have been laid in succeeding years. Cable and Wireless Ltd., in co-operation
with the Post Office, carried out a comprehensive Commonwealth telephone
cable plan. The plan was agreed upon in 1958, and covered the construction
of three long-distance telephone cable systems: CANTAT (2,100 nautical
miles), from Scotland to Canada, was opened in 1961; COMPAC (8,130
nautical miles), connecting Canada, Hawaii, Fiji, New Zealand and Australia,
opened in 1963; and SEACOM (7,070 nautical miles), connecting Australia,
New Guinea, Guam, Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore, was completed in
stages from 1965 to 1967 and opened as a complete system in March 1967. All
three can provide 80 telephone circuits throughout, apart from the heavily
used section of SEACOM between Guam and Australia, which can provide
160. The submarine cables are linked overland across Canada and Australia by
radio microwave systems. CANTAT was the first single-cable ocean telephone

system to use the new lightweight cable and rigid two-way repeaters, both

Submarine cable systems using transistors in place of valves have been
developed by British manufacturers in consultation with the Post Office
Research Station. Three such systems have been laid between Britain and the
Continent. Deep-sea systems will go into service in 1969 between Britain and
Portugal and between Bermuda and Canada.
The Goonhilly satellite communication earth station in Cornwall was
brought into operation in 1962. After participating in the experimental
phases of commercial satellite communication, it is now in regular use
providing telephone circuits for the public service between Britain and North
America, and occasional television transmission facilities across the North
Atlantic. Major extensions, including the installation of a second parabolic
aerial, have been made during the past year to enable it to work to satellites of
improved design, the first of which was launched in 1968 by INTELSAT
(International Telecommunications Satellite Consortium, of which Britain is
the second largest shareholder). The new satellites will give global coverage,
and by mid-1969 Goonhilly will be a focal point for world-wide satellite
communications.
In addition to the radio stations for overseas telecommunications, the Post
Office has 11 coast radio stations in the United Kingdom. These stations
provide radiotelegraph and radiotelephone communications with ships at sea
at ranges of up to some 500 and 250 miles respectively. There is also the
long-distance radiotelegraph station, Portishead Radio, which communicates
with ships in all parts of the world.
These coast stations play an important part in the services concerned with
safety of life at sea. They keep continuous watch on the international radio¬
telegraph and radiotelephone frequencies for distress calls from ships or
aircraft and take immediate action to obtain assistance for any vessel in
distress. During 1967-68 the stations handled 603 urgent and SOS calls
from ships and aircraft.
In addition to the services for safety of life at sea, the stations exchange
radiotelegrams with ships and connect radiotelephone calls between telephone
subscribers ashore and suitably equipped ships; they also broadcast naviga¬
tional warnings and weather bulletins.
The stations operate a free medical advice service whereby the master of a
ship of any nationality may obtain advice from appropriate medical authorities
on the treatment to be given in cases of sickness or injury aboard ship. During
1967-68, 1,004 medical enquiries were dealt with in this service.
An Act passed in 1967 enabled the Post Office to set up a national data
processing service. Comprehensive bureau facilities are available for data
preparation and computer processing. Computer centres already exist in
London, Portsmouth, Derby and Edinburgh, and others are to be provided.
14 FINANCE
PUBLIC FINANCE
Public finance is concerned with the way public authorities (that is, the
central Government and local authorities) finance their activities—how their
expenditure is decided upon and how their revenue is obtained.
Money administered by public authorities1 can be roughly divided into:
1. The funds of the central Government raised mainly by taxation which are
paid into and out of the Consolidated Fund in accordance with the
proposals of the Government as approved by Parliament (principally the
House of Commons). Additional central Government funds are raised by
borrowing and are paid into the National Loans Fund set up under the
National Loans Fund Act 1968.2
There are also funds administered for special purposes by central
government departments and wholly or partially maintained by receipts
which do not pass through the Consolidated Fund. The most important
one is the National Insurance Fund, administered by the Minister of
Social Security and used for the payment of benefits under the National
Insurance Scheme.
2. The funds of local authorities, obtained partly from rates (local taxes on
dwelling-houses and other real estate) and income from property and
trading receipts, partly from grants and loans from the central Government
and partly from loans raised in the open market (see p. 72).
The following broad account of government finance is concerned mainly
with central Government taxation and borrowing and only incidentally with
local government and other public funds.
Financial control, as exercised by the House of Commons, is based on law,
parliamentary rights and custom.
As the power of Parliament grew in late medieval and Tudor times, the
principle that taxation by the Crown required parliamentary consent was
gradually evolved. The principle was established, at the end of the constitu¬
tional struggles of the Stuart period, by the Bill of Rights 1689.
In medieval, Tudor and Stuart times, it is broadly true to say that once the
king was granted the right to raise a given sum by taxation, he was free to
spend it as he chose. In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, the House of
Commons gradually developed the modern system of controlling expenditure
through the device of Appropriation which was embodied in the Exchequer
and Audit Departments Act 1866. But by a Standing Order of the House of
Commons dating from the early eighteenth century the Crown’s consent is
required for all proposals involving new spending from the Consolidated Fund.
The House of Commons cannot, therefore, initiate expenditure which must be
proposed by a Minister.
1 For an account of public finance in Northern Ireland and its relationship to that of the
United Kingdom, see pp. 364-7.
2 Prior to April 1968 the funds from both these sources were paid into the Exchequer.
The term ‘Exchequer’ took its name from the ‘chess-board’, or table with chequered
cloth, round which the King’s financial officials sat for accounting purposes in the
twelfth century.
356
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
From the very early days of Parliament it had been established that such
financial control as Parliament possessed should be exercised by the House of
Commons. This control became effective, as regards taxation, in the seven¬
teenth century, but as regards expenditure it was not effective until the
nineteenth century. The controlling power of the House of Commons is
acknowledged today in the Speech from the Throne at the opening of a new
session of Parliament, which is addressed to both Houses but contains a
special paragraph on expenditure addressed to the Commons alone.
The Commons have traditionally claimed that the Lords have no power to
modify financial provisions, though they may reject such provisions; thus,
to minimise the chance of rejection, the practice was started in 1861 of
embodying the main financial provisions for the ensuing year in a single Bill.
Since the passing of the Parliament Act 1911, however, if the Finance Bill is
certified by the Speaker to be a Money Bill, it may be presented to the Queen
for the Royal Assent and become law without the consent of the House of
Lords if it has not been passed by them within one month (see p. 36).
Today, the authority of the House of Commons has to be obtained for all
expenditure by the central Government itself and for the raising of revenue
by taxation or borrowing. All government revenue, other than the proceeds of
borrowing and sums received by government departments in the course of
their normal activities (known as appropriations-in-aid), is paid into an
account with the Bank of England (known as the Exchequer Account) which
forms the Consolidated Fund. With certain exceptions (the main ones being
government loans and national insurance benefits), all payments by the
Government come out of this account.
The following sections outline the machinery by which expenditure and
revenue are authorised and controlled, the purposes on which public money
is spent and the sources from which revenue is obtained.
ESTIMATES AND
EXPENDITURE
Classification of
Expenditure
Central government expenditure falls into three main groups:
1. The main part of government expenditure which is authorised by annual
Appropriation Acts and includes, broadly, expenditure on defence, on the
social services and on the general administration of the country. These are
called Supply Services because the House of Commons, when voting
money, is granting to the Crown ‘such aids or supplies as are required to
satisfy . . . the pecuniary necessities of the Government’. It should be
noted that some of this expenditure may also depend on legislation, such
as the National Health Service Acts, which relates to a specific object of
expenditure.
2. Expenditure which is specifically authorised by Acts of Parliament other
than annual Appropriation Acts. These are the Consolidated Fund
Standing Services which represent a direct charge on the Consolidated
Fund, covering the residual cost of servicing the National Debt,1 the
financial provision made for members of the royal family, and salaries and
pensions of judges and certain high officers, such as the Speaker of the
House of Commons and the Leader of the Opposition, whose independ¬
ence of the Government is thought to be better guaranteed by permanent
grant than by annual vote.
1 The servicing of the National Debt is charged in the first instance to the National
Loans Fund. After taking account of certain receipts by the Fund, including interest
received on loan to nationalised industries and local authorities, the residue is charged
to the Consolidated Fund.
FINANCE
357
Authorisation
of Expenditure
Scrutiny of
Expenditure
The Treasury
3. Government lending and debt, which under the National Loans Act 1968
are channelled through the National Loans Fund. These include most of
the Government’s domestic lending to the nationalised industries, local
authorities and public corporations as well as the principal repayments and
the servicing (that is, interest and expenses) of the National Debt.
The Estimates for the Supply Services are considered by the House of
Commons during the 29 days (known as Supply days) which are allotted by
Standing Order of the House to consideration of Supply business in each
session. The choice of subject for debate on these days rests with the
Opposition. The House usually discusses general questions of policy relevant
to the Estimates, though any Estimate may be examined in detail if members
wish and if time allows (see p. 39).
Estimates for Supply Services in the financial year beginning on 1st April
are submitted to the Treasury by each department in the preceding December.
Estimated expenditure is grouped under main headings called ‘Votes’ which
are further broken down into subheads and items. If the House of Commons
approves the Estimates, the sums asked for are voted and later confirmed in
the Appropriation Act; this Act appropriates the money to specific Votes.
No civil department may spend money granted on one \ ote for the purposes
of another; but Service departments may do so providing they get Treasury
sanction, which, in turn, requires the retrospective authorisation of Parliament.
Within each Vote, ‘virement’, that is, the spending of money on one subhead
instead of on another, is permissible so far as Parliament is concerned, but
only with Treasury consent.
An insufficient Estimate, or a new service not covered by the Vote, or
virement of a magnitude or character wffiich the Treasury considers should be
brought to the attention of Parliament, requires a Supplementary Estimate.
The Treasury exercises the same power of scrutiny over this as over the
ordinary Estimates.
Control of expenditure is maintained by the Treasury, by the Comptroller
and Auditor General, and by the Public Accounts and Estimates Committees
of the House of Commons.
The power of the Treasury to control expenditure derives from the responsi¬
bility of the Chancellor of the Exchequer for financial policy.
A central function of the Treasury is to present the Civil Estimates to the
House of Commons. In considering the Estimates submitted by departments,
the Treasury has to look at the proposals for expenditure in relation to
prospective national resources and to weigh the advantages of administrative
proposals against the monetary and economic cost, taking into account current
government policy; to decide the relative merits of expenditure proposed by
departments; and to eliminate any overlapping, uneconomic or wasteful
expenditure where this has escaped the net of departmental financial control.
Apart from the scrutiny of Estimates, throughout the year the Treasury keeps
a close control over such matters as rates of pay and the aggregate size of the
staff in all government departments, in addition to exercising a general
supervision over all departmental expenditure. The Treasury also lays down
general rules of financial and accounting procedure for departments and
prescribes the principles on which departmental contracts shall be made and
the limits within which certain classes of losses may be written off.
In 1961 the Plowden Committee on the Control of Public Expenditure
recommended in their Report {Cmnd. 1432) that regular surveys should be
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
made of public expenditure as a whole over a period of years ahead and in
relation to prospective resources, and that decisions involving future expendi¬
ture should be taken in the light of these surveys. Surveys, therefore, are now
made annually and have become an established part of the Government’s
machinery for the planning and control of expenditure (see p. 230).
Control over issues of money to departments and the audit of accounts is
exercised by the Comptroller and Auditor General, which is a permanent
Crown appointment. Since 1866 he has had two functions: as Comptroller he
controls receipts and issues of public money to and from the Exchequer
Account and the National Loans Fund; and as Auditor General he audits
departmental accounts and submits his report on the Appropriation Accounts
and other accounts, as required by statute, to Parliament. His statutory
function is to ensure that all expenditure is properly incurred, for example,
that no payments are made which go beyond any relevant statutory authority,
and that Treasury sanction has been obtained wherever necessary. In addition,
however, he has been encouraged by successive Public Accounts Committees
(see the next paragraph) to examine departmental expenditure with a view to
drawing attention to any cases of apparent waste or extravagance.
The Public Accounts The accounts of each department and the reports on the accounts made by
Committee the Comptroller and Auditor General are considered by a select committee
called the Public Accounts Committee. This was first set up in 1861, on the
motion of Mr. Gladstone, for the purpose of ensuring that expenditure was
properly incurred in accordance with the purpose for which it was voted and
with any relevant Acts of Parliament. The terms of reference of the committee
are to examine the accounts and these terms have been widely interpreted by
successive committees which have investigated whether full value has been
obtained for the sums spent by departments and have examined cases in which
the administration appears to have been faulty or negligent. The committee
has therefore become a powerful instrument for the exposure of waste and
inefficiency. It embodies its findings in reports which may be debated in the
House of Commons. Its recommendations are considered by the Treasury
in consultation with departments and put into effect, so far as they are
accepted, according to Treasury instructions. A reply to each report is
submitted by the Treasury to the committee of the following session and
where the recommendations have been unacceptable to the Treasury the
committee may either accept the objections or return to the charge in sub¬
sequent reports.
The Estimates This committee was originally set up in 1912 and has been reappointed
Committee annually except during the war years. In i960 it was made a select committee
set up each session under standing orders. The committee’s functions are
to examine the Estimates, to report how, if at all, the policy implied in the
Estimates can be carried out more economically and to consider the principal
variations between the Estimates of the current year and those of the previous
year and the form in which the Estimates should be presented. Usually, the
committee selects each year a few Votes for review.
Through the medium of a number of sub-committees, the committee carries
out extensive investigations into the departments or subjects under considera¬
tion. In practice the Estimates for the current year are not affected, but the
committee’s recommendations produce changes in future Estimates and
strengthen Treasury control. One of these sub-committees examines the
winter and spring Supplementary Estimates and the principal variations
between the Estimates presented and those of the previous year. The other

THE BUDGET
Budget Policy
