sub-committees are organised on functional lines, each sub-committee being
allocated a different sphere of government policy and administration. Addi¬
tional parliamentary time has been allocated for discussion of the reports of
the Estimates and the Public Accounts Committees.
‘Budget’ is an old word meaning a bag containing papers or accounts. The
use of the word in public finance originated in the expression ‘The Chancellor
of the Exchequer opened his Budget’, which is applied in Parliament to the
annual speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer explaining his proposals for
balancing revenue and expenditure.
The annual Budget speech is normally the main occasion of the year for
reviewing the central Government’s finances and the economic state of the
nation, and its formal basis is the Chancellor’s proposals for raising money by
taxation. In recent years it has become the practice for Chancellors to discuss
in the Budget speech the prospects for the economy in the period ahead in
some detail. By the time the Budget is introduced (usually in April) the
Estimates of expenditure under various headings will have been presented to
Parliament and published, and the expected total of government expenditure
for the year will be known. The Chancellor estimates the yield of the revenue
on the basis of existing taxation and proposes such changes in taxation as he
considers desirable on economic grounds. These proposals are later embodied
in detail in a Finance Bill. The interval between the Budget Statement and the
Royal Assent to the Finance Bill (usually given in July) is covered by legisla¬
tion (mainly the Provisional Collection of Taxes Act 1968), whereby changes
in income tax, corporation tax, purchase tax, and customs and excise duties
have immediate statutory effect if adopted by Resolution of the House of
Commons.
The Budget also takes into account the finance needed to cover government
lending. Details for the current year were given in a White Paper, Loans from
the National Loan Fund ig68-6g, issued on Budget day. For 1968-69 it is
estimated that rather more than half of the net issues from this Fund would
be loans to nationalised industries; just under one-third would be loans to
local authorities; and the remainder loans to public corporations, private
industry, and certain advances within the central Government.
The original purpose of the Budget was purely financial—to provide money
for government expenditure. From an early stage, however, it was appreciated
that taxation would affect the distribution of income and property and the
level of expenditure on particular goods and services. At a later period it was
realised that taxation also affected the nation’s total expenditure and therefore
the general level of economic activity. Since the second world war, Budgets
have been consciously designed in greater or lesser degree to bring the total
demand for goods and services into balance with total national output.
The Budget affects the general level of expenditure and, therefore, the total
demand for goods and services in the following way: if there is an increase in
government expenditure without an increase in taxation then total demand for
goods and services will tend to rise; the same thing will happen if there is a
decrease in taxation without a decrease in government spending. In this way
the Budget can be used to counter unemployment. On the other hand, if
there is an increase in taxation without an increase in government expenditure,
or a decrease in government expenditure without a decrease in taxation then
the total demand for goods and services will tend to fall. Particular taxes may
be used with the intention of bringing about certain desired effects. For

Sources of

Income Tax
example, taxes on income and capital affect the distribution of wealth because
the rates vary according to the size of the income or capital, the proportion of
a high income or capital taken in tax being much greater than the proportion
of a small one; while taxes on expenditure may influence the allocation of
resources and the pattern of trade by discouraging or encouraging the con¬
sumption of particular goods.
The main objectives of British budgetary policy in recent years have been
the achievement and maintenance of a strong balance of payments together
with a high rate of economic growth and a high level of employment. In order
to regulate demand more closely, successive governments have adopted a
much more flexible attitude towards fiscal policy and have not hesitated to use
budgetary measures between annual Budgets. At the same time consideration
is being given to the long-term strategy for taxation and to ways in which the
existing system of taxation can be improved by ensuring that its incidence
is fair and by closing loopholes. In support of the devaluation of the pound
sterling in November 1967 (see p. 223) budgetary policy combined with cuts
in public expenditure are being used to reduce the level of domestic demand.
In the United Kingdom the principal taxes fall into three main categories.
First, taxes on income, which include income tax, surtax and corporation tax;
second, taxes on capital, which include estate duty, capital gains tax and the
tax on'short-term gains; and third, taxes on expenditure (including taxes
on the ownership or use of certain assets)—these include not only customs and
excise duties and the purchase tax, but also the selective employment tax (in
service and construction industries), local rates, stamp duties and licence duties
(for example, on motor vehicles and dogs). Taxes on individual (though not
corporate) incomes are progressive taxes, that is, larger incomes and estates
bear a proportionately higher rate of tax. The Board of Inland Revenue
collects the taxes on income and capital and the stamp duties, the Board of
Customs and Excise collects the most important taxes on expenditure, the
customs and excise taxes and the purchase tax, while a variety of authorities
are responsible for the collection of the remainder, including the Ministry of
Social Security for the selective employment tax.
Income tax is imposed at a standard rate for the year of assessment beginning
on 6th April, which is at present 8s. 3d. in the £ (41-25 per cent). The tax
imposed on an individual is graduated by means of personal allowances and
reliefs, by reduced rates of tax on the first sections of taxable income1 and by
the surtax. In the case of a married couple the incomes of husband and wife are
aggreg^ed and are treated as one income, but higher allowances are given
than for a single person. Earned income bears less tax than other income as
certain fractional deductions (‘earned income relief’) are allowable.
A single person earning £1,000 a year pays £186 in income tax, while a
married man with the same earned income pays £137 > ^ ^as ^wo children
under the age of 11, his tax (after taking into account the receipt of family
allowances) falls to £73; when the children are between the ages of 11 and 16,
the tax is £58; if the children are over 16 and receiving full-time education,
only £43 is paid. The range of tax payable by a single person varies from, for
example, £41 on an earned income of £500 a year to £1,515 on an earned
1 The balance of income remaining after deduction of the personal allowances and
reliefs is taxable income. For 1968-69 the reduced rates are: 4s od. in the £ on the
first £100; and 6s. od. in the £ on the next £200. The remainder is charged at the
standard rate.

Most wage and salary earners pay their income tax under a PAYE (‘Pay-as-
you-earn’) scheme, under which tax is deducted at source, thus enabling them
to keep up to date on tax payments.
In general, income tax is charged on all income which originates in the
United Kingdom and on all income arising abroad of persons (including
companies) resident in the United Kingdom. The main exceptions are that
interest on certain United Kingdom government securities belonging to
persons not ordinarily resident in the United Kingdom is exempt; and
income from certain classes of possessions abroad is chargeable not on the
amount of income arising but on the amount of income remitted to the United
Kingdom. The United Kingdom has entered into agreements with many
countries providing for relief from double taxation; where such agreements
are not in force unilateral relief is allowed.1
The surtax, which is essentially an income tax at higher rates, is charged on
personal incomes exceeding £2,000 a year after deducting certain personal
allowances in excess of the single person’s basic allowance. In addition, the
same earned income relief as for income tax and a special earnings allowance
(not exceeding £2,000) are deductible from earned income only. Surtax is
imposed at rates which increase progressively until, on the portion of taxable
income above £15,000, the combined rate of income tax and surtax payable
in 1968-69 (being income tax for 1968-69 and surtax for 1967-68) reaches
18s. 3d. in the £.
A special charge on investment incomes of £3,000 or above, after deduction
of the personal allowances which can be claimed for surtax, was imposed for
the year 1967-68 in the 1968 Budget.
The Finance Act 1965 introduced a new system of taxation of companies by
means of a corporation tax on profits instead of income tax and profits tax.
A company now deducts income tax from dividends and other distributions
and pays it over to the Inland Revenue as a separate matter from its own
liability. The rate of corporation tax is fixed retrospectively in the Budget for
the past financial year; for 1967-68 it is 42^ per cent. The tax is assessed on
the profits of accounting periods, the rate of tax being the rate for the financial
year in which the accounting period falls. The basic rule for the calculation of
income for corporation tax purposes is that, except for special provisions, it is
computed in accordance with income tax principles.
Estate duty is chargeable on the value of property (whether legally settled or
not) which passes or is deemed to pass at death. Thus, it is not limited to
property owned by the deceased. It may, for example, extend to trust funds
to the income of which the deceased was entitled during his lifetime, and to
gifts made by the deceased within seven years of his death (one year in the case
of a gift for public or charitable purposes). Estates with a net capital value of
£5,000 or less are exempt from duty, but on estates of a higher value there is
a progressive duty ranging from 1 per cent to 80 per cent.
Capital gains accruing on the disposal of assets are liable to capital gains tax
or, in the cases of companies, to corporation tax. Where assets were acquired
before 6th April 1965, the charge is restricted to the part of any gain attribut¬
able to the period since 6th April 1965. The rate of tax for persons, other than

companies is 30 per cent, but in the case of individuals may be less, depending
on their circumstances. Certain assets are exempt from tax including a
principal private residence, chattels worth less than ,£1,000 (and any chattels,
except those used for the purpose of a trade, with a predictable life of less than
50 years), private motor cars and National Savings securities. The gains of an
individual for a year are exempt if, after deducting losses, they do not exceed
£50. Gains arising from the disposal of assets within 12 months of their
acquisition are in general liable as short term gains to income tax (and surtax)
and not to capital gains tax.
The largest group of taxes on expenditure are those administered by the
Customs and Excise Department, namely, the duties on tobacco, hydrocarbon
oil, alcoholic drinks, purchase tax, protective duties, betting and certain
miscellaneous items. In British usage the distinction between customs and
excise depends on whether the goods are imported (customs duties) or British
produced (excise duties). These taxes are sometimes known as indirect taxes
since they are normally paid by the importer, manufacturer, or wholesaler,
who adjusts prices charged to customers accordingly. In 1968 the tax burden
was equivalent to 3s. nd. on a gallon of petrol, 4s. 3d. on a packet of 20
standard plain cigarettes, £2 on a bottle of whisky, and io^d. on a pint of beer
of average strength.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer has power to vary by Order the rates of
purchase tax and any of the other main groups of customs and excise duties
(that is, tobacco, alcoholic drinks, oil, and the minor revenue duties). These
powers, known as the ‘regulator’, require annual renewal.
Purchase tax is charged on a wide range of goods, nearly all of them
consumer goods, at four rates, which are currently 12^ per cent, 20 per cent,
33 J per cent and 50 per cent of the wholesale value. Articles subject to revenue
duties of customs and excise are in general exempt from this tax; other goods
free of purchase tax include food (other than confectionery, soft drinks and
ice cream), fuel, books and newspapers, young children’s clothing and foot¬
wear, certain non-proprietary drugs and medicines, some household appliances
and textiles.
The principal betting duties are: the pool betting duty (which applies to
football pools and betting by coupon at fixed odds) charged at a rate of 33^ per
cent of the stake money; and the general betting duty, which is charged on
most other kinds of betting at the rate of 5 per cent of stake money. Gaming
is taxed at different rates by licence fees.
Taxes on motor vehicles are collected by the local taxation authorities (the
county or county borough councils in England and Wales and the correspond¬
ing councils in Scotland); the proceeds are paid by the local authorities into
the Exchequer. The licence duty on a private motor car is £25 a year; motor
cycles and three-wheel vehicles, etc., pay £2 10s., £5 or £10 a year according
to engine capacity.
A selective employment tax, designed, among other things, to encourage
economy in the use of labour in the service industries, became operative in
September 1966. It is paid by all employers throughout the United Kingdom
at a rate per week of 37s. 6d. for men, 18s. pff women and boys and 12s.
for girls. Employers, however, are affected in various ways. Employers in
manufacturing industries in the development areas receive a refund of tax and
additional sums, made up of a selective employment premium and a regional
employment premium (see p. 249). Employers in manufacturing industries

not in the development areas and employers in transport and communications,
public service, including the nationalised industries, agriculture, extractive
industries and charities have the tax refunded but receive no premium.
Employers in service industries and construction pay the tax without refund,
but schemes have now been introduced for the refund of the tax in respect of
certain part-time and elderly workers, employees working overseas and
employees in hotels in certain rural parts of development areas.
After allowing for the Budget changes, total expenditure for the financial year
ending 31st March 1969 is estimated to reach £11,489 million, including £764
million for Consolidated Fund Standing Services and .£10,725 million for
Supply Services. The estimate for total revenue is £12,875 million of which
£12,475 million is receipts from taxation. A surplus of £1,386 million for
transfer to the National Loans Fund is therefore expected. Net lending from
the National Loans Fund (see p. 355) is estimated to reach £1,744 million.
Thus the balance to be met by borrowing and special transactions is estimated
to total £358 million.
Table 26 shows total revenue from taxation and other sources anticipated
in 1967-68 and 1968-69. Table 27 shows receipts and payments from the
National Loans Fund in these years and the Government’s borrowing require¬

Capital expenditure consists chiefly of loans to the nationalised industries, the
local authorities and other public corporations, such as the New Towns
Development Corporations. These loans, less repayments, are financed from
the National Loans Fund by the surplus of revenue over expenditure (if any),
by the proceeds of government borrowing including borrowing from extra-
budgetary funds, such as the National Insurance Fund, and by the sterling
receipts (if any) accruing to the Exchange Equalisation Account.
Exchequer borrowing may be in the form of borrowing from the public
either through the National Savings Movement (see p. 370) or by borrowing
on the market by means of new issues of securities. New issues of government
securities are made from time to time for the purpose of refinancing maturing
issues (conversion issues) or to raise new money (issues for cash). Since 195^
capital requirements of the nationalised industries have been met in full by
the central Government while those of the local authorities are met partly
through the Public Works Loan Board (see p. 74) and partly by the local
authorities borrowing direct from the public in the form of mortgages or
stock issues or deposits (mainly placed by the overseas banks).
The National Debt increased particularly rapidly during and immediately
after the first and second world wars. It rose from £651 million in 1914 to
£7,435 million at the end of the first world war, and from £7,131 million in
1939 to £23,637 million in 1946. On 31st March 1968, the total National Debt
(provisional) was £33,484 million, of which £2,303 million was repayable
in currencies other than sterling, mainly to the United States and Canadian
Governments. Of the £29,675 million of internal debt, £5>734 million was
short-term debt, mainly in the form of 91-day Treasury bills, while the long¬
term loans included a variety of stocks, bonds, loans, and certificates carrying
fixed rates of interest (ranging from 2^ to per cent) and with fixed or
indeterminate dates of repayment.

The general system of public finance in Northern Ireland is, in its main
features, similar to that operating in the United Kingdom as a whole, under
which public revenues, with a few minor exceptions, are paid into the
Exchequer Account, from which no money can be withdrawn except on the
authority of Parliament. That authority is expressed in the case of Consolidated
Fund charges in permanent legislative form, and in the case of Supply Services
by annual Appropriation Acts based on estimates prepared by departments
and sanctioned by the Ministry of Finance.

The major sources of revenue flowing into the Northern Ireland Exchequer
are the main national taxes imposed by the United Kingdom Parliament over
the whole country and paid, in the first instance, into the United Kingdom
Consolidated Fund. These taxes, which are referred to in the Government of
Ireland Act 1920 as ‘reserved’ taxes (that is, reserved to the United Kingdom
Parliament), comprise the Inland Revenue group (income tax, surtax,
corporation tax and capital gains tax) and customs and excise duties on goods.
After the cost of collecting these taxes in Northern Ireland (and the cost of
some other reserved services) and an Imperial Contribution have been
retained in the U mted Kingdom Consolidated Fund, the balance, termed the
‘Residuary Share of Reserved Taxes’, is paid to the Northern Ireland Ex¬
chequer where it joins up with the transferred taxes (that is, where taxation
powers have been transferred to the Northern Ireland Parliament) to form the
public income. Among items of Transferred Tax Revenue are estate duties,
stamp duties, betting duties, various excise licence duties, motor x chicle
duties and selective employment tax.

A joint Exchequer Board, representative of the Treasury and the Ministry
of Finance for Northern Ireland, constituted in accordance with the Govern¬
ment of Ireland Act 1920, determines the amount of Reserved Revenue and
the cost of Reserved Services attributable to Northern Ireland for each year,
the amount of the Imperial Contribution, and such other questions affecting
the financial relations of the two Governments as may be referred to it.
In the Northern Ireland Budget for 1968-69 (year ending 31st March),
total revenues were forecast at ^296 million and expenditure at ^294 million.

The Public Debt of Northern Ireland, totalling £244 million on 31st March
1968, is covered by repayable advances and investments held by the Ministry
of Finance.
Outside the Exchequer system in Northern Ireland, various funds have been
established, in addition to statutory Reserve and Sinking Funds, for specific
purposes. In general, these funds follow the United Kingdom pattern, the
principal funds being those relating to National Insurance and government
loans. The latter constitutes a pool of capital money available mainly for local
and public authority borrowings; on 31st March 1968, a sum of approximately
£198 million was outstanding against such borrowers.
BANKING AND PRIVATE FINANCE
The British banking system is long established and well integrated. It
comprises a central bank; commercial banks which carry on the usual main
banking services; the United Kingdom offices of banks whose main business
is in other countries; merchant banks and other specialised institutions.
The Bank of England is the central bank and its principal business is to act
as banker to the Government and to the other banks, as the agent of the
Government for important financial operations and as the central note-issuing
authority; it also maintains relations with central banks overseas. It was
established in 1694 by Act of Parliament and Royal Charter as a corporate
body, and its entire capital stock was acquired by the Government under the
Bank of England Act 1946.
As the central bank, the Bank of England is responsible for co-ordinating
the application of the Government’s monetary policy. One of the main
instruments for this purpose is the Bank rate—the minimum rate at which the
Bank of England will discount approved bills of exchange and a key factor in
the general pattern of interest rates.
As banker to the Government, the Bank of England holds the main
government accounts and it acts as the Government’s agent for the issue and
registration of government loans. It is responsible for the day-to-day execution
of monetary policy by dealing in the markets for Treasury bills and Govern¬
ment stocks. It also operates, as agent for the Treasury, the administration of
exchange control which has been in force since 1939.
The commercial banks maintain large balances with the Bank of England
and these balances form part of the banks’ cash reserves. In addition, under
an arrangement made with the London clearing banks and Scottish banks in
1958, the Bank of England may call on these banks for ‘special deposits’
which, not being freely disposable, do not rank as part of their liquid assets.
The scheme, which affects the ability of the banks to lend, is being used to
keep credit conditions in line with the changing needs of the economy. The
Bank of England gives guidance to the main banking and financial organisations
on the advances policy it wishes them to adopt.
The Bank of England has the sole right in England and Wales of issuing
bank notes. Notes thus issued need a 100 per cent cover in gold and securities,
together with a limited amount of coin, the part covered by securities and
coin being the ‘Fiduciary Issue’, the level of which is subject to parliamentary
control. (The Scottish and Northern Ireland banks have limited rights to issue
368

The

notes; these issues, apart from an amount specified by legislation for each
bank, must be fully covered by Bank of England notes and by coin.) In
practice very little gold is now held by the Issue Department of the Bank of
England, the bulk of the United Kingdom gold (and foreign exchange) reserves
being in a separate government fund, known as the Exchange Equalisation
Account; this account was originally established in 1932 for the purpose of
checking undue fluctuations in the exchange value of sterling, and is operated
by the Bank of England as agent for the Treasury. 1 he provision of coin for
circulation is the responsibility of the Royal Mint, a government department.
The principal commercial banks in the United Kingdom are the 11 London
clearing banks,1 5 Scottish banks and 3 Northern Ireland banks. They are
limited liability companies which in the main are subject to the ordinary law
relating to such companies. Together, their deposits amounted to over ^11,000
million at the end of 1967 and accounted for about two-thirds of the total
deposits of the banking sector, which also includes the overseas banks,
accepting houses and the discount market. They provided full banking services
throughout the United Kingdom, operating through nearly 14,000 branches
at the end of 1967. Several have interests in other clearing, domestic or over¬
seas banks and in finance companies.
During 1968 two mergers have taken place between members of the large
London clearing banks and one between two Scottish banks. A further merger
(between Barclays, Lloyds and Martins) was not pursued following an
adverse report by the Monopolies Commission. The mergers are designed to
provide for the growing financial needs of industry and to develop overseas
business.
Together with the Bank of England the London clearing banks make up the
membership of the London Bankers’ Clearing House. In 1967 cheques, bills
and drafts valued at ^46,555 nfiifi°n monthly and credit transfers valued at a
further £846 million monthly passed through the clearing house.
The primary business of the commercial banks is the receipt, transfer and
encashment of deposits. Deposits on current account on which no interest is
paid are repayable on demand, while on balances on deposit account interest
is paid at a rate generally 2 per cent below Bank rate. The London clearing
banks maintain a ratio of about 8 per cent between cash reserves and total
deposits. It is also a convention among the commercial banks that at least
28 per cent of deposits should be held in the form of liquid assets. Prior to
1963 this ratio was 30 per cent.
The banks’ profits are largely earned through their advances to customers
partly in the form of overdrafts and partly in the form of loans (with or
without collateral security); these are normally for a short term only unless
renewed. The ratio of London clearing bank advances to total deposits
declined from about 43 per cent in 1938 to 17 per cent at the end of the
second world war but it has since risen and in June 1968 it was around 50 per
cent. In recent years the banks have been asked to restrain the growth of their
lending and to ensure that, within the total, priority is given to finance for
exports and for productive investment in manufacturing industry and
agriculture: this has involved the restriction of advances to the personal
sector. The banks’ ‘liquid’ assets, that is, those that are quickly realisable,
are their loans to discount houses (money at call), and their holdings of
1 The five largest of these banks have been known as the ‘Big Five’; in addition, there
are six smaller banks, three of which have their headquarters outside London at
Liverpool and Manchester.

Treasury and commercial bills and certain export and shipbuilding credits
refinanceable with the Bank of England: they also hold a proportion of their
assets as portfolio (mainly British Government securities) or trade investments.
Improvements have also been made to money transmission services in the
introduction in i960 of the credit transfer scheme, now called ‘the bank giro’.
Subsequently, credit transfer charges for customers were abolished and a
system of direct debiting introduced which enables a creditor, with the prior
approval of the debtor, to claim money due to him direct from the latter’s
banking account. Other innovations have been in the increasing use of credit
cards for the settlement of accounts in retail shops and the experimental
introduction of cash dispensing machines.
A new departure in British banking is the Post Office Giro which is to come
into operation in October 1968. It provides a postal cheque service for all
customers with a current account, but no overdraft facilities. Payments and
withdrawals may be made through any post office in Britain, but the records
of all transactions and all the accounts are maintained at a single central office
at Bootle, near Liverpool.
There are also 34 British overseas and Commonwealth banks, many of them
having their headquarters in London. They provide a comprehensive banking
service in many parts of the world and engage in the financing of trade not
only between Britain and other countries but also between third countries.
There are also currently in London 15 United States banks, 11 Japanese banks
and over 40 other foreign banks.
The merchant banks have helped to give London an international reputation
as a world financial centre for short-term and long-term borrowing. They
are of two kinds, and are known as accepting houses and issuing houses
according to whether they specialise predominantly in the work of acceptance
credit1 or in transactions involving the sponsoring of capital issues on behalf
of their customers. They arrange to issue and themselves underwrite long-
and short-term loans to governments of, or enterprises in, overseas countries
in sterling (where permitted by exchange control regulations) or in other
currencies which have been deposited with them; this latter type of transaction,
in what are called the euro-dollar markets, has increased considerably in
recent years. They are also engaged in the work of the gold and foreign
exchange markets, and they have many other functions in connection with the
financing of trade, investment management, and insurance.
The London discount or money market is a distinctive part of the British
banking system. It consists of 12 discount houses and its principal function
is to marry the needs of lenders of money for short periods with those of the
borrowers of such money.
The discount houses borrow ‘at call’ from banks and other financial
institutions at a low rate of interest. To them the Bank of England acts as a
lender of last resort. The clearing banks do not borrow money directly from
the Bank of England; if they need to add to their cash resources they call
in part of their loans to the discount market. If, as a result, any particular
1 Acceptance credit has been defined as fundamentally a three-month operation
financing exports from and imports to Britain and to other markets. The expression is
derived from the method of financing trade by which commercial bills are ‘accepted’
or guaranteed by a merchant bank against documents, after which they may be
discounted for cash by a discount house.

discount house is unable to cover its needs for cash elsewhere, it is obliged
to borrow from the Bank of England, traditionally at Bank rate or above for
a minimum of seven days; recently, however, the Bank has also lent at market
rates, usually overnight but sometimes for longer periods.
An important part of the money borrowed by the discount houses is
invested in British Government Treasury bills. The discount houses accept as
an informal responsibility that they should cover the Government’s need to
borrow on Treasury bills, which are offered on tender each week.
The clearing banks do not, in the ordinary way, buy Treasury bills at the
weekly tenders except on behalf of customers, but they purchase, from the
discount market, bills which are of a maturity required by the banks.
The discount houses provide a specialised market in commercial bills and
in short-dated Government bonds (that is, those with not more than five years
to run before repayment) and local authority bonds.
The National Savings Movement started in 1916 to help finance the war by
promoting savings. The present movement encourages the widespread
investment of savings in Trustee Savings Banks and the Post Office Savings
Bank and in National Savings securities. The movement is led by the National
Savings Committee for England and Wales and similar committees for
Scotland and Northern Ireland.1 The committees are bodies of independent
persons representing regional savings organisations and various national
institutions connected with such matters as finance, industry and education.
They are assisted by a salaried staff of civil servants. Voluntary local savings
committees, often assisted or promoted by local authorities, co-ordinate the
work of voluntary local savings groups.
Three forms of National Savings securities are currently on sale: the
National Savings Certificate, the British Savings Bond,2 and the Premium
Savings Bond. National Savings Certificates, in units of £1, are encashable
at par at any time; interest, which is free of income tax and surtax, is only
paid on encashment; the limit on individual holdings is 1,000 units of the
current issue. British Savings Bonds, sold in units of ^5 with a maximum
holding of £10,000, bear interest at 6 per cent and are repayable at par on one
month’ snotice. Premium Savings Bonds are in units of £1 and individual
holdings are limited to £1,250. After a qualifying period of three months the
bonds give investors a chance to win tax-free prizes instead of receiving
interest. There is now a weekly draw for a prize of £25,000 and a monthly
draw for prizes ranging from £25 to £5,000. At the end of June 1968, £646
million was invested in this form of savings. Nearly all British Government
securities are held on the Post Office Register and can also be bought or sold
at most post offices.
The Post Office Savings Bank, which celebrated its centenary in 1961, is the
largest organisation of its kind in the world. It provides a countrywide system
for depositing and withdrawing small savings and has over 23 million active
accounts. Ordinary Accounts bear interest at 2| per cent and the first £15 of
interest is tax free. Up to £10 can be withdrawn on demand at any post office,
but a few days’ notice is required for larger amounts. The moneys are lodged

The Trustee Savings Banks, also started in the nineteenth century, operate
under their own trustees but are subject to statutory provisions and National
Debt Office surveillance. There are 78 individual banks with 1,405 Trustee
Offices and over 11 million accounts. Deposits can be made either in the
Ordinary Departments, the Special Investment Departments or the Current

are similar to those in the Post Office Savings Bank. Withdrawals can usually be
made on demand though notice is required for large sums. Deposits are
invested with the National Debt Commissioners and both capital and interest
are guaranteed by the Government. The Special Investment Departments
offer a higher rate of return (between 5 and 6 per cent, taxable). Deposits are
limited to £5,000, but are not Government guaranteed. At the end of June

were £1,069 million and in the Special Investment Departments £1,267
million. Most Trustee Savings Banks operate cheque services, which were
first authorised in 1964 on deposits in the Current Account Departments. In
January 1968 the Trustee Savings Banks set up their own unit trust (see

The Co-operative Wholesale Society formed a deposit and loan department
about the year 1870, and the right of a co-operative society to engage in
banking was recognised in the Industrial and Provident Societies Act of
1876. The primary purpose of the Co-operative Wholesale Society Bank
was to serve the co-operative movement, whose financial centre it has
become, but its clients include trade unions and other mutual societies, local
authorities and individual depositors. The bank’s headquarters are in

Manchester. The Scottish Co-operative Wholesale Society, which has its
headquarters in Glasgow, has similarly engaged in banking since 1948.
It has been the policy of the commercial banks to leave the provision of
many special financial facilities to other financial institutions. These facilities,
which are supplementary to the credit facilities of the banking system, are
mainly provided through the savings banks, finance corporations, hire-
purchase finance companies, the stock exchanges, investment trusts, building
societies and the insurance market. The firms engaged in such activities are
in the main highly specialised, for example, discount and other finance houses,
stockbrokers, insurers, insurance underwriters and brokers.
Two corporations, the Finance Corporation for Industry Limited and the
Industrial and Commercial Finance Corporation Limited, were set up in
1945 to assist in dealing with the problems of post-war reconstruction and
development. The corporations are ordinary limited companies with no
official representation on their boards and having no recourse to public funds.
Another corporation, the Commonwealth Development Finance Company
Limited, was established in 1953 to assist development projects in the
Commonwealth. Among other financial corporations are the Agricultural
Mortgage Corporation Limited and the Scottish Agricultural Securities
Corporation Limited.
The FCI was formed to assist in the provision of capital (in amounts of
^200,000 and upwards) for the re-equipment and development of industry.
The FCI has an authorised and issued capital of £25 million and may
borrow up to four times this amount, making a possible total of resources of
£125 million. The share capital is held as follows: 40 per cent by insurance
companies, 30 per cent by investment trust companies and 30 per cent by the
Bank of England. At 31st March 1968 the capital called and paid up was
2 per cent (£500,000); the Bank of England paid £5 million in advance of call
in 1959. The liability of the shareholders in respect of the uncalled capital
represents security to the banks providing loans for the corporation’s working
capital. The value of its investments at that date was £75-7 million.
The ICFC has a smaller issued capital than that of the FCI and has as its
main object the provision of credit and finance by means of loan and share
capital for small and medium-sized industrial and commercial concerns in
Great Britain, particularly in cases where the existing facilities provided by
banking institutions and the Stock Exchange are not readily or easily available.
It has a number of subsidiaries including Technical Development Capital
Ltd. and others which own ships which are chartered to responsible ship¬
owners.
The authorised and issued share capital of the ICFC at 31st March 1968
was £40 million fully paid up, provided principally by the London clearing
banks and the Scottish banks in proportion to their size, with a token
participation by the Bank of England. In addition, public debenture issues
have been made to a total of £60 million. The current resources of the ICFC
group, including reserves shown in the balance sheet, therefore total more
than £121 million.
The Commonwealth Development Finance Company was set up in 1953 as
a new channel for the investment of private capital in Commonwealth
development schemes. Its authorised share capital is £30 million, of which
about 14^ million ‘A’ ordinary shares of £1 (2s. paid) are held by industrial,

shipping, mining and banking interests in the United Kingdom, and nf
million ‘B’ ordinary shares of £1 (10s. paid) are held by the Bank of England
and certain central banks in the Commonwealth. Commitments entered into
from its inception in 1953 up to the end of March 1968 amounted to the
sterling equivalent of approximately £39 million.
There are 23 stock exchanges in the British Isles, of which 15 are in England
and Wales, five in Scotland, one in Northern Ireland and two in the Irish
Republic. In addition the Provincial Brokers’ Stock Exchange operates in
no cities and towns throughout Britain and the Irish Republic. The
Federation of Stock Exchanges in Great Britain and Ireland, comprising with
one exception all these organisations, was set up in July 1965 to co-ordinate
their work. Four Scottish stock exchanges are linked, as are also those in the
north of England and in the Midlands and west of England.
The London Stock Exchange is by far the most important of these stock
exchanges and is one of the world’s two foremost free markets in securities.
Some 9,481 securities are quoted on the London Stock Exchange; at the
end of March 1968 these had a total market value of £103,000 million. About
8,300 securities of companies are quoted, including a number of leading over¬
seas companies. Companies issues represented 40 per cent of the securities at
nominal values, and the remainder were British and overseas government and
corporation stocks; at market values the proportion was about four-fifths.
The London Stock Exchange is linked by cable or telephone with stock
exchanges all over the world. Therefore, a quoted company, subject to any
limitations imposed by the exchange control regulations, has a world-wide
market for its issues. This is an important factor in the raising of new capital
by government and commercial borrowers. Arbitrage transactions by brokers
—the buying or selling of a particular security on one stock exchange with the
intention of reversing it on another—play an important part in equating
price differentials between different markets and maintaining a continual
flow of business between centres.
The stock exchanges do not fix dealing prices; the terms on which bargains
are made between members reflect the interaction of supply and demand
for the securities concerned. All the stock exchanges operate under strict
rules of conduct which they formulate themselves.
In recent years there has been a constantly rising demand, except for short
periods, for ordinary (equity) shares, partly in expectation that such shares
will maintain their real value or grow in value in periods of rising prices.
Insurance companies and pension funds invest a larger proportion than
formerly of their assets in these shares, and the Trustee Investments Act 1961
permits trustees, under certain conditions, to invest up to half the funds they
hold in trust in equity shares.
The ownership of securities on the London Stock Exchange is much more
widespread than formerly: it is estimated that there are about 2^ million
shareholders in the United Kingdom and that their shareholdings are widely
distributed. The largest public company in Britain has nearly 600,000
shareholders and there are several others with more than 100,000.
Through investment trusts and unit trusts, investors may spread their risks
and obtain the benefit of skilled management.
The ordinary type of investment trust is constituted as a public company
registered under the Companies Acts with limited liability; its business is
to invest its capital in a range of stocks and shares. Like other companies,
1
374
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
it may issue several types of stocks or shares and may retain part of its profits
to build up reserves. Investment trusts grew to importance in the latter half
of the nineteenth century and have been prominent in directing capital
towards overseas investment.
Unit trusts are constituted by trust deed between a management company
and a trustee company which holds the securities. Normally, the managers
sell units to the public and invest the proceeds in a fairly wide range of
Stock Exchange securities. The costs of running the trust are defrayed partly
by an initial charge which forms part of the price of a unit, and partly by a
semi-annual service charge which is taken usually out of the income of the
trust. The level of both charges is controlled by the Board of Trade, whose
authorisation is required before units can be offered to the public; this is
only granted if the trust deed is satisfactory to them.
The first British unit trust was formed in 1931 and by 1939 there were
98 trusts, with assets estimated at £80 million. This medium of saving
has grown considerably since I957- ^ en^ June there were nearly
2 million unit holdings. The value of the funds invested in authorised trusts,
numbering some 180, has risen from £60 million in 1958 to £1,190 million
in June 1968; it has more than doubled since the end of 1966. There are now
a wide variety of trusts, both as to the range of investments covered and the
ways in which they cater for the differing needs of investors.
The Insurance
Market
Insurance
Companies
Although a certain amount of insurance is provided by friendly societies and
trade unions, most insurance services in Britain are in the hands of either
mutual or joint stock companies or Lloyd’s underwriters.
Table 29 shows the distribution of business in terms of net premium
income in 1966, the latest year for which figures are available.
There are about 400 insurance companies incorporated in the United Kingdom
but most of the business is in the hands of about 100 companies. Most
British insurers write several of the main classes of business although some
specialise in one class, particularly in life assurance, where about 40 companies
write only that type of business. A few specialise in re-insurance.
In addition about 150 overseas companies carry on business (and even more
companies are represented) in the United Kingdom, thus emphasising the
international nature of the London market. Some of the large British
companies, however, have their administrative headquarters in the provinces.

In 1966 the total insurance funds of the British insurance companies and
collecting societies amounted to about £ 13,000 million, the bulk of which is in
respect of life assurance business. The accumulation of life funds has
increased greatly with the growth of group pension schemes.
There is no government control over the investment policy of insurance
funds and these represent one of the most important sources of funds for
investment in commerce and industry. More than a third of the total assets
of British insurance companies is invested in equity shares and debentures,
and this proportion has been rising slowly.
Lloyd’s is an incorporated society of underwriters in London. The name
‘Lloyd’s’ is derived from Edward Lloyd’s coffee house, established in the late
seventeenth century, where merchants with maritime and other interests
gathered to transact business. By the middle of the eighteenth century,
Lloyd’s coffee house had become the principal centre of underwriting business
and of intelligence about shipping movements. Although in its earlier history
the activities of Lloyd’s were confined to the conduct of marine insurance
business, there has also been built up at Lloyd’s a very considerable world¬
wide market for the transaction of other classes of insurance business, except
life assurance, of which the amount transacted at Lloyd’s is small.
Lloyd’s is now regulated by a series of special Acts of Parliament starting
in 1871; the affairs of the Society of Lloyd’s in its corporate capacity are
administered by the Committee of Lloyd’s, which does not itself transact
insurance business.
Lloyd’s is not a company but a market for insurance, where business
is transacted by individual underwriters for their own account and risk and
in competition with each other. Insurance may only be placed through
Lloyd’s brokers, who negotiate with Lloyd’s underwriters on behalf of the
insured. Only elected underwriting members of Lloyd’s, who must transact
insurance with unlimited liability and who have met the most stringent
financial regulations laid down by the Committee of Lloyd’s, are permitted to
transact business at Lloyd’s; these financial safeguards give a security behind
the Lloyd’s policy which is second to none. Since February 1968 non-
Commonwealth underwriters have been eligible for membership of Lloyd’s,
if they satisfy these requirements.
Today there are over 5,800 underwriting members of Lloyd’s grouped into
some 300 syndicates and represented at Lloyd’s by underwriting agents who
accept risks on behalf of the members of their syndicates.
In conjunction with its marine insurance business Lloyd’s has built up a
world-wide organisation for the collection and diffusion of shipping
intelligence.
The insurance market is completed by the insurance brokers, acting on
behalf of the insured; brokers are an essential part of the Lloyd’s market and
a valuable part of the company market. Many brokers specialise in re-insurance
business, acting as intermediaries in the exchange of contracts between
companies, both British and overseas, and often acting as London repre¬
sentatives of the latter.
Over two-thirds of the fire, accident and marine insurance business is
carried on overseas, partly by re-insurance on the London market and partly
through branches and agencies established in over 100 countries. The basic
principle of this international business is that resources capable of meeting
any potential loss are instantly available for use in any part of the world.

Building
Societies
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Behind this large and international volume of business stand the very
substantial assets of the companies, in addition to substantial reserves of
uncalled capital, and the whole of the deposits, underwriting trust funds and
personal fortunes of Lloyd’s underwriters.
The principal function of building societies is to supply long-term loans on
the security of private dwelling-houses purchased for owner-occupation,
though loans are occasionally made on the security of commercial and
industrial premises and farms. The funds of building societies are derived
mainly from the general public who invest in shares or deposits. The amount
of share capital is not fixed; shares, which have a fixed value, are not dealt
with on the Stock Exchange but may be withdrawn in cash if notice is given.
The Building Societies Acts 1874 to 1962 prescribe the general way in which
societies must conduct their business. The Chief Registrar of Friendly
Societies has discretionary powers to stop a society either advertising or
accepting money from investors if he considers that the way in which the
society’s business is conducted is jeopardising investors’ money. The rapid
expansion of building society activity in the twentieth century has been
accompanied by a concentration of most of the business in the hands of a
few very large societies. At the end of 1967* 554 societies were in operation,
with total assets of £7,446 million. Six of the largest societies, however, each
with assets of over £250 million, account for 50 per cent of the total funds.
The amount advanced on mortgage in 1967 was £1,463 million.

Imports
OVERSEAS TRADE
Although relatively small in area and accounting for less than 2 per cent of
the world’s population, the United Kingdom is the world’s third largest
trading nation, conducting about 12 per cent of international trade in manu¬
factured goods in 1967.
For well over a century international trade has been of vital importance to
Britain’s economy. Britain relies upon imports for about half its total con¬
sumption of foodstuffs and nearly all the raw materials needed for its industries.
Its exports of goods and services together represent about a fifth of the gross
national product. It is a major supplier of machinery, vehicles, aircraft, metal
manufactures, electrical apparatus, chemicals and textiles. It is the world’s
largest market for foodstuffs, and among the largest for metals and ores,
textile raw materials, petroleum and many other products.
Changes in value, volume, composition and geographical distribution of
imports and exports are outlined in the following paragraphs.
The value of imports (c.i.f.) passed the £2,000 million mark in 1948 and,
with rapidly rising prices of raw materials, reached £3,892 million in 1951.
Because of the tendency in subsequent years for import prices to fall, the
1951 level was not reached again until 1957. Since i960 imports have
recorded peak levels except in 1961 and 1962. There was a particularly rapid
expansion in 1964 followed by a smaller rise in 1965 and 1966 and a slightly
larger one in 1967 when they were valued at £6,442 million. The increase in
exports (f.o.b.) during the 1960s has been at a steadier rate, increasing at an
average annual rate of 6 per cent from the 1959 total of £3,423 million to
reach £5,047 million in 1966. Exports fell slightly in 1967 to £5,026 million,
being affected by the slackening in the growth of world trade in manufactures
and by dock strikes in the autumn.
Between 1961 and 1967 the volume of exports rose by 19 per cent and
that of imports by 31 per cent. Since 1956 the terms of trade, that is, the ratio
between the general level of export prices and that of import prices, have
moved progressively in Britain’s favour except for small adverse movements
in the two years 1963-64.
The value and volume of exports and imports in selected years from 1958
to 1967 are shown in Table 30.
The expansion of domestic agricultural production reduced Britain’s depend¬
ence on imported food supplies and the proportion of imported foodstuffs to
total imports has fallen from 39 per cent in 1954 to 27 per cent in 1967 when
imports of foodstuffs (including beverages and tobacco) were £1,765 million.
There has been a similar downward trend in the proportion accounted for by
basic materials—from 30 per cent in 1954 to 16 per cent in 1967. This is
because industrial production has tended to increase faster than the consump¬
tion of imported raw materials; the result of a growing economy in materials’

consumption per unit of output, with the gradual switch from the production
of goods with a high material content (for example, textiles) to those with a
relatively low material content (for example, advanced engineering products);
and also of increasing use of substitutes and synthetic materials.
Imports of crude petroleum and lubricants are by far the biggest single
item by value among Britain’s imports: they have accounted for about n per
cent of the total value of imports during the past ten years, and amounted to
£716 million in 1967.
The most marked change in recent years has been the rise in the proportion
of imports of finished manufactures, from nearly 7 per cent of total imports in
1957 to over 19 per cent in 1967* Strong growth in these imports is a common
feature in the trade of industrial countries. Most of the rise in recent years
has been in capital goods which account for nearly three-quarters of the
value of imports of finished manufactures. Imports of semi-manufactures
have also been increasing steadily and since 1962 have accounted for a
greater proportion of the total import bill than basic materials. This trend is
due partly to the tendency for countries producing the basic materials to
embark upon subsequent stages of manufacture themselves and partly to the
growth in production and exports of semi-manufactures by developing
countries. Imports, by value, of semi-manufactured (excluding chemicals)
and manufactured goods amounted to £1,272 million and £1,244 million
respectively in 1967, accounting for 20 per cent and 19 per cent of Britain s
total imports.
More than five-sixths of Britain’s exports consist of manufactured goods.
By far the most important group are engineering products, which in 1967
accounted for 44 per cent of total exports, compared with 39 per cent in 1957.

Within this group, exports of many types of machinery, electrical equipment,
road vehicles, tractors and scientific instruments have expanded markedly
over this period. The share represented by chemicals has grown fairly steadily
reaching g-8 per cent of total exports in 1967. The proportion accounted
for by metals has tended to fall. Exports of textiles have fallen from over
18 per cent of the total in 1948 to 9 per cent in 1957 and 5 per cent in 1967.
Exports of coal are now of minor significance, and those of petroleum
products stayed at 2-3 per cent in 1967, their level for the previous three
years. The proportion accounted for by foodstuffs has also shown little
change in the past few years.

Relatively, trade with other members of the Commonwealth and with the
sterling area as a whole has tended to decline. Exports to the sterling area in
1964 and 1965 increased as fast as exports as a whole but fell back slightly in
1966 and 1967 and as a proportion of total exports dropped to 30 per cent,
compared with 43 per cent in 1957. There has been a similar relative fall in
respect of imports. Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the Republic of
Ireland, however, are among Britain’s most important trading partners. The
United States has been both Britain’s largest single market and source of
supply since 1957. The proportion of total exports going to North America in
1967 (just under 17 per cent) almost equalled the previous peak of 1959-
Exports to the United States increased by over 50 per cent between 1964 and
1966 but fell back slightly in 1967. Imports from the non-sterling Middle East
showed a sharp increase, almost entirely as a result of larger shipments of
crude oil. The decline in recent years in imports from Latin America was
reversed in 1967, largely as a result of increased oil shipments from Venezuela;
exports were also up on 1966. Britain’s trade with the Soviet Union and
Eastern Europe has been growing rapidly over the past decade though it is
still small in relation to trade with other parts of the world. Exports to Japan
rose by over 25 per cent for the second consecutive year.

IMPORTS EXPORTS
Re-exports are goods which are exported (1) in the condition in which they
were imported or (2) after having undergone minor operations—such as
simple blending, cleaning, husking, repacking—which leaves them essentially
unchanged. Traditionally, the greater part of United Kingdom re-export trade
has been in raw materials and foodstuffs, for example, wool, rubber, tea, non-
ferrous metals and fur-skins. Commodities imported from Commonwealth
countries and sent on to countries in Europe, particularly traditional re-exports
such as tea and wool, account for a considerable proportion of the total value.
In recent years a considerable re-export trade has developed in manufactured
goods, part of which is accounted for by machinery, for example, aircraft and
aero-engines, which have been repaired or overhauled in the United Kingdom.
In 1967 the value of re-exports was ^184 million. The principal items were:
fur-skins, non-ferrous metals, aero-engines, electrical and other machinery
and tea. Over half of the re-exports went to countries in Western Europe.
As previously mentioned, the United Kingdom has traditionally imported
more goods than it exports; however, the gap has normally been covered by
net earnings from ‘invisible’ transactions. These are defined as earnings from
the provision of services to overseas persons or from the ownership of overseas
assets.
Invisible transactions are divided for statistical purposes into six main
groups: government; transport (shipping and civil aviation); travel; other
services; interest, profits and dividends; and private transfers. Some of these
figures are precise (for instance, for government transactions), others are
estimates. Table 32 shows the breakdown of the figures from i960 to 1967. The
total invisible balance in 1967 was £233 million (in recent years the annual
surplus has averaged around £160 million). Excluding Government trans¬
actions, the net balance on private transactions was a surplus of ^859 million.
Private invisible receipts in 1967 rose to £3,033 million (second only to the
United States). Earnings from invisibles amounted to slightly more than half
the total from visible exports.
As shown in Table 32, in recent years there have been surpluses on
civil aviation services and a deficit on travel and tourism which was lower
in 1967 than for some years; there is also a considerable net surplus on
‘other services’ which covers a variety of items including royalties, films

the sterling area. Over half the net deficit in respect of government expenditure
relates to military expenditure overseas; other substantial items of expenditure
are grants to developing countries and subscriptions to international
organisations.
Tourist Trade Tourism yields a substantial income from overseas; in the ten years 1958-67
overseas visitors spent over ^1,800 million in Britain. For 1967 alone these
travel and tourist receipts, excluding fares, are provisionally estimated at about
£236 million. United Kingdom residents on holiday, or travelling for business
or other purposes overseas, spent about ^275 million (excluding fares) in the
same year. The total number of visitors to the United Kingdom in 1967,
excluding visitors from the Republic of Ireland, is estimated at some 4-3
million—an increase of some 8 per cent over the 1966 figure, and more than
twice the number in 1956.
Britain’s national tourist organisation is the British Travel Association,
which derives the major part of its income from a government grant-in-aid.
The Association undertakes publicity overseas aimed at attracting visitors to
Britain and works towards the improvement in Britain of hotel accommoda¬
tion, catering, transport, entertainment and other amenities for the tourist. It
maintains offices in 16 overseas countries. The Association works in close
COMMERCIAL
POLICY
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 383
collaboration with the Scottish Tourist Board and the Wales Tourist Board
(contributing to their information and publicity services), as well as the
Northern Ireland Tourist Board, which is a statutory body receiving a grant
from the Government of Northern Ireland. In Northern Ireland the Ministry
of Commerce can assist, by way of grant, schemes submitted by local
authorities for the promotion of tourist traffic.
Britain’s prosperity depends on the prosperity of those who buy her exports
and theirs will depend on how they sell their exports elsewhere. Thus Britain
is a strong advocate of the removal of artificial barriers to trade and to this end
has taken a leading part in setting up such organisations as the International
Monetary Fund (IMF), the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
(GATT), the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
(OECD) (formerly the Organisation for European Economic Co-operation)
and the European Monetary Agreement (formerly the European Payments
Union). Britain has had a large share in these organisations’ activities,
especially those to free trade from the restrictions which grew up in the
second world war and post-war periods. It has also played a full part at the
two plenary sessions of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Develop¬
ment held in 1964 and 1968 and is a member of the Trade and Development
Board which acts on behalf of the Conference between sessions.
Customs duties on imports into Britain are divided into two broad cate¬
gories: revenue duties (to which there correspond excise revenue duties on
comparable British-produced goods) and protective duties. Purchase tax is
chargeable on imported as well as home-produced goods but in the main the
charge on imports is deferred until the goods are sold by a registered to a
non-registered trader. In the financial year 1967-68 revenue duties charged
on imported goods yielded about £2,075 million, by far the greater part of
which came from tobacco and hydrocarbon oils (petroleum products). The
yield from protective duties in the financial year 1967-68 was £215 million,
or about 3 per cent of the value of all imports.
At the beginning of the twentieth century the only customs duties were
those imposed for revenue purposes on a small range of products. Certain
duties were imposed during the first world war (the McKenna Duties), in
1921 (for strategic reasons) and in 1925 (initially for revenue purposes) but it
was not until the Import Duties Act 1932 that any serious departure was made
from the principle of free trade. This measure provided a degree of protection
for British industry and, at the same time, a basis for negotiations with foreign
countries already in possession of a tariff structure. A series of bilateral trade
negotiations between 1932 and 1939 led to some modification in the level of
protection but in the next ten years, because of government purchase and
import controls introduced during and immediately after the second world
war, the tariff lost much of its importance. The substantial relaxation of
quantitative import controls from 1949 onwards re-established the tariff as the
main instrument of protection.
The Import Duties Act 1958 replaced the existing legislation relating to
the protective tariff and brought it up to date in a single measure. Following
the passing of the Act, the tariff was recast into an internationally agreed form
(the Brussels Nomenclature), which came into use from 1st January 1959.
Under the Customs Duties (Dumping and Subsidies) Act 1957, the Board of
Trade is empowered to impose duties on imported goods of any description
which have been dumped or subsidised and which are causing or threatening
material injury to a particular industry.

General Agree¬

and Trade

Under the Anti-Dumping Code, agreed as part of the Kennedy Round
negotiations (see below), the Government in 1968 strengthened its
anti-dumping legislation, enabling provisional action to be taken where a
prima facie case of dumping with consequent material injury has been made
out.
The United Kingdom’s protective tariff has been considerably modified in
recent years as a result of a series of multilateral tariff negotiations held under
the auspices of the GATT, which seeks to increase the volume of world trade
by reducing tariffs and other barriers to trade, and by eliminating discrimina¬
tion in international commerce. Tariff reductions, and bindings against
increase, negotiated between countries under the GATT are applied equally
to all other GATT countries under the ‘most favoured nation’ clause.
As a result of the latest series of GATT tariff negotiations, the ‘Kennedy
Round’ (May 1964-June 1967), average reductions of over 30 per cent are to
be made by the major trading countries in their tariffs on industrial goods.
The reduction to be made in the British tariffs on dutiable industrial goods
imported from the EEC, the United States and Japan will amount to about
37 per cent, 40 per cent and 34 per cent respectively. This is closely in line
with the reductions which these countries are making, and they will affect well
over 70 per cent of British exports of dutiable industrial goods to these coun¬
tries. Some reductions in the tariffs on agricultural goods are also being made.
The implementation of the tariff reductions will be spread over 1968-72,
the first cuts being made on 1st July 1968.
The British Government announced in March 1968 that it would be willing
to accelerate its tariff cuts, completing them in 1969, provided that similar
concessions were made by the other principal trading countries in order to
maintain the expansion of world trade.
The principle of Imperial Preference was introduced into the United Kingdom
customs duties in 19*9 an<^ the Ottawa Conference in 1932 agreements
were concluded with independent Commonwealth countries providing for
reciprocal preferential tariff treatment over a wide range of goods. The
Import Duties Act 1932 had already provided for the duty-free entry of goods
from the United Kingdom dependencies.
Under the Import Duties Act 1958 goods grown, produced or manufactured
in the Commonwealth preference area may be exempted from duty or charged
with duty at a preferential rate (and the Commonwealth preference rate of
duty for nearly all goods is nil). Certain countries outside the Commonwealth,
including the Republic of South Africa and the Republic of Ireland, are part
of the Commonwealth preference area.
In 1964 at the first United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
(UNCTAD) in Geneva, Britain declared itself prepared to extend tariff
preferences to all the developing countries if other major industrialised
countries would do the same, if the Commonwealth countries concerned
would agree and provided that preferences were not given in such a way as to
impede the continuing reduction of tariffs on a most-favoured-nation basis.
The establishment of a system of generalised preferences for manufactures
and semi-manufactures exported by developing countries was agreed in
principle at the second UNCTAD conference in New Delhi in 1968. The
detailed arrangements are to be worked out during the course of 1969.

The European Free Trade Association (EFTA) was set up under the Stock¬
holm Convention of January i960 by Austria, Denmark, Norway, Portugal,
Sweden, Switzerland and Britain, with the object of creating an industrial free
trade area between the members and of working towards a wider European
settlement. Under the Convention, protective tariffs and quotas on trade in
industrial products between members of EFTA were to be eliminated by
1st January 1970. The first tariff cuts were made in July i960, and duties were
finally removed (with certain minor exceptions) on 31st December 1966, three
years earlier than originally planned. Finland, which joined EFTA in 1961 as
an associate member, made its final tariff cuts in December 1967. EFTA is
the first completed free trade area in the world and forms a single market of
almost 100 million people. Since 1959 intra-EFTA trade has more than
doubled and has increased more than twice as fast as trade between the group
and non-member countries.
A free trade agreement between the United Kingdom and the Irish Republic
came into operation on 1st July 1966. On that date the United Kingdom
removed all protective import duties on goods of Irish Republic origin
imported from that country. After 1st July 1975, with certain exceptions,
the Irish Republic will not apply any protective duties on goods of United
Kingdom origin.
In August 1961 the British Government applied formally to join the EEC
but negotiations were suspended in January 1963. A renewed application for
membership was made in May 1967. At the meeting of the EEC Council of
Ministers in December 1967 five of the member states favoured the opening
of negotiations with Britain, but the French Government did not agree, and
the request for accession remains on the Council’s agenda.
The export trade and virtually all the import trade of the United Kingdom are
conducted by private firms.
Methods of export trading vary considerably, according to the firm, the
industry, the product and the market. A good deal of United Kingdom export
trade, especially of the smaller manufacturing firms, is conducted through
exports merchants in the United Kingdom; many firms, however, sell to
importers and consumers abroad through their own agents or resident repre¬
sentatives in the countries concerned; in other cases, sales are made through
a firm’s own branch offices, distributing organisations or subsidiary sales
companies established in overseas markets.
Similarly, in import trade, many large firms engaged in manufacture or
domestic trade buy directly from overseas suppliers, while smaller firms may
find it more convenient to buy through intermediaries such as import/export
houses, commission agents, and the representatives of overseas firms. Since
January 1957 overseas trading undertaken directly by the Government has
been confined to imports of certain jute goods; this is to protect employment
in Dundee, where the jute industry forms the mainstay of employment.
Most of the restrictions imposed on the movement of goods and services
during and immediately after the second world war have been progressively
abolished. Because of the balance of payments deficits, exchange control
requirements for investments outside the sterling area have been revised and
made more stringent.
Exchange control is confined mainly to transactions between residents of the
United Kingdom and residents of countries outside the sterling area. Since the
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
end of 1958 residents of all countries outside the sterling area have been able
to settle transactions between themselves in sterling. Sterling held by non¬
residents of the sterling area on an external account is freely convertible into
other currencies, including dollars.
The remaining important restrictions relate to the movement of capital
from the United Kingdom to non-sterling countries. Exports of goods to
destinations outside the sterling area are subject to exchange control and, in
general, have to be paid for within six months in any foreign currency (except
Rhodesian pounds) or by sterling from an external account. Control is also
exercised over imports to ensure that currency authorised for their payment
is used for that purpose.
Since April 1966 certain restrictions have been placed on the release of gold
for manufacturing purposes and on the buying, selling and holding of gold
coins.
Exchange control policy is the responsibility of the Treasury, but most of
the administration is, in practice, carried out by the Bank of England as agent
of the Treasury; and, in turn, the Bank of England has delegated to the
commercial banks a wide variety of powers to deal with applications.
Following its illegal declaration of independence in November 1965,
Rhodesia was removed from the sterling area and all transactions betw een
residents of the United Kingdom and residents of Rhodesia became subject to
exchange control.
A basic allowance of £50 per person is at present allowed for private travel to
countries outside the sterling area. The purpose of this restriction is to assist
the balance of payments. This allowance covers all foreign exchange expendi¬
ture taken in the form of cash or travellers’ cheques, and also the cost of hotel
and other travel services, except fares paid in sterling to travel agents in the
United Kingdom. The amount of sterling notes that a traveller may take out
of the country is restricted to £15 a journey.
The Import, Export and Customs Powers (Defence) Act 1939 empowers the
Board of Trade to make statutory orders prohibiting or regulating the import
or export of goods. The powers of both import and export control derive from
the same legislation, but the purpose and mechanism are quite distinct.
In accordance with its international obligations under the GATT and the
IMF, the United Kingdom Government has progressively removed quanti¬
tative restrictions from almost all imports from the countries of the free world.
The very short list of goods on which controls remain includes some items of
special difficulty and a few where restrictions are recognised internationally,
such as arms, ammunition and radioactive materials. They require a specific
import licence and quotas have been set up for most of them. Some quotas
refer specifically to individual countries and are usually shared out among
exporters by the authorities of the countries concerned. Others are accorded
on an overall or global basis; these are generally allocated by the United
Kingdom authorities to United Kingdom importers, usually on the basis of
their share of the trade in the commodity in the past. Apart from these
quantitative controls, some further restrictions or prohibitions are applied
on health grounds (for example, on animals, plants and drugs); and there is
also a temporary general import restriction on goods from Rhodesia.
Except for the control necessary to ensure that exports to destinations outside
the sterling area are paid for in the proper manner, United Kingdom exports
