are not, except in a very minor way, subject to any government control or
direction. The few controls that are in operation are imposed to supervise
exports of military and strategic importance; to conserve materials which may
be in inadequate supply; to assist exchange control operations in preventing
the export of capital in the form of valuable goods; to ensure the humane
treatment of horses, cattle, sheep and pigs; and to prevent the export of works
of art classed as national treasures. Normally, individual licences are required
for specific consignments of goods subject to export licensing control. Goods
controlled for strategic reasons, not included in the category of atomic energy
materials and appliances, arms and ammunition, may, with certain exceptions,
be exported to the Commonwealth, the Irish Republic, the Republic of South
Africa and the United States of America without licence. There is also a
temporary general export restriction on goods to Rhodesia.
The British Government1 assists exporters by its efforts to create conditions
favourable to the export trade and by providing credit insurance facilities and
information and advice about opportunities for trade in other countries.
Its general economic policy includes the use of fiscal, credit and other
measures to maintain a stable economy and to control excessive demand for
goods and services by the home market, and action through international
negotiation to reduce barriers to the free flow of trade and payments.
Facilities exist for the repayment of protective duties paid on goods which
have been imported for export trade purposes. The export rebate scheme,
introduced in October 1964 to relieve exported goods of the burden of
certain indirect taxes which enter into their production costs, was terminated
at the end of March 1968.
Exporters wanting assistance and advice can consult Board of Trade offices
throughout Britain and, through these offices, the commercial posts of Her
Majesty’s Diplomatic Service overseas. There are over 200 posts located in all
the principal cities and trade centres abroad and they supply the Board of
Trade with information of every kind affecting trade with their territories.
Overseas officers regularly report on local economic and commercial
conditions, pay special attention to local demand for particular commodities,
and generally assist the exporter to overcome any difficulties he encounters
in trade with the country in question, particularly those arising out of govern¬
mental regulations. These officers investigate potential markets for British
products, advise about methods of trading with particular areas, and seek out
and pass on opportunities for export business and enquiries for British goods.
Assistance is also given to United Kingdom exporters in appointing agents
and locating potential importers. From records kept up to date in London by
reports from its overseas commercial officers, the Export Services Branch of
the Board of Trade can provide information concerning any country on:
1. prospects for exports and requirements of particular markets;
2. governmental regulations affecting trade, including import restrictions
and tariffs and duties on particular commodities;
3. methods of trading;
4. local tastes and preferences in design; and
1 Export promotion is also assisted by the Scottish Council (Development and Industry)
and the Development Corporation for Wales. In Northern Ireland, the Ministry of
Commerce provides a liaison service with the Board of Trade Export Services Branch
and the overseas posts.

5. the commercial standing of firms with which an exporter contemplates
business relations.
The Government’s official information services overseas help to promote
trade by publicising British industrial achievements and providing informa¬
tion on new developments in British industry.
The Overseas Marketing Corporation, financed partly by private equity
capital of £100,000 and partly by short-term loan capital of £400,000 made
available by the Board of Trade, was set up in November 1967 to seek new
opportunities for British exports and to ensure an adequate marketing effort
to fulfil them. The Board of Trade also supports, by a three-year grant
commenced in July 1967, the Export Marketing Partnerships scheme
operated by the Institute of Marketing.
The Export Credits Guarantee Department is an autonomous government
department responsible to the President of the Board of Trade. ECGD carries
on a commercial business, providing insurance for exporters against the main
risks in selling overseas. These facilities have been progressively developed
since the Department was first formed in 1919. From very small beginnings
the amount of business covered by ECGD has grown to reach almost a third
of the country’s export trade. ECGD is obliged to carry on its business on a
self-supporting basis, and in no way does it provide subsidies to exporters,
nor is it a charge on the taxpayer.
The risks covered include insolvency or protracted default of the buyer,
governmental action which blocks or delays transfer of payment to the
United Kingdom exporter, imposition of new import licensing restrictions
in the buyer’s country, war between the buyer’s country and the United
Kingdom, cancellation or non-renewal of a United Kingdom export licence,
or ‘any other cause of loss occurring outside the United Kingdom and not
within the control of the exporter or the buyer, and not normally insurable
with commercial insurers’. Cover may commence from the date of contract
or (at lower premiums) from the date of shipment.
The main types of export insurance policy are:
1. Comprehensive policies normally covering goods sold on terms of up to
six months’ credit. The exporter insures the whole of his trade, or the
whole of his trade with an agreed group of markets, for the twelve
months or three years covered by his policy. For certain engineering goods
this type of cover is extended to goods sold on credit terms of up to five
years.
2. Specific policies which cover large, single capital transactions sold on
credit terms normally not exceeding five years.
In April 1961 ECGD introduced financial guarantees for United Kingdom
banks providing finance on a long-term basis for overseas purchasers of large
capital goods and works, and in January 1962 the London Clearing Banks, the
Scottish Banks and a number of insurance companies agreed to provide finance
at fixed rates of interest for such loans, and also in respect of other export
financing on longer than three years’ credit which was secured by an ECGD
guarantee to the bank concerned. In April 1965 bank guarantees covering
100 per cent of the credit, instead of the previous 90 per cent, were made
available for two or more years’ credit and at the same time the premium was
halved. A similar scheme was introduced in March 1966 to include the
financing of exports for credit between 30 days and two years. Cover is also
Trade Fairs
Export
Councils
FINANCING OF
INTERNATIONAL
trade
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 389
available for British concerns carrying out services (including construction
projects), for overseas firms or, under certain conditions, entering into an
international consortium.
The exporter or merchant is normally required to retain an interest in the
debt or risk involved and, consequently, guarantees are given up to a maximum
of between 90 and 95 per cent of loss; 100 per cent cover is now available for
transactions involving over three years’ credit which have already operated
satisfactorily for one year. Premium rates are assessed separately for each
country and vary according to the risks and the terms of payment.
Some 300 exhibitions, of which about 200 were trade fairs, were held in
Britain in 1967 compared with 154 in I954- Some of the specialised fairs, such
as the Motor Show and the Royal Agricultural Show, attract large numbers of
the public, as well as many trade buyers from home and overseas, and provide
an important means of advertising and selling British goods.
United Kingdom products are shown at most of the large international
trade fairs throughout the world and United Kingdom manufacturers have
been prominent at the many specialised fairs held in Europe and North
America. Special displays of British consumer goods have also been presented
in hotels in North America and elsewhere. Two ‘all-British’ fairs at Toronto
and Vancouver were held in 1967, organised for the Board of Trade by British
Overseas Fairs Ltd.
Participation in trade fairs, ‘British weeks’ and store promotions overseas is
a form of export promotion for which the Government provides information,
financial assistance and, in certain cases, free facilities. (‘British weeks’ differ
from trade fairs and exhibitions in that they are primarily designed to promote
sales of consumer goods in shops overseas.) The amount allocated to the
Board of Trade for these purposes has risen from ^60,000 in 1955-56 to
nearly ^4 million in 1968-69. In 1967 the Board of Trade assisted some 4,000
British firms to participate in 211 specialised and general trade fairs in 38
countries; and provided practical help to two major and seven minor British
weeks, and to some 250 overseas store promotions.
The British National Export Council (BNEC), a promotional body formed in
July 1964, is sponsored by the Government and by representatives of industry,
trade, finance and organised labour in Britain. A Commonwealth Export
Council was set up in October 1964 to assist the BNEC in achieving its aims
with respect to British exports to the other members of the Commonwealth.
Associated with both these councils are 12 Area Committees with the primary
responsibility for developing British exports to a particular market or group of
markets: Africa, Asia, Australia, the Caribbean, Israel, Latin America, the
Middle East, New Zealand, Europe, Canada, Southern Africa and the United
States.
The tasks of the BNEC are to keep all British export activity under constant
review; to stimulate exports in all markets; to advise on organisations relating
to particular markets; to provide a central point for the export effort; and
services for this purpose such as the sending overseas of export missions.
There is an annual scheme for Royal recognition of outstanding export and
technological achievement by industry, namely, the Queen’s Award to
Industry; the first awards were made in 1966.
In the nineteenth century, the rapid growth of British industry, commerce
and shipping under the stimulus of the industrial revolution made Britain
the market as well as the workshop of the world. It became the site for the
39°
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Commodity
Markets
The Foreign
Exchange
Market
The London
Gold Market
chief world markets in raw materials (see below), freight, insurance, and
precious metals. A sound commercial banking system and a flexible system
of central bank control have been built up, while specialised institutions such
as discount houses, merchant banks, accepting houses, the stock exchanges,
investment trusts and finance corporations have evolved to satisfy particular
needs for short-term or long-term finance. The facilities provided by merchant
banks and accepting houses, for example, have long been used to finance
shipments of goods not only to and from Britain, but also between other
overseas countries.
At the same time, the banks which were already engaged in financing trade
were able to assist in raising finance for longer-term ventures. British capital
invested in overseas countries has furthered their development, increased
their output and exports, and provided markets for manufactured goods. A
substantial volume of loans has been floated in the London capital market by
Commonwealth Governments (see p. 394). A number of specialised institu¬
tions have also been established in recent years to assist the provision of
financial services for overseas countries (see p. 395).
Britain is the traditional centre for marketing many of the world’s basic
commodities. Among the more important are the Baltic Exchange (the market
for shipping and air transport, grain, seeds and vegetable oils), the London
Commodity Exchange (cocoa, coffee, copra, hides and skins, rubber and
sugar), the London Wool Exchange, the London Metal Exchange, the
Liverpool Cotton Exchange and the Liverpool Corn Exchange. A fishmeal
market opened in London in April 1967 and a soya bean oil futures market
in July 1967. These markets not only cater for the import of goods for home
consumption but do much business in effecting transactions between buyers
and sellers in other countries. In addition to these formal markets, there is
scarcely any product which cannot be traded through an intermediary
in Britain. For example, London is the world’s most important philatelic
market and also the leading international centre for the sale of works of art.
The Foreign Exchange Market is subject to United Kingdom exchange
control regulations governing the purchase and sale of foreign currencies in
the sterling area, but these regulations have been progressively relaxed in
recent years. The turnover of the market has increased materially since the
introduction in December 1958 of external convertibility for the principal
European currencies.
The market consists of over 120 authorised banks and nine firms of brokers,
all linked together by telephone in the United Kingdom, and by telephone,
telex and cable with overseas centres.
The London Gold Market, which had remained closed from the outbreak of
war in 1939, was reopened in March i954> under the general supervision
of the Bank of England. It has regained its pre-war position as the leading
centre for dealings in gold, handling the major part of the gold coming on to
the free markets of the world. All authorised banks may deal in gold but, in
practice, dealings are largely concentrated in the hands of the five members
of the gold market plus one or two others. Membership of the market confers
the right to be present twice daily at the price-fixing when the official London
gold price is settled.
A gold pool was set up in i960 to co-ordinate the gold operations in London
(including supplying gold to private buyers) of certain European central banks
r
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Following heavy world-wide
speculation in gold at the end of 1967 and the beginning of 1968, the gold pool
was closed in March 1968. Officially held gold is now used only to effect
transfers among monetary authorities where these are not replacing gold sold
in private markets.
The Sterling As a result of Britain’s early lead in international trade and finance, several
System countries tended not only to use sterling as their natural currency for inter¬
national transactions, but also to maintain central currency reserves in
Britain. When Britain abandoned the gold standard in 1931 these countries,
which came to be known as the ‘sterling bloc’ and later as the ‘sterling area’,
did likewise, and pegged their currency exchange rates to the pound sterling.
In 1939, after the outbreak of war, the pound sterling was no longer freely
convertible into other currencies and the sterling area became more formally
defined as a currency area for exchange control purposes. The United
Kingdom imposes no exchange control on transactions with residents of other
sterling area countries.
All the Commonwealth countries (except Canada and Rhodesia), together
with Iceland, the Irish Republic, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, the Republic of
South Africa, South West Africa, the Republic of Southern Yemen, the
British Protected States in the Persian Gulf, and Western Samoa, are members
of the sterling area. The main feature of the sterling area is that the greater
part of the overseas trade of member countries is financed in sterling; much
of their foreign reserves are held in sterling. Member countries sell their
foreign currency earnings in London in exchange for sterling and purchase for
sterling the foreign currency they require. The United Kingdom reserves of gold
and foreign currencies are held in the Exchange Equalisation Account. These
arrangements are voluntary; there are no strict or centralised rules of conduct.
Consultations were held during 1968 between Britain and sterling area
countries to devise means of offsetting fluctuations in their sterling balances,
which have consequent unsettling effects on the British balance of payments
and the international monetary system. As a result 12 central banks outside
the sterling area agreed to make available a $2,000 million medium-term
credit facility, so as to enable Britain in return for certain assurances from
sterling area countries to offer a dollar-value guarantee on the bulk of each
country’s official sterling reserves.
THE BALANCE OF PAYMENTS
A summary of Britain’s balance of payments position between 1964 and 1967
is given in Table 33, p. 393.
The transactions fall into three main groups—current account, long-term
capital account and monetary movements. The balance on current account is
composed of the balance of visible trade (that is, the difference between mer¬
chandise imports and exports and re-exports) and the balance of invisibles.
On long-term capital account, the main groups of items are intergovernmental
loans (including amortisation) and other identified net long-term investment
abroad by United Kingdom residents, or in the United Kingdom by non¬
residents. The third heading, monetary movements, reflects in part the
United Kingdom’s position as an international banker. It includes miscel¬
laneous capital transactions, generally of a short-term character, changes in
external assets and liabilities of the banking system and changes in the United
Kingdom reserves of gold and convertible currencies.
392
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Between 1945 and 1951 the balance of payments on current account
fluctuated widely. From 1952 to 1963 there were surpluses in all years except
for 1955 and i960. In 1964 there was a substantial deficit of £399 million,
which fell to £91 million in 1965 and turned to a surplus of ^15 million in
1966. This improvement was not maintained in 1967, when a deficit returned
of ^404 million. This was partly the result of a distortion of the trade statistics
(with a bulge of imports early in the year which had been held back in antici¬
pation of the removal of the import charge in November 1966 and with delays
to exports during and after the dock strikes of September-November), and
the increases in oil freight payments to foreign tanker owners following the
closure of the Suez Canal, while devaluation, in November, added to the
import bill through increased prices in sterling terms.
The net outward flow of long-term capital, which reached a peak of £370
million in 1964, was reduced to £104 million in 1966 and to £26 million in
1967. The reduction was largely due to a sharp increase in overseas private
investment in Britain and to drawings (in 1966 and 1967) on a special
United States Export/Import Bank credit to finance purchases of American
military aircraft. Net private investment abroad in 1967 totalled £424 million
and net private investment in Britain £395 million, the latter an increase over
1964 of £253 million. Part of this increase represented a sharp rise in invest¬
ment in Britain by foreign oil companies.
The balance on current and long-term capital transactions combined was in
surplus in 1961 and 1962 but moved into a considerable deficit in 1964. By
1966 this deficit had been substantially reduced, but it increased to £490
million in 1967. This was more than accounted for by the sharp increase in the
adverse balance of visible trade; there was a marked increase in net invisible
earnings and a reduced net outflow of long-term capital.
Movements of short-term capital may mean that changes in the balance on
current and long-term capital accounts are not necessarily reflected in the
reserves of gold and convertible currencies.
The general level of the reserves has not changed greatly since the early
1950s and has usually been in the region of £1,000 million. In 1964, when
there was a very large deficit in the balance of payments, they fell to £827
million. Subsequently, they have regained their £1,000 million level. At the
end of 1967 the reserves amounted to £1,123 million, at the new parity of
£1 to $2.40 established on 18th November 1967 and including the Treasury
dollar portfolio, part of which was transferred to the reserves in February 1966
and the remainder in November 1967. The reserves were made up of £538
million in gold and £585 million in convertible currencies. Britain’s net
external liabilities in sterling (excluding liabilities to the IMF) amounted to
£3,900 million at the end of 1967. Nearly two-thirds of these were towards
countries in the overseas sterling area. On the other hand, net external claims
in non-sterling currencies amounted to £38 million.
In addition to its reserves of gold and convertible currencies, Britain has draw¬
ing rights on the IMF based on its quota, which was raised to $2,440 million
(£871 million) in March 1966. (The sterling equivalent of the British quota after
devaluation in November 1967 is £1,017 million.) Britain has had recourse to the
IMF on several occasions since 1946: $1,500 million was drawn in 1961 and
repaid by 1962 and $1,000 million was drawn in 1964 and repaid by November
1967. Drawings of $1,400 million in May 1965, $123 million in March 1966
and $1,400 million in June 1968 are still outstanding (September 1968).
Britain has also taken part since 1961 in the international network of
reciprocal credit (‘swap’) facilities arranged between central banks. These

In the estimates of Britain’s external assets and liabilities,1 it should be
emphasised that the various elements are fundamentally different in kind and
are subject to different methods of valuation, hence the totals are of limited
significance. However, they do illustrate two features of basic importance in
Britain’s external situation. It has a very large excess of long-term assets over
long-term liabilities and a considerable excess of short-term liabilities
over short-term assets. At the end of 1967 net long-term assets amounted to
about ^4,757 million while net short-term liabilities amounted to about
£2,746 million.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Britain’s official long-term liabilities have mostly arisen from the second world
war and its aftermath. At the end of 1967 about £2,887 million was still out¬
standing, of which £2,172 million was owed to other Governments, the greater
part to the United States and Canada. Devaluation had increased the amount
outstanding by about one-sixth.
The largest item among official external long-term claims is British
Government aid in the form of loans (see p. 396).
Overseas investors in Britain are allowed to repatriate the proceeds of the
sale of their investments, including any capital gains that may have accrued.
Earned profits and dividends can be transferred, irrespective of the amount;
transfers of this kind have never been restricted. In 1967 the net inward flow
of direct and other private investment amounted to nearly £400 million.
Overseas long-term liabilities arising from investment in the private sector
of the British economy has increased steadily since the war. I he market value
of overseas portfolio holdings of British company securities at the end of 1967
was of the order of £1,450 million. The book value of direct investments held
in Britain by companies incorporated abroad (except banks, oil and insurance
companies) was about £2,350 million, of which some 82 per cent was in
manufacturing and some 12 per cent in distribution.
Nearly two-thirds of this direct investment of £2,350 million (which since
1961 has grown at an average compound rate of 11 per cent a year) came from
the United States, some 12 per cent from Canada and some 8 per cent from
Switzerland (of which a substantial part originated in the United States, the
investment being made through a Swiss holding company). The approximate
book value of the net assets in Britain of United States and European oil
companies was some £1,000 million.
Private investment abroad may take several forms: portfolio investment,
that is, investment in overseas securities including the loans raised by overseas
countries on the London capital market; or direct investment by the estab¬
lishment of subsidiary companies abroad, by ploughing back profits earned
overseas, or by acquiring an interest in an overseas enterprise.
Apart from the voluntary programme introduced early in 1966 to restrain
the flow of British capital to Australia, South Africa, New Zealand and the
Irish Republic, the United Kingdom imposes no restriction on investment m
the sterling area by United Kingdom residents. Direct investment is frequently
made from a firm’s existing resources, tlowever, borrowers outside the United
Kingdom must in certain circumstances obtain the consent of the Treasury
if the amount borrowed exceeds £50,000 in any one year. Borrowing by
Commonwealth Governments in the London capital market has fallen in
recent years, but averaged about £50 million a year in the 1950s.
Direct investment outside the sterling areas is normally permitted provided
that it is financed by foreign currency borrowing or by the re-investment of an
appropriate portion of profits. Other means of finance (including the use of
official exchange in a limited category of cases) are allowed only when
investment promises a benefit to the United Kingdom balance of payments in
the short-term. A survey by the Board of Trade estimated that the flow of
private direct investment abroad by British companies (excluding oil) was
about £267 million in 1967; 53 per cent went to the sterling area, xhe
figures include long-term and short-term investment and reinvested profits.
Britain’s private long-term capital assets abroad include portfolio invest¬
ments which, at the end of 1967, had a total estimated market value of some

£4,150 million. In addition, the book value of British direct investments

of 1967. Roughly half of this was invested in manufacturing industries and
some 16 per cent in distribution. The approximate book value of oil companies’
assets at the end of 1967 was some £1,600 million. The total value of the
overseas interests of British insurance companies is not known but the value
of their direct investments in the United States alone amounted to £500
million at the end of 1967. The British insurance industry also operates
extensively in other foreign countries and throughout the Commonwealth.
Owing to the increase in recent years in British Government aid to developing
countries, intergovernmental loans form the largest item among official
external long-term claims. The total of such loans outstanding at the end of
1967 was £679 million and included £529 million in loans to governments of
overseas sterling area countries. New Government loans (less repayments)
totalled £61 million over 1966-67. Other official lending, which amounted to
£165 million at the end of 1967, includes investments of the Commonwealth
Development Corporation (see p. 396) and the United Kingdom Atomic
Energy Authority.
In addition, there are the official subscriptions to, and shareholdings in,
international financial organisations (see below). The Government also owns
real estate overseas, such as embassy buildings and military installations.
Britain’s aid programme to the developing countries includes loans and grants
for economic development, technical assistance, budget support and con¬
tributions to multilateral agencies providing financial aid and technical
assistance to these countries.
Since 1945 total aid disbursements amount to over £2,200 million and in

Since the end of the 1950s Britain’s aid programme has become world-wide in
scope, and the net flow of resources to the developing countries, including
private capital as well as official aid, has reached 1 per cent of the national
income in each of the last five years. In 1967 total aid disbursements amounted
to nearly £208 million, of which bilateral disbursements were £189 million
including £33 million technical assistance. Assistance provided through
multilateral agencies was £19 million.
Economic difficulties in 1966 and 1967 made it necessary to introduce
measures to restrain public expenditure and particularly expenditure overseas.
The target for the basic aid programme in 1968-69 is being maintained,
however, at the 1967-68 level of ^205 million; in addition; there will be an
increase in Britain’s contribution to the International Development Associa¬
tion (one of the World Bank agencies), an annual contribution of £6 million to
the Food Aid Convention as part of the Kennedy Round (see p. 384), and
economic assistance to Singapore and Malaysia in connection with the
withdrawal of British forces.
Historically, Britain’s aid programme began as part of the discharge of her
responsibilities towards the dependent territories and the main emphasis
remains on territories which are, or were until recent years, a British
responsibility. In 1967 nearly £139 million (89 per cent) of bilateral financial
aid was disbursed to Commonwealth countries both dependent and
independent.
Of the total bilateral financial aid of £156 million in 1967, 41 per cent was
in grant form and 59 per cent in loans. Budgetary aid is provided in grant
form. Development aid is in either grant or loan form depending on the
economic circumstances of the recipient countries, but is mainly in loan form.
The terms of new development loans from Britain have been progressively
softened since 1958 and a policy of interest-free loans for the poorest
developing countries was introduced in June 1965. In 1967, the total value of
loan commitments entered into, excluding investments by the Common¬
wealth Development Corporation (CDC), was £79 million and of these over
90 per cent was on interest-free terms. The recipients included Ceylon, The
Gambia, India, Indonesia, Jordan, Kenya, Malawi, Pakistan and Turkey.
Where loans are made on interest-bearing terms waivers of interest for a
period of years are granted in appropriate cases, and both kinds of loan may
carry grace periods during which repayments of capital are not made. Of all
loans committed in 1967, 95 per cent of value carried grace periods for capital
repayments averaging about six years, while the weighted average maturity of
loans was about 25 years.
Loans and grants are used mainly for the purchase of goods, equipment and
services from Britain, although there may be a substantial element for local
costs in appropriate cases. Between 1958 an<i the end of 1967 I52 l°ans were
negotiated involving a commitment of £603 million, of which ^4^° million has
been disbursed. The largest recipients have been India and Pakistan. During
the same period bilateral grants amounted to around £714 million.
Aid to dependent territories includes budgetary assistance, development
grants and loans under the Colonial Development and Welfare (CD & W)
Acts, technical assistance, and investments by the CDC. Grants account for
the predominant share of this assistance. Economic aid to the dependent
territories increased to a peak of £100 million in 1961, but has declined to
£30 million in 1967 as colonies have become independent.
Independent
Commonwealth
Countries
Technical
Assistance
Multilateral
Contributions
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 397
Although Britain’s formal responsibility to a dependent territory ceases when
it attains independence, its continuing needs have been recognised by offering
aid in appropriate forms. Almost all independent Commonwealth countries
have received help towards their development by way of loans. All except
India, Pakistan and Ceylon can receive CDC investment. In 1967 independent
Commonwealth countries received £150 million in bilateral financial aid and
technical assistance (80 per cent of the bilateral programme).
The CDC was set up in 1948 to provide finance and management for
development projects in Commonwealth countries, and acts on a commercial
basis, often in partnership with private enterprise or territorial governments.
Most of its finance has been provided by loans from the British Government
(£8 million in 1967). By the end of 1967, a total of £114 million had been
invested out of a total commitment of £142 million. Of the latter, £26 million
was in the Far East, £23 million in the Caribbean and virtually all of the
remainder was in Africa.
Expenditure on technical assistance (the provision of skilled personnel, advice
and training) has increased to form 16 per cent of the total aid programme in
1967. The largest component of expenditure (£21 million in 1967) is that of
sending or maintaining experts, including volunteers; the next largest is for
students and trainees in Britain (^’6 million).
Under the Overseas Service Aid Scheme (OSAS) and associated schemes
Britain meets the additional costs of employing experienced expatriate British
personnel in the public services. The scheme cost £15 million in 1967 and
covered over 10,000 expatriate officers in 39 Commonwealth countries,
principally in East and Central Africa. Britain receives large numbers of
students and trainees from developing countries. Over 9,400 were financed in
Britain in 1967 under regional programmes of technical assistance, by awards
under the Commonwealth Education Co-operation Scholarships and Bursary
Schemes, and under the various schemes of the British Council. At the end of
1967, of the 13,500 British persons other than volunteers who were working
in developing countries and financed by the British Government, almost
9,600 were engaged in the maintenance and improvement of education, public
administration and communications.
In addition, the British Volunteer Programme has been expanding (the
first volunteers were sent overseas in 1958-59) until in 1967 there were 1,772
volunteers in developing countries. These included graduates and school-
leavers, whose recruitment, training and placing overseas is undertaken by a
number of voluntary bodies; 75 per cent of the British costs (^i-2 million
in 1967) are met by the British Government.
Britain is the second largest contributor (after the United States) to the
World Bank group of institutions including the International Development
Association, to which Britain has undertaken to provide £65 million in the
three years 1968-70. Britain has contributed £35 million to the United
Nations Development Programme since its inception in 1950 and has provided
more experts and training places under multilateral schemes than any other
country—1,288 experts and 157 training places in 1967. Other contributions
are to the regional development banks, the World Food Programme, the
United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA),
and the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF).

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
WHOLESALE
TRADES
INTERNAL TRADE
Britain’s internal trade can be divided into two broad categories: trade in raw
materials, capital goods and intermediate products (for example, vehicle
components) and trade in consumer goods, involving the network of distribu¬
tive trades by which home produced or imported goods reach the consumer.
(For the pattern of consumers’ expenditure see p. 228.)
There have been a number of official statistical enquiries into the distributive
trades. The latest censuses taken in Great Britain refer to the wholesale trades
in 1965 and the retail trades and certain service trades in 1966. Sample
monthly and annual enquiries are also undertaken, covering such aspects of
the distributive trades as turnover, stocks and capital expenditure. Most of the
figures given in the following pages derive from either the last published
censuses or the sample enquiries.
The first census of retail distribution and other services to be taken in
Northern Ireland relates to 1965.
Only a proportion of the trade in consumer goods passes through wholesalers:
sales are also made to consumers through producers’ own selling organisations
(including their own retail outlets and mail order businesses); and other sales
are made directly by producers to retailers. Wholesale channels are particularly
in evidence in the distribution of textiles, agricultural produce and foodstuffs.
The 1965 enquiry showed that out of a total of 23,643 business units engaged
in wholesale distribution in Great Britain, 3,435 dealt in clothing, footwear
and textiles, 2,007 in grocery and provisions, 2,630 in vegetables and fruit,
and 3,469 in other food and in drink. In addition, there were 8,282 dealers
(wholesale or retail) in coal, builders’ materials, grain or agricultural supplies,
and 9,117 dealers in other industrial materials and machinery. The value of
stocks held by wholesalers and dealers at the end of 1967 is estimated at
£1,087 million; expenditure on capital assets during the year was about
£146 million.
Methods of wholesale distribution vary according to the type of merchandise
handled. Fish, for example, is auctioned at the ports to port wholesalers (who
sell to inland wholesalers at the main distribution centres) or, increasingly, is
sold by contract to fryers and processors, or direct to retailers. Fruit and
vegetables may be sold by growers to commission agents (who dispose of the
produce either to wholesalers or direct to retailers) or the grower may deal
only with wholesale firms. The sale of some agricultural products is regulated
by statutory marketing boards (see p. 307).
London’s wholesale markets play a leading part in the distribution of
foodstuffs, particularly imported supplies. Every year Covent Garden handles
about 1-2 million tons of fruit and vegetables, and over 405,000 tons of meat
and poultry pass through Smithfield market; Billingsgate is the principal
distributing centre in Britain for fish. Others in London include Leadenhall
Market (poultry) and Spitalfields Market (fruit and vegetables).
The co-operative movement in Britain has established its own wholesale
societies, the two largest being the Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd.
(CWS) and the Scottish Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd. (SCWS), to
serve the needs of retail societies, membership being restricted to incorporated
co-operative organisations. The CWS had sales of over £470 million in 1967
and the SCWS had sales of some £90 million.
Two kinds of voluntary wholesale chains have developed in recent years
particularly in the food trades. Firstly, local retailers’ buying groups were
formed and later (since 1954) wholesaler-sponsored voluntary chains (groups
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
399
of independent traders linked to a wholesaler or a group of wholesalers). Both
kinds offer the lower operating costs of large-scale trading without loss of
independence but the position of the wholesaler is stronger in the latter. The
1961 Census of Distribution showed that about 27 per cent (or 40 per cent in
terms of turnover) of smaller grocers—mostly medium-sized independents
and small multiples with not more than nine branches—-then belonged to
these chains.

Main Groups of
Retail Business
Retail businesses in Britain may be classified under three main headings:
(1) multiple traders, that is, organisations other than co-operative societies
with ten or more branches; (2) retail co-operative societies (see p. 400); and
(3) independent retail businesses, including for this purpose the small
multiple stores (that is, chains of stores with nine or fewer branches). Busi¬
nesses in each of these categories may own department stores. Other retail
outlets include gas and electricity showrooms owned by the area gas and
electricity boards, and mail order houses (see p. 402).
First results of the 1966 Census of Distribution (Table 35) show that, in
comparison with 1961, a larger volume of trade had been handled by rather
fewer shops. A notable feature is the continuing expansion of large multiple
firms relative to other types of shop. Independent shops, however, still
account for over half of Britain’s retail trade.
A very wide range is covered in the size of retailing establishments. Ten
shops (nine of them department stores) had sales in 1961 exceeding £5 million
or takings of more than £2,000 an hour; at the other extreme there were more
than 70,000 establishments taking less than £2,000 a year. Some of these were
market and street traders, whose volume of business may be very small.
According to the Census of Distribution there were nearly 74,000 shops
owned by multiples (including multiple department stores) in 1966 with
a total turnover of £3,858 million. This form of organisation showed the
largest rise in numbers between 1961 and 1966 and their share in total sales
went up from 29 per cent to 35 per cent. In the food trades their turnover
increased by 59-6 per cent, compared with 6-5 per cent for independent
retailers and only 2-8 per cent for co-operative societies.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The share in total retail trade of co-operative stores dropped from 11 to 9 per
cent between 1961 and 1966 which was rather less than the relative decrease
in the number of stores.
The retail co-operative societies are voluntary non-profit-making organisa¬
tions engaged in retail trade and controlled by their members, who are also
their customers. Any operating surplus is returned periodically to members as
a dividend; the amount distributed is proportionate to the value of the
members’ purchases. They also sell to the general public, but membership is
open to anyone paying a small deposit on a minimum share, which entitles the
member to an equal voice with other members in determining the policy of
the society. Investment by individual members is limited to £1,000 (less in
some societies). Only a low rate of interest is paid on the shares.
At the end of 1966 there were 762 retail co-operative societies registered
under the Industrial and Provident Societies Act. Amalgamations are slowly
diminishing the number of societies (the total in 1958 was I>015)-
largest single society in Britain is the London Co-operative Society with just
over i-i million members and a turnover of nearly £70 million a year. Total
sales of the retail co-operative societies in 1967 reached about £1,100 million
(this figure includes certain activities not covered by the Census of Distribution
figure in Table 35). The approximate average rate of dividend paid to
members in 1967 was 7d. in the £.
Independent shops have been giving ground only slowly in the face of
increased competition from the larger undertakings. The proprietors of
many of the smaller shops often have other means of livelihood. Average
turnover per shop has continued to increase, though by less than for the retail
trade as a whole. None the less, even allowing for a 15 per cent increase in
prices, the average independent shop sold more goods in 1966 than in 1961.
There were 778 department stores in Britain in 1966 having a turnover of
over £660 million—about 6 per cent of the total turnover of all retail
establishments. Department stores were defined for the purposes of the
census as having 25 or more persons engaged in selling a wide range of
commodities notably clothing and household goods. Co-operative societies
owned 238 department stores in 1966, and 213 were owned by multiples.
Out of a total of nearly 500,000 establishments recorded by the 1966 Census
of Distribution, and shown in Table 36, grocery and other food retailing
groups numbered over 225,000 establishments, and the clothing and foot¬
wear group over 81,000.
Though the total value of retail trade in Great Britain (inclusive of
electricity and gas showrooms and mail order business) rose by a quarter
between 1961 and 1966, rates of growth (measured in turnover) varied
appreciably between different types of trade. The slowest growth was in
general stores, in the food sector, and department stores. The fastest growth
was in radio and television hire, mail order business, gas and electricity
showroom sales of durable goods, sports and leisure equipment, and chemists
and photographic goods. However, the actual trends are blurred by the
introduction into specialised shops of other specialities, for example, clothing
multiples opening food sections, and vice versa. Though gas and electricity
showroom business was buoyant between 1961 and 1966, their combined
turnover is relatively small, amounting in 1966 to just over £185 million.
Provisional results of the Northern Ireland 19^5 Census of Retail
Distribution (and other services) show total spending of £385 million through

The real expansion in the volume of sales in Great Britain between 1961 and
1966, taking into account the exclusion of market traders (included in the 1961
Census) and a general increase in prices of 15 per cent, was about 7 per cent,
or an average of 1-4 per cent a year.
The development of self-service in retail establishments since 1950 has
probably contributed to the notable expansion in sales achieved by the
multiple stores. According to the 1961 Census of Distribution, self-service
sales exceeded ^525 million, two and a half times the level of 1957, and the
average turnover in fully self-service grocery shops was over £55,000 compared
with £13,000 in other grocery shops. About 9,500 stores, of which 9,100 were
grocers, were operated wholly or partly on self-service lines towards the end
of 1961, compared with 4,000 in 1957, less than 500 in 1950 and 10 in 1947;
by the end of 1966 it is estimated that there were probably over 17,000.
Supermarkets may be defined as self-service shops with a minimum selling
area of 2,000 square feet. There were about 870 supermarkets in 1961, accord¬
ing to the Census of Distribution, of which 524 were owned by multiples,
308 by co-operative societies and 38 by independents. It has been estimated
that by the end of 1966 over 3,000 had been opened.

Service Trades
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
New forms of automatic vending machines have come to the fore since 1955.
Possibly some 300,000 machines are in use. An increasing number of coin-
operated machines are being installed in factories (over 7>00° factories are
estimated to provide facilities) and commercial premises as well as in normal
retail outlets. Machines now sell not only cigarettes, sweets and stamps but
also hot and cold beverages, prepared foodstuffs, stockings, paper-back books
and other commodities including various forms of fuel. Organisations
specialising in automatic vending machines (not otherwise engaged in retail
trade) numbered 56 in 1966, with sales of over £11 million.
Some 11,700 mobile shops1 were reported in the Census of Distribution for
1961, with sales amounting to ^93 million. Nearly a quarter of this turnover
was concentrated in Scotland (where the density of population is lower than
in England) compared with a tenth of all retail sales. Co-operative societies
accounted for 39 per cent of sales through mobile food shops, against 16 per
cent in ordinary food shops. For the most part, mobile shops were concerned
with food sales; about 42 per cent were travelling grocers, and over 28 per cent
and 21 per cent respectively were greengrocers and butchers. Only a very
small proportion (about 6 per cent) were non-food shops, and these specialised
mainly in paraffin supplies and hardware.
Stamp trading—the practice of giving stamps in proportion to the value of
goods sold (notably by food shops and petrol stations) which may be exchanged
later for a ‘free gift’—has expanded rapidly in recent years. There are,
however, signs that the rate of growth is levelling off. According to an
unofficial estimate made in 1966 they are saved, on average, by about 32 per
cent of housewives and 38 per cent of motorists. The two largest stamp
companies in Britain claim about 90 per cent of the business, the rest being
shared among a number of small companies. Issuers of stamps are required by
law to mark them with their cash value and redeem them in cash if so
requested. The annual rate of turnover of the two largest companies is about
£19 million.
A facility which is spreading in Britain is the ‘credit card . Users are issued
with a card on production of which their signature is accepted on bills in
participating shops, hotels and restaurants. The issuers then meet the bills and
recover from the card-holder through a single account presented periodically.
Users of certain cards are also required to pay a regular subscription.
Mail order trading has been one of the most rapidly growing forms of selling
in Britain in recent years. The 1966 Census of Distribution showed that the
sales of specialist retail mail order businesses had almost doubled in five years
from ^227 million to £431 million; an increase of just under ten times since
1950, when they amounted to £46 million.
Sales by manufacturers direct to the public totalled j£i44 mihi°n in I9^I»
compared with £70 million in 1950. Mail order sales accounted for 24 per
cent of the former total, sales to employees for 11 per cent, and charges for
work done for 9 per cent. Other direct sales, including sales by door-to-door
salesmen, accounted for the balance. Included in these sales were items as
various as carpets, washing machines, brushes, books and soft drinks.
Closely connected with the distributive trades are those which offer a service
directly to the public, notably catering and hotel trades, laundries and dry

cleaners, garage and motor repair trades, hairdressers and boot and shoe

In 1964 there were 151,000 establishments primarily concerned with catering
(defined to cover public houses, canteens, and fish and chip shops, as well as
licensed hotels and restaurants, etc.) with a total turnover in that year of £2,036
million. Hotels and holiday camps (excluding boarding houses and unlicensed
hotels) had receipts of about £286 million, of which £124 million was from
residential accommodation. Nearly half the total turnover of the catering
trades was from the sale of alcoholic drinks. Between 1964 and 1967 the
catering trades’ turnover increased by 13 per cent.
There were about 6,000 commercial laundry, launderette and dry cleaning
businesses with an annual turnover of about £182 million in 1966. Between
1961 and 1966 turnover increased by 61-7 per cent.
There were nearly 47,000 businesses in the motor trades in Britain in 1962,
with nearly 58,000 establishments. Total turnover amounted to £2,979 million,
including transactions between traders amounting to £800 million or less.
Traders classified as new vehicle dealers had nearly 14,700 establishments and
accounted for two-thirds of total turnover. Over 14,000 establishments were
classified as being primarily petrol stations, and 12,600 were also general
repairers. Between 1962 and 1967 the motor trades turnover has increased by
43 per cent.
Takings in hairdressing establishments increased very rapidly between 1950
(£38 million) and 1961 (£97 million). They rose again to £136 million
between 1961 and 1966. There are about 48,000 hairdressing establishments.
There are some 8,700 establishments specialising in boot and shoe repairs
(excluding repairs handled through footwear shops); they had takings of £26
million in 1966.
Other establishments found in shopping areas and offering a service to the
public include those of radio and television rental companies (over 2,500
shops), licensed betting offices (over 15,000 in 1964) and over 3,500 funeral
undertaking businesses.
British industry’s annual expenditure on packaging has been estimated at
nearly £770 million. The expansion of self-service shops, the spread of branded
and standardised products, and developments in partly prepared foods, for
example, ready-washed vegetables and ready-made cake mixes, have been
major factors in the great changes which have taken place in packaging
methods. Paper packaging, including cartons and boxes, remains the most
extensively used (turnover of some £340 million a year), the fastest growing
sector being paper sacks. New uses are being found for tinplate (output,
£120 million a year), especially in sales of soft drinks and beer. Glass and
plastic packaging each account for about £60 million a year. The use of
plastics continues to develop; output of polypropylene film reached some
4,000 tons in 1966.
The rapid growth of sales of household and durable consumer goods, such
as cars, furniture, washing machines, television sets, refrigerators and cookers,
has been greatly helped by instalment purchase. Instalment credit debt
outstanding to the main providers amounted to £1,041 million at the end of
Hire-purchase
Sales

Advertising
Consumer
Protection
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
March 19681; nearly three-quarters was owed to finance companies and the
remainder to durable goods shops and department stores. A few finance
companies which operate on a national scale account for a high proportion of
the total business.
The Board of Trade has powers to regulate the terms of hire-purchase and
credit sales agreements in order to restrain the expansion of consumer credit.
The current terms are: a minimum deposit of 25 per cent on most durable
consumer goods except cookers and water-heaters (10 per cent), mattresses
and furniture (15 per cent), and photographic and optical equipment and cars
(33I per cent). There is usually a maximum repayment period of 30 months
for most goods except photographic and optical equipment (2 years), cars
(2% years), motor cycles (3 years), and cookers and water-heaters (4 years).
Hire-purchase in Northern Ireland directly financed by the major finance
houses operating from offices in Northern Ireland amounted in 1967 to nearly
£18 million and at the end of 1967 the hire-purchase debt owed to them
amounted to ^17 million.
About £447 million is estimated to have been spent on all forms of advertising
in 1967. About £282 million was expended on press advertising and £124
million (including tax) was spent on television advertising. The remainder
was divided between outdoor signs, posters, films, and radio. Most of the
advertising is carried out by advertising agencies, which, in some cases, also
provide marketing, consumer research and other services; their representative
organisation is the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising. The trade associa¬
tion for the industry as a whole, including agencies, advertisers and owners of
advertising media, is the Advertising Association. It was responsible for the
setting up of the Advertising Standards Authority, an independent body
whose objective is the promotion and enforcement of the highest standards of
advertising, in particular through the British Code of Advertising Practice.
Various legislative measures exist in the United Kingdom to protect the
consumer against specific abuses. Non-statutory organisations also exist to
further the consumer’s interests. Weights and measures legislation, one of the
earliest forms of consumer protection, was brought up to date and extended
in scope by the Weights and Measures Act 1963; it is strictly enforced by
qualified inspectors of local weights and measures authorities. The Trade
Descriptions Act 1968 deals with misdescriptions of goods and services and
provides the power to require informative labelling of any class of goods. The
purity, hygiene and description of food are controlled by the Food and Drugs
Acts 1955 and 1956. The Consumer Protection Act 1961 gives the Home
Office power to make regulations to ensure the safety of any class of goods.
The Hire-Purchase Act 1965 and the Hire-Purchase (Scotland) Act 1965
provide safeguards to the consumer who buys goods on hire-purchase or
credit sale terms. The protection extends to agreements up to £2,000 although
most of the safeguards do not apply to credit sale agreements for less than £30.
Similar legislation operates in Northern Ireland. As a precaution against
fraud, virtually every hire-purchase agreement on a car is registered with
H.P. Information Ltd., a non-profit-making company whose members are car
dealers or finance companies concerned with car sales; dealers and finance
houses can check with it in confidence.

The Consumer

Resale Price
Maintenance
The British Standards Institution (see p. 247) has established a number of
standards for consumer goods, and the Council of Industrial Design (see
p. 216) helps to foster improvements in the design of consumer goods.
The Consumer Council, financed by grant-in-aid from the Board of Trade,
was set up in 1963 to concern itself with and promote the consumer’s interests.
Within the limits of its finance and terms of reference it is fully independent
and so free to criticise government departments and to exert pressure
on other bodies. (It is debarred from engaging in comparative testing of
products, law enforcement action or taking up complaints on behalf of
individual consumers.) It works closely with the Citizens’ Advice Bureaux
(see p. 122).
Advice to its members on the merits of consumer goods is provided by the
Consumers’ Association (CA), a private body financed by the subscriptions of
members. It arranges tests and makes reports on the quality of goods bought
on the open market and its findings are published in its monthly bulletin
Which?, issued to subscribers. The Research Institute for Consumer Affairs,
established with a grant from the CA, undertakes research into consumer
goods and services, and publishes reports. There are also a number of local
independent consumer groups, which in 1963 formed themselves into a
national Federation of Consumer Groups. Assistance with certain aspects of
consumer guidance is also given by a number of other private bodies and by
certain government departments and local authorities. Individual trades and
industries have also taken measures to raise standards of quality.
The practice of resale price maintenance and its enforcement by cutting off
supplies was made unlawful under the Resale Prices Act 1964; certain
exemptions may be granted by the Restrictive Practices Court (see p. 237).
16 LABOUR
Less than 200 years ago, government concern with all aspects of employment
was at a minimum. State intervention came first in the sphere of safety, health
and welfare. The first factory legislation was enacted in 1802. The first
effective Factory Act was that of 1833 which set up a national system of
inspection to enforce its provisions. Trade unions—forbidden in the eighteenth
and early nineteenth centuries as a threat to civil peace and individual liberty
ceased in 1824 to be ‘actionable conspiracies in restraint of trade’. During the
nineteenth century new unions of skilled and semi-skilled workers grew up,
more soundly organised than their forerunners and more acceptable to the
public because their ambitions were more restricted. A number of employers’
associations, mainly local, were formed; unions and employers learned to
bargain together; and procedures for conciliation and arbitration began to be
agreed. Legislation passed in the 1870s clarified and regularised the legal
status of trade unions. In 1910, the first employment exchanges were intro¬
duced to provide a national service for putting employers in touch with
workers and vice versa. In 1917 the exchanges were transferred to the newly
created Ministry of Labour. The factory inspectorate was added to its
responsibilities in 1940- This department became the principal instrument of
the government’s labour policies in Great Britain; it was re-named the
Department of Employment and Productivity (DEP) in 1968 and took over
responsibility for prices and incomes policy and productivity. In Northern
Ireland employment matters are among the responsibilities of the Ministry of
Health and Social Services.
MANPOWER
The total working population of Great Britain at the middle of June 1967 was
about 25-3 million, some 47 per cent of the total population, and included
about 73 per cent of persons of normal working age (15 to 59 years for
women, 15 to 64 years for men). About 92 per cent of the men of working
age are today in or seeking gainful work. The remaining 8 per cent consist
mainly of those continuing their education, of the severely disabled and of
some persons of private means. The proportion of women of working age in or
seeking gainful work is much lower, about 53 per cent, as many housewives
either do not wish or cannot manage to take employment outside the home.
Just over half of the women at work are married. Besides those of normal
working age, there are over a million older men and women still at work. The
great majority of the working population work for a wage or salary, but about
i-6 million are employers or self-employed.
Northern Ireland, which has 2-7 per cent of the total population of the
United Kingdom, has 2-3 per cent of its working population. The ratio of
working to total population in Northern Ireland is about 40 cent, and
farmers and smallholders working their own holdings account for about
one-twelfth of the working population.
LABOUR
Growth in
Working
Population
TABLE 37
Manpower
Position in

1958-676
Deployment of
Labour
4°7
The rate of increase in the working population has slowed down (see Table 37)
since 1962 for demographic reasons. These include a tendency for young
people to stay longer in full-time education, a higher proportion of women
marrying and interrupting their working life (many re-enter the working
population later on when their family responsibilities permit), and a reduction
in immigration resulting in a change from a net inflow to a net outflow.
Because of the effect of the lower birth rates in the early 1950s and of the
change in migration patterns, no net growth in the working population
between 1967 and 1973 is expected, and because of the raising of the minimum
school-leaving age in 1973 it is expected to be lower between 1974 and 1976
than it was in 1967. After 1976 the working population is expected to increase
again, so as to show a total increase of some 3 per cent in the period 1967 to
1981, compared with an increase of some 5 per cent between 1956 and 1967.
Though successful development policies in the less-prosperous regions may
raise the numbers above the levels forecast, it is clear that increasing demand
for labour must be met by better deployment of manpower and improved
productivity. Married women form the only substantial reserve and the
Government is studying the nature of the obstacles to employing those who
are willing to work and how they may be overcome.

The present industrial distribution of employees in civil employment is shown
in Table 38. Of all employees rather less than 41 per cent are employed in the
mining and manufacturing industries and only about 2 per cent in agriculture
and fisheries, even during the harvest season. Over 57 per cent of those in
manufacturing are in the metal, engineering, vehicles and chemicals groups of
industries.
Most industries employ women as well as men though not always for the
same types of work, for example, few women are managers and few personal
secretaries are men. It is illegal to employ women in certain jobs, such as
underground work in coal mines. The industrial groups in which women are
chiefly employed are: the metal-using industries; the manufacture of textiles

industries in Great Britain (in firms with 11 or more employees) nearly 26 per

according to industry from over 38 per cent in chemicals and allied industries
to 14 per cent in clothing and footwear).

Manpower The DEP has a manpower research unit, set up in 1963 to examine manpower
Research Unit requirements over the whole economy and in particular industries and
occupations during a period five to ten years ahead. Its forecasts are designed
to help the industrial training boards (see p. 413) and all concerned with
training to meet future requirements in industry, youth employment officers
(see p. 410) and others giving vocational guidance to new entrants to the
labour force, and in economic planning generally.

The general unemployment rate in Britain as a whole in the last 20 years has
been among the lowest in the world—usually between 1 and 2 per cent—but
has been somewhat higher since 1966. It has been particularly low in the south¬
east and Midlands of England, and consistently higher in those parts of the
country which have the greatest dependence on shipbuilding, coalmining, and
certain branches of the heavy engineering and metal manufacturing industries,
notably parts of Scotland and Wales, and north-east England and Merseyside.
These areas have been the subject of a series of measures of selective
assistance to stimulate industrial expansion; and, more recently, counter¬
measures have been taken to limit expansion in areas of manpower shortage
(see p. 249). The general unemployment rate in Great Britain at July 1968
was 2-2 per cent; the areas with the highest rate were northern England (4-4
per cent), Wales (3-6 per cent) and Scotland (3-7 per cent).
The total working population of Northern Ireland—including employers and
self-employed but excluding certain unpaid helpers—was about 594,000 in
June 1967 (396,000 males and 198,000 females). The number of insured
employees was about 514,000. The largest productive industries are agricul¬
ture, engineering, textiles and clothing. Most of the agricultural work in
Northern Ireland is done without hired help.
The unemployment rate in Northern Ireland has remained higher than in
other parts of the United Kingdom. In July 1968 it was 7-1 per cent of the
insured employees. The Ministry of Commerce of the Northern Ireland
Government has wide powers (similar to those in Great Britain) to assist the
development and diversification of industry. It is using these powers
vigorously in an attempt to improve the situation.
GOVERNMENT EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING SERVICES
The main government employment services are provided in Great Britain
through the country-wide network of over 900 offices of the Department of
Employment and Productivity, which act as employment exchanges. The
services in Northern Ireland are run on similar lines by the Ministry of Health
and Social Services but there are some variations related to the much smaller
area of administration and the higher rate of unemployment.
The primary function of the employment exchanges is to introduce, free of
charge and without obligation, suitable persons seeking employment to
employers requiring employees, thus providing an efficient service to employers
and job-seekers and meeting the needs of the national economy. Employers
and employees alike remain free to use general or specialised fee-charging
private employment agencies and direct recruitment by advertisement or
personal introduction. The employment exchanges accept on their registers
both those seeking employment (full or part time) and those in work who
desire a change, and every exchange receives particulars of posts vacant and
applicants available in other areas. Local employment committees, on which
employers, workers and other local interests are represented, are attached to
certain employment exchanges as advisory bodies to secure the full benefit of
local knowledge and the close co-operation of employers and workers.
The employment exchanges offer a selective service to certain groups of
employers and employees through specialised registers. All exchanges hold
a Commercial Register of situations vacant and wanted in the distributive
410
Youth
Employment
Service
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
trades, clerical and typing posts and catering and other services. Forty of
the larger exchanges hold a Professional and Executive Register concerned
with senior posts in the professions, management, science, business and
technical employment at home and overseas. There are nearly 30 offices, in
places where there are large groups of hospitals, which have officers specially
trained to deal with the employment problems of nurses, midwives and those
in related occupations. Elsewhere nurses and their employers are dealt with
at the local employment exchange. In view of the increasing number of older
persons in the population, employment exchanges have instructions to make
special efforts to find them employment and to encourage employers to
consider older workers on their merits.
Vocational guidance services for young people and for the disabled are
described below as is the selection of candidates for the government vocational
training scheme (see p. 4*3)‘ Occupational Guidance Service tor adults
staffed by specially trained officers is operated at a number of the larger
employment exchanges. Guidance is given to adults of any age who may be
in doubt about the kind of work for which they are best suited.
Employment exchanges holding the Professional and Executive Register
are also ready to give information about the professions and allied occupations
to young men and women considering a career and to older people seeking a
new one, for example, ex-Regular officers of the armed forces.
The Youth Employment Service in Great Britain is the responsibility of the
Department of Employment and Productivity and is under the general
direction of the Central Youth Employment Executive (CYEE) composed of
senior officers of the DEP and the education departments. It is operated in
most areas through Youth Employment Offices established by local education
authorities in accordance with schemes approved by the Secretary of State and
75 per cent of the relevant expenditure of local education authorities is
reimbursed by the DEP.
The service has four main activities: (a) the CYEE produces and circulates
careers literature to schools and youth employment offices. Youth employment
officers (YEOs) work with teachers in schools to give pupils background
knowledge about careers; (6) YEOs give vocational guidance in individual
interviews; (c) school leavers are helped to find employment. Youth employ¬
ment offices also provide an employment service for any young person seeking
work, or employer seeking young workers; (d) YEOs followT up the progress of
the young people and give any necessary further advice. In many areas there
are specialist YEOs to advise the more able young people and the handicapped.
In Northern Ireland the functions of the Youth Employment Service are
similar to those in Great Britain but its organisation is different in that
parliamentary responsibility rests with the Minister of Education and the
service is operated by a statutory board composed of representatives of local
education authorities and other educational and industrial interests. Of the
board’s expenditure, 80 per cent is met by the Ministry of Education and
20 per cent by local education authorities.
Disablement The Disablement Resettlement Service is designed to help disabled persons
Resettlement to get and keep suitable work. It is available to anyone over school-leaving age
Service who is substantially handicapped as a result of injury, disease or congenital
deformity in obtaining or keeping employment. The DEP is responsible for
the administration of the Service and is assisted by the National Advisory
Council on the Employment of the Disabled.

411
The help given falls under five main headings:
Vocational guidance is given at local offices by specialised disablement
resettlement officers (DROs) in consultation, as necessary, with the local
disablement advisory committees, hospital resettlement clinics and medical
interviewing committees, and also in the industrial rehabilitation units.
Having regard to a disabled person’s qualifications and aptitude and to medical
guidance, the DRO endeavours to find the work most suited to each, with
or without an intervening period of industrial rehabilitation or vocational
training. A Register of Disabled Persons is maintained, and in mid-April
1968 the number registered was nearly 655,000; registration is voluntary. All
employers of 20 or more persons are required to employ a quota (at present
3 per cent for all industries, except shipping, in respect of the manning of
ships) of registered disabled persons. The number of registered disabled
persons unemployed in mid-April 1968 was a little over 65,000.
There are 30 specialised Blind Persons Resettlement Officers (BPROs)
attached to offices of the DEP.
Industrial rehabilitation is provided at 22 units run by the DEP. Their aim
is to provide the final link between sickness and employment by enabling
men and women to adjust themselves gradually to normal working conditions
and to receive vocational guidance based on skilled assessment of their
aptitudes in a practical workshop situation. Attendance at a unit is voluntary
and maintenance allowances are paid. They also provide special short
assessment courses for young people finding it difficult to enter suitable
employment and at some there are work preparation classes for severely
disabled school leavers (run in co-operation with local education authorities).
The staff includes a doctor, occupational psychologist, social worker, DRO,
industrially experienced workshop supervisors, and usually a remedial
gymnast, all under the general leadership of a rehabilitation officer.
The Department of Employment and Productivity gives financial assistance
to two centres conducted by voluntary organisations which provide similar
facilities for the blind, to four schemes by other bodies for the rehabilitation
of patients with mental handicaps, and to two centres for spastics.
There are vocational training facilities for the disabled at Government
Training Centres (see p. 413), educational institutions and employers’ estab¬
lishments. For the more seriously disabled there are special residential
training colleges run by voluntary organisations with the financial assistance
and technical help of the DEP. There are also arrangements for the training
of special categories such as the blind, and for providing grants to disabled
persons qualified to undertake study or training for professional or comparable
employment.
Remploy Ltd., a non-profit-making company, provides sheltered employment
for registered severely disabled people who are unlikely to obtain work except
under special conditions. At the end of 1967 it employed over 7,000 severely
disabled men and women in 85 factories. Some 130 home workers were
supplied with work from 8 centres. The directors are appointed by the
Secretary of State; loans and grants for capital development and to meet
operational costs are provided from public funds.
The DEP also gives financial assistance to local authorities and voluntary
organisations towards the cost of providing facilities for sheltered employment
for 2,300 severely disabled sighted workers and for 3»25° blind workers.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
As part of the policy of encouraging geographical mobility of labour within
Britain to balance resources and demands, the Department of Employment
and Productivity makes grants and allowances to help with costs of fares,
temporary lodging and acquisition of and removal to the new home, in
specified instances. They are available to unemployed workers moving to new
employment, and therefore settling, in another area, to key workers transferred
by a firm into a development area to inaugurate a new plant, and unemployed
workers recruited to new plants in development areas and sent to the parent
works for preliminary training.
Commonwealth citizens from overseas are subject to control under the
Commonwealth Immigrants Acts 1962-68, which apply, broadly, to all
Commonwealth citizens1 (except for those who were born in Britain or have
close family links, see p. 12). If they wish to enter Britain to take or seek
full-time employment, they must first obtain a voucher issued by the DEP.
They can apply themselves if they have certain special skills and qualifications
(mainly of professional or graduate standard), or an employer can apply on
behalf of a particular individual. The issue of vouchers to citizens of
independent countries is mainly restricted to those with offers of employment
in manufacturing industries (these restrictions do not apply to citizens of
Malta or of dependent territories). Commonwealth citizens who wish to
work in Northern Ireland, and who are not ‘Northern Ireland workers’,2
need special Northern Ireland employment permits, which are issued only
in respect of definite jobs.
Foreigners are admitted to Britain to take up employment provided they
hold a permit issued to the prospective employer by the Department of
Employment and Productivity (the Ministry of Health and Social Services
for Northern Ireland if the proposed employment is in Northern Ireland).
In Great Britain, over 60,500 such permits were issued in 1967. Some 15,300
workers, mainly skilled, came to work in industry and commerce, 15,500 to
work in the hotel and catering industry, 11,300 for domestic work and 8,200
as student employees. Employment is limited to a maximum of one year in
the first instance but may be extended on the employer’s application.
Before a permit is issued, the DEP must be satisfied that there is a vacancy
for which no suitable British or foreign worker already long-resident in
Britain is available, and that the wages and conditions of employment are not
less favourable than those enjoyed by British workers. These conditions are
waived for student employees who are admitted for limited periods in order
to improve their English and to gain a wider knowledge of their occupations.
A foreigner in employment in Britain may not change his job unless his
prospective employer has obtained prior approval from the DEP.
Britain, as a member of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and
Development, participates with 13 European countries in the arrangements
for assisting nationals of the countries concerned to obtain employment in
other member countries.
As part of its plans for increasing productivity in industry the Government is
fostering the expansion and improvement of industrial training. The whole
framework of training in industry and commerce was strengthened by the
1 The Commonwealth Immigrants Acts apply also to citizens of the Republic of
Ireland but no control is imposed on persons travelling between Ireland and Britain.
2 People qualified by birth and residence to work in Northern Ireland.

Government
