413
Industrial Training Act 1964. Under this Act industrial training boards are
appointed to be responsible for the quantity and quality of industrial training
in the industry concerned; up to June 1968 23 boards had been set up. Each
board can provide its own training courses or arrange for other organisations
to provide training. It raises a levy from employers and makes grants to those
whose training it approves. The Secretary of State meets the initial adminis¬
trative costs of each board and is making grants towards certain other
expenditure: for example, training courses for trainers and research projects.
To advise the Secretary of State on the administration of the Act and on
industrial training questions generally, a Central Training Council (CTC)
consisting of employer and trade union members, representatives of national¬
ised industries, educationists, selected chairmen of training boards and others
with a special interest in industrial training has been set up. It also advises on
the running of the Industrial Training Service (ITS), which is grant-aided by
the DEP. The work of the ITS includes assessing training needs both for
industries and individual companies, developing training schemes, and
promoting group training.
In some of the industries for which training boards have not yet been set
up, apprenticeship training is governed by agreements between employers’
associations and trade unions. Practical training is provided mainly within
the individual firm, and associated technical education is obtained by attending
a technical college. Training of operatives is usually arranged by the individual
firm but in a few industries there are agreed national or regional schemes.
Government assistance includes grants for approved courses for training
officers, for the appointment of training development officers and for the
promotion of group training schemes. A direct contribution is made by the
Government’s own training centres (see below).
The Government Vocational Training Scheme, administered by the
Department of Employment and Productivity, is intended to augment what
industry is doing to overcome shortages of skilled workers in industries of
national importance as well as helping persons in special need, such as the
disabled (see p. 411) and ex-Forces men and women, to fit themselves for
suitable employment. Training is provided for suitable persons over 18 years
of age who are unskilled or whose prospects of work in their existing trade
are poor. (Employed persons as well as the unemployed are accepted for
training in trades of importance to the national economy.) Most of it is done
at the 38 (being increased to 55) Government Training Centres (GTCs),
which are within easy reach of the main industrial centres of the country,
and between them offer courses in about 40 different trades, with emphasis on
those in which there is a shortage of skilled labour. Schemes of training for
particular trades are agreed with representatives of the employers and
workers concerned.
For the disabled and for ex-Regular Service men and women and the un¬
employed with special resettlement problems, training in other trades is also
available under the scheme at technical and commercial colleges and private
training establishments or by means of individual courses at employers
establishments. For severely disabled persons training is provided at four
residential training colleges run by voluntary organisations with government
financial assistance.
During training, trainees are paid good allowances to maintain themselves
and their dependants. During 1967, 12,250 people were trained under the
scheme and over 90 per cent of them were subsequently employed in the
trade for which they had been trained.
414 BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Training can also be given in GTCs to workers sponsored by their employers
where it can be fitted in with the DEP’s other training commitments. The
employer continues to pay the trainee’s wages.
The Department of Employment and Productivity’s Regular Forces
Resettlement Service helps Regular officers and other ranks returning to
civilian life to find suitable employment. Nearly all those leaving the Services
are successful in securing satisfactory resettlement. The DEP arranges special
six-week business training courses for Regulars and ex-Regulars (mainly
ex-officers) at commercial and technical colleges; four-week courses in
industrial supervision are provided at a centre in London for non-technical
warrant officers and senior NCOs (or other Service equivalent ranks). In
addition to full courses for a civilian trade, refresher courses and conversion
courses required for ex-Service men and women can be arranged under the
Vocational Training Scheme.
The DEP also provides assistance with training for firms moving into a
development area or expanding an existing business there. The assistance
includes grants for training carried out by the employer and direct training of
employees on the firm’s premises by staff loaned by the DEP. A new scheme of
grants administered by the industrial training boards has been introduced to
promote craft and technician training in development areas. Grants are
available to employers in these areas (see p. 249) who provide additional off-
the-job training facilities for apprentices or technicians, or otherwise increase
the numbers of such trainees.
Special DEP A special service to industry is the Department of Employment and Producti-
Services vity’s Training Within Industry for Supervisors (TWI) scheme. Its object is
to develop the skill of supervisors in instructing others, in human relations, in
improving methods and in preventing accidents (there are separate program¬
mes for each of these). There are special versions of TWI, usually in courses of
a week’s duration, for supervisors employed in offices, retail distribution and
hospitals, and an in-plant training development service including the training
of operatives as instructors. Training Officers of the DEP either give these
courses or train emplovers’ nominees to enable them to run TWI courses in
their own concerns.
In addition, courses in industrial instructional techniques for the training of
apprentice and trade instructors are available to outside firms (as well as GTC
staff) at the Department of Employment and Productivity’s two Instructor
Training Colleges (one in England and one in Scotland), and at five Instructor
Training Units.
Vocational training services at GTCs, TWI courses, and courses at
Instructor Training Colleges are available to trainees from overseas under
approved schemes (for instance, those of the ILO or the Colombo Plan).
TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT AND WORKING CONDITIONS
Legislation and There are few restrictions in Britain on the freedom of an employer to hire
Conventions an employee on any terms which the employee will accept. Recent legislation,
however, embodies certain safeguards for the employee. The Terms and
Conditions of Employment Act 1959 provides machinery for enforcing on
an employer the observance of terms or conditions established by collective
agreement in his industry; under the Contracts of Employment Act 1963
employers are required to give their employees written particulars of the
main terms of employment, and both employers and employees are given
Earnings
LABOUR 415
rights to minimum periods of notice when employment is to be terminated;
and under the Redundancy Payments Act 1965 employees with a minimum
period of service of two years are entitled to lump sum payments if their jobs
cease to exist (for example, because of technological improvements or because
of a fall in demand) and their employers cannot offer suitable alternative work,
the cost being partly met from a fund subscribed to by industry as a whole
Employers are under no legal obligation to recognise a trade union, or
to refrain from refusing to employ trade unionists; nor is a collective agree¬
ment with a trade union held to be in itself a legal contract of employment,
though the terms of a collective agreement may be expressly or by implication
incorporated in an individual contract of employment. However, it is by
collective agreements that in the majority of trades and industries minimum
or standard wages, normal working hours and other terms of employment are
effectively settled. The negotiation and observance of settlements continue
to depend primarily on the strength, integrity and representative character
of the signatory organisations rather than on any legal sanction. The deter¬
mination by statute of minimum wages, holidays and holiday pay is in
principle confined to those trades and industries where the organisation of
employers or workers, or both, is inadequate to negotiate collective agree¬
ments and to ensure their observance. (For Government powers embodied
in prices and incomes legislation, see p. 232.)
Legislation prescribes minimum standards of safety, health and welfare in
most places of employment; a single comprehensive statute is under
discussion. However, it is recognised that the causes of many accidents are
not amenable to statutory control. Therefore, voluntary action taken by
employer organisations, often in association with trade unions, is encouraged.
The further considerations which affect workers’ satisfaction with their
jobs and promote harmony between employers and employed, which can be
summed up as ‘good human relations’ between management and individual
employees, are hardly susceptible of codification; they have been recognised
for some time and are receiving increasing attention from managements and
from voluntary and official organisations.
Minimum or standard time rates for the lowest-rated manual workers, as
determined by agreements or by statutory orders, vary between 4s. qd. and
6s. od. an hour for men and between 3s. 6d. and 5s. od. for women. Actual
earnings are usually higher. Higher rates are sometimes paid, and piece rates,1
shift rates and overtime rates raise the level of average earnings.
On the basis of the latest survey in a series conducted half-yearly by the
former Ministry of Labour into earnings and hours of work in manufacturing
industries and some leading non-manufacturing industries throughout
Britain, the average earnings of full-time male adult manual workers in
October 1967 were 9s. 3d. an hour and £21 7s. 6d. a week. Full-time women
manual workers at the same date earned an average of 5s. 6d. an hour and
£10 ns. 2d. a week.
Minimum time rates for women manual workers tend to be set at around
70-90 per cent of the corresponding male rate, though the gap is gradually
closing. Women’s earnings are markedly lower than those of men, partly
because on average they work shorter hours, with less overtime paid at
premium rates, but also because a smaller proportion of women do skilled
work. The Government has announced its intention of implementing the
1 Piece rates are of declining importance in manufacturing industries, where methods
of production tend to dictate the output of a worker, not his or her own skill or energy.

Salaries and
Fees
principle of equal pay and is having talks with the Trades Union Congress
and the Confederation of British Industry about the problems involved.
Earnings in coalmining, not covered by the half-yearly survey, are somewhat
above the average; earnings are about the average in railway work and below
the average in agriculture.
Between 1955 and October 1967 average weekly wage rates increased
by 67-5 per cent and average weekly earnings by 96 per cent. Part of the
increase has been offset by a rise in prices of about 45 cent. The trends of
manual workers’ wage rates and earnings, salary earnings, and retail prices
from 1955 to 1967 are shown in the diagram below.
Remuneration in commercial, technical and professional careers is normally
by annual salary, often on a scale carrying annual increases, and such careers
generally afford opportunities for promotion to posts with higher remunera¬
tion. Starting salaries may be in the range of £yoo-£goo (lower for trainees
in their teens and higher for some graduates entering industry). The average
weekly earnings of male administrative, technical and clerical employees in
October 1967 were found by a Ministry of Labour survey to be £27 18s. od.
The average weekly figure for females was 3^14 18s. od.
Most of the senior posts in business, the professions and the Civil Service
are in the range of £2,750 to £7,000 a year. The posts with salaries in the
range of £8,000 to £15,000 a year include those of Cabinet Ministers, top-
ranking judicial appointments, the highest positions in government depart¬
ments and the largest municipal authorities, editors of daily newspapers,
some persons outstanding in their professions and in the higher managerial
posts in industry, commerce and banking. A few persons in business draw
still higher salaries, while the earnings of star entertainers and certain other
very successful people exceed £20,000 a year.

LABOUR 41?
Women have the same right of entry as men to nearly all public offices,
administrative posts and professions. They are paid the same salary for
doing the same work in journalism, broadcasting and architecture, and as
Ministers of the Crown, members of Parliament, salaried magistrates and
solicitors. Women in independent professions are not expected to charge
lower fees than men. The principle of equal pay applies to non-manual work
in the public sector but remains the exception in private non-manual
employment.
The average earnings of all salaried employees increased by 95 per cent
between 1955 and 1967, as illustrated in the diagram opposite.
In October 1967 the number of hours actually worked by manual workers
averaged 46-2 for full-time men and 38-2 for women on full-time work. Agreed
weekly hours are mainly in the range 40 to 42 and are generally worked as
either a five-day or a five-and-a-half-day week according to the industry and
the rule of the particular establishment. Hours actually worked by men are
somewhat longer owing to overtime working. While the hours of work of
adult men are not, in general, restricted by statute, normal hours of work for
both sexes and those of all ages are usually within the legal limits on the hours
of women and young persons.
National legislation limits and defines permissible hours of work for
women and young persons in a number of industries or trades—the maximum
permitted, with limited exceptions, being 48 hours a week and 10 hours a
day (9 hours a day for 6-day-week workers) in premises covered by the
Factories Act (see p. 418) for adult women over 18 and young people between
16 and 18; young people under 16 are limited to 44 hours a week. The
employment of women and young people at night is prohibited in industrial
undertakings, except that in certain continuous process industries young men
over 16 may, subject to certain conditions, be so employed.
With a few exceptions, manual workers (including shop assistants) in indus¬
tries covered by agreements or statutory orders are entitled to paid holidays
of at least 12 days or two weeks. Moreover, payment is made for bank or
statutory public holidays, which are as follows: in addition to Good Friday
and Christmas Day, there are bank holidays in most parts of England, Wales
and the Channel Islands on Easter Monday, the last Monday in May or first
in June, the last Monday in August or first in September, and the first
weekday after Christmas (Boxing Day); and in Scotland on New Year’s Day,
the last Monday in May or first in June and the last Monday in August or
first in September.1 Northern Ireland observes all the English holidays and,
in addition, has a holiday on St. Patrick’s Day, 17th March, and on 12th July
(commemorating the Battle of the Boyne, 1690); the Tuesday after Easter is
also a customary holiday for industry and trade. Many agreements provide
that payments should also be made for specially proclaimed holidays.
In some industries agreements provide for extended holidays related to
length of service, work status, or both.
Where statutory wage-regulating machinery exists, it consists of bodies
known as Wages Councils. These are composed of equal numbers of repre¬
sentatives of employers and workers in the respective sectors of industry,
1 The appointed dates for the spring and autumn bank holidays in 1969 are 26th May
and 1 st September.

with additional independent members. Wages Councils may submit proposals
for fixing minimum remuneration and holidays with pay to the Secretary of
State who must then make orders giving statutory force to such proposals,
subject only to his right to return them as a whole for further consideration.
The DEP’s Wages Inspectorate helps employers and workers to interpret the
provisions of wage regulation orders and sees that they are complied with.
Agricultural Wages Boards (there are separate boards for England and
Wales and for Scotland) perform similar functions in relation to employment
in agriculture.
A variety of additional benefits in monetary form exist in varying degree. It
has been estimated that, in 1964, 13 million employees were covered by
occupational sick pay schemes and between 11 and 12 million by occupa¬
tional pension schemes (additional or complementary to the state schemes,
see p. 126). A smaller number are covered by schemes for redundancy pay¬
ments above the statutory minimum (see p. 415). Such ‘fringe’ benefits are
rather more usual among clerical and professional employees receiving a
standard salary than among manual workers with a chance to earn overtime
and other additions to their pay. The former also tend to get longer holidays.
Senior members of firms may enjoy the use of a company car.
Employers have a duty at common law to take reasonable care of their
employees and provide a safe system of working, while employees have a
duty of care towards each other. In addition, minimum required standards
of safety in certain kinds of workplaces or work are laid down under a number
of statutes; some of these also deal with health and welfare.
Factories,
Offices, Shops
and Railway
Premises
About 213,000 industrial premises (factories, warehouses, shipyards and
docks) come under the Factories Act 1961 (consolidating earlier legislation),
which is administered by the Department of Employment and Productivity
and enforced by Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Factories, which forms part of
the DEP. About 700,000 premises come under the Offices, Shops and Railway
Premises Act, which is also administered by the DEP; enforcement is shared
by Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Factories and local authorities. Under these
Acts, anyone intending to employ other people in industrial or commercial
premises to which they apply has to notify the enforcing authority of his
intention before he begins to employ people and every fatal accident and every
accident causing more than three days’ incapacity must be reported; under the
Factories Act provision is also made for compulsory notification and for
investigation of certain dangerous occurrences.
The Acts are designed to secure the health, safety and welfare of employed
persons, and a wide range of provisions in the Acts and in regulations,
according to the nature of the premises, deal with such matters as. the
fencing of machinery; precautions against fire, dangerous substances and
special risks; the safe condition of the premises, cleanliness, lighting, tempera¬
ture and ventilation; and the employment of women and young persons.
Comparable provision with appropriate variations covers mines and
quarries under the Mines and Quarries Act 1954; two statutes are concerned
with agriculture—the Agriculture (Poisonous Substances) Act 195^ and the
Agriculture (Safety, Health and Welfare Provisions) Act 1956; and specialised
statutes and delegated legislation are concerned with transport—the Railway
Employment (Prevention of Accidents) Act 1900, the Merchant Shipping
Acts, the Road Traffic Acts and the Air Navigation Order and Regulations.

Prevention
Advisory Bodies
Training for
Safety

As with the Factories Act these other provisions are, with some exceptions,
enforced through inspectorates—the Mines and Quarries Inspectorate (part
of the Ministry of Power which is responsible for safety in mines and quarries),
the Agricultural Inspectorate of the agricultural departments, and, as regards
railways, the Railway Employment Inspectorate of the Ministry of Transport.
The Board of Trade is responsible for administering the Merchant Shipping
Acts and for safety in air transport (most of the powers in respect of air
worthiness are delegated to the Air Registration Board, see p. 348), and the
Minister of Transport is responsible for road and rail transport safety matters.
There are at present no specific statutory safety requirements in hotels,
places of entertainment or educational establishments, except in so far as
they are covered by fire regulations applicable under local authority by-laws
to all large buildings or (in respect of their offices and shops) by the Offices,
Shops and Railway Premises Act. The Department of Employment and
Productivity has no statutory responsibility in regard to safety in workshops
or laboratories in educational establishments, though it keeps in touch with
university authorities and the education departments. Employers, however,
are bound by their common law obligation to provide a safe system of work,
and employers and educational authorities may voluntarily seek the advice and
help of the Factory Inspectorate, which is given freely on request.
The voluntary accident prevention movement is strongly supported by the
Factory Inspectorate. Inspectors enquire into notified accidents and safety
aspects of machine design and specification, circulate expert advice by personal
exhortation, lectures and literature, and encourage the appointment of safety
officers and the formation of works safety committees. The Factor}7 Inspector¬
ate maintains an industrial health and safety centre in London, at which
various types of machinery demonstrating the effectiveness of guards are
displayed, as well as a wide range of protective clothing and equipment. The
DEP also actively encourages the development of voluntary central organisa¬
tion within each industry at national level for the consideration of safety
matters and the formulation of policy on accident prevention.
Organisations in industry are now concerning themselves to an increasing
extent with the promotion of safety at work and the provision of information
and advisory services to their members. They participate also in joint standing
and advisory committees appointed by the Secretary of State. Representatives
of the Trades Union Congress, the Confederation of British Industry, the
nationalised industries and other interests meet on the Industrial Safety
Advisory Council under the chairmanship of the Secretary of State.
Training for safety is an important facet of the accident prevention effort and,
to help in this work, the Department of Employment and Productivity
provides a safety course in its TWI scheme (see p. 4I4)> I9^S Central
Training Council, which advises the Secretary of State under the Industrial
Training Act 1964 (see p. 413), drew the attention of Industrial Training
Boards to the need to include specific provisions for safety training in their
general training recommendations.
The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA) provides a
variety of safety courses for special needs at its Industrial Safety Training
Centre in Birmingham and elsewhere. Other courses are organised by bodies
such as local accident prevention groups and organisations such as the
Federation of Civil Engineering Contractors. RoSPA also helps the accident
420
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Other Measures
HEALTH AND
WELFARE
prevention movement by providing publicity and organising conferences; its
corps of Regional Industrial Safety Officers work to promote safety activity
among top-level managers. The British Safety Council also provides publicity
and offers safety training courses.
A substantial amount of research is being done by industry, universities
and other academic bodies, and government research organisations into
problems of guarding machines, ergonomics, safe handling, electrical hazards,
protective personal equipment, construction methods, fires and explosions,
psychological factors and causes of accidents, both generally and in particular
sectors of industry. A register of research into industrial health and safety
matters has been compiled by the DEP to give an indication of the scale and
nature of research being undertaken. Industrial research associations include
amongst their more purely economic research projects the improvement of
working conditions and the reduction of hazards.
The National Coal Board has its own safety organisation—a Standing
Committee on Safety, a chief safety engineer, and safety engineers at divisions,
areas and the largest collieries. It conducts courses of safety training for
workmen and officials and is constantly on the alert for new methods of
reducing risks. Its research programme includes a number of projects with a
direct bearing on safety.
The Minister of Power has a statutory responsibility for research concerning
the safety and health of coal miners. This responsibility is largely exercised
through its Safety in Mines Research Establishment.
To safeguard the many interests which might be adversely affected by the
use of chemicals in agriculture and food storage, a voluntary scheme is
operated by the Government with the help of an advisory committee and with
the full co-operation of the chemical industry.
Transport operators and Ministries concerned with road and air travel give
high priority to safety measures affecting crews and passengers. Every
endeavour is made to counter the higher risks resulting from rising traffic
densities, by improving the design of vehicles, transport plant and equipment,
by traffic regulation and control of standards of maintenance and by training
crews in competency and safety awareness.
Local authorities have power, under the Public Health Acts, to regulate the
provision of suitable sanitary accommodation in houses and at places of work
and to treat workplaces which are dirty or badly ventilated or overcrowded
as nuisances the abatement of which can be enforced. Factories, certain other
industrial premises, offices, shops and railway premises must comply with the
health and welfare requirements of the Factories Act or the Offices, Shops and
Railway Premises Act. These include: the cleanliness of workrooms, adequate
ventilation and suitable temperature and lighting, the avoidance of over¬
crowding and the provision of sanitary accommodation, and the protection
of workers against inhaling harmful dust or fumes; the provision of washing
facilities, lockers or other accommodation for outdoor clothing, drinking
water, first aid, and seats. Legislation concerning safety in other types of work,
for example, agriculture, also prescribes appropriate measures.
The laws restricting the employment of children, young persons and women
form an important part of protective legislation. National legislation, besides
forbidding any employment of children under 13 years of age, forbids the
employment of children who have not reached the statutory minimum school¬
leaving age (see p. 150) in any industrial undertaking; of women and young
persons underground in mines and in certain other dangerous occupations
LABOUR
421
Industrial
Health Services
Other
Amenities
(for example, certain processes connected with lead manufacture); and of
women in factories and workshops within one month of childbirth. It also
limits and defines the permissible hours of employment for women and young
persons (see p. 417). Local authorities, moreover, have wide powers under the
Children and Young Persons Acts 1933-63 as well as the Education Acts
1944-48, which regulate hours and conditions of employment of children
under 15 years within their areas within the limits of national legislation.
There are some 1,600 appointed factory doctors1 and some 700 works
medical officers whose duties include the initial and periodic medical examina¬
tion of all young people entering industry, and certain other medical
examinations required under the Factories Act for workers in particular
hazardous trades.
These are the main legislative provisions relating to health and welfare at
work, but it is essential to note that employers frequently achieve standards
considerably higher than those prescribed by law. They are helped to do this
by the inspectorates, by government departments and agencies, by employers’
associations and trade unions and by expert voluntary bodies.
A number of employers voluntarily maintain medical services for their
employees over and above the statutory requirements. It is estimated that
there are about 450 factories with full-time and about 4,500 factories with
part-time doctors employed. In addition several thousand nurses are employed
in industry.
The big employers, including the state and the boards of nationalised
industries, have naturally taken the lead but a number of smaller factories
also provide medical services and in a few cases have joined together in group
medical services. The Secretary of State is advised on measures to further the
development of industrial health services by the Industrial Health Advisory
Committee which includes members nominated by the Confederation of
British Industry, the Trades Union Congress, the nationalised industries,
the British Medical Association, the Royal College of Nursing and other
organisations closely concerned with the promotion of industrial health.
Occupational hygiene services can give valuable assistance in securing
healthy working conditions in industry. Her Majesty’s Factory Inspectors
give advice on occupational hygiene problems as part of their normal duties.
In addition there are at present two centres in Great Britain which undertake
studies of particular problems or health risks and also carry out routine
physical, chemical and biological tests for industry.
Research facilities are provided by government agencies such as the
Medical Research Council; by university faculties of industrial health and
social medicine; and by the research departments of various industries and
large industrial concerns. Field investigations are carried out by the Factory
Inspectorate, which has specialised medical and technical branches.
Other types of amenity vary considerably from one firm to another. The
requirements of a factory, office or shop where the work is light, and where
many employees are women or young persons, are different from those of an
iron foundry or steelworks, where much of the work is arduous and is under¬
taken by men. Progressive firms are careful to find out what their employees
want, and welfare policy is often decided in consultation with the workers,
through regular consultative machinery or by other means. An increasing

number of firms pay part or all of the cost of recreational facilities. Some have
their own rehabilitation centres or support convalescent homes. The provision
of low-priced meals at the place of employment has become usual in large
undertakings and quite common in smaller ones. Many offices and shops
which are unable to provide canteen facilities for their staff have adopted
luncheon voucher schemes; there are over 15,500 firms using this service.
Practically all large industrial firms and many small ones now have a personnel
department staffed by one or more specialist officers. While the form of
organisation of personnel departments varies, personnel officers are generally
responsible for advising all levels of management on every aspect of labour
relations. They also have particular duties with regard to recruitment,
selection, education and training, transfer of labour, the application of wage
agreements, the promotion of good communication and consultation and the
supervision of working conditions and employees’ amenities.
Recruitment and promotion policies are matters which each undertaking
decides for itself, although in some industries the decisions may be limited
by collective agreements or by trade practices. Great importance has recently
been attached to selection; and courses for training personnel officers in
modern interviewing techniques, including the use of test procedures, are
now well attended.
Both official and voluntary organisations are concerned with promoting
better human relationships in industry. The Government has sought to
extend by research the available knowledge of the factors influencing human
relations in industry and human efficiency. Such research is sponsored or
conducted by the Social Science Research Council (see p. 291) and the
Medical Research Council (see p. 195). Voluntary organisations include
bodies which deal with management problems and provide a service to
subscribing firms; professional associations, linking individuals with a com¬
mon interest in particular functions of management; and bodies providing
specialist services, usually on a fee-paying basis.
In addition to the assistance the Department of Employment and Produc¬
tivity can give where employees are recruited through employment exchanges,
members of its industrial relations service are available to give advice on
personnel policies, personnel management techniques and problems of human
relations at the workplace, as well as assisting in the formation and support of
machinery for negotiation and settlement of disputes (see below).
The safety, health and welfare of employees in Northern Ireland have been
the subject of legislation which, with some exceptions, is similar to that in
Great Britain and is embodied in the Factories Act (Northern Ireland) 1965
and the Office and Shop Premises Act (Northern Ireland) 1966. Many firms
voluntarily employ safety officers, and an Industrial Safety Group for the area,
supported by representatives of industry, trade unions, insurance companies
and public authorities, makes a valuable contribution in the field of industrial
accident prevention on similar lines to what is done in Great Britain.
The structure of labour relations in Britain is established mainly on a voluntary
basis, and rests on the organisation of employers and workers into employers’
associations and trade unions. These organisations1 discuss and negotiate
1 Some employers, including the central Government and the public corporations
operating the nationalised industries, negotiate directly with the trade unions repre¬
senting their different types of employees.
LABOUR
423
terms and conditions of employment and other matters affecting the work¬
people at their work. In some industries these negotiations are conducted
simply by ad hoc meetings, which are held when necessary; in others, voluntary
joint machinery has been established on a permanent basis. Normally these
arrangements for collective bargaining suffice to settle all questions which are
raised, but provision is often made for matters not so settled to be referred
for settlement to independent arbitration. The machinery for settlement in
certain trades where wages cannot be effectively controlled by voluntary
agreement has already been described (see p. 417).
The existence of these employers’ and employees’ bodies facilitates liaison
between the Government and industry on labour matters in which they have
a common interest (though it does not preclude individual contact). Standing
arrangements exist for consultation at national level between the Government,
the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), the Trades Union Congress
(TUC) (see pp. 424 and 425) and the nationalised industries through the
National Joint Advisory Council, which was set up in 1939 to advise the
Government on matters in which employers and workers have a common
interest. It meets quarterly under the chairmanship of the Secretary of State.
A Royal Commission appointed in 1965 to investigate the whole range and
scope of employers’ and employees’ organisations, and the legal framework in
which they operate, reported in June 1968 (Cmnd. 3623). It made numerous
recommendations aimed at a complete overhaul of the system of collective
bargaining and industrial relations in Britain.
Employers’
Associations
Many employers in Great Britain are members of employers’ organisations
wholly or partly concerned with labour questions. The primary aims of such
organisations are to help to establish suitable terms and conditions of
employment, including a sound wage structure and proper standards of
safety, health and welfare; to promote good relations with employees and
the efficient use of manpower; and to provide means of settling any disputes
which may arise. Different employers’ organisations vary in the emphasis
which they put upon these different aims and in the means by which they try
to achieve them. Some concentrate on defensive action, trying by negotiation
and representations to modify proposals of trade unions and Government in
their members’ interests. Others also try to give their members practical help
and advice in developing positive employment policies and assistance on
recruitment, training and further education.
There is diversity of structure as well as function. Generally, however,
employers’ organisations are organised on an industry basis rather than a
product basis. Some are purely local in character and deal with a section of
an industry; others are national in scope and are concerned with the whole
of a particular industry. In some of the chief industries there are local or
regional organisations combined into national federations, while in others,
within which different firms are engaged on making different principal
products, there is a very complex structure with national and regional
federations for these different sections of the industry as well as for the
industry as a whole. Although there are some 1,360 employers’ organisations
dealing with labour matters, about 90 of these are national employers’
associations, many of which are in membership of the CBI and are the ones
that negotiate the important national collective agreements with trade
unions.
The final authority of a local or small national organisation may be a meeting
where all member firms are directly represented; but in larger organisations
424
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Confederation
of British
Industry
Trade Unions
some form of indirect representation is necessary, either through local
organisations or through regions or sections into which these are grouped.
The representatives thus chosen, together with a number of office holders,
form a general council or central committee, which meets perhaps once a
quarter, mainly to make major policy decisions, to elect committees and to
ratify their work. A small paid staff under a director or secretary carries out
the organisation’s day-to-day work. There is usually a small working group,
consisting of senior officials and committee chairmen, which meets to deal
with urgent questions and co-ordinate the work of committees.
The central body of employers’ organisations is the CBI, which deals with
all matters (not only labour relations) affecting the interests of organised
employers and represents them nationally to the Government and the public
and also internationally, for instance, in the International Labour Organisa¬
tion. CBI representatives sit on various government advisory committees, on
other statutory bodies and on a number of voluntary bodies concerned with
labour matters.
In nearly all industries and occupations some workers—and in some industries
nearly all workers—are organised into trade unions. These have grown up
gradually and independently over a great many years, and consequently, their
form and organisation vary considerably as to their traditions and attitudes,
for example, their degree of concern with political movements. Trade unions
started more than two hundred years ago among the skilled craftsmen and
spread later to the general labouring and unskilled classes. More recently
trade unionism has increased among clerical, supervisory, technical and
administrative workers. A number of associations of professional workers,
formed primarily for the preservation and improvement of professional
standards, have also come to exercise many of the functions of trade unions,
including negotiations on salary and fee scales, and are legally trade unions.
The qualification for membership of some unions is occupational (for
instance, they may recruit clerks or fitters wherever employed), while in others
the qualification is industrial (that is, they seek to recruit all persons in an
industry, whatever their occupation). In a number of unions recruitment is
based on a combination of these principles. A few large unions recruit
members in a number of different occupations and industries.
At the end of 1966 the total membership of British trade unions was about
10,111,000. There were 574 unions but rather more than two-thirds of all
trade unionists were in the 18 largest unions, while just over a half were in the
nine unions with a membership of over 250,000. The number of trade
unionists has increased during the last decade but the number of unions has
gone down owing to amalgamations.
The basic unit of organisation in most British trade unions is the local
branch (sometimes called a lodge). Every member of the union belongs to a
branch. He may attend its meetings, make suggestions about terms and
conditions of employment, discuss the work of the union, and take part in the
election of the union’s officers. The branch takes action on certain matters
considered to be entirely, or mainly, of local interest and forwards its views on
wider issues for action by the union’s national or regional bodies. Many
unions also have shop stewards or other representatives at the place of work
to enrol members and collect dues, to ensure that local and national agreements
operate satisfactorily, to take up individual problems with management
and to keep the union informed of developments at the workplace. Only in a
few trade unions is organisation based primarily on the place of work.
LABOUR
425
Trades Union
Congress
Scottish Trades
Union Congress
In most large unions the central organisation is along the following lines:
elected officials, including a general secretary assisted by clerical and specialist
staff, are in charge of the work of the head office and are responsible to an
elected national executive council or committee which may be part-time or
full-time, and which is responsible to annual or biennial conferences of
delegates from the branches. Executive committees or councils play an
important part in the government of the unions; between conferences they
are the highest authorities and carry out policy decisions made by delegates.
Most unions also have some regional, district or area organisation.
Trade unions may affiliate to one or more federations or confederations
whose main purpose in most cases is to represent all or most of the trade
unions in an industry in negotiations with employers. The scope and authority
of these federations and confederations vary greatly.
In Britain the national centre of the trade union movement is the TUC which
celebrated its centenary in June 1968. The TUC’s objects are to promote
the interests of its affiliated organisations and to improve the economic and
social conditions of the workers. Its membership comprises just over 160
organisations, some of which are themselves federations of smaller organisa¬
tions. Together they represent about 8-8 million workpeople. The TUC
deals with all general questions which concern trade unions both nationally
and internationally and gives assistance on questions relating to particular
trades or industries at the request of the trade union concerned.
The congress of delegates, which constitutes the TUC proper, meets for a
week every year to discuss matters of general interest to trade unionists and
to employees generally. It elects annually a General Council which represents
it during the remaining 51 weeks of the year. This is responsible for carrying
out congress decisions, for watching economic and social developments, for
providing educational and advisory services to unions, and for presenting to
the Government the trade union viewpoint on economic, social and industrial
issues. It is also empowered to mediate in inter-union disputes in certain
circumstances and, through the General Council’s Incomes Policy Com¬
mittee, to comment on claims for improvements in wages and working
conditions notified to the TUC by affiliated unions.
The TUC is a non-political body but under the Trade Union Act 1913
individual trade unions can, by a ballot vote of members, decide to set up a
political fund, financed by a separate levy, which any member can refuse to
pay without loss of his normal union rights and benefits. About 100 separate
trade union organisations, including most of the largest trade unions, have
such a fund and, in most cases, it is used to support the Labour Party.
Both the TUC and many unions conduct extensive educational services for
members, mainly concerned with industrial subjects, trade unionism and
industrial relations principles and practice.
Branches of various trade unions in a locality generally affiliate to a local
trades council, which acts as a forum for the discussion of matters of common
interest and as a local agent of the TUC, by which it is registered each year.
There are just over 500 trades councils in England and Wales alone, grouped
together in 22 federations.
Affiliation to the TUC is open to all trade unions anywhere in the United
Kingdom, but Scottish trade unionists have their own national centre, the
Scottish Trades Union Congress, similar within its objects to the TUC. The
Scottish TUC, to which trade unions may affiliate in respect of their member¬
ship in Scotland (a number of unions are affiliated to both bodies), also accepts

affiliation from trade councils and has an affiliated membership of about
842,000. It holds an annual congress and has consultations with the Govern¬
ment on issues affecting Scottish trade unionists.
In most of the main industries there are, at national level, joint committees
(sometimes referred to as joint negotiating machinery) composed of represen¬
tatives of employers and trade unions. Their functions vary considerably,
some being simply negotiating bodies, while others deal with a wide range of
subjects affecting the interests of the industry concerned. Provision is
sometimes made in their constitution that a dispute on which it is not found
possible to reach agreement should be referred to some form of conciliation
or arbitration by independent persons, including the means provided under
the Conciliation Act 1896, or the Industrial Courts Act 1919.
Collective agreements between employers’ associations and trade unions are
not civil contracts between particular employers and employees, and are not
in themselves enforceable at law. Observance of agreed terms and conditions
is based mainly on the good faith of employers and the mutual respect and
vigilance of trade unions and employers’ organisations, but can be secured in
particular instances through reference to the Industrial Court.
Arrangements for negotiation and joint consultation also exist at district and
factory level in many industries, where matters are discussed either between
the appropriate representatives of the two sides on an ad hoc basis, or through
regular machinery provided by District Joint Industrial Councils or similar
bodies and Works Councils. Such bodies discuss how agreements reached at
a national level may be applied to their district or factory, but as a rule have
no power to alter the terms of such national agreements. They also discuss
new problems which may arise, and if no solution can be found at factory or
district level, refer them to the national body.
Matters which prove difficult to settle by negotiation are sometimes referred
by agreement to independent conciliators or arbitrators, and one way in which
the parties can find such persons is by invoking the help of the Secretary of
State. Under authority derived from the Conciliation Act 1896, and the
Industrial Courts Act 1919, the Secretary of State has certain powers to assist
industry to settle disputes which it is not found possible to resolve through an
industry’s own machinery and procedure. These powers are all intended to
supplement and not to supersede the industry’s own machinery. There is no
legal obligation on the parties to a dispute to notify the dispute to the Secretary
of State nor to place the question before a conciliator.
To assist conciliation in industry the Department of Employment and
Productivity has an industrial relations service, staffed by specially trained
officers who keep in touch with the course of relations between employers and
workers at national, district and, in some cases, factory level and assist them,
if requested, to settle their problems by joint discussion and negotiation.
Conciliators have no legal powers.
Disputes which cannot be settled in this way may, at the request of both
parties, be referred to voluntary arbitration, either by a single arbitrator, or
an ad hoc Board of Arbitration, or by the Industrial Court, a permanent
tribunal established under the Industrial Courts Act. The court normally
consists of three members—the president, one member experienced in
representing employers and one in representing workpeople.
Like collective agreements, arbitration awards are not in themselves
enforceable at law, but under the Terms and Conditions of Employment
Strikes and
Lockouts
Communica¬
tion and
Joint
Consultation
LABOUR 427
Act 1959, reports that a particular employer is not observing the recognised
terms or conditions of employment in his trade or industry may be made to
the Secretary of State by organisations which are parties to the relevant
agreement or award. If the matter is not otherwise settled, the Minister must
refer it to the Industrial Court which, after hearing the case, may issue an
award requiring the employer to observe the recognised terms or conditions.
Such an award becomes an implied term of the contract of employment of
individual employees and so enforceable at law.
The Secretary of State is also empowered to appoint a Court of Inquiry or
Committee of Investigation into a dispute, whether existing or apprehended.
These procedures are primarily means of informing public opinion of the
facts of a dispute (the report of a Court of Inquiry has to be laid before
Parliament). Although the recommendations contained in the reports of such
bodies are not binding on the parties, they often provide the basis for further
negotiations leading to a settlement.
Over the past 30 years the number of working days lost each year through
stoppages of work arising from industrial disputes, that is through strikes and
lockouts, has been on an average about 2^ million which, taking the working
population as a whole, works out at approximately one hour per worker per
year. These figures, however, only record the time lost at establishments
where strikes actually take place; they take no account of the effect in other
establishments or industries. Nevertheless, the time lost through strikes is very
much less than that lost on account of sickness, accidents and absenteeism and
Britain’s record over the past ten years or so compares favourably with that of
most other industrial countries.
Strikes in Britain are not in general caused by a breakdown in the collective
bargaining machinery. This on the whole works smoothly and well. In fact
it is estimated that about 95 per cent of all strikes, accounting for between
60 and 70 per cent of the time lost through strikes, are the result of unofficial
(and usually unconstitutional) action.
These unofficial strikes are therefore symptoms of a breakdown in relations
between management and workers at the place of work itself. The problem of
securing a fundamental improvement in relations between employers and
workers and the loyal observance of agreements and constitutional procedures
freely negotiated is currently the subject of public discussion as well as in
industry generally, but it seems likely that there is no single solution.
The concept that workpeople need to have a proper understanding of
management’s aims and plans if they are to co-operate with them has focused
attention on the quality of communication down the chain of responsibility
to workshop level (a matter which depends on personal relations and on the
adequacy of supervisor training) and prompted the establishment, in many
undertakings, of means for joint consultation, such as those provided by a
works council.
A wide range of subjects can be fruitfully discussed by works councils,
including hours of work (within the framework of agreements), safety and
health, productivity, absenteeism, labour turnover, training and education,
and amenities generally. Works councils are usually kept informed about the
state of the firm’s business, and frequently consider problems resulting from
decisions to change production methods. It is usual to exclude all questions
relating to wages and conditions of employment, and other matters covered by
negotiation between employers’ and workers’ organisations although there is
428
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Labour
Relations of
Public
Authorities
Central and Local
Government
Nationalised
Industries
some merging of consultation and negotiation in plant-level productivity
bargaining.
The Department of Employment and Productivity industrial relations
service is ready to assist these developments by advice on techniques, by the
supply of publicity material and by encouraging and promoting joint
consultation.
While labour relations in government service and in the nationalised industries
are, in general, organised on the same principles as in private industry, there
are some special features.
Non-industrial employees in central government service, where salaries and
conditions of service are under the direct control of the Treasury, are per¬
mitted and encouraged to join the appropriate Civil Service staff associations
(trade unions) and there is a highly developed system of negotiation and joint
consultation by means of the National and Departmental Whitley Councils
(see p. 64). If there is failure to reach agreement by negotiation a department
or association may, subject to certain limitations, report the dispute to the
Secretary of State for reference to the Civil Service Arbitration Tribunal, an
independent body appointed by the Secretary of State by powers under the
Industrial Courts Act 1919. Industrial employees of the central Government
are organised by trades and not by departments; negotiations regarding their
wages and conditions of employment take place on Trade Joint Councils and
unresolved matters are referred to the Industrial Court for arbitration. In the
major employing departments, Departmental Joint Councils also exist for the
discussion of matters other than trade questions which are of mutual concern
to the department and its industrial employees (and which are domestic to the
department).
In local government service there are separate National Joint Councils for
the main grades of employees (such as manual, clerical and technical
employees) which deal with wages and conditions of service as well as other
matters. There are corresponding regional and district councils.
In the nationalised industries, the main corporations, though not subject to
detailed governmental control, have a statutory duty to establish satisfactory
arrangements for collective bargaining in their industries and for joint
consultation with their employees; but in carrying out these duties they are
free to choose the arrangements that suit them. The main difference from
private industry is that the corporations are not usually members of
employers’ associations (although the majority are ‘industrial associates’ of
the CBI). In some industries they are sole or main employers, but even
where part of the industry is in private hands, as for example in road transport,
the corporations are separately and directly represented on wage-negotiating
bodies.
Wages and conditions of service in the nationalised industries are generally
settled by negotiation between representatives of managements and trade
unions at the national level; in most cases there are also regional and local
bodies, similarly representative, to deal with local implications. Most of the
industries use the facilities for arbitration offered to industry generally by the
Department of Employment and Productivity but coalmining and rail
transport have their own special arrangements. Consultations at all levels,
including the workplace level, have been arranged in all the nationalised
industries according to the traditions and needs of each industry.
Northern
Ireland
LABOUR 429
Some of the nationalised industries have felt that joint consultation was
best carried out by their negotiating bodies; others have established separate
and specially constituted joint committees at all levels.
The system of labour relations in Northern Ireland is based on the same
principles as that of Great Britain and, in these matters, the Minister of
Health and Social Services has powers and duties similar to those of the
Secretary of State in Great Britain. Nearly 90 per cent of trade unionists
in Northern Ireland are members of trade unions with headquarters in Great
Britain.
17 SOUND AND
TELEVISION
BROADCASTING
Broadcasting of sound and of television in the United Kingdom is regulated
under powers conferred on the Postmaster General by the Wireless Tele¬
graphy Acts 1949-1967, which prohibit the sending or receiving of radio
communications, except under licence.
Sound broadcasting services are provided solely by the British Broadcasting
Corporation (BBC), which was established as a public corporation by Royal
Charter in 1927. Two television services are provided by the Corporation
(BBC 1 and BBC 2) and one by the Independent Television Authority (ITA),
which was established by the Television Act 1954. Major developments in
broadcasting have followed recommendations made by the Committee on
Broadcasting (Pilkington Committee) in 1962.
Users of sound and television sets must obtain an annual receiving licence,
which can be bought from most post offices. There were some 17-8 million
receiving licences current in Britain in June 1968 of which more than 15
million were for sound and television combined and 2-5 million (including
nearly 1 million for sets fitted in cars) for sound only. A combined sound and
television licence costs £5 (^6 from January 1969); a licence for sound only
costs 5s. An additional licence fee of £5 is required for colour television.
Registered blind people are entitled to free sound licences or to combined
licences at a reduced rate. One licence covers all receiving sets in a household,
but a separate licence is required for a set fitted in a car.
Broadcasting The constitution and finances of the BBC are currently governed by the Royal
Authorities Charter of 1964 and the Licence and Agreement with the Postmaster General
of 1963, and those of the ITA by the provisions of the Television Act 1964 and
the Licence issued to it by the Postmaster General in 1964. Both the Royal
Charter and the 1964 Act specifically define the services of the BBC and ITA
as a ‘public service’ with the purpose of disseminating information, education
and entertainment.
The BBC and the ITA are independent authorities in the day-to-day
operations of broadcasting, including programmes and administration. The
Government, however, retains ultimate control, and the Postmaster General,
as the responsible minister, is answerable to Parliament on broad questions
of policy and may issue directions to the BBC and the ITA on a number of
technical and other subjects. The Postmaster General also has powers to
prohibit the broadcasting of any particular matter or class of matter, or to
revoke the licences of the BBC or ITA at any time; these powers, however,
are treated as major reserve powers, and no formal veto has ever been placed
on the broadcasting of a particular item. Both the BBC and the ITA are
required to prepare annual reports and accounts.
The number of hours of television broadcasting are regulated by the
Postmaster General; he has approved an arrangement which permits any one
SOUND AND TELEVISION BROADCASTING
431
The British
Broadcasting
Corporation
The Independent
Television
Authority
service a maximum of 50 hours a week (30 hours a week for BBC 2)1, together
with extensions for certain stated purposes, such as religious and educational
programmes, schools broadcasts, ministerial and party political broadcasts,
and outside broadcasts. In 1968 the BBC was broadcasting about 53 hours of
programmes from London in its domestic sound services during a normal
weekday.
The Corporation consists of 12 governors (including a chairman, a vice-
chairman and separate national governors for Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland), each appointed for a period of not more than five years by the
Queen on the advice of the Government. As a corporate body, the governors
are responsible for the conduct of the whole broadcasting operation, including
the content and presentation of the programmes in sound and television,
and the provision and working of the necessary installations and equipment.
The BBC must refrain from expressing editorial opinion on current affairs and
on matters of public policy and is relied upon to treat controversial subjects
with impartiality.
The governors are advised on all aspects of their work by a number of
councils, established in accordance with the terms of the Charter: for example,
the General Advisory Council; the National Broadcasting Councils for
Scotland and Wales, which are responsible for domestic services in those
countries; and the regional advisory councils for the English regions and for
Northern Ireland. There are also a number of other councils and committees,
not specifically required by the Charter, but established by the BBC to advise
on such matters as schools broadcasting, further education, programmes for
immigrants, religious broadcasting, science, engineering, music, agriculture
and charitable appeals. Each of the local radio stations (see p. 433) has a
broadcasting council, representative of the local community, appointed by the
Postmaster General.
The chief executive officer of the BBC—the Director General—is appointed
by the governors and with him they discuss all major matters of policy and
finance. The Corporation’s Board of Management consists of the Director
General and those responsible for various sections of the BBC, such as, radio,
television, external broadcasting and engineering.
The services of the BBC are financed from: an annual sum, voted by
Parliament, for the domestic services, which is related to revenue derived
from the sale of broadcast receiving licences; an annual grant, voted by
Parliament, for the external services; and profits from BBC publications,
mainly the Radio Times, which has a weekly sale of over 4]; million copies and
attracts a large advertising revenue; and income from BBC Radio and
Television Enterprises (see p. 436). The net revenue from the sale of licences
for the year ended March 1968 amounted to ^74,747,000, the surplus on
trading was £945,300 and the grant for the external services was £10,566,000.
The cost of providing the local radio services is raised mainly from local
sources.
The Independent Television Authority consists of a chairman, a deputy
chairman and, at present, eleven other members (three of whom have special
responsibility for Scotland, Wales and Monmouthshire, and Northern Ireland
severally) appointed by the Postmaster General. The IT A owns and operates
the transmitting stations, but the production studios and equipment are
owned, and the actual programmes are provided, by programme companies
1 To be increased to 53^ hours a week (32 hours for BBC 2) in 1969.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
appointed by the IT A. Fifteen programme companies are at present under
contract: Anglia Television Limited; ATV Network Limited; Border Tele¬
vision Limited; Channel Television Limited; Grampian Television Limited;
Granada TV Network Limited; Harlech Television Limited; London
Weekend Television Limited; Scottish Television Limited; Southern
Independent Television Limited; Thames Television Limited; Tyne-Tees
Television Limited; Ulster Television Limited; Westward Television
Limited; and Yorkshire Television Limited. A common news service is
provided by Independent Television News Limited, a non-profit-making
company in which all the programme companies are shareholders.
The Authority has controlling and regulatory powers of a wide and
important character over the content and quality of programmes: for example,
it ensures that a ‘proper balance’ of views is expressed and has drawn up a
code on violence stating that special precautions are to be taken when children
are likely to be viewing. There are also safeguards in the Television Act 1964
to prevent newspaper shareholdings in a programme company leading to
results contrary to the public interest. However, the IT A believes that
newspapers bring valuable qualities to the development of television and is
not opposed to investment by them.
In the discharge of its duties the IT A is advised by a General Advisory
Council and by committees on educational broadcasting, religious broad¬
casting, charitable appeals and advertising. A specialist panel advises on
medical and allied advertisements.
The chief executive officer of the IT A is the Director General. There are
also two deputy directors general, and a headquarters and regional office staff
covering all technical and administrative services. Regional officers act as
representatives of the IT A to the programme companies.
There is an Independent Television Companies Association, a body
designed for joint discussion and action by the companies. It is particularly
concerned with advertising policy, in co-operation with the ITA.
The ITA receives no payments from licence revenue; the finance for its
operations is drawn from annual rental payments made to it by the programme
companies amounting to over £8-5 million in the year ended March 1968.
In return for the valuable public concession enjoyed, the programme com¬
panies also paid to the ITA for transfer to the Exchequer a further sum
(the levy) related to their advertising revenue (see p. 435); this amounted to
about £25 million during the same period.
Sound The BBC operates its domestic sound broadcasting services from 1 long-wave
Broadcasting an(l 62 medium-wave transmitters at 45 transmitting stations, and from
228 very high frequency (VHF) transmitters at 75 stations. The VHF service
is available to over 99 per cent of the population of the United Kingdom.
Regular stereophonic broadcasts of music on the BBC’s VHF programmes
began in 1966.
In addition there are 69 transmitters for the external broadcasting services,
44 in the United Kingdom and 25 overseas for relay purposes, including a
station on Ascension Island, in the Atlantic.
There are 144 studios for the domestic sound programmes, of which 64
are in London and 80 at various centres in the regional areas. The external
services use 33 London studios. There are also 39 semi-automatic studios
which can be operated by programme staff without engineering assistance.
Domestic Services Each of the separate, but inter-related, domestic sound services has its own
characteristics. Radio 1 (broadcasting 18 hours a day in conjunction with
External Services
SOUND AND TELEVISION BROADCASTING 433
Radio 2) provides a programme of continuous popular music. At other times
of the day Radio 2 also provides light music and entertainment programmes.
Three-quarters of the daily radio audience listen to these services. Radio 3
includes the Music Programme (which provides a range of classical music for
some 10 hours during the day), the Third Programme, which offers works of
artistic and intellectual distinction each evening (and has an estimated
audience of 1^ million people), educational sessions and a sports service on
Saturday afternoons. Radio 4 (broadcasting 17 hours a day) is a general
programme providing the principal news and information services of the
BBC. In addition a wide range of music and drama is presented; broadcasts
for schools are an important feature. The various regions of Britain have their
own version of the service.
Eight local radio stations, run by the BBC, are broadcasting on an experi¬
mental basis in Brighton, Durham, Leeds, Leicester, Merseyside, Nottingham,
Sheffield and Stoke. The stations daily transmit some four or five hours of
programmes of particular interest to the local community which they serve.
The external broadcasting services of the BBC are intended to provide a link
of culture, information and entertainment between the peoples of the United
Kingdom and those in other parts of the world; to report events of world-wide
importance with speed, accuracy and objectivity; and generally to reflect
British opinion and the British way of life. These services are broadcast in
English and in 39 other languages for some 700 hours a week. The external
services news department provides more than 150 news bulletins every day.
The services are divided into the European Services and the Overseas
Services: the European Services broadcast over 250 programme hours a week.
They comprise an English service, heard throughout Europe, and services in
18 other languages, including French (providing programmes for both
European and African listeners), German, and the languages of countries of
eastern, central and southern Europe; the Overseas Services, which are
directed to countries outside Europe, broadcast over 450 programme hours a
week. They comprise the BBC World Service with its audience of English-
speaking listeners, which broadcasts 24 hours a day, and a number of regional
services in English and 22 other languages. These regional services consist of
the African, Arabic, Eastern, Far Eastern, and the Latin American Service.
Special programmes are provided for North America (including French for
Canada), the Caribbean, the Falkland Islands, Malta and Mauritius.
The external services include the English by Radio and Television, Trans¬
cription, Topical Tapes, and Monitoring Services. The English by Radio
service transmits some 230 programmes of English lessons weekly, with
explanations in 29 other languages, reaching an audience of several millions by
direct transmission from London and by re-broadcasts from some 270 local
stations. BBC English-teaching courses on gramophone records and tapes are
on sale in most countries. Two English by Television series have been seen in
over 60 countries. The Transcription Service records nearly 400 hours of
BBC radio programmes annually, distributing them to radio stations in all
parts of the world. The Topical Tapes Service produces 15 weekly pro¬
gramme series which are sent to 60 subscribing radio stations. The Monitoring
Service provides news reports from foreign broadcasts; it has an exchange
agreement with its United States counterpart which gives virtually world-wide
coverage.
The government departments concerned writh overseas relations prescribe
the languages and hours of external broadcasting, but tne content of the
programmes remains the responsibility of the BBC.

The BBC maintains offices in New York, Ottawa, Toronto, Buenos Aires,
Sydney, New Delhi, Singapore, Beirut, Berlin and Paris.
In 1936 the BBC launched the world’s first regular public service by high
definition television. Two programmes are now being transmitted: BBC 1,
which is available to over 99 per cent of the population of Britain from
93 transmitting stations; and BBC 2, at present from 29 stations, which is
available to more than two-thirds of the population. During 1967 the first
regular colour television service in Europe began on BBC 2. BBC 1 is trans¬
mitted on 405 lines on very high frequency (VHF) and BBC 2 on 625 lines on
ultra-high frequency (UHF). A duplicate BBC 1 service with colour is to be
introduced on 625 lines on UHF by 1970. In the course of a year, the BBC
television service broadcasts on a national network for some 6,100 hours.
BBC studio productions in London come from 16 main studios. The BBC
also has fully equipped regional studio centres at Manchester, Birmingham,
Cardiff, Glasgow, Bristol and Belfast; these centres contribute programmes
to the national network as well as producing others of only local interest.
In addition a number of small interview studios (used mainly for short
insertions into news bulletins) have been established throughout the country.
Outside broadcasting covers most parts of Britain with its mobile units.
Self-contained television services are available in Wales and Scotland.
The first regular independent television (ITV) service was inaugurated in
1955 by a programme transmission from the ITA London station at Croydon.
In 1968 programmes were being transmitted on 405 lines on VHF from 32
stations throughout Britain reaching more than 98 per cent of the population.
By 1970 duplicate ITV programmes with colour will be introduced on 625
lines on UHF.
Independent television is organised on a regional basis. Programmes are
produced at studio centres in Aberdeen, Belfast, Birmingham, Bristol, Cardiff,
Carlisle, Dover, Glasgow, Leeds, London, Manchester, Newcastle, Norwich,
Plymouth, St. Helier, and Southampton; they are designed for either local or
national broadcasting. The programme companies broadcast for some 3,500
hours a year in each region.
Both the BBC and the ITV services include news, talks and documentary
programmes and programmes of music, drama, light entertainment, films,
sport and outside broadcasts. Religious broadcasts, broadcasts for schools and
educational programmes for adults are also features. There are programmes
designed to stimulate thought and widen people’s horizons, such as interviews
with outstanding personalities, investigations into matters of public interest,
and programmes on the arts; and there are programmes of specialised interest
such as children’s and family programmes, programmes for women and
regional programmes. In addition, there are special series of party political
broadcasts under arrangements agreed between the broadcasting authorities
and the leading political parties. The use of a second BBC channel offers
greater opportunities for the provision of programmes for minority interests
or particular needs such as further education including the proposed Open
University (see p. 156). The Corporation estimates that its average viewing
audience for documentary programmes is some 8^ million.
The BBC seeks to avoid giving publicity to any individual firm or organised
interest except when it is necessary to provide effective and informative
programmes under the terms of the Charter. It must not broadcast sponsored
