programmes or, without the consent of the Postmaster General, broadcast any
matter for payment. Advertisements are broadcast on independent television
subject to the relevant provisions in the Television Act, in particular that
there should be no sponsoring of programmes by advertisers, that all adver¬
tisements should be clearly distinguishable as such and recognisably separate
from the programme, and the amount of time given to advertising should not
be so great as to detract from the value of the programmes as a medium of
information, education and entertainment. The IT A has drawn up a Code
governing standards and practice in advertising, giving guidance about the
types and methods of advertisement that may not be used. Certain types of
advertising are prohibited, notably that of cigarettes (under a Government
ruling of 1965). Advertisements may not be inserted in certain types of
programmes, for example, in broadcasts to schools. The cost of inserting
advertisements in the ITA service is borne by the advertisers, who pay the
programme companies for advertising time.
Wire relay systems receive programmes at a central point, and from there
distribute them by wire to listeners and viewers. Wire relay companies are not
allowed to originate programmes of their own; their function is to distribute
programmes put out by authorised broadcasting stations. A specified minimum
of their programme material must be taken from BBC sources. At the beginning
of 1968 there were some 850 wire relay services, of which some 680 provided
both sound and television. The number of subscribers at that date was nearly
i*5 million, more than i-2 million of whom were receiving television services.
An experiment in pay television is being undertaken by a company, Pay-TV
Ltd., in two areas of Britain. The service is operated over wire relay systems
as an additional programme; subscribers pay for the programmes they choose
to view. The service is subject to the same code of conduct as applies to
existing television services.
The Postmaster General is advised on the technical aspects of television and
VHP sound broadcasting by the Television Advisory Committee, which
consists of an independent chairman, the Director General of the BBC, the
Director General of the ITA, representatives from the radio industry, indepen¬
dent members, and representatives of interested government departments.
Research into technical problems is carried out by the scientific and
engineering staffs of the BBC, the ITA, the Post Office and the radio industry.
Recent developments by the BBC include: the electronic conversion of mono¬
chrome and colour television pictures between the European and the American
systems; and the reproduction of television pictures in slow motion.
The BBC and the ITA (together with the Independent Television Companies
Association) are active members of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU),
which was established to advance international broadcasting projects. The
union now has 28 full members among the broadcasting organisations in
Western Europe and 40 associate members (mostly from outside Europe,
including the United States of America and many of the nations of the
Commonwealth). It maintains a technical monitoring station, where frequency
measurements and other observations on broadcasting stations are carried out.
The range of inter-Commonwealth broadcasting co-operation is very wide.
The BBC provides a large amount of technical aid, particularly in staff
training to Commonwealth broadcasting organisations. Members of the BBC’s

Eurovision
Inter-continental
Television
staff are also seconded for service overseas. The BBC, the Australian Broad¬
casting Commission, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, the New
Zealand Broadcasting Corporation, the Rank Organisation and Reuters have
jointly set up Visnews Ltd., a Commonwealth and international newsfilm
agency which provides a daily service of international news on film for more
than no television subscribers in 68 countries. United Press International, a
television newsfilm agency, and Independent Television News are jointly
providing an international service to television stations by satellite (see below).
The BBC’s Radio and Television Enterprises undertake the world-wide
sale of BBC sound and television programmes; they also buy material for the
use of the BBC services. Overseas sales of ITV programmes are undertaken by
the separate programme companies.
Both the BBC and the independent television companies are associated
with the Centre for Educational Television Overseas (CETO), which helps
education in developing countries through television. The centre receives an
annual grant from the Government of £70,000, but most of its funds come
from private sources, including the independent television companies. The
BBC provides free technical and other facilities. Training in television work is
also provided for overseas trainees at the Thomson Centre, in Glasgow, run
by the Thomson Foundation, a charitable trust. The Ministry of Overseas
Development is spending about £100,000 annually on radio and television
training for overseas students in Britain.
The BBC and the ITA also participate in the work of the International
Telecommunication Union (ITU)—the United Nations specialised agency
responsible for the regulation and control of all international telecommuni¬
cation services (including sound and television), for the allocation and
registration of all radio frequencies and, through its international consultative
committees, for the promotion and co-ordination of the international study of
technical problems in broadcasting.
The BBC is a regular contributor to the network of European television (Euro¬
vision). This network now includes 23 organisations in Western European
member countries; the exchange of television programmes between them is
arranged by the EBU, which maintains an International Television Co-ordin¬
ation Centre (Eurovision) in Brussels. The range of Eurovision is steadily
increasing as countries expand their networks and facilities, and new countries
participate. Successful programme exchanges have also been made between
Moscow and London by both the BBC and the ITV companies.
The first inter-continental television relay across the Atlantic by means of
Telstar, the communication satellite, was seen in Britain in 1962; it was
followed by live programme exchanges between Europe and America, and in
1964 between Europe and Japan by Telstar II. In 1965 the Early Bird
synchronous satellite marked a further significant advance in inter-continental
television by the first transatlantic exchange of programmes; simultaneous
two-way live television was achieved for the first time between Europe and
America. Early Bird is stationary relative to the earth over the Atlantic, and
thus permits continuous contact between ground stations on opposite sides
of the North Atlantic. The first exchange of live television between Britain
and Australia took place at the end of 1966 via the Intelsat II satellite. An
important advance in international communications was the development by
BBC engineers of the standards converter which enables programmes in
colour, using the American system, to be transmitted live by satellite and
re-broadcast in Britain and Europe using another system.
18 THE PRESS
The British press caters for all political views, different levels of education
and a wide range of interests. It is not subject to State control or censorship.
A very large number of newspapers per person are sold in Britain every day,
and although there are relatively few national newspapers, some of them have
circulations comparable with the greatest in any other part of the world. Ten
of the national newspapers (five dailies and five Sundays) and one London
evening newspaper have circulations in the millions.
The high daily consumption of newspapers in Britain is partly due to the
fact that the term ‘daily’ covers both morning and evening newspapers and
that most people buy both. It is also due to the concentration of the population
in a relatively small area and the highly developed system of distribution,
which means that the national newspapers are available almost everywhere on
the day of publication.
Britain imports just over half its newsprint requirements, about million
tons annually, while the rest is made from imported raw materials. The average
size of national morning newspapers varies between 13 and 26 pages, and that
of the Sunday newspapers between 27 and 38. The price of the national
mornings ranges from 3d. to 8d. and that of the national Sunday newspapers
from 6d. to is. od. In addition to their normal paging a few newspapers carry
regular weekly colour supplements. The Times issues an entirely separate
Business News section with every edition.
According to The Newspaper Press Directory1 133 daily and Sunday news¬
papers and just over 1,200 local (mainly weekly) newspapers are published in
Britain. These figures include certain specialised papers, the circulations of
which are limited not by region, but by interest; for instance, business news¬
papers, sporting newspapers, newspapers in foreign languages for groups of
nationals of other lands resident in Britain, and religious newspapers.
Ownership Newspaper ownership in Britain is concentrated mainly in the hands of a
comparatively small number of large press groups, although a large proportion
of provincial newspaper enterprises are still private companies and there are
some instances of individual and partnership proprietorship. The six major
newspaper and periodical publishers are: International Publishing Corpora¬
tion Limited; Associated Newspapers Limited; Beaverbrook Newspapers
Limited; the Thomson Organisation Limited; United Newspapers Publica¬
tions Limited; and S. Pearson Publishers Limited.
The large national newspaper and periodical publishers are major corpora¬
tions with diversified interests over the whole field of publishing and com¬
munications, and some have shares in the independent television contracting
companies. The International Publishing Corporation and the Thomson
Organisation Limited also have newspaper interests overseas.
Although pronounced views may be expressed in newspapers and their
political leanings may be obvious, they are financially independent of any
political party and not obliged to follow any specific party line. In order to
preserve their character and traditions, certain newspapers and periodicals
1 Changes in the number of newspapers occur constantly; figures are based on the
1968 edition of The Newspaper Press Directory.

The ‘National*

Provincial
Newspapers
(including The Guardian and The Observer) are governed by arrangements
which vest ownership of the undertaking in trustees, or operate it in accord¬
ance with a deed of trust, or provide that the transfer of shares be in the hands
of trustees. Others have management arrangements intended to ensure the
authority and independence of the editors.
The trend towards concentration of newspaper ownership, which began in
the early nineteen hundreds and was accentuated after the second world war,
giving rise to some public concern lest press monopoly would affect freedom
of information, was studied by two Royal Commissions on the Press, one of
which reported in 1949 and the other in 1962. The results of the recommenda¬
tions of these Commissions included the establishment and reconstitution of
the Press Council; the provision in the Television Act 1963 which stipulates
that, if it appears to the Independent Television Authority at any time that
newspaper shareholdings in television programme companies have led or are
leading to results which are contrary to the public interest, the Authority may,
with the consent of the Postmaster General, notify the companies that their
programmes may cease to be transmitted; and the provision in the Monopolies
and Mergers Act 1965 which gives the Board of Trade powers to control the
transfer of a newspaper or newspaper assets to a newspaper proprietor whose
newspapers have an average daily circulation amounting, with that of the
newspaper to be taken over, to 500,000 or more copies, after (in some cases)
the Board of Trade has received a report from the Monopolies Commission
(see p. 238).
Technological advances in the newspaper industry include the introduction
of web-offset lithography (which is often combined with photo-composition
and the use of the computer in the composing room) and facsimile
transmission.
Ten morning papers are ‘national’ in the sense of circulating throughout
the British Isles, and there are seven national Sunday papers (see Table 39).
All the national dailies are produced in London, but those with big circulations
also print northern editions in Manchester, and two have Scottish editions
printed in Edinburgh and Glasgow respectively. The leading Scottish papers
{The Scotsman and The Glasgow Herald) have a considerable circulation
outside Scotland. Each of the (two) London evening papers has ownership
affiliations with a national daily, but both have their distinctive style, drawing
their readership very largely from people living in and around London.
The provincial newspapers of England and Wales (86 morning or evening
dailies and Sundays and 835 newspapers appearing once or twice a week)
provide mainly regional and local news. Some of the daily newspapers also
give extensive coverage to national affairs, and a number co-operate to
provide their own foreign news service. The leading provincial newspapers
have wide regional circulations; a few have nation-wide reputations.
Generally speaking, provincial evening newspapers are non-political, while
the morning newspapers are independent or conservative in outlook.
The total circulation of the provincial morning and evening papers is
estimated at about 8 million. Of the morning papers The Journal (Newcastle),
the Yorkshire Post (Leeds), the Northern Echo (Darlington) and the Western
Mail (Cardiff) have circulations of over 100,000 and two provincial Sunday
papers—the Sunday Sun (Newcastle upon Tyne) and the Sunday Mercury
(Birmingham)—have circulations of over 200,000. Individual circulation

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
figures of provincial evening papers start at about 25,000; most are in the
50,000-100,000 range; a few have circulations of over 400,000. Weekly
papers are mainly of local appeal; they are also a valuable medium for local
advertising. Most have circulations in the 8,000-35,000 range, but one or two
have much higher circulations of up to 100,000.
The London local weeklies (151) include papers for every district in
Greater London. They are assembled mainly in groups of six to eight,
affiliated in some cases to larger groups.
Scotland has six morning, seven evening and twro Sunday newspapers, in
addition to the Scottish editions of the Daily Express, Daily Mail and Sunday
Express. The leading morning papers are The Glasgow Herald (circulation
85,097) and The Scotsman, published in Edinburgh (circulation 74,395)-
Others are: the Daily Record and the Noon Record, published in Glasgow,
the Courier and Advertiser, published in Dundee, and the Press and Journal
of Aberdeen. Evening papers include the Edinburgh Evening News and
Dispatch, Glasgow’s Evening Times and Evening Citizen, Dundee s Evening
Telegraph and Post, Aberdeen’s Evening Express, the Paisley Daily Express
and the Greenock Telegraph and Clyde Shipping Gazette. The Sunday papers
are the Sunday Mail and the Sunday Post.
Weekly newspapers published in Scotland number 146. The most widely
known is the People's Journal and Weekly News which has many local
editions.
Northern Ireland has two morning newspapers, one evening paper and one
Sunday paper, all published in Belfast: they are The News-Letter (Unionist)
and the Irish News (Nationalist), the evening Belfast Telegraph and the
Sunday News. There are 42 weekly newspapers in Northern Ireland, with
circulations ranging from about 5,000 to over 25,000. The majority are
published by individual companies.
One daily morning newspaper, the Western Mail, published in Cardiff, has a
circulation of 100,905, mainly in southern Wales. In north Wales the
Liverpool Daily Post gives wide coverage to events in the area. Evening
papers published in Wales are the South Wales Echo, Cardiff, the South
Wales Argus, Newport, and the South Wales Evening Post, Swansea. North
Wales is served by the Liverpool Echo and to a smaller extent by the Manchester
Evening News. ,
The weekly press (some 55 papers) includes the English language papers
(by far the largest category), some of which carry articles in Welsh; three
bilingual papers; and 11 papers in Welsh, of which five are denominational.
The Channel Islands have two daily (evening) papers (one in Guernsey and
one in Jersev), the Guernsey Star with morning and evening editions and a
Sunday paper (Island Sun) and two weeklies, which also circulate in Alderney
and Sark. The Isle of Man Times is issued from Mondays to Wednesdays with
a special weekly edition which is published on Friday: there are four ot er
weeklies.
There are over 4,600 periodical publications in Britain, classified as general
and specialised’ and ‘trade, technical and professional’. There are also over
1 000 ‘house magazines’ produced by industrial undertakings business
houses or public services for the benefit of their employees and/or clients.
THE PRESS
441
General and specialised periodicals include magazines of general interest;
women’s magazines; publications for children; religious periodicals for all
denominations; fiction magazines; magazines dealing with sport, gardening,
hobbies, and humour; journals specialising in various subjects such as politics,
finance and economics, science, agriculture, medicine and the arts; and the
publications of learned societies, trade unions, regiments, universities and
other associations.
The weekly periodicals with the highest sales in Britain are: Woman
(2,760,455); Woman's Own (2,109,925); Woman's Weekly (1,673,128);
Woman's Realm (1,263,704); and Weekend (1,281,786); Reveille (1,246,124);
together with the Radio Times (4,007,248) and TV Times1 (2,494,351). The
leading journals of opinion are The Economist (circulation 99,709), a politically
independent publication covering topics from a wider angle than its title
implies; the New Statesman (circulation 89,371), which is a review of politics,
literature and the arts with an independent socialist political tendency; the
Spectator, which covers much the same subjects from an independent con¬
servative standpoint; Tribune, which has a strongly left-wing but anti-com¬
munist bias; New Society, which covers the sociological aspects of current
affairs; and New Scientist, which reports on the progress of science and
technology in terms which the non-specialist can understand. Punch (116,086),
traditionally the leading humorous periodical, has in recent years devoted
increasing attention to public affairs.
Literary and political journals and those specialising in international and
Commonwealth affairs, published monthly or quarterly, generally speaking
appeal to the more serious type of reader.
Business magazines include technical, trade, export and professional and
semi-professional journals, the publication of which has become one of the
more important aspects of the British publishing industry. In addition to
circulating in Britain, these journals have a considerable circulation outside
the United Kingdom and are an important media for selling British goods
overseas. Their publication ranges in frequency from weekly to quarterly.
In addition to the circulation of periodicals published in England, a farming
weekly, the Welsh Farm News, and several monthly and quarterly journals
in both Welsh and English are produced in Wales.
Four monthly illustrated periodicals are published in Scotland: Scottish
Field, Scotland's Magazine, Scots Magazine and Scotland; and two weeklies
devoted to farming interests, Farming News and Scottish Farmer. Among
literary journals, probably the most famous is Blackwood's, published in
Edinburgh. Numerous popular magazines are also published in Scotland.
In Northern Ireland, weekly, monthly and quarterly publications cover
farming, the linen industry, building, motoring, politics and social work.
News Agencies There are three principal British news agencies :
Reuters Ltd. is a world news agency owned by the newspapers of the
United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand through the Newspaper
Publishers Association, the Press Association, the Australian Associated Press
and the New Zealand Press Association, and operated on a non-profit-making
basis under the terms of a deed of trust which guarantees the independence
and integrity of the news service and ensures that all profits are used to
develop it. Founded in Aix-la-Chapelle in 1850 and transferred to London

in 1851, Reuters has about 1,000 correspondents in some 570 cities throughout
the world, and links with 53 associated news agencies, which give it access to
coverage by many thousands of local reporters. Some half a million words of
news and Economic Services reports are received in London every day from
which regionalised news, specially tailored to the needs of recipients in the
United Kingdom and eight main overseas regions, are transmitted through
an extensive private network of communications to 124 countries, and are
distributed to approximately 6,600 daily newspapers with an aggregate
circulation of 300 million, as well as to radio and television networks feeding
nearly 650 million sets. Reuters Economic Services supply a comprehensive
service of market prices and financial reports to some 5,800 private sub¬
scribers throughout the world. A computerised message-handling system is
used to speed up the handling and distribution of news.
Press Association Ltd., the British national news agency founded in 1868,
is co-operatively owned by the principal newspapers of the British Isles
outside London. It provides London and provincial newspapers, the broad¬
casting organisations and Reuters with complete service of home news,
including general and parliamentary news, legal reports, and all branches of
financial, commercial and sports news. Provincial papers are also supplied
with the world news of Reuters and the Associated Press. Through its
Photographic Department the Press Association serves London and provincial
newspapers with a daily picture service, including its own world photos and
those of the Associated Press, by wire broadcast to the provinces. Its Special
Service Department supplies reports of local or special interest to daily and
weekly trade papers and periodicals. All profits are used to develop the service.
Exchange Telegraph Company Ltd. (Extel), an independent news agency
founded in 1872, is a public company with over 1,000 shareholders, which
supplies financial and sporting news to newspapers and broadcasting organisa¬
tions. Racing services are also supplied by teleprinter and telephone to
subscribers in London and the provinces from offices in all important cities
and towns. . . ,
Associated Press Ltd., which is the British operating company of the
Associated Press of America, supplies a world-wide overseas news service to
the British press and broadcasting organisations.
A number of other United Kingdom, Commonwealth and foreign agencies
and news services have offices in London, and there are agencies in other
cities, specialising in various aspects of newspaper and periodical requirements.
Syndication of features is not as common in the United Kingdom as in some
countries, but a few agencies specialise in this type of work.
The training of British journalists comes under the Industrial Training Board
for the Printing and Publishing Industry1 as a statutory operation. The national
training scheme is at present run by the National Council for the Training o
Journalists, which represents the principal press organisations. The scheme,
which is compulsory for all junior entrants and in which adult entrants also
participate whenever possible, consists of a six-month probationary period
followed by a three-year apprenticeship (two years for graduates). During t e
apprenticeship, trainees combine on-the-job experience with eight-week
residential training courses at centres established by the National Council
throughout Britain. There are now seven of these centres for reporters (five in

England, one in Wales, and one in Scotland) and one centre for photographers.
The syllabus covers practical journalism, shorthand, English, law, government
and current affairs, and at the end of their apprenticeship trainees take a
professional examination organised by the National Council. The centres
also run specialist courses for senior journalists, particularly in sub-editing
and new production techniques.
Recent developments in training include: the start of pre-entry courses
lasting a year for students who have reached a recognised educational level;
preparations for a postgraduate course at Sussex University; and the introduc¬
tion of a training scheme for journalists on magazines and other periodicals.
Under the Commonwealth Press Union Travelling Fellowship Scheme for
the training and education of young journalists throughout the Common¬
wealth, each year about eight journalists from overseas spend five months
in the United Kingdom: two months in the offices of newspapers or
periodicals and three months acquiring a general idea of life in Britain.
A limited number of travelling scholarships are also awarded to British
journalists to enable them to visit Commonwealth countries overseas.
The Thomson Foundation provides scholarships and organises training
courses at the Foundation’s Centre in Cardiff for journalists from all parts of
the world.
Both employers and employees in the industry are well organised. On the
employers’ side the most important organisations are the Newspaper
Publishers Association, whose members are proprietors of the national
daily and Sunday newspapers; the Newspaper Society, which represents
the regional and London suburban press; the Scottish Daily Newspaper
Society, which represents the interests of daily and Sunday newspapers in
Scotland; the Scottish Newspaper Proprietors Association, which represents
the owners of weekly newspapers in Scotland; Associated Northern Ireland
Newspapers, whose members are the proprietors of weekly newspapers
in Northern Ireland; and the Periodical Publishers Association, whose
membership embraces the independent publishers of trade and technical
publications and general magazines. On the employees’ side there are the
Institute of Journalists (loj), founded in 1884 as the National Association
of Journalists, and the National Union of Journalists (NUJ), founded in 1907.
All working journalists (including those engaged in radio, television, public
relations and freelance journalism) are eligible for membership of both these
organisations. To facilitate an eventual merger, an interim arrangement has
been made for dual membership without the payment of extra subscriptions.
The aims of the NUJ and the loj are the improvement of the economic status
of journalists, the promotion of their professional welfare, and the safeguarding
of the status of the press and its editorial staffs. Total membership is nearly
23,000 (NUJ about 20,500, loj about 2,350).
The main aims of the Guild of British Newspaper Editors are to sustain
the dignity of editorship, to raise and safeguard the professional status of
editors, to protect the rights and freedom of the press, and to improve the
education and training of journalists: the Guild has about 350 members. The
British Association of Industrial Editors is the professional organisation to
which most editors of house journals belong.
The Printing and Kindred Trades Federation is the federation of the
printing trade unions which include the National Graphical Association, the
Society of Graphical and Allied Trades, and the Scottish Typographical
Association.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Press
Council
The Press and
the Law
The Press Council, established in 1953 and reconstituted in 1963, has a lay-
chairman and 25 members. Its aims are: to preserve the established freedom
of the British press; to maintain the character of the British press in
accordance with the highest professional and commercial standards; to keep
under review any developments likely to restrict the supply of information of
public interest and importance; to deal with complaints about the conduct
of the press or the conduct of persons and organisations towards the press; to
report on developments in the British press which may tend towards greater
concentration or monopoly; to make representation on appropriate occasions
to the Government, to organs of the United Nations and to press organisations
abroad; to publish its adjudications and periodical reports recording its work
and to review from time to time developments in the British press and the
factors affecting them. Reports, which include statistics of the newspaper and
periodical press and a series of articles examining the structure of the leading
press groups, are published annually.
The press in Britain has the same freedom as the individual to do and say
what it likes provided it does not transgress the law; in general, it is at liberty
to comment on matters of public interest. Apart from enactments relating
directly to such matters as the registration of newspapers for postal purposes,
there are no specific press laws but certain statutes include clauses which
apply, in particular or incidentally, to the press. These relate to such matters
as the extent of newspaper ownership in television companies; the transfer of
newspaper assets (see p. 438); restrictions on newspaper reporting of prelim¬
inary hearings of indictable offences (in England, Wales and Northern Ireland);
the right of press representatives to be admitted to meetings of local authori¬
ties ; restrictions on the publication of (a) divorce and domestic proceedings in
courts of law, (b) advertisement and investment circulars, which are governed
by Acts dealing with fraud, and (c) advertisements of remedies for certain
diseases, which are covered by public health legislation; agreements between
the Post Office and newspaper proprietors on telegraphic communications,
which must comply with telegraphs legislation; restrictions on certain types of
prize competition; and copyrights, which come under copyright laws.
Of particular relevance to the work of the press are the laws on: libel and
defamation; contempt of court—a newspaper may not publish comments
on the conduct of judicial proceedings which are likely to prejudice their
reputation for fairness before or during the actual proceedings nor may it
publish before or during a trial anything which might tend to influence the
result; and seditious libel, incitement to disaffection and revealing official
secrets.
Legal proceedings against the press are comparatively infrequent; the
majority of actions that do take place are libel actions brought by private
individuals. In such cases, the editor, proprietor, publisher, printer and
distributor of the newspaper, as well as the author of the article, may all be
held responsible.
19 SPORT
Central and
Local
Government
Participation
In Britain, the word ‘sport’ is used generally to describe such activities as
organised outdoor games, athletics, field or country sports, indoor games and
sports, aquatic sports, and such popular pursuits as horse-racing, greyhound
racing, show jumping, riding, rock climbing, orienteering, motor racing, and
rifle shooting as well as those (for instance, archery, fencing, gliding and
skating) which, although less popular judged by the number of participants
and spectators, all have their own devotees. Those who engage in sport may be
professionals (that is, paid players) or amateurs.1 Professionals keep up the
technical standards of the sports in which they take part and spectators make
a vital contribution by their enthusiasm and their financial support; but the
sporting life of Britain derives its character principally from the amateur
element—people who devote time and energy to organising sport and to
teaching and training, as well as the many thousands of all ages who engage
in sport for pleasure alone.
The Government is not directly concerned with the organisation or promotion
of sport in Britain but it has assumed responsibility for providing encourage¬
ment, guidance and help; it gives financial aid to national and local voluntary
organisations towards approved expenditure on playing fields, swimming
baths and other facilities for physical recreation, and to national governing
bodies of sport in Great Britain towards the cost of their administration and
coaching schemes and for the holding of world championships and events of
similar importance in Britain. The Government is advised on matters relating
to the development of amateur sport and physical recreation by the Sports
Council, whose members serve in a voluntary capacity and are appointed for
their wide experience of all aspects of sport and recreation. The chairman of
the Council is the Parliamentary Under-Secretary for Education and Science,
who is the minister with special responsibility for sport. Nine regional
sports councils in England, one council in Scotland and one in Wales,
composed of members appointed by local authorities, representatives of
the government departments principally concerned, and selected members
of sporting organisations in the region, have also been set up as a means of
extending throughout the country the facilities planning work of the Council.
In Northern Ireland the Ministry of Education is advised by the Youth and
Sports Council.
The Council works in close co-operation with the Central Council of
Physical Recreation, the National Playing Fields Association, the Scottish
equivalents of these bodies, and the British Olympic Association.
In 1967 direct government expenditure on sport totalled £2 million. In
additional to capital grants towards the provision of facilities and grant-aid
towards the current costs of national voluntary organisations on adminis¬
tration and coaching, grant-aid was also given for research projects sponsored
by the Sports Council, and to recognised schools sports associations. Local
authorities also spend money on sports facilities, such expenditure being
1 Some sports, for example, athletics, Rugby Union football, hockey and rowing, are
entirely amateur, but in other sports the distinction between professional and amateur
status is becoming less strictly defined.

taken into account in determining the aggregate amount of Exchequer grant
to local authorities under the rate support grant system (see p. 72)-
In Northern Ireland £352,000 in grants was given to public authorities
and voluntary organisations for sports facilities and coaching schemes in 1967-
Facilities for The Secretary of State for Education and Science, the Secretary of State for
Sport Scotland and the Ministry of Education for Northern Ireland require that
all publicly maintained schools shall provide for the physical education
(gymnastics, games, athletics, dancing and swimming) of their pupils. Schools
in the national systems (excepting those solely for infants) must have their
own playing field, or the use of one, and most secondaiy schools have a
gymnasia and other amenities such as swimming pools, sports halls and halls
designed for dance and movement, which local education authorities are
encouraged to make available to the public in the evenings, at week-ends, and
during the school holidays. Facilities for, and instruction in, many kinds of
sport are likewise provided at the independent preparatory and public schools
and at the universities (some of which have departments of physical education).
Local authorities also provide playing fields, gymnasia, tennis courts, golf
courses, boating lakes, swimming baths and sports centres on an increasing
scale, and some arrange further education classes in various physical
education subjects. In addition, some larger industrial and commercial
undertakings have developed sports facilities for their employees.
Composite The national voluntary organisations most closely concerned with the general
National Bodies development of sport are the Central Council of Physical Recreation, the
Scottish Council of Physical Recreation, and the National Playing Fields
Association. The British Olympic Association, whose main functions are
connected with the participation of British teams and competitors in the
Olympic Games, is also interested in all matters likely to benefit sport or
physical recreation in Britain as a whole. In addition, each sport has its own
governing body, with, in most cases, entirely separate autonomous go\erning
bodies in Scotland and Northern Ireland.
The Central The Central Council of Physical Recreation (CCPR), which is an association
Council of Physical of all national bodies in England, Wales and Northern Ireland concerned with
Recreation the development of post-school physical recreation, provides the Sports
Council with such services as may be agreed in the administration, technical
and research fields. Its funds are partly raised by voluntary contributions but
it also receives grants from the Department of Education and Science and
from the Ministry of Education for Northern Ireland. Its General Secretary
is also the Director of the Sports Council.
The CCPR consists of about 300 members, over 200 of whom represent
national bodies concerned wholly or in part with the development of some
branch of physical recreation. The Council’s headquarters are in London and
it has nine regional offices in other parts of England. Its activities in Wales
are controlled by a representative Welsh committee, and in Northern Ireland
by a separate section with its own executive committee.
Broadly, the Council’s function is to promote all forms of physical
recreation. Its activities include the organisation of courses for coaches and
instructors, courses in personal performance, lectures, displays and other
publicity events. In 1967-68 over 2,000 such courses, attended by nearly
47,000 people, were organised. Its staff give advisory, technical and adminis¬
trative help wherever required, but particularly to the headquarters, regional,
county and local branches of the constituent organisations and to local

educational authorities and industrial concerns. Its regional officers are the
secretaries of the regional sports councils.
The Scottish Council of Physical Recreation (SCPR) is the counterpart in
Scotland of the CCPR, and has 140 affiliated organisations, including the
governing bodies of all the Scottish sports; it receives a grant-in-aid from
the Scottish Education Department.
The main aim of the National Playing Fields Association (NPFA) is to
stimulate the provision of playing fields, playgrounds and sports centres
especially for children, by publicity and technical and financial assistance.
Since its inception in 1925 it has distributed over million in the form of
grants for playing field and playground schemes and about ,£371,000 in the
form of loans. It assists more than 400 schemes a year.
The NPFA council is composed of representatives of the governing bodies
of various sports organisations, of the British Olympic Association and the
CCPR, and of a number of educational bodies, voluntary youth organisations,
physical education associations and local authorities. The national head¬
quarters in London employs a small full-time staff, including a technical and
research department which gives advice on all aspects of recreational
planning including the provision and layout of indoor and outdoor sports
facilities. Advice is also given on matters relating to the play and recreational
needs of children from their earliest years, and the establishment of play¬
grounds and play leadership schemes. The Association derives its funds
mainly from voluntary contributions but it also receives a small contribution
toward administrative costs from the Department of Education and Science.
The NPFA has branches in Scotland and Northern Ireland; there are also
branches in nearly every English and Welsh county; administration is carried
out, in the main, on a voluntary basis—in many cases in association with a
local authority or Rural Community Council.
There are five National Recreation Centres in Britain, outside London—-two
in England, one in Wales and two in Scotland—administered by the CCPR
and the SCPR. The centres, all but one of which were established by voluntary
funds, provide a wide range of courses for coaches, instructors and per¬
formers in many games, sports and other physical activities. A programme of
improvements, the capital cost of which will be borne by the Department of
Education and Science, and, for Scotland, by the Scottish Education Depart¬
ment, is being carried out and will continue over the next two or three years.
A sailing centre, likewise to be administered by the CCPR, is to be established,
at Cowes, Isle of Wight, to provide courses on sailing, boat handling, cruising,
navigation, racing, boat maintenance and boat building, for school and youth
groups and for adults.
The Crystal Palace National Recreation Centre in London covers 36 acres;
has a main stadium with seating for 12,000 spectators; a sports hall with
seating for 2,000 spectators; a swimming hall with pools of Olympic dimen¬
sions, a teaching pool and a gallery for 2,000 spectators; an indoor cricket
school; practice rooms suitable for all indoor activities; a hostel for 140
residents; and staff housing. The Centre, managed by the CCPR, is designed
not only to provide training facilities for leaders, coaches and athletes, but also
for international competitions.
Outdoor games played in Britain include team games such as football,
cricket, and hockey, and games such as lawn tennis and golf, in which
448
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Football
individuals or couples match their skill. Judged by the number of participants
and spectators, the most popular of the team games are football and cricket;
the most popular of the individual games is lawn tennis.
Although football of a kind was played in the Middle Ages or even earlier,
as an organised game it dates from just over a century ago. One type of
football, in which only the feet are used, was adopted at Cambridge in 1848;
the other type, in which the ball is handled as well as kicked, was first played
at Rugby School, whence it derives its name, and was adopted by the
Blackheath football club in 1859.
In England the controlling body of the non-handling game, Association
Football1 (‘soccer’), is the Football Association (FA) formed in 1863. Its chief
function is to promote the interests of the game and to prevent infringement
of the agreed rules; it also arranges for the instruction of promising young
players (some ^20,000 is spent annually on coaching); organises various
matches and competitions, including the international matches played by
England, the Amateur Cup competition, the FA Sunday Cup competition,
two national youth competitions, and the competition for its own leading
trophy, the Football Association Challenge Cup; and chooses and manages
English international teams. Over 350 clubs are registered with the FA, more
than 250 as full members and between no and 120 as associate members.
There are also some 25,000 clubs affiliated to county (that is, district or
regional) associations. The FA derives its main income from subscriptions
and admission charges to international and cup matches, and ploughs back a
large portion of the money into the game. Scotland, Northern Ireland and
Wales have their own controlling bodies: the Scottish Football Association,
the Irish Football Association and the Football Association of Wales.
The principal professional matches in England and Wales (played once or
twice weekly) are controlled by the Football League, which comprises 92
professional clubs in these countries. The funds of the League are derived
largely from contributions paid by member clubs in the form of a levy of
4 per cent of the net gate receipts from league matches, after allowable
expenses have been deducted; from annual payments from the leading
football pools promoters for the use of league fixture lists; and from television
rights.
In Scotland the Scottish Football League comprises 38 clubs; Northern
Ireland has its own League. Clubs belonging to the English and Scottish
Leagues are organised in divisions, the members of which compete against one
another for the respective league championships. Their positions in the
divisional tables are decided at the end of the season by the number of points
gained for wins or draws. During the season about 30 million people watch
Football League matches and gate receipts usually amount to between
£7 million and £8 million.
Several million people stake small weekly sums on the results of the league
matches by filling in what are known as ‘pools’ coupons. The odds against
winning anything in the pools are very great, but the prizes are high and
individual payments of ^300,000 are occasionally made. The promoters
deduct varying amounts from the stakes for commission and expenses.
The annual competition for the FA Cup is organised on a knock-out basis
and the Cup Final is one of the most important football matches of the year
1 Recommendations, for improving and developing association football as a sport, as a
maior public entertainment, and as a form of voluntary services, have been made in the
report of a Committee on Football appointed by the Department of Education and
Science in 1966.
SPORT
449
in England; it is always played at Wembley Stadium, near London, which
can accommodate some 100,000 spectators. The Scottish Cup Final is played
at Hampden Park, Glasgow. The matches between England, Scotland, Wales
and Ireland also excite great interest, as do other international matches.
There are many more amateur association football players than there are
professionals (the comparative figures are nearly 1 million amateurs, including
schoolboys and members of the armed forces, to 7,000 or 8,000 professionals),
but with one or two notable exceptions their teams cannot compete on equal
terms, since professional teams are more systematically and intensively
trained. Amateur teams compete against each other for the Football
Association Amateur Challenge Cup.
Rugby Football (‘rugger’) is played under the auspices of the Rugby
Football Union, established in 1871. The rules of the game are completely
different from those that govern soccer, and there are 15 players, instead of 11,
in a side. International matches between England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland,
and France are played regularly at the leading rugby football grounds of each
country, including Twickenham, London—the headquarters of the Rugby
Football Union—and there are tours by international teams to and from
New Zealand, Australia and South Africa. Other important rugger matches
are the county championship competitions, the annual match between the
universities of Oxford and Cambridge, the Hospitals’ Cup Final, and the
Inter-Services tournament. Membership of the Rugby Union is strictly
confined to amateur clubs of which there are over 1,600 in membership, with
981 schools.
Rugby League Football—a 13-a-side game played by professionals as well
as amateurs—is played in the north of England. The League, which was
instituted in 1895 and now has its headquarters at Leeds, regularly sends
touring teams to Australia and New Zealand and has annual international
games, professional and amateur, against France. The major match of the
season—the Rugby League Challenge Cup Final—has attracted crowds of
95,000 at Wembley Stadium in recent years.
Cricket is often called the English national game. It originated as a rustic
medieval pastime; by 1550 it is known to have been played by boys at
Guildford Grammar School, and after the Restoration it became fashionable
with the nobility, who competed with each other to sponsor matches for very
large sums of money. Among the many clubs founded in the eighteenth
century was the famous Hambledon Club in Hampshire, wdiose members
were cricket’s elite and supported the most brilliant players of the day. In 1787
the Marylebone Cricket Club (MCC) was founded in London and, assuming
responsibility for reframing the ‘Laws of Cricket’, became the governing body
of the game in Great Britain. Its first headquarters were at a ground on the
site of the present Dorset Square, rented by a Yorkshireman called Thomas
Lord, who gave his name to this and the two succeeding grounds. The second
ground, at which MCC was established from 1811 to 1813, was on the
perimeter of Regent’s Park. The present ground, at St. John’s Wood, was
opened in 1814.
Cricket in Britain is now governed by the MCC Cricket Council, made up
of representatives of MCC, the Test and County Board of Control (represent¬
ing first-class cricket) and the National Cricket Association (representing club
and junior cricket). MCC retains world-wide responsibility for the laws of
cricket.
The game is played in schools and universities, and most towns and villages,
as well as industrial sports clubs, have teams which play at least one match a
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
week from May to September. In the London area a large number of pitches
are provided by local authorities to augment those leased or owned by clubs.
In the Midlands and the north of England there is a network of League
cricket, contested by teams of Saturday afternoon players reinforced by one
or more professionals, often distinguished overseas players.
The focus of the season centres on a series of ‘Test matches’ played between
England and a touring team from overseas (or sometimes two teams). The
first of these matches was played in Melbourne between England and
Australia in 1877. Since then international tours have taken place regularly
between countries of Test status, who now number seven. The matches last
30 playing hours spread over five to six days and arouse great popular interest.
The principal grounds in England on which Test matches are played are
Lord’s; the Oval, Kennington, London, headquarters of Surrey County
Cricket Club; Old Trafford, Manchester; Trent Bridge, Nottingham;
Headingley, Leeds; and Edgbaston, Birmingham.
In addition to the Test matches a First Class County Championship,
decided on a points system, is played for by 17 counties, each playing 28
three-day matches. The counties not deemed first-class and second elevens of
the first-class counties play in a Minor Counties Championship. I he Univer¬
sity Elevens of Oxford and Cambridge rank as first-class and play an annual
match at Lord’s. Since 1963 the counties have also competed in a single
innings knock-out competition for the Gillette Cricket Cup.
Before the second world war the game was played by many top-class
amateurs. Modern economic conditions have, however, greatly reduced the
number of true amateurs who can afford to play full-time cricket so that,
since 1963, the distinction between amateur and professional in county and
Test cricket has been abolished. In 1968 the qualification rules were relaxed
to allow a limited number of top-class overseas cricketers to play in the
English county championships.
The forerunner of modern lawn tennis (the game known as;'eM depaume) was
introduced into England from France in the fifteenth century and a ‘tennis
court’, built by Henry VIII, is still in use at Hampton Court. The modern
game, first played in England in 1873? quickly became very popular, in 1877
the words ‘and lawn tennis’ were added to the title of the All England Croquet
Club at Wimbledon, near London, and in the same year the first championships
were played. The Lawn Tennis Association, the controlling body of the game
in Britain, was founded in 1888. The governing body of the game in the w orld
(the International Lawn Tennis Federation, with headquarters in London and
Paris) was founded in 1913.
The number of people who play lawn tennis has greatly increased during
the present century, particularly since the game has spread to practically
every country in the world. In Britain the game is played in almost all girls
schools and in very many boys’ schools where the pupils are of secondary
school age. It is also played on private courts, in parks and recreation grounds
and at several thousand tennis clubs.
The annual championships held at Wimbledon for two weeks at the end
of June and beginning of July are the main event of the lawn tennis season
in Britain and, in fact, in the world. These championships, in which men and
women of many nationalities compete, draw large crowds; there is accom¬
modation for over 30,000 spectators in the grounds of the All England Club
14,000 can be accommodated round the centre court where the finals are
played. Other tournaments which attract a good deal of attention are: the
British Hardcourt Championships, the British Junior Championships, and
SPORT
451
the County Championships. There are also competitions for boys’ and girls’
schools on a national basis. The most important international events are the
Davis Cup (for men) and the Federation Cup competition (for women).
Women players from Britain and the United States of America also compete
annually for the Wightman Cup.
Golf Golf originated in Scotland, where for centuries it has borne the title of the
Royal and Ancient Game, but it did not become really well known in the other
countries of the United Kingdom until towards the end of the nineteenth
century. Since then, however, it has gained steadily in popularity (particularly
since the mid-1950s); nowadays there are golf courses in the vicinity of many
towns and villages in all parts of Britain—some owned by local authorities,
but the majority owned by golf clubs—and the question of the game’s large
land requirements is being studied by the Department of Social and Economic
Research at the University of Glasgow. The headquarters of the Royal and
Ancient Golf Club is St. Andrews, Scotland.
The main event of the golfing year is the British Open Golf Championship,
which was first played in i860; other important matches include the Walker
Cup (for amateurs) and the Ryder Cup (for professionals), both played
between Britain and America; the Amateur Championship; the World
Amateur Team Championship; and the Ladies Championship.
Hockey Variants of hockey (as distinct from ice-hockey) have been played in Britain
for at least five centuries. Modern hockey, however, dates from the formation
(in 1886) of the Hockey Association of England, which standardised the rules
relating to men’s hockey. Nowadays men’s hockey is an Olympic sport; there
are some 2,000 men’s hockey clubs throughout Britain with 30,000 male adult
players; some 600 boys’ schools also play the game. Although there are no
professional county teams and no cup ties in England, a county championship
is held annually. In Scotland there is a Scottish cup competition and six local
league competitions and the Welsh Hockey Association organise a Welsh cup
competition. Regular amateur international matches (inaugurated in 1894) are
also played. Men’s hockey Olympic arrangements are in the hands of the
British Hockey Board, which comprises the Associations of England, Scotland
and Wales.
The controlling bodies of women’s hockey are: the All England Women’s
Hockey Association (founded 1895) to which are affiliated some 900 clubs and
2,200 schools, representing a total membership of about 72,000 adults and
1 • 1 million schoolgirls; the Irish Ladies Hockey Union; the Scottish Women’s
Hockey Association; and the Welsh Women’s Hockey Association. The first
international women’s hockey match took place in 1896. Nowadays such a
match is played annually at Wembley Stadium (in addition to those played in
other parts of the country), where it attracts some 60,000 spectators.
Lacrosse Lacrosse, adapted from the game played by the Iroquois Indians of North
America, is played mainly by women—in girls’ schools, at lacrosse clubs, and
at universities. International matches are played, as well as regional matches,
by women’s teams representing the East, West, South, North and Midlands
of England, under the auspices of the All England Women’s Lacrosse
Association.
The men’s game, of which the controlling body is the English Lacrosse
Union, is played in ten universities, six teacher-training colleges, and by clubs
and schools, mainly in the London, Manchester, Leeds, Sheffield and
Nottingham areas. Matches played include county matches, an annual fixture

Netball
Polo
Bowls
Mountaineering
between the North of England and the South, and international matches
between Australia, America, Canada and England.
Netball is a popular game for girls and women. The controlling body is the
All England Netball Association to which are affiliated the English county
associations, the netball clubs of the three Women’s Services and sections of
the national youth and university organisations for girls and women. Inter¬
county and home international matches are played regularly and inter-
Commonwealth tours are arranged.
Polo, of which the earliest records are Persian, was first played by the British
in India, and brought to England in 1869. The governing body of British
polo is the Hurlingham Polo Association to which all the Commonwealth
polo associations and that of South Africa are affiliated. Polo players are a very
small section of the community, for the cost of keeping polo ponies is high.
However, many of the clubs now own trained ponies which are hired out to
members at moderate cost. There are about 375 players handicapped by the
Hurlingham Polo Association, but many less expert players take part in club
games for which they may be locally handicapped.
Public interest in polo has increased in recent years and large numbers of
spectators attend inter-club tournaments and matches between high-handicap
teams composed of players from several countries.
The game of bowls has been played in Britain since the thirteenth century.
Nowadays the flat green game is regulated, as far as the English Bowling
Association is concerned, by the International Bowling Board (IBB), founded
in 1905. The Bowling Associations of Ireland, Scotland and Wales also come
under and play to the laws laid down by the IBB, but there are other bowling
associations in England—the English Bowling Federation, the Crown Green
Association and the English Women’s Bowling Association—which are not
under the IBB’s control.
During the summer bowls is played on bowling greens in the open; in
winter it is played on indoor greens, which are increasing in number. At one
time regarded as a pastime for the elderly, the game in now played by people
of all ages. Over 2,620 bowling clubs in England are affiliated to the English
Bowling Association alone. International, inter-county matches, and national
championship competitions of singles, pairs, triples and fours are played.
The popularity of mountaineering has greatly increased in recent years. The
number of clubs in the British Mountaineering Council (BMC) and the
Association of Scottish Climbing Clubs, the representative bodies of the sport,
has increased to over 160 in the last six years, mainly by the addition of smaller
town and district clubs and university and college clubs to the older, larger
clubs such as the Alpine Club (founded in 1857, the oldest mountaineering
club in the world), the Climbers’ Club, the Scottish Mountaineering Club and
the Fell and Rock Climbing Club. A number of local education authorities,
as well as national bodies such as the YMCA, the Scouts and the Central
Council of Physical Recreation, have established mountaineering training
centres in the hills. Training courses are run jointly by the CCPR and BMC,
the Mountaineering Association, the Youth Hostels Association and other
bodies, and many schools have mountaineering sections. Membership of the
known clubs is about 15,000 but several times this number take part in
climbing and mountaineering.
British mountaineers have taken a leading part in exploring most of the
great ranges of the world and in climbing their peaks; for example, the first
SPORT
Ski-ing
Athletics
Highland Games
453
ascent of the Matterhorn in 1865, of Everest in 1953, and of Kangchenjunga
in 1955. In recent years frequent expeditions have gone to far off mountains,
to Greenland, Alaska, the Andes, Patagonia, the Caucasus and the Pamirs,
as well as the Himalayas.
Ski-ing in Scotland has become very popular, especially at the winter sports
centres established in the Cairngorms, Deeside, Glencoe and Glenshee,
where ski-runs equal to those in other areas of Europe have been developed,
and ski-lifts, ski-tows and professional instruction are now available. There are,
in addition, 24 artificial ski-slopes in other parts of Britain.
Amateur athletics, which include running (track, road and cross-country),
relay racing, jumping, hurdling, throwing and race-walking, are governed by
the Amateur Athletic Association (AAA), which was founded in 1880 to
encourage amateur athletics, to improve the management of amateur athletic
meetings by the establishment of uniform regulations, and to promote annual
championship meetings. The Association, whose membership increased
rapidly, is now organised from club to national level by honorary officers
and managed by representative members appointed by the Northern, Midland,
Southern and Welsh areas and by affiliated clubs and associations (amateur
athletic clubs, schools and youth organisations), of which there are hundreds
throughout England and Wales. The AAA administers a coaching scheme
under which eight full-time national coaches, working mainly in separate
regions, lecture, demonstrate and coach in schools, youth clubs, evening
institutes, training colleges and universities and at special courses organised
by the national associations, by regional associations or by the Central Council
of Physical Recreation. Some of the work of the national coaches is directly
concerned with coaching young athletes but their main duties are to instruct
men who wish to qualify as honorary coaches, about 1,650 of whom give
voluntary services in the counties and districts of England and Wales. Scotland
and Northern Ireland have their own amateur athletic associations, with
similar functions; there are also separate women’s AAAs for each country.
International athletics and the selection of teams representing the United
Kingdom are dealt with by the British Amateur Athletic Board, which is
composed of representatives of the three national associations for men and
of the Women’s Council, and is affiliated to the International Amateur
Athletic Federation.
Track meetings are held throughout Britain from April to October. The
main events in England and Wales are: the AAA championships for men
and international matches held at the White City, London; area and county
championships; and the universities, Services, business houses and schools
championship meetings. Clubs usually compete in cross-country running
from October to March, and county, area and national cross-country
championships are held.
Teams representing Britain compete in the Olympic Games (held every
four years), and separate teams representing England, Wales, Scotland, and
Northern Ireland compete in the Commonwealth Games, held at four-yearly
intervals between the Olympic Games.
The Highland games are traditional gatherings of local people in the High¬
lands of Scotland, at which sports (including tossing the caber, putting the
weight, and throwing the hammer) and dancing and piping competitions
take place. Among the better known Highland games are the Braemar
Gathering on Deeside (traditionally attended by the royal family), the

Country Sports
Hunting
Shooting
Argyllshire Gathering at Oban, and the meeting at Aboyne. The Highland
games are a unique spectacle which attracts large numbers of spectators from
all over the world.
The most popular country sports are hunting, shooting and fishing; these are
old-established sports with a long history, and they still play a considerable
part in the life of the countryside. The organisation which looks after their
interests is the British Field Sports Society.
In Britain hunting means primarily fox hunting on horseback with a pack of
hounds; but it also includes stag hunting, which preceded fox hunting and
still goes on, mainly in Devon and Somerset; hunting the hare, either on foot
with beagles or with harriers when the followers are mounted; and otter
hunting along the banks of rivers. Hunting depends not on right but on the
goodwill of small landowners and farmers, the majority of whom support
their local hunt by allowing it to ride over their property.
Fox hunting originated some 200 years ago. Originally a sport mainly for
the landed gentry and local farmers, it has gradually widened its appeal, in
spite of the fact that it is an expensive pastime for those who ride to hounds.
The sport is not without its critics, but an ever larger number of people,
including many townsmen, take a keen interest in it. Most hunts meet two
or three times a week and it is estimated that between 25,000 and 30,000 people
ride to hounds weekly, and many others follow in cars, on bicycles or on foot.
The fox hunting season proper starts in early November and lasts until April;
it is preceded by cub hunting, that is, the hunting of young foxes, when young
hounds are trained. At the end of the season most hunts organise steeple¬
chases, known as point-to-points, which are patronised by large crowds.
There are 200 packs of hounds in England and Wales, 13 in Northern
Ireland, and 10 in Scotland. The packs range in size from the large establish¬
ments in the Midlands of England (for instance, the Belvoir, the Cottesmore,
the Quorn, and the Fernie) to small kennels in the west and north.
Hunts are financed mainly by the subscriptions of their members (^15 or
less to £50 or more), from ‘caps’ (contributions paid by non-subscribers), and
from the proceeds of such annual events as the point-to-point races and the
hunt ball. Sometimes the Master of Fox-hounds (MFH), who is in charge
of the hunt, bears a proportion of the cost.
Game shooting as an organised country sport may be said to date from the
early part of the nineteenth century; nowadays, game consists mainly of
grouse, partridge, pheasant, snipe and woodcock.
There is virtually no free shooting in any part of Britain. In the first place,
a shot gun certificate, for which a fee is payable, must be obtained from the
local chief of police by anyone who possesses, purchases or acquires a shot
gun1; and secondly, nearly all game birds are to be found on privately owned
land, shot over either by the owner and his friends or by syndicates which have
leased the shooting. However, in some parts of the more remote countryside,
rough shooting may be enjoyed in a less formal way. Much of the country’s
wildfowling is controlled by the Wildfowling Association of Great Britain and
Northern Ireland, through its numerous clubs.
1 A shot gun is defined in the Criminal Justice Act 1967 as ‘a smooth bore gun having
a barrel not less than 24 inches in length, not being an air-gun’. Shot guns with barrels
less than 24 inches long are subject to control under the Firearms Acts 1937 and 19^5t
and a firearm certificate must be obtained from the police by anyone wishing to possess,
purchase or acquire them.

455
Fishing
Aquatic Sports
Grouse, partridge, pheasant and certain other birds are ‘preserved’: that
is to say, there is a ‘close season’ during which they are protected by law and
allowed to breed in security, often under the care of privately employed
gamekeepers on numerous estates. The grouse, partridge and pheasant
seasons open on 12th August, 1st September and 1st October, severally, and
last for between four and five months. Grouse shooting takes place mostly
in Scotland, northern England and North Wales; partridge and pheasant
shooting in nearly every county in England, Wales and Scotland, the former
mainly over farm land, and the latter in or near woodland; and wildfowling on
the marshes and fenlands of the coastal areas.
The Game Research Association, formed by landowners, farmers and others
interested in game conservation and research, collects and collates information
on a national scale and makes a detailed study of factors controlling game
population.
Deer stalking, which derives its name from the fact that, in order to get
an effective shot, a very cautious approach is needed (since red deer have a
keen scent, are far-sighted, and take alarm at the slightest sound), is mainly
a sport of the Highlands of Scotland. The deer are preserved in privately
owned ‘deer forests’, ranging in size from 9,000 to over 30,000 acres. The
close seasons in Scotland are October to June, inclusive, for stags and
February to October, inclusive, for hinds. In England and Wales, the close
seasons are May to July for stags, and March to October for hinds.
Fishing is the most popular of the country sports in that it is within the reach
of everyone in some form or another (from the small boy with his hook and
line to the experienced fly-fisherman), and that many more people fish in
their leisure hours than hunt or shoot.
The outstanding forms of the sport in Britain are salmon and trout fishing.
Trout streams are to be found in most parts of the country, and in Scotland
there are also many hundreds of lochs which provide good sport. Salmon
fishing may be enjoyed in England, North Wales and Northern Ireland,
but the best salmon rivers are to be found in Scotland. In England and
Wales the most widely practised form of fishing is for coarse fish such as
pike, perch, carp, roach, dace, tench, chub and bream, and the National
Federation of Anglers (NFA) has some 450,000 members in over 3,000 clubs
comprising 116 associations. Match angling—competitive fishing for coarse
fish by weight—is a feature of the many angling clubs affiliated to the NFA,
particularly in the Midlands and north of England. A national angling cham¬
pionship, composed of 112 teams of 12 anglers, is organised annually by the
NFA, and the NFA enters a team in the International Angling Competition.
Fishing around the coasts is another popular pastime, while deep-sea
fishing for tuna and shark has gained many adherents during the past 20 years.
Coastal and deep-sea fishing is free to all (except for salmon and sea trout
fishing in Scotland) but, as a rule, freshwater fishing has to be paid for and
local enquiries made about any permit or licence required. Most coarse
fishing is let to angling clubs; trout and salmon fishermen either rent a
stretch of river, join a club, stay at an hotel with its own fishing rights, or
pay for the right to fish by the day, week or month. The cost of salmon
fishing is often high.
Aquatic sports include rowing, sailing, swimming, canoeing, punting and
water ski-ing. The first three are the most commonly practised in Britain
and are included in the Olympic events and the Commonwealth Games.
